author: MadSin
review: So if you are like me and you want to play as Mando with Baby Yoda in the actural Razor Crest you need a code and there is other Stuff unlockable with codes too, here is the list:    ARVALA7 - The Razor Crest ship    C3PHOHO - C-3PO (Holiday Special)    WOOKIEE - Chewbacca (Holiday Special)    TIPYIPS - D-O (Holiday Special)    WROSHYR - Darth Vader (Holiday Special)    LIFEDAY - Gonk Droid (Holiday Special)    KORDOKU - Poe Dameron (Holiday Special)    KH7P320 - Aayla Secura    XV4WND9 - Admiral Holdo    OKV7TLR - Dengar    SIDIOUS - The Emperor    WBFE4GO - Nute Gunray    Z55T8CQ - Poggle The Lesser    GR2VBXF - Ratts Tyerell     3FCPPVX - Tarkin    SKYSAGA - Temmin Wexley (listed as Snap Wexley for Lego Survey reward)    SHUTTLE - Resistance I-TS Transport shipThere are two locations within the game menus where you'll find a code entry screen, which will let you type in any of the Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga cheats listed above.    1. Open Holoprojector, move to Extras tab then follow Enter Code prompt.   2. Enter the Pause menu and select the key icon labelled Enter Code.If you enter the code correctly, you'll receive a notification to confirm it has been accepted and revealing what has been unlocked. As with previous games, you'll only need to enter each Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga cheat code once, which will permanently unlock the item or feature and, where applicable, the option to enable or disable it through the menu.

author: TheRedViking
review: Let me start out by saying two things. 1: I like the Complete Saga better, but that may be because that game was my childhood. 2: This is a fantastic successor to the CS. Now I will get into what I view as the pros and cons of the game. SPOILERS?Pros: 1. Lego humor has never been funnier2. The game is open world3. Ship combat is fun4. The visuals are stunning 5. There is so much to do6. Taking a capital ship is fun7. There are so many details in this game8. Can't believe I have to say this but in today's gaming industry we finally have a game that isn't a mess at launch 9. Side quests are fun Cons: 1. My biggest gripe is that when it comes to the actual missions they feel lacking in content, they could have added more from each episode for sure. My biggest issue with this is that there is no level for the opening battle scene from Revenge of the Sith, that was my favorite level in Complete Saga. That may just be me though 2. This isn't really a con for me because I am definatly a more casual gamer, and this is a game for children, but the game is very easy. If your tired of Dark Souls and Elden Ring and just want to relax look no further. This game is for sure worth the 2 year delay and the $60Edit: After taking the Death Star this game is better

author: BILLIE WESKER
review: The definitive LEGO Star Wars game Pretty much covers Episodes I-IX with content and references to the other films / shows. One of the few times Deluxe Content is actually worth it plus Pre-order. I've played these from the first installment and mastered every game since then going on almost 20 years. This game truly captures the familiar vibes while adding its own modern twists. Gameplay is pretty smooth and the combat reminds me a little bit of DMC / GOW. I love how you can do Mute Voices with Retro Graphics. Performance runs like water even on an older PC and the graphics are crisp. Runs about as well as Consoles. I played on there first before getting early access here. You can do Controller as well as Keyboard and Mouse. I rate this: 100% True JediMay the Force be with you and God Speed.

author: Hank Hill
review: I want to make the point that this game is not LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga. I know people wanted it to be, but it isn’t. The mechanics are different, the levels are different, the style is different, everything is different except for the story. There have been a lot of complaints about the level design being “too easy” or the levels are too short. Again, I want to point out that LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga came out 15 years ago and LEGO and Travelers Tales have changed their format, level design, and overall gameplay a few times over since then. I personally did not want a “remastered” game, I wanted a new game, one that would change the formula of LEGO games. I would say that this game definitely does that. To be clear, at the writing of this review, I have completed 6 of the 9 films on story mode alone (1,2,3,4,5,7).Looking to the complaint of the short levels, I will agree, the levels are significantly shorter in this game than in the past. That does not mean, however, that there is less content. In addition, I think the voice actors do a great job of summarizing the Star Wars story with letting direct quotes and general set pieces direct the story. The one thing that seems to be more interesting about this game is that the open world is very integrated into the story. You have to go from one mission to the other (for the most part) by traveling to the planets yourself, or the different areas of said planets. The story definitely feels shorter, but I would say it reminds me of a “spark notes” version of Star Wars, especially with the voice acting in the game adding depth to the story. The mumble mode is a fun nostalgic call back to the old games, but in my unpopular opinion, it does not work for this game. The reason why it worked in the old games was because the characters mouths don’t move, but they are fully voice acted with detailed mouth movement. The Clone Wars voice actors sound phenomenal in the prequel trilogy and would highly recommend playing through with mumble mode off. Of course, I will play some stuff with mumble mode on for funs sake.For those worried about trekking over everywhere to get to missions, there is a designated area in the menu to play just the missions again once it has been played through on story mode. This game still has a lot of unlockables, lots of upgrading, and plenty of time to spend hanging out in the Star Wars universe. The combat in this game is really new and exciting with “combos” being implemented as well as interesting mechanics with both lightsabers and blasters.Overall, I would say this game is an exciting, fun, new aspect of not only the Star Wars franchise, but also LEGO games in general.10/10Pro:Fun nostalgic callback to my childhoodInteresting new levelsOpen world is refreshing and seamless into the storyCompletionist dreamVoice Acting is wonderful (Prequel trilogy with Clone Wars voice acting is *wonderful*Mumble modeCons:Levels/Story is slightly shorter than previous installments of LEGO gamesOpen world can be overwhelming when starting offSome small bugstl;dr – game is super fun, “this is where the fun begins”10/10

author: Miss Luny
review: I played many of the Lego Games in the past, and even thou they were mostly the same, beside the settings, I always had a good time with them.But they definitely needed an overhaul, and thankfully with this Game, they finally got it!                       Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga includes the Story of all 9 Movies in a compressed way. The cutscenes are cut down to the very basic information’s of the Story, which isn’t a bad thing directly, since the Lego games were never meant for long drawn out cutscenes. It can be hard to follow what’s going on thou in case you haven’t seen the Movies. Over the course of the Story, you visit all Iconic locations from the franchise like you would expect. You can choose to either begin the game at Episode 1, 4 or 7, depending on the order you want to experience them.                       The gameplay is mostly the same as in the old games, destroy everything and loot studs! The game isn’t too hard and you don’t lose to much in case you die, its designed to be a relaxing, enjoyable experience and they definitely succeed with that. But thankfully, they did improve the game systems. The 380 Characters you can unlock are sorted into different categories like Jedi, Hero, Scavenger, Bounty Hunter, Droid etc. Each category has different skills you can invest into which can be upgraded in 3 Tiers each on top. You get skill points by collecting Special Bricks in each level, which are rewarded for different goals and challenges.The combat system also got a general overhaul and is now more versatile compared to the old games.   Beside that you can also collect Mini-kits, Vehicles and of course, new Characters. The levels feel bigger to me like in the old games and more open ended. Each is filled with a ton of Stuff to do, if you enjoy collecting Items and upgrades, you will find your happiness here. And like in the old games, the levels are designed in a way, that not everything can be looted the first time you visit a location. Some items need talents or Characters you will only obtain later to reach.                The Graphic is a lovely mix of detailed Lego Models and Bricks/Structures and a more real general atheistic of the environments, which works out flawlessly in my eyes. The Audio is really good, it sounds like you would Star Wars expect to sound.                          If you enjoyed the old Lego games, you will immediately feel at home in the Skywalker Saga, all the new features, and a game that can be enjoyed solo or in coop with a friend, with the good Lego Humor on top guarantees a good time. If you are new to the Series and/or just found the game because you are a Star Wars fan and you are on the lookout for a relaxing game that can keep you busy for hours, or just for a while after a long day, I can fully recommend Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga to you as well!

author: OMN1CRON (🔨 WORKCATION 🌴)
review: ... because I think this will be one of the longest review I've ever written. Well, it probably won't be a real review. I think it will be more of a story about me and the initial conflict about the game.I've been putting off this „review“ for weeks because I don't even know exactly why this is so important to me and I just can't find the right words.It may well be that this has something to do with the partly negative reviews, which I can also understand somewhere. But also because I was a bit disappointed with the game myself at first and I needed some distance from the game to think about it. After all, I've been waiting for this game for a long time and I'm really looking forward to it. Admittedly, it's also one of the few games that I bought right after it was released.I downloaded the game, started it and then went to the menu. Let's see what has changed. Yes, hello, what is that? That's a menu, a real one. No longer such a spartan menu as in the other Lego games where you can only adjust the volume, effects and a few graphic settings. Yes oops. I can adjust a lot of things. That's amazing. I really like that. A few settings made and off you go. Hm, now I have to decide which level or which part to start with. Well, since I'm as old as the Star Wars films themselves, I went with the "classic" variety, the order of release. So in this case Episode IV. So the first level and... "wow, what's that," that looks mega. That's absolutely amazing what had an effect on me graphically and playfully. I would not have expected that in my life. So get into the fray and diligently cut up and tear down everything that comes in my way and yikes, what's up now? As ? Why is the level over now? I've only just played what feels like 5 minutes? What's happening ? , I look at the cutscene when my wife comes home and says: oh cool, the new Lego Star Wars. And how is it ? Yeah, um, I don't know, I said. Actually totally great, but I just played a level and it was over after what felt like 5 minutes. How can that be ? It wasn't like that in The Complete Saga. Exactly, that wasn't it and that's what made it so difficult for me and somehow I didn't enjoy it anymore. Of course, I then took a closer look at what had been written about the game so far and especially the negative reviews and the more I read, the “worse” things got for me too. At some point I didn't feel like playing the game anymore that I really left it there for days.One morning when I opened Steam at work I came across these two videos:When I watched these videos it kind of “clicked” for me and when I got home in the evening I grabbed my kids and said, listen, you have to play the new Lego Star Wars now.How you make your kids play Lego Star Wars... Well, I wouldn't necessarily call it that. I'd rather say I've changed the  priorities a bit, but joking aside, I asked them if they wanted to do that because I assumed they weren't averse to it anyway and because they've also enjoyed playing Lego games so far.But since I didn't want to buy the game again, family sharing and my own score had to be used and I couldn't continue playing myself for the time being. But it doesn't matter, it was a good thing because after a short time I heard the first giggles, laughter and phrases like "oh, how cool is that" or "that's mega" from the rooms.Unlike my son, who, like his father, first destroys everything in the area to see what is left at the end and only then deals with the rest, my daughter prefers to spend time exploring Tatooine, taking her time in peace to stroll around the area and see what there is to discover, who to talk to and what else you can do. In the following days, more and more friends joined them. It got louder, wilder and more and more difficult to get the kidz away from the game.What I mean to say is that Lego games are actually primarily designed for children, even though the games have been enjoying increasing popularity among (younger) adults for quite some time. Nevertheless, one shouldn't forget that children (by that I don't mean all adults for the moment) have a different point of view and also value other things. For the moment, a child doesn't really care if R2D2 suddenly can't hoover anymore, as long as it's even aware of it. For me, the character editor has never been relevant, except for the respective achievement. Others do, and that's fine, but there will certainly be reasons from the developers that some things in the game just aren't the way we used to be. Maybe even licensed. I think you can't always have everything, no matter how nice it is.When I asked them what they think of the game, everyone said it's the coolest Lego (Star Wars) game they've played. Yes, but what about The Complete Saga? I mean how does it compare to that?The answers were quite simple and unanimous.  They are just two different games and they have nothing to do with each other.The point that was so decisive and important for me. Considering the game as a sequel, remake or whatever, apart from the technical changes/innovations, it's fair to say it's bad.But that's not it. In no way.It is a new, independent and, above all, different game that should not be compared. Even if it's a bit difficult at times. But if you can do that, then the game is also a lot of fun.The Star Wars story is told more in the cutscenes. These are, in this case, also shortened to be suitable for children and the dialogues actually only consist of the well-known quotes. Strictly speaking, Lego Star Wars doesn't actually tell a story, but is more of a commentary track that emphasizes silly jokes. These jokes usually consist of the characters suddenly deviating from the script and doing something different, unexpected or stupid.So if you haven't seen the films, it can happen that these references aren't funny without an explanation and don't make any sense in relation to the story either. The game is clearly aimed at fans, but it's also suitable for children.The Skywalker Saga is a Lego game I've been expecting in 2022 and have been wanting for years.The fact that Lego games aren't perfect, that one or the other doesn't work that well and that the level of difficulty isn't particularly demanding is simply part of it for me and it doesn't bother me in the least.✅ Extremely extensive game✅ large open world✅ great design✅ typical Star Wars music✅ Slapstick humor✅ funny animation✅ new melee mode / combos✅ new collectibles✅ different skills✅ high replay value❌ Missions could be a little bit longer❌ Puzzles repeat themselves❌ maybe a little too easy❌ Gameplay not motivating in the long run❌ Camera position not always optimal

author: N-V US
review: 100%'d the game so I've done every scripted thing you can do and what can I say about this.Well for fans who wanted a LEGO Star Wars game as good as TCS since it came out, this is the answer you're looking for. It's humor and zany cutscenes have devolved since the older games, but the tradeoff is a complete rework including redone levels, an excellent combat system and an expansive galaxy that has a decently immersive effect.First, the Story: The story does a more accurate job of retelling the saga with tons of decent voiceacting (you can turn off voice acting with mumble mode to have an older LEGO experience. I will say though, mumble mode isn't single mumbles, they mumble out entire sentences, so it feels a little weird), the cutscenes work with or without voiceacting which is a surreal dynamic experience that the devs get my kudos on, but the levels themselves are really short and kind've disappointing. They introduce "level challenges", there are 3 in every level and they're alternative ways of going about each one. They're fun in general, but if you're trying to 100% they can be a nightmare sometimes. Minikits have been reduced from 10 to 5 per level, which was debatably my favorite part about replaying a level. Overall, cutscene and immersion-wise, the levels are fun to play and have the same great puzzle-solving they've always had, replayability is quite low though.First-Time through 9/10Free-Play 100% 6/10 (basically, thank god they're short)Now Galaxy-Mode was easily the most fun I've had through the whole experience. Instead of collecting gold bricks to a grand total of 250, (using the Marvel Avengers game as the mold here since it's the last one I 100%'d, god it sucked), there are 1,160 bricks, (known as "kyber bricks") that are collectable through completing level challenges, collecting minikits, getting "true jedi" on each level, doing side quests among 33 planets, destroying kyber comets, smuggling, doing bounty hunts, and puzzles on each and every planet. It was a ton of fun to mark each planet off the list as I collected each planets' worth. Some quests can only be done if you've progressed through the story up until that point, or until you've done other side quests. Personally, I recommend playing the base game all the way through 4-6, 1-3, 7-9, THEN doing galaxy-mode, so there will be less holdups. In advance, there was only 1 planet that gave me trouble and it was Endor, my guess is, the fire VFX would keep spawning as you loaded new areas, and it wouldn't unload areas you're not in anymore so the constant fire VFX made it a laggy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. (However, entering a village hut loading zone, then exiting refreshed the lag, which led me to believe it was fire VFX that wouldn't unload.) Other than that, the quests and puzzles are really fun to complete.9/10, it is the after-story experience you want.I'll wrap it up here with the UI, combat/upgrade system, and the red bricks rework.So the UI for the most part is pretty straightforward, might take a bit of learning but once you have it down, it all makes sense, stuff goes where it should go, changing characters is a bit messy and if you have OCD about how you want your free-play characters organized, that might be a huge problem because thats the only place where the UI falters heavily. Once you play, you'll figure out what I mean.The combat system is EXTREMELY intricate, you have a third person firing mode with guns and saber-throwing. There's also cover you can hide behind (and rebuild if it gets destroyed) and shoot from if you want to play that way. The biggest highlight though is the melee combat system. You initiate combat with a standard attack which can then go into changeups like heavy attacks, uppercut moves, and spike moves, depending on which corresponding button you press. These changeups become extremely prevalent in the lightsaber boss duels which make you feel like you control how the corresponding movie-scene flows.The red brick rework has been made easier to manage and deal with, you don't collect red bricks, instead you collect "Data cards" (1 per particular planet) in galaxy mode. They aren't specific to certain extras, you get the data card and choose which extra you want. (I recommend not buying anything until you get your first data card and do the stud multiplier route, things are hella expensive this time around so I'd say focus on getting all multipliers before you buy anything else) That being said "Stud magnet" and "Fast build" aren't extras anymore, they're "Upgrades"The upgrade system integrates things like collecting studs, building faster, sprinting quicker, having more health, doing more damage, etc. which is where kyber bricks come in, as they are used as it's currency, plus an additional stud fee. (Now this is the exception to my advice about "not buying anything", buy upgrades when you can) There are core upgrades and class upgrades for specific character types, (Jedi, Hero, Bounty Hunter, Scoundrel, Scavenger, Villain, Dark Side, Astromech Droids, and Protocol Droids.) all of which have their own abilities and uses.All of these features really make the experience flow a lot smoother and are a perfect 10/10 for me.TL;DR: buy the game if you've been wanting a decent Lego Star Wars game, things are different for the better, mumble mode is there, and if you get deluxe, you get classic character packs (if nostalgia is your thing) among other misc. character packs. red bricks have been changed into a more easily flowing system, and the combat = good.Big word of advice: once you're in galaxy mode, buy the rumor for the character "Grummgar", complete all the missions to get him and you get to run really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fast around some of these bigger planets to complete your side quests.

author: iamzachhunter
review: Lego Star Wars I/II/III/Complete Saga were four of my favorite video games as a young lad. I pre-ordered The Skywalker Saga a few days before its release; and at 100 hours of the game played, all 9 episodes completed, and 900 Kyber Bricks collected, I feel I can give an informed review. I will be judging the game on individual metrics, and then I'll give my final score.Exploration - 10/10If I could only mention one aspect of this game at exceeded my expectations, it would certainly be the vast galaxy laden with puzzles, side missions, and collectibles. I would hazard a guess that the average player will spend upwards of 200 hours achieving 100% completion of this game. The developers give the player the freedom to explore hub worlds immediately after discovering the planet; this allowed me to take frequent breaks from the episodic story to pursue all of the hidden collectibles throughout the worlds. In my opinion, the most fun part of this game is exploring the hub worlds. It is a completionist's paradise.Progression - 7/10I really appreciate when developers put time into erecting a progression system in their game - especially in an open-world genre; this allows players to work towards an eventual goal as they complete missions. In the early game, I looked forward to acquiring faster sprint speeds and stud magnet ranges. Later, I looked closer at the class-specific abilities and started investing in the Bounty Hunter and Dark Jedi. I wasn't expecting much in the way of a progression system from this game and was pleasantly surprised when I learned one was implemented. That said, I can't score the game too highly as I feel that most of the abilities are not particularly impressive. Once I had collected 500 Kyber Bricks, I was able to unlock all of the useful abilities, after which my interest in collecting more Kyber Bricks diminished. I still fully intend on obtaining all 1166, but the short-term rewards are lackluster at this point.Story - 3/10I must say the story missions in this game were a chore to play. I started off with the Phantom Menace and quickly learned that the enjoyable part of the game was exploring the hub worlds, not advancing through the tediously scripted missions. I felt like for almost the entire story mode, I was traveling between checkpoints as main characters spouted the dialogue from the movies, switching classes to interact with the same darn button puzzles, or engaging in "intense" light-saber combat with the bosses. I was told the combat system in this game was to be more advanced, and while it technically is more complex than the original Lego Star Wars games, the developers gave up on the puzzles integrated with the boss fights. It is simply a slashing fest for five minutes for every boss: Maul, Dooku, Grievous, Anakin, Vader, Sidious, Kylo, etc. In most boss fights, once the boss reaches a certain threshold, they will run away; and it usually takes several minutes to catch up with them. This really breaks the urgency of combat. And this often occurs 2-3 times per boss. The space combat is much more enjoyable as there are no breaks in combat. You simply search and destroy the given targets until the mission is over. Luckily, there are other aspects of this game that make up for the missions' shortcomings.Movies - 9/10So glad to see that the wit of Lego games as persisted all of these years. There were many occasions I audibly laughed at the humor throughout the movies in this game. My only complaint is that you cannot access the movies anywhere in the menus. In previous installments, you could purchase and watch the movies in the shop at your leisure. It made it difficult to share funny moments with my friends/family, as I would have to find a clip on YouTube of the scene I was on just to show it.Performance - 8/10As this game has just released, I am going to cut it some slack on occasional bugs I encountered throughout playing it. I experienced only one crash in the entire game - when I attempted to equip the Shore Trooper character in my first hour of game play. The only serious bug I repeatedly encountered is the Trade Federation Battleship occupying the center of space battles when it wasn't supposed to be there. It had no substance, so it was still possible to complete the missions. Graphically, the game is beautiful. I never experienced frame drops at 3840/2160p 60hertz. (RTX 3060ti) My one complaint with the graphical settings is the FOV status. I felt way too close to my character throughout this game. I would have appreciated an in-game setting to adjust this.Overall Rating - 37/50 or 74%I thoroughly enjoyed exploring the hub worlds in this game, solving all of the puzzles, collecting all of the Kyber Bricks and Data Cards, unlocking all of the characters. To supplement the boredom of the story missions, I listened to Ben Shapiro podcasts while I played with the sound off. I wouldn't say this lives up to the glories of The Complete Saga, but did anyone actually think it could be that good? No, I don't think so. But this game still is a lot of fun a deserves the attention that any Lego Game gets.Final RecommendationsStart with Episode 7 and unlock the scavenger items as Rey. You get them early on, and multiple puzzles require them to be completed. You don't have to finish episode 7. Just get the gear and jump back to one of the good trilogies. Don't try to 100% every hub world immediately, some Kyber Bricks and Characters can only be obtained after completing a side mission that is started on another planet. Once you've obtained all of the Kyber Bricks visible on the map, you've done all you can do for the time. Also, make sure to check inside interiors on the map. Kyber Bricks do not appear on the tracker until you're in the building.

author: Ace of Losers
review: If you really want it, wait for a sale. It's been a while since I played a lego game so maybe it's the nostalgia talking, but there seems to be something (or multiple somethings) missing from this installment. While a lot of new ideas were tried, it seems to have come at the cost of enjoyable content and 'real' gameplay.The worlds, while detailed, personally feel to lack some charm in previous titles and instead feel designed to maximize the time it takes to do anything to pad the game. Many world objects that I believe would have been 'lego based' in older games have been rendered realistically/geometrically to the point that in some areas the characters themselves are the only lego objects on screen.The move to voiced characters has also led to a fall off in cutscene quality. Whereas in the past they were very expressive and creative in getting across the plot, now much of it is just through dialogue. I do appreciate however that they allow the option to return to the classic 'mumble voice' mode.Finally the difficulty seems far too easy. I know this is a childrens game so I'm not expecting dark souls but it is literally almost impossible to die even without any upgrades equipped, especially in the space battles. This lack of a challenge has made many of the fights a bore and something I'm forcing myself to push through. Additionally, there is no requirement to play the levels with the 'intended' characters. Instead you're able to select any character you want even on the first playthrough of the level (making freeplay near pointless and many levels very easy to break/make even easier).I really wanted to like this game, but so far I've been unimpressed. However I do plan to finish it and hopefully will have my mind changed by the end.

author: Audish
review: The hardest part of writing this review has been not playing the game long enough to write it. That doesn’t normally happen with me, I’m a big fan of having my fill of a game, penning a review, and moving on. But not this time. The Skywalker Saga is a perfect mix of immensely engaging and endlessly sprawling, a game that can ask me to do the same thing at hour 60 that it asks at hour 1 and I agree to it eagerly. It breaks a surprising amount of ground for a Star Wars game, and also remains fun and light-hearted enough that you’ll never really tire of it. And not even the technical issues can mar my enjoyment of this massive adventure.“The Skywalker Saga” refers to the nine mainline Star Wars movies that chronicle the rise, fall, and legacy of Darth Vader. From the lakes of Naboo to the sands of Tatooine, and all the way to the blasted surface of Exegol, you can play through all of the big beats of the Star Wars films. But unlike previous LEGO games, this isn’t so neatly broken up into stages. Each episode has five story missions, but they’re stitched together through open-world exploration across 28 planets seen in the movies, often with scripted events and cutscenes to fill in the gaps between missions. You’ll fly the trench run, battle the Separatist leaders, and take down Starkiller base, but you’ll also defrost Rebels at Echo Base, serve up orders at the diner on Coruscant, and rummage through Maz Kanata’s castle. And if you can believe it, playing through the events of the films is only the start of your journey.As far as a retelling of the Star Wars epic, the LEGO version hits all the right notes. It sometimes picks some unexpected moments to turn into missions, like Yoda’s battle with the droid armies on Kashyyyk or Princess Leia running around on the Tantive IV, but always turns these into fun romps. The open-world segments are also plenty of fun and do a lot to round out the story, taking you through notable events while also leaving you free to roam for cash and collectibles. Missions contain plenty of variety, including space battles, large army clashes, on-rails shooting sequences, and more. Even the normal on-foot adventuring gets mixed up with multiple teams doing things at once and branching paths. Most notably, climactic battles with characters like Darth Vader and Kylo Ren have been given a ton of attention, becoming multi-stage challenges with all sorts of dodging, blocking, and combo mechanics that echo the boss battles of more… severe games.As fun as playing through the movies is, the cutscenes and dialogue are a huge part of what makes this game so fun. LEGO has really made a name for itself with licensed properties by parodying them without losing their core appeal, and that’s more evident than ever here. Cutscenes are always hilariously slapstick, the major characters all have their own running jokes that get used to great effect over the course of nine episodes, and even the most dramatic scenes get broken down into comedic beats. The big climax to Episode I against Darth Maul had me in tears with how funny it was, for example. You’ll see plenty of that cleverness with every mission and dialogue from random NPCs, too, and the fact that LEGO Star Wars never lets that air of wacky hijinks falter goes a long way towards keeping the game fresh.Fresh is what you need this to be, too, because the real meat of the game is collecting things. There is a staggering, unconscionable amount of things to find here, between the 380 characters, 100+ ships, dozens of quests and challenges, and more. New to this LEGO outing is the chance to upgrade the abilities of your characters, who are split across about ten different classes. You need kyber bricks for these upgrades, of which there are over 1100 scattered all over the galaxy. The challenges to obtain them range from looking behind corners to planet-hopping odysseys that end in hidden boss battles. Side quests can also be impressively involved, spanning land and space, and throwing you into all kinds of battles and hunts. You can even capture certain capital ships, which essentially turn into secret stages with their own unique events and mechanics.There’s so much to see and do in The Skywalker Saga, it’s easy to lose sight of what may be this game’s greatest achievement and biggest appeal. This is essentially the first open-world Star Wars game, offering you the chance to freely wander any of the planets and notable locales of the films at your leisure. Sure, you’ve got characters to unlock and collectibles to hunt down all over, but I cannot overstate how magical it is to simply touch down on Coruscant or Kamino or Bespin or Takodana and just be there. The folks who made this game went to incredible lengths to make every location feel like a real place, with beautiful, realistic environments and effects. They meshed this immersion perfectly with their LEGO characters and objects, too, because your bricks and figures look absolutely life-like with plastic seams, reflections, and even sand and dirt caking their surfaces on some worlds.It’s worth noting there are a fair number of technical issues at the moment, ones that may or may not get sorted out via patches. I’ve had to reload the game a few times because of explosions or textures not rendering correctly. One of the instanced space battle areas is aligned around a background model that can make it really hard to see. Most importantly, there can be crashes from time to time, including one consistent one during an Episode III mission that I had to turn my graphics settings all the way down to get around. Surprisingly, that had little impact on how the game looked, so this one seems both extremely well-optimized and also rather unstable. I’ll also add that I haven’t really lost any progress to crashes, because the game is saving constantly, but it’s definitely an annoyance.With that out of the way, I really have nothing but love for this one. If nothing else I’ve said in this review has sold you on The Skywalker Saga, let me say this: I have never really liked the LEGO games, not even the Star Wars ones. I’ve played several in the past, but never stuck with any of them for more than a few hours, owing to hollow, simple gameplay and tedious collecting. In stark contrast to that, I am absolutely obsessed with this one. It’s crowded out all my other games, drawing me back day after day to hunt more kyber bricks and character unlocks. Above all, it’s just fun. It never forgets how light-hearted and charming it is, and everything it offers the player is there to help you enjoy it even more. This is the Star Wars game I’ve been waiting decades for, an open-world romp that does everything it can to make you enjoy your time in a vast galaxy of adventure.Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at  or on my !

author: Brent
review: ~OVERALL RATING~70%~ SUMMARY ~It's a reasonably fun game that does a fantastic job capturing the key story elements from all 9 movies. It's actually amazing at how it does it - you'd expect that turning the movies into games would mean each game would be 20 hours each, but somehow they packed it all in and still made it fun. I took 22h to complete the core game, doing minimum side quests, and finished all 9 episodes in that time so it's only a bit longer than watching the movies themselves.It's just not quite deep enough for my tastes. The lightweight, whimsical style of LEGO and the fairly simple gameplay and skill tree just didn't do that much for me. It's perfect as a kids game though, and there is a vast amount of content to explore. I reckon I touched 40% of the total game - there are huge amounts of collectables and areas to explore that I just skipped right past.The art, music, sound and production are spectacular though - this game is a finely crafted masterpiece. It's really just the overall feel of it that didn't do it for me.~ DIFFICULTY ~🔲 My 90 year old grandma could play it✅ Easy🔲 Normal🔲 Hard🔲 Dark Souls~ GRAPHICS ~🔲 MS Paint🔲 Bad🔲 Meh🔲 Graphics don't matter in this game🔲 Good✅ Beautiful🔲 Masterpiece~ MUSIC ~🔲 Bad🔲 Not special✅ Good🔲 Beautiful~ STORY ~🔲 This game has no story🔲 Like playing Angry Birds for the story✅ It's there for the people who want it🔲 Well written🔲 Epic story🔲 A Tolkienesque masterpiece~ PRICE ~🔲 Free🔲 Underpriced✅ Perfect Price🔲 Could be cheaper🔲 Overpriced🔲 Complete waste of money~ REQUIREMENTS ~🔲 You can run it on a microwave✅ Average🔲 High end🔲 Supercomputer~ LENGTH ~🔲 Very Short (0 - 2 hours)🔲 Short (2 - 15 hours)🔲 Average (15-30 hours)✅ Long (30-60 hours)🔲 Extremely long (60-110 hours)🔲 No ending~ FUN ~🔲 I'd rather watch paint dry🔲 Hard to enjoy✅ Repetitive🔲 Actually pretty amusing🔲 The kind of fun you'll remember🔲 Ride of your life~ REPLAYABILITY~🔲 It's a one-time experience✅ Only for achievements🔲 If you wait a few months/years🔲 Definitely🔲 Infinitely replayable~ WORTH BUYING ~🔲 No✅ Wait for sale🔲 Yes

author: AviaRa
review: A long time ago, the announcement of  got me excited, making it one of my most anticipated titles, but its constant delays made it clear that my galaxy’s visit is still far, far away…Yet, I remained so patient that even Yoda blissfully shivered from my accomplishment.Was it worth the wait? Absolutely.By portraying all three trilogies,  provides a coherent, entertaining storyline filled with humorous twists and quips that never become boring. Truly. Not only that it feels like a complete, parodying recreation, but it also comes up with its own jabs that even make fun of some of the decisions made in each instalment; thus, even horrendous episodes like  or  are enjoyable. Moreover, it inspires itself by the popular  memes, which is a nice touch as it underlines its dedication to the fandom.Due to that, it caters to the fans rather than to everyone—and that is fine. Could you enjoy it without being familiar with the films? Probably, as the game still has a lot to offer, but many jokes might fly over your head at lightspeed. I am glad that it is like that, though, as it would lose part of its charm otherwise.The way you experience the campaign is a bit different this time; it lets you galavant through the galaxy and visit numerous planets, with an occasional unique mission here and there. Thus, it feels like a thorough, delightful journey rather than a bland list of levels, making the whole adventure more satisfactory.As it is an action-adventure title – from a tighter third-person perspective this time – the usual gameplay loop revolves around exploring, platforming, hoarding all the collectables and, of course, fighting. When you are not directly following the story, you can just venture away and explore the universe on your own. However, do not expect a seamless open world; instead, it consists of a bunch of playable areas in each system. I would say it is better that way because the locations are designed with care to provide just enough content without overwhelming you.Apart from relaxing sightseeing, there are the said collectables to find; picking them up is not pointless, though, as you use them to upgrade your characters’ abilities or unlock additional, hilarious rewards, like a fierce Porg companion or baguettes that replace the lightsabers. To obtain them, you usually have to solve a simple environmental puzzle. Even though that might get a bit repetitive after a while, I did not mind it because I adored discovering new locations and trying out other iconic characters.Speaking of those, you can unlock them, along with starships, by completing side missions. These quests often tend to deliver an even more over-the-top take on . At one point, you might find yourself smuggling trampolines to Mustafar, ending it with a bouncy fight against Bossk, or you could be crushing down a revolt of cloned woolamanaders – who are essentially cute blue apes – on the Kamino facility. This kind of content serves as a sweet, optional stuffing that can spice up your journey.That leads us to the combat, which surprisingly has a lot of depth when compared to an average  game. For sure, it is still pretty effortless, so do not expect any hardships or obstacles in your way. There are, however, several possibilities to use, as apart from mashing one button, you can engage in various combos that make encounters more fun and satisfying to observe. Whether you viciously slice through a bunch of Clones with Maul’s double-bladed lightsaber, blast everyone’s heads off with Boba Fett’s carbine rifle, or slap others as C-3PO, you know it is going to be a joyful time. And if that does not convince you, then undulating around as Mamma the Hutt, licking everyone in the process, should do so!These differences do not only influence the combat but the overall interaction with the world, as well. Where a Jedi will take advantage of their agile movement or the Force, a bounty hunter will rely on a jetpack and grappling hook; due to that, the character classes complement each other. It is a simple yet effective system that pushes you to try out more of the iconic heroes or villains.Unfortunately, the skirmishes in space are disappointing, though serviceable for what they are. While there is a decent variety of starships to choose from, the combat lacks the complexity of the ground one. You only have one attack option, with the possibility of unleashing a homing missile, and that is it. Thus, all of these encounters are bland and uninspiring, becoming boring later on. The exceptions are a few main missions or battles with capital ships, which at least offer unique objectives that balance out the monotonous gameplay.Additionally, the absence of online cooperative play is saddening. Even though you can use , it is not enough, mainly because every progress made counts only for the host while your friends gain nothing. That is weird and discouraging, as you suddenly cannot use the characters and abilities you unlocked but rely purely on your friend’s ones. Also, doing all the collectables twice does not sound that appealing either.Where  beautifully shines is its audiovisual presentation. Simply put, it is top-notch. All the planets with their iconic locations are glamorous to lie your eyes on, and all the ships, even the capital ones or Death Star itself, are made purely of  bricks, which nicely distinguish them from the rest of the environment. Just galavanting through the deserts of Tatooine or the city of Theed, listening to its iconic themes is heartwarming.Another nice touch is the presence of some of the original trilogy’s actors, who reprise their roles, like  as C-3PO or  as Lando. You can also hear a few familiar voices from the animated  show. Naturally, not everyone could be present, but the attempt still shows the dedication put into this project. Moreover, the number of additional monologues and even dialogues between numerous characters is astonishing; even Darth Vader and Kylo Ren have their small talk, and at times, they might even perform an amusing animation when you let them stand in place for a while. The love and care just jump at you at every bricky corner you pass by.That would be perhaps the best summary for .Overall, I adore this title, as it is a special experience that managed to awake an inner child in me, a kid that enjoyed watching the films over and over again. The humorous nature and relaxing gameplay make for an excellent combination. Yes, some aspects could have been a tad bit better; however, that does not take away the dozens of hours of fun I had. Thus, I can wholeheartedly recommend it to any  enthusiast.Now excuse me; I still have a few collectables to find.

author: CornGolden
review: Hello there!When I heard there was gonna be a remake of Lego Star Wars Ep's 1-6 with the added bonus of those things we'd all like to forget about called Ep's 7-9, I was pretty excited about the announcement as a huge Star Wars fan and thought long and hard whether I should pre order this game or not.The old Lego Star Wars games from the PS2/Xbox/Gamcube era (and later Xbox 360, PS3, and Wii with the Complete Saga) were a thing of beauty and kind of helped Lego kick off their long running series of Lego themed games ranging from Indiana Jones, to Harry Potter, to Marvel and DC super heroes.Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga now allows us to experience the entirety of the Star Wars series again in Lego form and fully voice acted too which the old games didnt feature. The voice acting is just the 1st major change for this game. Along with this the combat has been changed up to feel more hack and slashey with lightsabers, and more third person shooter like with blasters, a major step up from the old games.You can now freely move the camera around and access most of the games features from the select menu without ever having to return back to a central hub area like in the older games. There's side missions you can do to gain more studs and hidden collectibles to find again scattered throught the episodes. You now have the new Kyber bricks collectible which helps you level up your character abilities and powers. This game also contains the largest collection of Star Wars characters and vehicles available to play as spanning all 9 episodes and even The Mandalorian and Solo if you have the DLCs with more characters being added soon. The graphics are also very pretty and look good no matter what graphics settings, and can run well on some older hardware like GTX 10 series GPUs.Some other upsides of the remake are the almost seamless transitions from world to world when going through levels (with some slight technical hiccups here and there, but I'll get to that later). You can enable silly extra options like "mumble mode" to make the characters sound the way they did in the original games or alter the gameplay for a good laugh. The Skywalker Saga also pays pretty good respect to the original films, keeping a lot of memorable lines from the movies for important moments of the story, while sometimes sprinkling in the Lego goofiness for laughs. The game is also not difficult to play compared to the original games, which makes it more welcoming to younger audiences and casuals who are Star Wars fans, but aint big on gaming. For me personally, the easier difficulty of the game wasnt to my liking, but with this being a family friendly Star Wars game, I can understand why this was done.Now onto the downsides. While I like the game so far and feel satisfied with it as a Star Wars fan and a gamer, I am disappointed with the way some moments of the story were cut out, probably due to time constraints, or shortened by just having certain characters or locations show up at parts of the story they werent supposed to be in yet (eg. Yoda explaining Kamino being gone from the archives to Obi Wan in the Library and never showing the part with the younglings wisdom and the cool space map in the training room), but again this can be understood in order to cram 9 movie stories into 1 game. Still, the games progression through episodes feels too quick and it doesnt help that intense action filled moments dont happen frequently like in the old games, and leads to moments where you just walk from point A to point B with little to no resistance only to activate the next cutscene.The game also has some bugs and glitches that can lead to soft locks that require a restart. Had my game soft lock on me 3 times when trying to start a mission or go into a cutscene and had to restart. Had a glitch when trying to buy Zam Wesell from the in game shop where my studs would be spent but Zam still showed up as not having been bought. I had another odd glitch where side missions in spaces just wouldnt show up and I was flying in empty space, I could only see the story mission icon and the blue asteroid thing floating by. In the droid factory level for episode 2 the games fps plunges as low as 28 fps at times on areas where theres a lot of machinery and enemies moving on screen. Also one thing that annoys me is that every time I restart or tab out of the game it never saves my resolution settings and always sets me to 1080p 50 fps every time, had to play on fullscreen mode for this game too because trying to use windowed borderless after restarting will just put you in windowed only and cant be fixed unless you switch from fullscreen back to windowed borderless.Personally, I like the game and recommend it to any Star Wars fan for episodes 1-6 remade alone (7-9 will always be a mistakes barfed up by Disney's lousy writers), but I'd wait a while to buy this on sale for $20-30 at the most, the gameplay and pace of the game don't warrant $50, or $60 with the deluxe edition. Unless your a hardcore Star Wars fan like me, wait for a sale.

author: Heresy
review: This isn't a bad game, not really. But when you stack it up against its 15-year-old predecessor, it comes a bit short. Sure, you technically have MORE content. But, personally, I find it hard to consider repeating the same exact puzzles on every planet, the same exact fetch quests with different names, and the same exact on-rails "levels" as meaningful content.Let's actually talk about the levels for a bit. When you get to an *actual* level in the game (say, the first mission in The Force Awakens, the Canto Bight prison break in The Last Jedi, or the escape from the Death Star in A New Hope), they're surprisingly open, have relatively clever puzzles, and come across as a pleasantly surprising update to a 15 year old formula. Unfortunately, these moments are far and few between. Most levels are either boss fights that follow the exact same formula of spam attack until the boss runs off, immunity phase, repeat; and on-rails vehicle segments that all function exactly the same, with the only difference being the ship you're piloting. This would be less of an issue if these were, say, 1 per episode like in The Complete Saga. Instead, you have issues like Revenge of the Sith being almost entirely boss fights with only one (Droid Attack on the Wookies) and a half (the first 1/2 of Down for the Count) being *actual* levels. instead of 6 levels per episode, now you only get 5 - and most of them are exactly the same. The other segments of the films that could have been (and in the past, *were*) levels are now relegated to painfully dull, pace-killing walking simulator segments, in which you spend 5 minutes walking to a location/character to listen to some dialogue or watch a cutscene, and then repeat until you get to one of the 5 actual levels.The majority of the work in this game went to the open world, which - while visually impressive - lacks any sort of substance. As mentioned before, all the side quests and puzzles are carbon copies of one another, rendering them repetitive and borderline pointless. Yes, objectively speaking, 700+ puzzles is more than The Complete Saga or The Clone Wars had, but does the total amount matter if only about 100 are unique?A similar issue exists with the characters. Wow, over 1,000 characters with more on the way in the form of DLC! Unfortunately, they almost all function exactly the same - and most don't even have voice acting. This is something I really don't care about (IMO the LEGO games were better when they didn't have voiceovers), but, at the same time, if you're going to have VO, then at least apply it consistently. Even characters who have voice acting will lose it if you elect to use certain skins instead of the default. Again, does having "more" matter when it's done in such a half-baked way?Finally, there is no end to the technical issues that mar this game. Six months after release and performance issues still plague certain levels. To TT's credit, they did fix these issues somewhat - "Better Call Maul" went from literally unplayable for me to actually running at a consistent framerate after patches - but the performance hits are still apparent in areas such as the Droid Factory. This points to underlying engine and optimization issues, which - unfortunately - are not so fixable. Additionally, bugs crop up left and right: things as simple as audio getting stuck and constantly looping, to things much more gamebreaking as not being able to lift Force objects. There are bugs tied to acquiring collectibles that actively prevent the player from getting 100% completion. One side quest in particular has a bug where you have to specifically quit to the main menu in order to get it to advance. If you go somewhere else in-game or ALT-F4, it simply will not progress. The latter two problems have been known issues since the game's launch; neither have been fixed. With the release of the Galactic Edition (and the questionable DLC practices that came with it), the chances of these issues ever being fixed has decreased from slim to none.So, final verdict: if you love Star Wars, and love LEGO games, and don't mind uninspired, repetitive content or just want a game to keep you or a kid busy for the next several months, then this is by all means a fine game. If you're looking for a worthy update or successor to The Complete Saga or even other, newer LEGO games, this isn't it. Personally, if you have a choice between The Complete Saga and this game, I'd go with the former every single time. That's not nostalgia talking, it's just simply a better, more technically polished game in spite of its age.

author: Reddod
review: Am I satisfied with my purchase? Yes. Overall the game is a fantastically fun romp through everyone's favorite fictional space epic about destroying each other over politics with lasers. Tons of stuff to do and see, its a good time. Would I recommend 100%ing it like I just finished doing?NO.The blessing, but also massive problem with 100%ing a game and playing it for so long is you see everything the game has to offer, and I mean EVERYTHING. Sure while I saw every character, every joke, every reference, every unlock, I also saw every glitch, every bug, every cut or rushed corner or idea. Every repetitive nonsense, every boring game moment. I physically recoiled in my chair every time I was forced into 3, brain dead difficulty dogfights every time I just wanted to transport cargo through ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hyperspace. Around the 70% mark the game had already become very painful to digest, but I stuck it out just so my ape brain could see the sticker on my steam profile and the infinite shower of coins you get as a 100% bonus despite the fact that money has no value after you've 100%ed the game. (Also by the way the last challenge that stood in my path to 100% was bugged, and I had to replay the level 13 times before It randomly worked by accident that last time. I will murder Kylo Ren with a snowman.)The story missions are quite abridged, fast forwarded and simplified if you will, which really sucks if you are a person who genuinely cares about the story and wouldn't mind being retold it again in detail. It stings a bit when even the quiet reflective and powerful scenes from the movies are cut short or played completely for laughs. The real meat and potatoes of the game is through exploring all of the different planets, or at least the planets that the poor time crunched devs had time to finish, looking at you Kijimi.  Overall if you pick up and play the game it will be a good time and worth the money, but the second you start to reach deeper you soon realize that the Skywalker Saga puddle is actually quite shallow and rough around the edges. Still the best Lego Game since the Wii era of Lego games though. Over all 7/10, not enough Watto.

author: Zap105
review: I'll be honest, kinda underwhelmed.I was uber hype for the game during development, even after the delays, because I grew up playing Lego games with my brothers, and I was more than ready to play this supposed "ultimate Lego Star Wars" when it dropped.Unfortunately, after months of not touching the game, I just haven't been able to bring myself to keep playing past Episode 1, and even completing that single episode felt like a chore more than a game. PROS:-Amazing and dynamic graphics and cinimatics-Faithful, yet humorous take on the Star Wars film plots, as is par-for-the-course in Lego games-Large open world(s) to explore and find collectables-Lightsaber combat is fun-That Darth Maul fight was absolutely GLORIOUS -A leveling/powering up system that incentivizes finding Kyber bricks-Funny back-and-forth interactions between the characters you choose (one of my favorites: Young Anakin: "That's a cool suit! Where can I get one?" Darth Vader: "Patience, child. Patience")CONS:- Walking. a LOT of walking.This isn't even a joke, about 60% of episode one consists of traveling between locations where nothing happens (except some dialogue if you're lucky) and you can't fast travel to speed things up. As an added bonus, if there's characters talking, you are slowed to an absolute CRAWL for the duration of the area in order to avoid skipping any dialogue.- The aforementioned saber combat, while fun, is uncommon, at least if you're following the "story mode" - Blaster combat, while having a nice, over-the-shoulder playstyle, feels clunky and monotonous. (more of a personal nitpick i guess)- Starfighter combat is janky, slow, and repetitive. I found myself many times asking "Wait, another wave of enemies?" as i slowly steered my fighter to shoot the barely-moving fighters. Easily one of the most disappointing parts of the game, especially considering how the fighter combat in the Lego The Force Awakens game worked.- The mind-boggling amount of the EXACT same puzzle with little-to-no variation ( batteries, platforming, more batteries, character panel, and EVEN MORE BATTERIES)- The way you unlock characters outside of the story (glorified fetch-quests of talking to the right people) is very, very annoying and not at all rewarding to pull off when you finally find the right joker to ask about the character you want.Heck, it's hardly worth the hunt because all characters are basically just reskins of the same handful of classes (Jedi, hero, astromech, etc) with no gameplay variance between them.- The sheer quantity of the kyber bricks being kinda just spat all over the world, not in any really clever ways with cool puzzles or sequences like old lego games did, just in a "oh, didn't think one would be here" kinda way.The most "unusual" puzzle (if you can even call it that) that I remember from my playthrough of Episode 1 consisted of rebuilding pipes to fill tanks with water on Tatooine and, despite being the most "unique" puzzle I encountered, was by far and away the most monotonous, boring, and frustratingly slow sequence of events and took a good 10 minutes, not from difficulty (it only gave you the pieces you need at a time, so a bit hard to mess up), but from the sheer length of the "challenge". The reward? A single kyber brick. SO fuggin worth my time...- "Actual" levels don't really feel unique or special, usually feeling like an extension of the open world area (and not in a good way. It kinda feels like "Oh wait, that was a level I just did? all i did was WALK do a hero panel and shoot 3 droids"TL:DR-Once my nostalgia-tinted glasses were taken off, I was left with a monotonous, boring, repetitive, aimless, wannabe Lego Star Wars game that, while it it has some good stuff to work with and matches today's standards of graphics, feels incomplete or unfinished gameplay-wise.A real shame. At least we have The Complete Saga still which, I might add, still holds up today, at least in my mind. Go check it out instead of The Skywalker Saga. You won't be sorry.

Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself

author: Spooky_Traps
review: Gonna be a very thorough review, as I finished playing Episode 1 It's worth buying the deluxe version of this, as is it the same price as any regular 60 dollar mainstream videogame. With the deluxe version, you get additional DLC character add-ons to use during freeplay. One thing that surprised me the most about this game was how short each level is compared to previous LEGO franchise games where you go through many modes within each level. I finished the entire Phantom Menace in just over an hour, while the time it took me to complete one level in 2016 Force Awakens Game about 45 minutes to an hour. That could be due to the 2016 game being the entire movie plot, but it was very surprising to have only the Gungan Battle Mission last merely 7-10 minutes. It reminds me of the Complete Saga game, if not a bit shorter. I'm so happy that Lego incorporated the Clone Wars voice actors to VA their given characters in the Prequels. It was awesome to notice that. Also, the open world mechanics are amazing and will for sure last you days just to cover one planet at a time. There are so many opportunities to complete civilian missions and collect kyber blocks to upgrade your skills. Using the holoprojector is still new to me, as that is where you will be able to access your freeplay characters and ships, as well as purchase unlockable characters.   One of the griefs that I have about this game lies within the DLC, and that is not having the ability to access the Bad Batch, Mandalorian Season 2, and Rouge One character packs. Part of my reason for buying the deluxe edition was for the immediate access to these amazing characters so it's a bit frustrating to have to wait longer till April 19 and May 4th. The villain duels are flat out amazing to play, I am definitely replaying those missions just for the fun of it If you're a die-hard fan of the Lego Star Wars Franchise I would absolutely recommend this to play.

author: 星鸢
review: Nominated for best to go game award Oh boy...Long HAVE I WAITED for this game. TT games really took a while to get ground with it. I was in shamble with every delay announcement., but I am glad things eventually worked out amazingly. Not only we get additional content from the Mandalorian seasons and the Bad Batch, the game also runs amazingly well without any major frame rate drops. The visual is by far the best the studio has put out. Though the lightsaber effects are still a bit weird when you turn around a little...No big deal though. Things I wish to have in EA's battlefront 2 like Rogue One characters, the two series related contents I've mentioned above, more skins for iconic characters like Ben Kenobi and Kylo Ren, and BANTHA, are all in this game. What's not to love? Except probably the absence of FOV slider and Online COOP. I hope they will add these two features in the near future, especially the FOV slider. This default view really would mess some people up during extensive play sessions, and I am one of them. You don't have issues with these two things? Then hop your ass in and buy the game! Oh yes, you better buy the DELUXE EDITION. It gives you all the sweet characters from the Solo, Rogue One, the Mandalorian, the Bad Batch and some other stuff! Pretty good deal if you ask me, whether you are a fan of Star Wars/Lego or not. Trust me, this game will make you feel the love and efforts the developers have put in. Now I hope they get some good rest from those crunches.

author: Flavius Claudius Julianus
review: How the Lego SkyWalker Saga has more content than the new Star Wars Battlefront games is beyond me. Proof that when you have merit and care about the product, you can produce quality.Finally! A Star Wars game where developers can take liberties with the lore without offending fans. This game REALLY makes you feel like a Star War. Playing this is a kind of nostalgic bliss. The Lego Star Wars games were my exposure to Star Wars as a kid and were how I first experienced the movies. I still remember being a little kid when the first Lego Star Wars came out. It was the greatest thing ever, I at least put like 500 hours on that game as a kid. When I played it originally I couldn’t read yet so it was very hard for me, but it was always amazing. I  still can’t read, and actually don’t know how I am able to write this but here we are. As a somewhat adult man, I gotta say we’ve come a long way from the days I would grind the Lego Star Wars II Mos Eisley level on my Gameboy… what a feeling. The hours I put into the Complete Saga, along with all the other games is astronomical (no pun intended), yet I feel like a little boy again whenever I pick up and play the Skywalker saga. It’s just phenomenal. It has its issues too, but it’s just amazing overall. It's a solid game and a great rehash of the old game. Looks absolutely stunning! LEGO humor is intact, which is great. Some levels from the old game aren't in this one but it's pretty much an updated Complete Saga with more modes and features and even more characters to play around with. I've had so much fun with it and it's a superb game.It's everything I wanted as a huge fan of the older games, plus a little more. It has so much amazing content that I love and I think it's worth every penny, especially for someone who enjoys completing games.I'm a big Star Wars fan, and this definitely has become one of my favourite Star Wars games. Let alone Lego games. This is pretty much everything I could have asked for from a Lego Star Wars game. I enjoyed every single level and the open world is amazing. I have to reiterate it isn't perfect and I have a few small problems with it but I could see this become one of my favourite games of all time.Whoever is running the Lego company really  knows what they’re doing. The games and movies they make are always so high quality it’s astounding. It’s one of the very few children’s companies that actually seem to care about their product. Well, whatever they’re doing… it’s better than what Disney has been up to that’s for sure.This might just end up being the best Lego game of all time.10/10

author: leia (she/her)
review: SPOILER WARNINGSPOILER WARNINGSPOILER WARNINGFantastic game! It's 100% clear to me that TT Games has made this with the old games in mind; not as a replacement, but as a successor, a game that kindly respects them rather than ignorantly bypassing them. (It even uses the original minikit collection sound as it's build complete sound! I have too many hours on The Original Trilogy and Complete Saga to ever forget that satisfying bit of audio.)The game has taken to a completely different set of levels. Instead of raiding the Jedi Temple in Episode 3, you'll be fighting Sidious in the senate chamber. Instead of fighting a bounty hunter mid-flight in the first level of Episode 2, you'll be exploring, trying to figure out what that dart thing really is.Frankly, it's a much more immersive way of going about the story. In LGS (The Prequels), you'd finish fighting Grevious then immediately transition to running and fighting clones on Kashyyyk, with little to no story explanation; it was a bit of a mess. Don't get me wrong, the levels were fantastic (and specifically levels 1 and 6 of Episode 3 had some of the best design of many of them.)Even in The Original Trilogy, you'd go from murdering Jabba the Hut to going around in speeders; the games seemed to be picking specific points to hit from the movies rather than retelling them, and that resulted in games that weren't all that immersive; games that really were a bit scrambled.This game is different. While the levels may be short, they're very involved and combat-filled. And, when you finish a level, you don't teleport to the next level automatically, you're still within the relative area of where you finished it; you have to travel to the next level yourself (or stay where you are and get Kyber Bricks, a fantastic part of the game that I can't stop participating in), really showing off the fantastic galaxy TT has made. The more story you complete, the more planets you have (and you can go anywhere anytime!)The game is a bit of a fabricated experience, though; it shows you what to do, and actively directs you towards that goal. You're always able to go your own direction, but you cannot 'untrack' the story mission, it is always tracked. You'll always have a tiny orange exclamation on your screen, nearly 24/7, adding to the odd smattering of UI elements the game's dropped on your screen. Of course, a fabricated experience isn't a bad thing; it's a kid's game, after all, meant for a very wide audience, not just 20-30 year old gamer nerds. The game does let you tune these to an extent (you can disable or enable consequence-free falling, for example, reducing stud loss to 0 when you fall into the void), but not everything can be turned off or skipped. For example, the game will give you a tutorial when it deems you should be shown it, locking your controls and forcing you to do what it's asking. You can't turn them off, either; just do what it's telling you to do. It's a little infuriating, to be honest.That's all nitpicking, though. In it's entirety, this is a massive, beautiful game, with a ton of massive, beautiful environments, and a ton of massive, beautiful levels (that are short in a linear sense, but have so much exploration to them that more than makes up for it!)I highly recommend this game, it IS worth the price. (For reference, I can count the times I've paid $60 for a game in the past 10 years on my left hand.)This was worth the price.I love this thing.THANK YOU TT GAMES YOU ALL ARE FANTASTIC

author: Sithis
review: incredibly addictive game;[+] amazing graphics[+] nostalgic af[+] cool easter eggs [+] fun quests with a nice LEGO touch[-] partly too long and especially boring boss fights[-] experienced the game starts lagging after a few hours

The controls probably should be more mouse-pointer-based, with an in-game cursor.3. I want to replay missions in the Skywalker Saga.4. There should be an explorable Starkiller Base planet, and Kijimi should be explorable. There also should be a Supremacy capital ship, too.5. Every episode should have 6 levels instead of 5. Episode I should have the Negotiations level at the beginning of the game, Episode VI should have a level in which you blow up the Death Star II after defeating the Emperor, Episode IX should have a level in which you destroy the ion cannons of the Final Order's star destroyers, and other episodes should have their own new level.6. The game probably should have villain missions for Villain and Dark Side class characters.
