author: gilbertxironman
review: SEIZURE WARNINGhello im one of the few epileptics in the world with photosensitive seizure. flashing lights or high contrast lighting can trigger a seizure with my condition. i love this game but i wish there was a setting to turn off the lightning and spark effects. those are the big two. i have to limit my play time but other than that love this game. best lego game ive played in years. hopefully we get an option to turn off effects in the future.edit: firstly i would like to thank everyone who wished me luck and stood up for me against the negative star wars fanboys. secondly, to everyone saying that they wished id have more seizures and hope i "shake on the ground and die" (yes someone said that) im not mad at you because your not worth mine or anyone's time. to everyone saying "there is a warning at the beginning of the game jack***" i know that but i had already bought the game prior. i am relatively new to pc gaming and did not know you could request a refund on the game if you don't pass 3 hours on it. i really wish that i could give this game a mixed review but unfortunately steam doesn't have the option. i understand that developers dont have to accommodate people with disabilities and i dont expect them to, it would be nice though. this comment was primarily for fellow epileptics who didnt know the game had intense lighting. thank you to everyone who told me there was a setting to turn off repeating effect that was very helpful and i took your advice. surprisingly there were a couple of epileptics that called me a liar and if you are really epileptic that you would know that no two people have the same type of epilepsy. so mine is different then yours 100 percent. i thought about removing my review or turning off comments but im not going to do that. if you want to keep hating on me and make fun of me for something i cant control that fine. im not losing sleep over it. i find it funny that people say im just mad because the game is too hard for me. i challenge you to find an easier game than a lego game.so in conclusion, haters you keep hating, thanks to everyone who left nice and helpful comments, and may the force be with youp.s. i changed the review so it says i would recommend the game because its a fun game but i cant make a review neutral

author: Lieutenant Tea™
review: This is the definitive Lego game. This is one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long while.The game has all 9 episodes, it took around 17-18 hours for me to beat in co-op, just for the base game, it will likely take hours upon hours to 100%. I really enjoyed episodes 1-7, 8-9 were questionable but more on that later. There's also tons of side quests and missions. If you're expecting a remake of the complete saga, you will be very disappointed. This game is very different but in a good way. They tried so many new things and it worked. The game is now semi-open world, it has some rpg elements like quests and upgrades, etc.I beat the main story in co-op, and it was great in co-op, I'm pretty sure it would be enjoyable in singleplayer too. No online multiplayer kinda sucks but Steam remote play is surprisingly stable in this game, especially over ethernet. I played with people from halfway across the globe and 98% of the time it was flawless. As far as performance on the host machine it's not great, I'm running a RTX 3060 & Ryzen 9. The game dipped under 15 frames in some missions.This game has so much polish, for example on Tattooine or Hoth, your player will have sand or snow particles on them. And almost every character has unique dialogue with each other, it results some interesting character reactions with characters from different episodes. It also has the normal Lego slapstick humor we all know and love.Episodes 1-6 are amazing, I enjoyed basically every second of those. I am not a fan of the sequel movies but I actually enjoyed episode 7 too. Episodes 8 was surprisingly mediocre. But episode 9 was straight up bad. On episode 9 I got straight up softlocked once or twice, the level design was confusing, it was pretty boring gameplay, on top of a bad plot. But the other episodes were amazing. I love 1-7.The game is very buggy. It's not uncommon to completely softlock yourself, or have another major bug. It's actually sometimes really annoying and happened to me a handful of times throughout my playthrough. But a good chunk of the game is flawless.Overall hard recommend whether you're a Star Wars fan and/or a Lego fan, adult or kid. It's amazing. I loved almost every minute of it.

author: Koshō
review: As a veteran Lego Star Wars fan, I have mixed feelings.This game is great on a technical level, having all 9 of the movies in one package. All the characters are beautifully animated and blaster fights have been massively improved since The Force Awakens. Unfortunately, thats where the positives end for me.The levels are very short. To some, that sounds like a good thing, but to me, it fails to make an impact on the player. Just when the level starts to get good, it ends.Also, the bugs. I have no idea how a LEGO game, has this many bugs. The mumble mode that so many LEGO veterans like me have been so excited for; it actually breaks some of the in-game sequences. In my experience, I also have quite a few game-breaking bugs that force a game reset, and even a crash to desktop.When I first booted this game up, I was beyond excited. When the bugs get fixed, I will delete this review to give a [Neutral] stance on this game instead.Edit: No Battle Over Coruscant level requires that this game recieves a permanent negative review.

author: veaac.fdirct
review: This game feels like a husk of a Lego game: The developers went with a very formulaic design instead of trying to make the game actual fun:* Most "missions" involve walking from A to B, talking a bit, sometimes a cut scene, and being dumped back in the hub area, just to walk to the next mission. There is usually one 5-10 minute mission per 1h hub area.* Lots of loading time... made worse by the mission  design which loads a new level for 30s of walking.* Many missions are uninspired: You are not doing anything interesting, varied, ...* Some missions were clearly not tested / designed in co-op, with the 2nd player not being able to do anything for some time* Hub areas are littered with collectibles that require little to no thought to collect.... just enduring the tedium. less than 5% of the tasks actually require some though. With more than 1400 things to collect it is all quantity, no quality.* Inconsistent UI/controls, and in general lack of polish and streamliningAltogether it feels like they were just doing the game by-the-numbers, instead of iterating the design, and much to the detriment of fun missions, and puzzles. It's a shame, but it seems the developer do not really know what made some of the older ones fun (Lego Lord of the Rings is still one of my favourite)

author: myrrdan
review: new edition, screws over every deluxe edition owner.. AND if you look carefully.. you're paying for character packs TWICE!!!you buy the individual character packs, 1 and 2, and then you're buying the character pack collection 1 & 2 combined.. Now, since i'm not stupid enough to dump more money into this game, i'm not sure if that 'collection' of character packs give you different characters, but with what they've done to their deluxe game purchasers, I would probably say they don't and they're just trying to make as much money as they can. It does look like you're paying for the same characters 3 times in some cases. As for the game.. very good lego game, very good star wars lego game. worth buying to play for either of those reasons. worth having in your collection.

author: Cyb3rb0t
review: This game just brings back old memories. Classic LEGO humour, characters and updated gameplay mechanics. Definitely hits you with a wave of nostalgia, but Skywalker Saga is reinvented beautifully and contains the best of both worlds, retaining the classic feel while also adding new additions. Awesome game if you just don't want something too serious to play or need to blow off steam.Recommended 10/10

author: TheWelshKiwi
review: I have waited until completing the game before reviewing so I can fully put together my thoughts on it.After 89 hours I overall had a pleasing experience, the game is one I would recommend to others although it would be better for you to wait until a major bug fixing update comes out. I was fortunate to not experience any game breaking bugs unlike other unfortunate users. However despite being able to play-through in the games entirety I have experienced a few bugs which I will list.- major fps drops in the ewok village open world area and in the droid factory level- character switching bugs when doing remote play co-op- random crashes- characters having no faces- mynock mynock puzzle breaking, was able to fix by using boba fett to catch the glitched mynock- unable to complete certain levels and level challenges in free play- the minimap option of rotate with player doesn't work all the time while it is selected for some reasonThis list of bugs whilst not game breaking were certainly a pain to experience. Another unfortunate thing is that from my experience the game was not optimised well for the remote play co-op. My friend and I encountered various issues whilst playing, particularly the character switching issues in free play which would cause the other player to randomly change character when the other player was selecting a character. We also found that the secondary player often had what we coined as "little brother controls" in levels due to many of the levels being 1 v 1 boss fight scenarios. This made the experience for the secondary player less enjoyable although I'm not sure what they could have done to help this.But enough of the negatives lets get into the positives, this game is nostalgia central. it reignited my love for Star Wars as well as my love for LEGO. The open world exploration is massive and really well done. There are hundreds of puzzles and little side missions that make up for the fairly small amount of story levels (only 5 per episode). I really enjoyed playing the game and actually followed through with 100%-ing it completely which for me never happens. There are plenty of the classic LEGO game witty jokes and funny cut-scenes which I enjoyed despite being and adult. The gameplay is really good, the fighting mechanics are really nice and I liked the camera angle that the game used. They could have done more with the ship and space gameplay but we have to remember that at the end of the day this is a game designed for children. Overall I'd give the game an 8/10

author: Badger
review: This review is based on my experience of completing Episodes 4, 5, 6 , and 1 story to completion.This pains me to write. I have been looking forward to this for years, and I am not enjoying what they made for us.The levels are short. The few puzzles there are, are lackluster. Building is rare if present at all. Difficulty is non-existent. Over-the-shoulder gunplay is repetitive since Troopers are just blaster sponges.This is a LEGO game only in style and name. They spent so much time developing open exploration that they didn't give platforming and puzzle design the time and care it deserves.Some more specific issues I've had:-Turning off aim-assist and health regeneration changed nothing in regards to difficulty. The only thing that changed was that it actually made the speeder level on Endor impossible, forcing me to turn aim-assist back on so that the speeder itself locked on as you can't aim.-Enemies and vehicles pose absolutely no threat, not even the AT-AT's. The Battle of Hoth is lazy, hardly feeling like you're actually taking down an AT-AT. Instead you're just flying through hoops in a clockwise fashion, providing no real satisfaction when you succeed.-The platforming doesn't feel good either. When grappling some climbable areas your character doesn't automatically lock onto the ledge. Instead you have to make sure that the game specifically prompts you to "A to JUMP" or "B to GRAPPLE". Otherwise you *will not* grab it, even if you are clipping through the geometry. And during some sections swinging between poles or vines on Dagobah does not feel natural. It locks you to one position, and the momentum is non-existent. There's a section in the Maul fight where you're supposed to platform across an electricity floor, but literally all you need to do is press A to jump across one at a time. No skill or difficulty at all, just one button.-The lightsaber duels are set up with a tutorial that seems promising, hinting towards more in-depth mechanics, but no. There is no satisfying dodging, or QTE. It's just as shallow as the rest of the combat.I understand this is a LEGO game, made for kids, but even The Complete Saga has an abundance of puzzles and at least some more difficult combat and platforming.And as of writing, there are also so many precious moments to Star Wars that are not shown in the Story missions. There is no infiltration of Theed palace. C-3PO isn't blown up and carried on Chewie's back. Leia doesn't find Wicket, she just appears at the village. You don't even get to blow up the Death Star in Episode 6. It just happens without you.

author: Darren
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: Forensick
review: As someone who has played every Lego game and 100%'ed a sizable chunk, I cannot recommend this edition.Playable levels have been reduced to 1/10th their original size and barely even reveal themselves during the gameplay loop. Instead, the developers have decided to create "Hub Collectibles: The Game."If your idea of fun is glitch jumping up walls or standing on buttons to open a chest for the over ONE THOUSAND  collectible gold bricks, then by all means, enjoy this to your heart's content. Just make sure you already have every character class in your immediate roster because they removed the ever-present selection screen and changed it to a convoluted menu that takes 20 clicks to pick a specific avatar.On the plus side, it has wonderful HDR support and impressive textures, lighting, and reflections.

author: nomsa
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Gamer Vader
review: Overall the game is very empty and lacking in a any gameplay. most levels take about 5 minutes to complete and have little replayability. Especially episodes 1 2 and 6 most of the events happened in cutsceans even blowing up the deathstar is not a level and happens in a quick 10 seconds cutsceane. Developers clearly spent 90% of thier time on how the game looks and 10% (or less) on how the game actually plays. The game boasts a massive 400+ character roster but once you unlock them there is nothing to do with them as levels are so short. Nostalgic player will relive their childhood for a short time before realizing all there is to do is walk around hub worlds and unlock collectables that dont actually serve a purpose in the game. But newer players will find a mostly empty gameplay experience that can be completed in a single afternoon. Was hopeing for a lot more given the 3 year wait time but at the end of the day there just isnt anything here. puzzles are embaressingly easy, so many kyber bricks are just sitting in the open with no puzzle behind them just lying the middle of the street. Space exploration is non existant except as filler from going from one level to the next. On the plus side the game does look amazing and many iconic locations can be explored and that classic lego humor peaks through every once in a while. unfortunatly this game will get pointless after unlocking the 1 millionth kyber brick than can only be used to unlock a pointless upgrade to your hero.  Similar to the early stages of No Mans Sky its a massive ocean but its not deep enough to even drown in. Was mostly dissapointing but had so good laughs along the way. 5 out of 10

author: DatWolf
review: I was very excited for this when it was announced back in 2019. Unfortunately for me it did not live up to expectations. While visually stunning, it lacked any kind of depth or simple problem solving reminiscent of past titles. There seemed to be a lot of "go here" now "go here" with little to nothing other than very similar side quest filler. It may just boil down to me being too old or not liking the more open world concept vs the older more linear titles. It gives off a very large as a lake and as deep as a pond vibe. All in all I think it fits the age range it was meant for. Anyone below the age of 10 or anyone with a short attention span should totally pick this up but anyone wanting a newer and prettier Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga should not waste their money.

author: GRIMM
review: LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is the latest in the long running line of licensed LEGO games from Traveller's Tales. It was also one of the most heavily anticipated games in the entire TT LEGO series. And why is that? Well, for 2 reasons... 1, the trailer looked amazing. But also because it was one of the titles that spent the most time in development and promised the most new features and changes to the series. If you look back at the long line of games you'd see we got a new LEGO title pretty much annually. In some years we even got as many as 2 or 3 new LEGO titles. Basically Traveller's Tales was pumping these out like clockwork. And then after 2019, after the release of The LEGO Movie 2 Videogame, nothing. We got our first glimpse in 2020, but it would not be for another 2 years until the game finally released. A little over 3 years between games. Yes, the anticipation for this one was as strong as the force. But was it really worth the wait? Skywalker Saga takes the formula of past LEGO games and makes a bold choice to switch things up, which results in a few steps forward, but also a few steps back. Where the game really shines would be in 3 key areas: Action, exploration and unlockables. But where it suffers mostly would be in the overall flow of the main game. The game is comprised of 45 stages spanning all 9 movies with 5 stages per movie. The stages are tied together by segments that will have you go through some of the free roam areas, but in general they are rather short. Most of the playtime will be spent revisiting stages to unlock things you could not access before with new characters in free play mode. It's a bit of a downer when compared to previous LEGO games, and this is primarily due to the fact that levels are not padded with puzzles but rather focus more on action segments with minimal puzzles, which is a 180 turn compared to previous titles. While the game does do a good job capturing many key moments from the movies, there are also a lot of key scenes at the same time that fans will notice are missing, or heavily compressed into short segments in cutscenes. While it's not unusual for LEGO games to rush through story pieces taken from movies, it is still a major bummer since we waited this long. Luckily the game makes up for some of this in other areas. For starers revisiting some stages is a blast. While some are going to be short no matter what, others do feel a tad bigger when revisiting to unlock things. Also the free roaming areas for the most part are massive with tons of side quests and lots of things to unlocks. You'll spend a lot of time hunting down these new things called kyber crystals, which are essentially the replacement for gold bricks. In past lego games gold bricks did not hold much merit. Some games allowed you to accept new quests if you got so many gold bricks, but that was pretty much it. Kyber crystals on the other hand can be used for currency to unlock new abilities or enhance character classes. And there are a ton of these to collect also, with over 1,000 of them scattered across the entire galaxy. Combat is also another major improvement over past LEGO games. In previous titles combat was simple, and pretty much a straight up button masher. That's not to say this one is not also a button masher. It still can be. But there is also a bit of strategy to be found here as you can pull off combos now. Sometimes enemies will even block your attacks if you mash the same button over and over, forcing you to press other attack buttons. It's a small change, but its still a very welcome one that takes away from the tedium of pressing the same attack buttons over and over. Ranged combat has also been overhauled, as you can freely aim in any direction now like a traditional over the shoulder 3rd person shooter. Some enemies will even have reactions depending on which body part you hit. Like shooting at their legs may make them fall over, or shooting the helmets of stormstroopers will actually make them fly off revealing the lego heads underneath for a followup headshot resulting in an instant kill. You can even sneak up on enemies for stealth kills. Hell, there's even a counter button, though I did not see much opportunity to use it as the LEGO characters you play as already seem kind of overpowered as usual not giving you many opportunities to need to use the counters. But when you do get an opportunity the counter will result in a special move reminiscent of some of the flashy spectacular special moves you'd see in some of the past lego games. Some of them very good for crowd control too. Needless to say, the combat changes overall are a very welcome addition to Skywalker Saga.Aerial and space combat is also a welcome change. In past games that featured this you usually had 2 types of aerial and space combat: On rails or tilted top down. Now there are still a few on rails segments here, but they have ditched the tilted top down space combat for full control of your spaceships, meaning you can get into  some full 3D dogfight action for once! And it's a blast when you are in these stages. You'll be weaving in and out tie fighters with your X-Wing, Millennium Falcon or whatever ship you have access to while taking down the enemies or shooting at cannons, satellite dishes or other objects on massive space stations or dreadnoughts or other massive spacecraft. Sadly this type of combat is limited to certain stages, and the space sections you'll find while exploring the galaxy are just that... space. It would have been nice to see more action in the free roaming space sections. Visually Skywalker Saga looks phenomenal. The name of the game is anything but realism, and instead your characters are all comprised the typical LEGO bricks. I mean we are talking a LEGO game. But the mixture of solid animation and little details make it a visual treat. You'll find little visual nods like when you walk around Tatoonie seeing bits of sand getting stuck to your minifigs, or walking through the snowy tunnels of Hoth and seeing your bricks getting snow stuck to them. Cutscenes also have some wonderful animation that look like a proper CG movie. Very spectacular and a great treat to behold. And the overall look of the worlds is also eye candy on the LEGO scale. Like many past LEGO games, it is a mix of bricks and more realistic looking set pieces also. Typically if it is made of bricks it can also be destroyed, so some areas can get completely wrecked leaving bricks scattered. Sadly the chaos does not last as bricks do disappear when destroyed after a short period. But all the same it is very satisfying breaking things down. Mostly the game runs great for me playing at 3440x1440 with an RTX 2080 Super playing on max settings. The overall stability of the game is far from perfect however  as there are still some bugs to be ironed out. I have had the game crash to desktop on me a total of 4 times in the 25+ hours I have played so far. 2 of the crashes while revisiting the General Grievous. There are also 2 areas which also are prone to massive frame drops even on high end machines as multiple people have reported (myself included). Those 2 areas being the Droid Factory Frenzy stage and the Ewok Village. Traveller's Tales is aware of some of these issues so now it is just a matter of how long before they are fixed. But when not encountering the 2 aforementioned sections the game runs extremely well for the most part. Pros:Amazing changes to combatHuge open world hubsTons of collectablesAerial and space combat is extremely funCons: Story skips or rushes through several key segmentsBugs still need to be ironed outOpen world space sections feel underwhelmingOverall, I think Skywalker Saga was indeed worth the wait. It might not be perfect, and some parts do feel rushed, but that aside I have had a blast so far playing the game.

author: Derangedraptor
review: I give it a thumbs down but really think it is just a meh game because the devs put a lot of love and care into it and made it follow the movies much better than the original games. That being said, if you are looking for an experience similar to the original trilogy game than don't buy this. In my opinion they gutted everything that made the original fun and replaced it with a lot of empty open world and near zero combat. Most of the game is spent going from place to place essentially seeing a lego set of the movies. I am incredibly underwhelmed. If I wanted to watch the dialog from the movies, I would just watch the movies. I came to smash things and solve puzzles and 99% of the smashing has been on random lego structures and the puzzles are badly placed and scattered across the open world rather than the actual missions. The only upside is how nice everything looks. Otherwise it totally fails in comparison to the original lego star wars games.Update 1: I played through the first three episodes and the Phantom Menace was by far the most boring. I would argue that the game got progressively more fun, but there were a ton of missed opportunities. The main one being that they make you go check on Anakins mother in ep 2 but don't let you fight the sand people, instead they make you wander around for 15 minutes with no action and then give you a cut scene.

author: Ev4est
review: If you are looking for a relaxing and immersive journey through the star wars universe this is a must have game, i havent even gotten into the second episode and have already seen the scale of explorable areas, this game is massive, and unbelievably pretty and dynamic. from strolling through the streets of tatooine, to the massive palace in naboo, the scenery and interactions with the world make it a really enjoyable and calming game. While i would never expect this from a lego game, it is rather tame in regards to combat difficulty, at least from what ive experienced so far. Its unlikely that though the journey your heart will be racing, hands sweaty, mind racing as you try to beat the final boss of an episode, because that isn't TT style of lego games, rather the combat is satisfying and fluid, rewarding you for combos and parries and massive hoards o enemies to mow down and fling pieces everywhere!! Great game overall, definitely the pinnacle of TT games, however if you like intensity in a game, this may not scratch that itch, its relaxing and slower, but really really immersive.

author: MrKeego
review: I must preface this review by stating that I have fully completed the game. I have 100% in-game plus the extra Steam achievements which are not required to pull the 100% lever on Yavin 4. I don't usually post Steam reviews for the vast majority of the games that I have in my library, but this is an exception. I hope my lack of formatting skills and/or awareness can be overlooked in favour of the review itself.Perhaps it was the hype that got me overexcited to buy and play this, considering my last REAL experience with LEGO Star Wars games was with the Complete Saga, and I believe perhaps this hype affected a lot of us whose last games were the Complete Saga. I hope that my review will stray away from nostalgia and focus on the real problems I have with the game, but first...THE POSITIVES:It would be wrong to say that content is lacking as a whole in this game. All of the character models are incredible, the planets and space battles/levels are beautiful, and a lot of work evidently went into making these characters and worlds come to life. The comedy through the story missions in particular, I felt, was excellent, and many gags landed perfectly, such as DJ's tool to get out of the Canto Bight prison being one of those orange brick separators and his reward from the First Order being a solid gold brick separator. Those moments stuck with me throughout my experience, but unfortunately they were far too short. I believe that is my main issue.THE NEGATIVES:I think you would understand given that I haven't recommended this game that I have far more problems with the game than I have praise. Thankfully I did not experience many bugs throughout my experience so I won't include any lengthy sections on them, but I do feel like a game that has been delayed for as long as it was should have been able to iron out the more "game breaking" bugs that certainly do exist.THE STORY of the game is incredibly lacking in comparison to the open world, so much so that I feel like the actual Star Wars story was put on the sideline in favour of the extra content. Extra content is not a bad thing in any capacity, but when it outshines the story then there is a problem. This game is the saga of the Skywalkers, hence the name, yet you will spend most of your time doing anything but furthering that goal. Extra content, challenges, and side missions should surely compliment the base game and not overshadow it. I feel as if the added content was done more out of "memery" than story telling. I remember more from having to annoyingly escort Gonk droids around than I remember of the Sequel trilogy levels as a whole.THE LEVELS are incredibly short. I get it: it's a LEGO game. The levels are always short, right? Well, no. With the Complete Saga as an example, the levels were as short as necessary, not as short as possible. I'll paint this picture with reference to the beginning of Episode I. "Negotiations" is present in both games. In the Complete Saga, it is an entire level. In keeping with telling a story, everything is present from the movie. The ship the Jedi arrived on is destroyed thus trapping them on the Trade Federation ship, it introduces the player to combat, Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan discover the invasion force destined for Naboo, they sneak aboard one of the Droid tanks, and the level is over. In the Skywalker Saga... the level consists of a cut-scene showing the destruction of the ship, one hallway and then you walk out into the hangar and that's it over. It's not even counted as a level in the game, which is something else that annoys me to a great degree. It actually feels like filler - no more than a connection between meeting our characters and landing on Naboo. It's underwhelming to say the least.MORE FILLER THAN CONTENT plagues this game. For certain levels I spent more time travelling to the necessary planet, waiting through loading screens, painfully making my way through walking segments, sitting through a cut-scene, all for a level that may last five minutes. The odd level will take longer, but what purpose does a level like the Naboo monster escape have to the Skywalker saga? Dodge attacks, shoot backwards, mission over. It's frustrating having levels like this but then the actual levels where you would expect content is lacking. Again, Negotiations could have been made a level and the Naboo underwater monster level could have been taken out entirely and nobody would lose any sleep over it. But every trilogy has these missions where when you start the mission you don't actually start the mission, you just start the build-up to the mission. Every time it happened my friends and I would jokingly shout "GAMEPLAY" as we walked forward half-listening to exposition that is incredibly rushed.LEVELS THEMSELVES LACK CONTENT outside of walking to the missions. Episode II's Geonosis Arena is probably the worst offender of this. Following the battle with the individual creatures, the arrival of the Jedi to the arena was almost non-existent. The main Jedi appeared, like Mace Windu, Kit Fisto and Ki-Adi-Mundi, but outside of that it was really quiet. And the arena battle amounted to basically nothing. In the Complete Saga, the Arena battle felt alive. It felt as if a battle was taking place around you and you were just trying to survive before the boss battle with Jango Fett. This time, Jango is part of the droid "attack", you kill him relatively quickly and that's that over. The Geonosis Arena battle meant an incredible amount for the story of Star Wars, with most of the Jedi being killed since they were unprepared for the combat they were facing and the overwhelming odds against them. In the game it's just an excuse for the Jango Fett boss battle. It's shockingly empty.100% IS A CHORE and incredibly frustrating. Gathering over 1,000 Kyber Bricks scattered across the planets was not fun, and realistically meant nothing because I easily beat the game (meaning the story levels) without upgrading many of my character classes. By the time I finished Episode IX I had hundreds of these things just sitting and waiting to be spent on upgrades that now meant nothing to me. The data cards were an interesting take but pretty much pointless outside of the stud multipliers. Why could they not have been bought with the billions of studs I amassed throughout the game at some kind of inter-planetary shop? I had far more studs than I knew what to do with any hardly anything to spend then on, and 25,000 studs for hints or whatever else means nothing when my pool of money was in the billions. Gathering characters was the least fun I had in this game. Sy Snootles, Mama Hutt, and other INCREDIBLY RANDOM characters are all in the game and have to be unlocked through purchase or missions, but they couldn't include a character customization option? I have no reason to run around as Babu Frik outside of two seconds of it being funny before realizing he's ultimately pointless and only included to add more characters... for some unknown reason.--------I could go on and on about issues plaguing the game, but I think I've at least shown the most egregious offenders in this review. I did not enjoy playing through this game for the most part. It felt incredibly rushed, it favoured side content instead of main story content, missions were far too short and linked with unnecessary long travelling sections, wanting to 100% this game was a slog instead of an enjoyment and so on. It has its moments, but I genuinely don't know if even the casual player would enjoy playing through this game. It lacks originality for a series where LEGO would make it original enough. It's just... bland. Uninspired, boring, frustrating... and bland. For those reasons I just can't recommend this game. I doubt many people will see this review, and I'm just a random guy on Steam so my takes probably hold no merit but hey... I thought it was important to say that no, this game has a lot of glaring problems.

author: T12A34N56K
review: LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is a fun game by all standards. The missions are fun, the jokes are enjoyable even at their worst, and the openworld is nicely made. If you want a fun game for you and your friends (skip the online coop problem) in the star wars universe this is the game for you. However, compering it to old LEGO games (Star Wars III: The Clone Wars, DC Super Villains) that I played this game is not as good at keeping you in after the campain is finished. In DC Super Villains I went for 100% complition due to the fact I wanted to collect all the characters. They all felt different and I considered the missions different and interesting. I did the same in The Clone Wars with the characters but in this game the way they have it set up they all feel the same due to the class sistem. I get that the Jedi and the Sith are preaty similar but Leia and Cody shouldn't be identical in abilities. This simple designe choise has a few effects on replayability and might be the reasson character customisation was dropped. This sort of character class sistem is boring because I have no reason to search for other characters once I get one off each class since I could do everything now, there were no new mechanics, no new interesting combinations, everyone feels the same. If to this you add an open world that barely throws staff at you unless you ask for it and even then it is week, you get a post mission world feels empty. The ships do not change that with few of them feeling different esprcialy when it comes to turn and roll rates (they are the same for all) makeing dog fights not skill based but spam turn better based. With all of that beeing said the game is still peaty good. The ground combat is fun and enjoyable, the missions are fun and if you sow the films you will enjoy them, the bosses are well made and the places look and feel good, its just that they didn't fill this wonderfull game with enough unique things.

author: T-Wayne
review: A long time ago in a galaxy far far away…EPISODE ITHE PHANTOM MENACETurmoil has engulfed the Galactic Republic. The taxation of trade routes to outlying star systems is in dispute.Hoping to resolve the matter with a blockade of deadly battleships, the greedy Trade Federation has stopped all shipping to the small planet of Naboo.While the Congress of the Republic endlessly debates this alarming chain of events, the Supreme Chancellor has secretly dispatched two Jedi Knights, the guardians of peace and justice in the galaxy, to settle the conflict.On the planet of Naboo the Jedi Knights encountered a gungan by the name of Jar Jar Binks. At first, they were irritated by it being so quirky and annoying. They then decided to activate what the sacred Jedi Order called “mumble mode” on their translators. Suddenly they were at peace once again and able to continue their quest to Tatooine, where they would meet a small boy, whose fate would have a major impact on the galaxy…

author: Azazel
review: Remember when you bought games and got everything you wanted at once, without sudden fees for some really tiny content that could easilly be a free update? Good times, good times.This game does in no way have the same feel nor charme as the complete Trilogy. Honestly, the Lego Games have felt dead and hollow for a long while now, and this is just the final nail in that coffin for me. Boring and mostly empty overworlds with "missions" that get all cleared the same way just there to inflate gameplay time, and absolute boring, short and soulless levels.A sad display.

author: Na0ki
review: This game felt so good during the first few episodes, but every second more made me realize that it's all fluff, mindless padding and barely challenging gameplay. Now, before you stop reading, I know this is a LEGO game. I know Lego games aren't supposed to be Elden Ring, however, if  the AI misses 99/100 shots while you're completely standing still, if the key to a door is literally a meter next to you, if the puzzles become so mind-numbing that TT Games gives you the skill to simply skip them, it becomes apparent that you never had proper gameplay, just padding. Kids these days play Fortnite, games that aren't really always easy, but if you even dare to put Mario or Kirby next to LEGO Star Wars the Skywalker Saga then you realize that even kids games have an ounce of a challenge to them. This game makes Mario or Kirby games seem hard.It isn't all bad. The planets to explore are amazingly designed. I had a lot of fun exploring these, getting the collectibles and enjoying the beautiful graphics. I never knew plastic could look so good. The combat is also giving me a strong Devil May Cry vibe, but it's obviously a bit easier. Doing combos in this game feels amazing until you realize that the foes you're put up against aren't even nearly worth the spectacle. They die in a few swings which never makes the combos outstanding, rather short-lived.Now. Let us talk about the bad. Every game deserves some criticism, even a LEGO game.This game has so much content, but most of it isn't quality.When it comes to the episodes, there is a lot of padding. Most of the time you spent 20 minutes going to the missions, and even when you arrive, they aren't really fun. The game acts like you overcome these great challenges, but none of the battles give you more than 5 enemies per spawn to fight. Great wars like the battle of Kashyyyk, the arena fight on Geonosis are completely mindless, and it ruins the atmosphere. These battles feel more like barren wastelands with the occasional droid trying to do some minor havoc by missing 90 shots. I can't even call the puzzles "puzzles", since you aren't even doing the one thing you're supposed to do during a puzzle. Thinking. Most of them are just pressing a button at the right moment with a 5-second window, or simply pressing 4 buttons in the correct order. This is yawningly boring and handholding on the next level. Especially level design completely suffers through that. There are never any stakes, no sense of urgency or whatever. I even ran through a level and somehow got the "True Jedi" achievement, my guy, I DIDN'T DO ANYTHING.The bosses too are most of the time recycled. The first boss you meet will be the most fun, because Darth Maul, Count Dooku, General Grievous, Darth Vader or Kylo Ren will have the exact same attack pattern. It is simply copy and pasted.The level selection itself is odd too. Each episode has 5 levels, which completely limits TT. The battle over Coruscant, the fight between Mace Windu and Palpatine are generic cutscenes. That is truly sad. The Complete Saga was better in that.Last, but not least, the cutscenes. The cutscenes are well animated, however the game doesn't do well in telling the story in its own way. It completely misses the impact of many cutscenes, like Anakin's mom dying or Order 66 happening. Luke loses his parents and immediately goes "I guess I wanna be a Jedi". They often miss the point, for the Sequels it makes sense, because they don't have a point, but the lack of explaining makes me want to rather watch Star Wars and play a game like LEGO City Undercover rather than playing this game, which has the "story" of Star Wars in a LEGO game setting. Humor too often falls flat. The Complete Saga had many jokes, some subtle, like Darth Vader's corpse sliding into Luke's ship. Disappointingly, the humor in this game is so on the nose and so constant, every serious scene you saw in the trailers gets ruined by humor before and after. Not even one cutscene goes without trying to tell a joke, I only laughed at 2. You can't be funny, if you start expecting when the jokes will come and are rapid firing into your funny bone. It doesn't work. 5/10, I had more fun exploring the planets than doing actual story related missions or side quests.

author: love sosa
review: Ladies and gentlemen, this is Chewbacca, a Wookiee from the planet Kashyyyk. But Chewbacca lives on the planet Endor. Now think about it; that does not make sense! Why would a Wookiee, an eight-foot tall Wookiee, want to live on Endor, with a bunch of two-foot tall Ewoks? That does not make sense!But more important, you have to ask yourself: What does this have to do with this case? Nothing. Ladies and gentlemen, it has nothing to do with this case! It does not make sense!Look at me. I'm a lawyer defending a major record company, and I'm talkin' about Chewbacca! Does that make sense? Ladies and gentlemen, I am not making any sense! None of this makes sense! And so you have to remember, when you're in that jury room deliberatin' and conjugatin' the Emancipation Proclamation, does it make sense? No! Ladies and gentlemen of this supposed jury, it does not make sense!If Chewbacca lives on Endor, you must acquit! The defense rests.

author: Penguin
review: Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is a disappointing game, a fact that took me a while to fully accept. I didn’t want to believe that one of my most anticipated games of the year could let me down in such a big way.I started off by playing Episode 1 and for the most part was enjoying myself. The updated combat system felt refreshing, the visuals were stunning not just for a Lego game but in general, and the cut-scenes still had that Lego game charm. After playing around in the open world between each mission, I realised my goal of achieving 100% would be easier by playing through the story missions first, then alternating between open world for collectables, and then replaying story missions in free play mode to collect everything I missed or was inaccessible. I got to the Darth Maul fight and thought it was quite fun. I was still enjoying myself at this point, but some doubt was starting to creep in. Around Episode 3 is when I started really noticing how much the game was using the old walk-and-talk method to convey immersion, where a character provides the illusion of gameplay but is not more than a cutscene with very limited control. Some missions would involve more walking than actually getting to play the level, which is an issue the original Lego Star Wars games didn’t have. For some reason, it seems this game is taking the modern approach of making games more cinematic, which may work in more story-driven games like God of War, but doesn’t really work here. The more the game progressed, the more issues I started to notice. While the combat is fun, it boils down to spamming X on the controller, with the occasional button added in as enemies can now block your attacks. You can pull off some quite spectacular combo moves with a lightsaber akin to Devil May Cry, but unlike that game, this game doesn’t reward you for being stylish, therefore providing little incentive to do more than the basics. Shooting is mindless, monotonous and sometimes broken, such as shots not being registered. Dying provides no inherent risk to the player, so any sense of challenge dissipates. The bosses all boil down to the same combo - damage them until their first health bar goes away, forced quick-time event, repeat until all health bars are depleted. There are over 300 characters in the game, but with only 9 dedicated classes, they feel like 9 characters with different skins and each of them functioning the exact same way. The story doesn’t know if it wants to be serious or funny, which provides a real jarring juxtaposition within story immersion. It really doesn’t feel like a Lego game, as it removes features found in old Lego games like puzzle variety, the ability to build fun objects and being able to create a custom character. It’s a traditional third person action-adventure game with a Lego skin. When I reached Episode 5, I realised I stopped having fun a while ago and was forcing myself to finish the story so I could move on to open world - the part of the game I really wanted to play. Once I finally reach that point, I started to enjoy myself again, but that  was short-lived when I realised that each planet you explore was basically a re-skin of another. Kyber bricks are the main form of collectable in this game, which are like the golden bricks found in other Lego games. Although most of them would only feature around 250-350, Lego Star Wars made the choice to have , more than half coming from the open world and roughly equates to 40-50 hours of game time (by my estimation). Each planet would house Kyber bricks found through basic exploration, races, side missions and more, but the variety caps after one planet. I have completed 67% of the game, acquired about 750 Kyber bricks, explored just over half of the planets and fully completed Episodes 1-3. During Episode 4 in free play mode and having close to 50 hours in the game, I realised I was playing only to reach the 100% goal and I wasn’t enjoying myself.I stopped playing and haven’t returned since. The game does have its positives. Collecting data bricks, (this game’s equivalent to red bricks in the other Lego titles), allows you to unlock some fun extras like big head mode, pew pew mode, all lightsabers turning into baguettes and more. I can’t pretend to act like this didn’t put a smile on my face and honestly, it extended my game time. The planets are perfect recreations of the ones found in the movies. Exploring Naboo, Tatooine and Coruscant was a great experience. I don’t recommend this game, but I can see how others may enjoy it more than I did. If you were thinking of picking it up, I’d honestly recommend playing the old Lego Star Wars games instead (they don’t have the sequel trilogy, but that may be an added bonus to some). It does most things this game set out to achieve, does it much better and will continue to be fondly remembered for years to come, which is more than I can say for Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga.

author: Ryan
review: This game is an absolute masterpiece that was well worth the wait. I played the original Complete Saga game as a kid with my sister, so I decided to play this one with her too, While the actual levels themselves are unarguably shorter than other Lego games, the game more than makes up for it with a massive open world filled with collectables and things to do, 3 challenges to complete in every level, and the return of the classic minikit system. It took me 88 hours to 100% the game purely because there were so many things to do. Definitely the best Lego game yet!

author: Elixir of Will
review: Skywalker Saga is a game I was low key excited about. I fell off the Lego games wagon a long time ago, sometime around Lego Indiana Jones/Lego Batman. I remember playing Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga for hours and hours with my brother during my childhood, so despite the fact that I’m not hugely into Star Wars, seeing the original announcement and occasional news of Skywalker Saga evoked some nostalgic feelings in me. I didn’t think it’d be my game of the year or anything, but a semi-open ~~world~~ galaxy Lego Star Wars is the kind of thing that would have blown my mind as a kid, so I figured it’d be moderately enjoyable and worth checking out. Unfortunately, the Skywalker Saga really let me down. My main complaints boil down to four things: the overall lack of polish, the lackluster method of storytelling, the lack of trust in the player’s intelligence, and the variety of systems that feel simultaneously overcomplicated, pointless, and too simplistic.When I first started playing Skywalker Saga, it appeared to be a pretty polished game, but that illusion quickly faded. Every single time I open the game with borderless window selected, it doesn’t display correctly until I switch to fullscreen and back again. There were also a lot of clunky moments - things like pressing a button prompt to interact with something but somebody/something getting in the way, so you’re locked into a walking animation until that is resolved, which can take quite some time. Worst of all, several times during my playthrough a level became completely glitched (typically during boss fights when the enemy froze while invincible and the scripted part failed to trigger), requiring me to restart from the beginning. Skywalker Saga’s story is fine - it’s Star Wars, enjoy it or don’t, I’m not getting into that. It’s the storytelling that I take issue with here. There are lots of silly moments as you’d expect, and that was enjoyable to see. The problem is that Skywalker Saga levels are so incredibly scripted and constantly take away your control to show you something (often something completely mundane that you could’ve easily figured out yourself if it weren’t shoved in your face). It really sucks all the fun out of it when you keep not being allowed to play and have to sit and wait and watch something happen. This frustration is further compounded in boss fights - most bosses have multiple health meters and they tend to become invincible as each one empties until some scripted thing can happen, which gets old extremely quickly. To make sure I wasn’t blinded by nostalgia about this, I went back and looked at some let’s play footage from TCS to compare with, and they were much more reserved - just placed at the start/end of levels rather than constantly interrupting you throughout. That seems to me like a much better system. I remember going back and replaying levels in TCS with silly characters (such as the custom characters, notably absent here), but I have zero interest in sitting through all that scripted stuff again.Then there’s the apparent lack of trust in the player’s intelligence, which is one of the things that I find incredibly annoying. Like many of its Lego game predecessors, Skywalker Saga frequently throws little puzzles at you that you need to solve throughout your adventures. This includes things like smashing things up to get pieces to build into something else, opening locked doors, or using a droid to do any number of things. Building weird little gizmos (the boxing glove drill was my favourite) to clear obstacles is fine, but the rest of this stuff just feels like useless padding. The droid unlocking minigame boils down to rotating a couple of rings around to align the correct pattern, which sometimes requires literally 2-3 button presses. Unlocking doors requires you to either do this very slow dpad QTE or remember a pattern of 4 dpad presses, depending on the door. These things and the droid QTE are all so incredibly simplistic and slow that it feels like their only point is to pad the game out, which really sucks. And don’t come at me saying “it’s a game for kids!”, because that’s not an excuse. You can put more complicated things than that in a game for kids, it’s been done before, they can handle it. There are a lot of additions to Skywalker Saga that were not present (or present, but less so) in TCS - things like an upgrade system, the explorable semi-open world, the more in-depth combat system with combos, the little weapons caches, mounts, etc. All of these things are really cool ideas that on paper should elevate the experience, but they fail to do so. The upgrade system is convoluted on multiple levels, requiring you to find and spend kyber bricks (only around 270/1000+ of which are in the levels themselves, by the way) to unlock perks. Annoyingly, the skill tree consists of a lot of unrelated perks which are locked behind one another, so it sucks to see later down the line that you can increase your damage by 10% but first you have to upgrade your movement speed, unlock the ability to detect hidden collectibles, and other things like that. I realize that a lot of games do things like this, but typically the skills are at least organized into sections that make sense, so unlocking the best combat skill requires investment into other combat skills, but here it’s just a bunch of unconnected nonsense. On top of that, a lot of the upgrades are really boring/useless - % damage increase to melee, % damage increase to ranged, faster build speed (lol), etc. Surprisingly, I found the semi-open world areas (more like hub areas, really) to be more annoying than anything else. I’m sure if you’re into the game it could be fun to go around doing the little side quests and exploring for secrets, but when you just want to play the story it’s incredibly annoying how many instances of “follow the moving gold objective indicator for a couple of minutes” there are. All that pointless walking around is pure padding and the game would have been better off without it. Another issue is that because the developers want you to be able to get distracted by something along the way, “follow the NPC” missions will stop in their tracks even if you get too far ahead of them. You literally have to follow them the entire way or they’ll just stop moving and progress will halt until you come back.Skywalker Saga’s updated combat system is probably the thing I dislike the most about the game. Sure, you have access to some different combos and it’s fun to aim the guns yourself, but this came along with enemies no longer being one hit kills like in TCS and instead having health bars. I despise the health bars. The game constantly throws mission objectives at you like “defeat the stormtroopers” where you have to whittle down the health bar of a bunch of boring basic enemies that pose zero challenge whatsoever. The combat system in TCS by comparison is incredibly simple, but I think it works a lot better overall - neither of the games are challenging, but at least you weren’t bogged down with so many boring time waster enemy segments. I guess I just feel like if you’re going to expand the combat and make enemies this much more tanky you’d be so much better off going even further with it whereas Skywalker Saga’s combat seems halfhearted and can still easily be mashed through… so what’s the point?At its core, Skywalker Saga feels like a game made by people that had a million different ideas on how to expand on the core gameplay of previous titles - a skill tree, a combat system with combos, semi-open world hub areas to explore, and a million other things, but none of it seems to really come together in the way you want it to. On paper, all this new stuff should’ve been exciting to play around with, but in practice none of it was fleshed out enough to be satisfying, and in many ways the new stuff ends up feeling like a big step back.

author: Jamie
review: Alright, let's get started. If you enjoy this game and are reading other reviews, understand that this review is based on my own personal experience with my friend while we played through all 9 stories in Coop.This is a game that I had initially looked forward to back when it was first teased. However, the much needed delays honestly caused me to lose interest in this product, for example I didn't even notice the game had released (even though it was on the top of my Steam wish list) until like 3 days after the fact when I started to see people posting glitches on Twitter.Now, the reason that I do not recommend this game is solely because it is absolutely not worth the full price in the current state it's in. The levels are rather boring and quite spaced out (some of them even drop your frames into the single digits.) If you're interested in this game, make sure that you get it on sale so that you don't feel as duped for how little there is going on in the game.Pros:Some jokes land and are actually goodThere's plenty of references to other medias that have a clever spin on themThe graphics are goodThe clone wars voice actors did a really good jobPlenty of things to collectGun play is fun when it's used which is quite rare"I don't like sand"The Combo system is quite fun, but it's hard to get a high combo since there's not enough enemies to get a higher combo than maybe 30 without abusing a bugCons: Really empty feeling hub worldsVery few enemies to fightVery few instances where you have to buildReally short missionsPlenty of bugs that really shouldn't be in the gamePoor quality of voice acting for some of the Original Trilogy and Sequel TrilogyAnimations on characters either not loading or just looping?Lots of clipping and things being where they shouldn't be (not just clone troopers in the wrong era)No online coopSteam remote play is super unreliable and can drop connections to dirt despite having no real reason to do soEnemies don't have enough health to make Melee combat feel rewardingTutorials that won't stop even after disabling them in the settings like literally 25~30 hours into the game and still getting tutorials on basic features Cover system isn't necessaryCoop boss fights are really boring, for example, one player is Obi Wan and the other is C-3PO sitting there watching the fightClaustrophobic multiplayer split-screen (what happened to the one that the other games used with a thin line that moved dynamically around the screen?)Upgrade system makes you overpowered way too fastDatacards remove the enjoyment of finding the red bricks of prior gamesOverall, my friend and I both gave it a 5/10 and we played through every mission in the game and have an overall completion 61.2% and have no interest of going back to finish it to 100% since so many features of the game are just boring.I understand that this game means a lot to many of you on how the game is a "upgrade" to the Complete Saga, but there are so many intentional game design choices I feel are just so poorly made (for example the missions can be completed in speed runner times without even trying that hard.)Like throughout the time playing this game, there were plenty of times where we had joked about the fact that this game was delayed by 2 years, such as when fish on Naboo would swim through the level itself.If you like Star Wars and Lego, you might like this one, but just wait until it goes on sale since again, it's not worth the full price.Like many Lego Star Wars games are collect-a-thons, this one bolsters a high amount of things to collect, but those collectables are used as a way to cover up many of the significant flaws with the base game. Sadly the level of polish on this game could've ultimately used another 4-8 months to resolve.Some exploits to have some fun with:Force characters can bypass basically every puzzle  • Standing on a crate that's meant to be lifted with the force can bypass some puzzles  • Droids are basically the crates and characters all in oneThere are more than a few instances where objects keep dropping money far past the point that they should no longer be doing so  • The barrier on the Hoth mission in Echo base can be shot infinitely and will repeatedly drop blue and gold studsSome characters can stun lock enemies There are many instances where you can shot at an enemy's spawn and rack up insanely high combosLego Star Wars is something that I hold near and dear to myself, and this game just has far too many flaws in it's current state for me to find it enjoyable. If you are still interested in this game, by all means, pick it up, play it and enjoy it as much as you'd like to. Don't let my review here stop you from enjoying the game just because you either disagree with me or have noticed similar flaws, since I am not advocating for you to avoid the game all together, I just do not believe that this game is worth buying when it's not on sale.Did you notice the Eddie Izzard reference to the Death Star Cantina standup routine? (this video here  ) like Darth Vader is literally in the Cantina on the Death Star itself when you go there. It seems that nobody really caught this reference since it's not as child oriented as many other jokes in the game are, and yes, I know about the "Better call Maul" joke.

author: Unit Omega
review: While there are parts that were handled better in the complete saga, this game really does present a step forward from other modern lego titles. I remember Lego Batman 3 where every quest was a meaningless fetch quest where Lego Kevin Smith would ask you to go pick up some dumb collectible. Lego Skywalker Saga has varied quests, fun openworld puzzles, and a very good use of cutscenes, meme lines, and other well timed gags that make reliving the star wars stories again still fun. Some reveiwers are saying the finished the game in 20 hours, but I have been finishing most puzzles on the way, and even in over 24 hours I have really only made it through the first 3 episodes.

author: amazonen66
review: This is that game I’ve always wanted, an open-world star wars game, but it's also the game I dreamed of when I played lego star wars 1 and 2 (separately of course), a bigger and better version of the lego star wars games. I always wanted to fly around in space, explore the different locations and planets, take in the vistas and unlock all the characters. This game is all that, but I’m not the person who wants that anymore. All I can see now is the shallow combat, the frankly bad side quests, and the wonky performance. I didn’t care about that back in the day, but again, I’m not that person anymore. I care now, I care about the experience and the story but I’m also a gameplay-first kind of guy and this game just didn’t deliver outside of the almost great combo system. The complete saga has better level design, it’s not the better game but as an adult, this is so easy to see- this game didn’t focus on level design as much. They wanted the world to feel sort of grounded and realistic but this hindered their puzzles and their levels. But as a kid, The Skywalker Saga would have wowed me to a degree so high I would probably get a heart attack and die right there and then. But now I can’t lie and say I didn’t expect more from a game I’ve wanted to play my whole life.So I guess it's fine.

review: Funny at times but honestly just not very fun. Tons of boring modern game conventions like open worlds filled with meaningless tasks and collectables that aren't placed particularly thoughtfully. I'd rather just play the Complete Saga again honestly!

author: Emzotic
review: Honestly I love this game though it might not be the same gameplay as the other Lego games but I love how this one plays. The episodes stories feel a bit short but the cutscenes make up for it. The only reason why I would not recommend this game at least for now is the amount of game breaking bugs I've come across. Mumble mode causes softlocks, there was a point where I couldn't get out of the ship when starting the game back up so I was basically stuck and wasn't allowed to free roam I don't know how I fixed it just did it itself, and things just not triggering so I can't progress and I'm forced to exit the level and re-do it it's just infuriating. There's a ton of more bugs I've encountered and so have other people. I would love to 100% this game but with the bugs I just can't right now I hope they will release a patch soon that fixes all of this and if they do I'll change my review to recommend it but for right now I just can't recommend this game just for the bugs itself.

author: Ching
review: Conclusion : As a player got 100% Achievement in all Lego video games with achievementsDon't buy this if you are a beginner, and trying to aim 100% in this game, you will only feel excruciating and sorrowful with the repetition of mechanism, why build a grave for yourself? I recommend Starwars fan or anyone to purchase this game , as long as you don't aim for 100% is fine.For LEGO achievements hunter like me, just click add to cart , what are you waiting for? No point for you to read this.Btw I can literally feel the enthusiasm of TT Games, they actually put efforts to make a better improvement, i can see they are seeking for new features , they're making a revolution. The interface is the most significant and also control, unlike previous games, like Press J to jump or press K for skills. Alternatively, you can press spacebar to jump in this time. The mouse  finally takes part in control >>> This is very importantThe playtime is also much longer than previous LEGO games...... I thought LEGO marvel super heroes 2 is the longest until this....Total 45 story levels ++ Collect total 1200 bricks in the games, this is insane....I won't want to have any touch in LEGO games in short period. maybe I will buy lego brawls when it is on sale.

author: Magic Pie
review: Don't buy right now.PC port is all over the place. After 30+ hours my game now tends to freeze on occasion with the audio still playing on freeplay and certain portions of missions. One mission called the "Droid Factory Frenzy" tanks frames. Running a 3070 on my rig at 1440p drops my frames to just a little over 30fps from above 140 fps. If you do decide to purchase the game, make sure to backup your saves constantly because there are rare occasions where the game crashing could corrupt your save.Edit:Ewok village tanks frames even further. Getting a range of 30-40 fps. This is outside of story progression. It feels horrible to play and makes collecting bricks and characters disorienting with the horrible frames.Edit:FPS are still present as of November 2022.more Edit:One month after release and still no fixes for the issues seen on PC. Be cautious of the port when buying.

author: CalebTheGreat
review: This game is great. It's filled to the brim with content, keeps the charm of the originals while updating features. It's probably the greatest collectathon game of all time with over 1000 kyber bricks 100s of minkits, level challenges, and characters. The levels are fun and mix it up a lot. I mean the amount of ideas they packed into the main story is great. But with that said some things really didn't seem like they were very utilized. Like the class special abilities. Also there is an abundance of quick time events that aren't partially interesting, but it is a kids game. And for a kids game it looks amazing, the graphics are great and the style has grown on me. I would give this game a 9/10 honestly because of all the fun I have had with it. But there is one huge thing  that holds it back. THIS GAME IS BUGGY. There are smaller funny things like Boba's infinite bast to huge game breaking bugs. Here are just a few of the big things that I and others have dealt with.> If you have mumble mode on in Ep 9 the story misson won't let you go on unless you restart game game without mumble mode on.> infinite loading between worlds> Stuck camera > infinite death loop> Random crashes when changing characters> And one of the worst things ever is the character menu, everytime you load in it shows all your characters are new, when you buy a character you have to cycle though before you can select them,  bought characters are shown as not bought and just over all it isn't a nice UI, its just hard to get to who want to select and the sound effects aren't great and it's because of the character menu that we have character dupe glitch.I could go on and on about lag and models not loading in. There is a whole lot wrong with this game, and it's probably has to do the how the game forced to be made at home during the pandemic and was delayed.  But these things can be fixed and changed. I don't thing every little bug will be fixed but in the future I hope this game is a lot more playable. And still with all the bugs I will keep on playing, because this is a fun game. So I would give this game a 7/10
