author: Kitty Nat
review: We've been waiting since 2019 for , originally scheduled for spring of 2020, to be released.  The delay was not all due to the pandemic.Was it worth waiting for?Er, mostly. Storyline is the usual solid adaptation, but the collectathon/completionist partcontimues looonnnnggg afteward.The game is organized into the nine movie episodes, plus a Galaxy Exploration for easy access to the hub worlds for Free Play.Since each trilogy has its ardent fans (and detractors), the game makes the opening of the first movie of each (Ep I: The Phantom Menace, Ep IV: A New Hope, and Ep VII: The Force Awakens) available to you from the start, so you can go to your favorite trilogy first or save it for last.The game engine has been rebuilt, but not reinvented.  Most of the gameplay will feel familiar to anyone who has played any other game in the TT Games LEGO franchise.In solo or co-op play, players switch amongst at least two characters, using their various abilities to solve puzzles and advance through the levels.Levels have a variety of segments.  Some are simple exploring.  The light saber duels are represented and involve lots of button mashing, often with breaks to chase the opponent and do more exploring.  There are some spaceship chases, and destroying enemy big ships.New are the combos you can do in battles for extra power or for more money from defeated mooks.  These are not particularly needed, though, and just hitting X a dozen times works, too.With all the shootouts in the franchise, the devs have provided some low cover that both sides can use.  I've never been into shooters, and mostly resorted to the Jedi.  It is slightly annoying to have my character slip into a "taking cover" pose when near the barriers that make up the cover.  The barriers are rebuildable, and the pieces become distractions with their "build me!" animation.A brand new twist here are the Classes.  Characters in these games have always seemed to fall into various categories or classes, and here they are official.  Classes here are Jedi (Luke, Obi-Wan, Yoda), Dark Side (Vader, the Emperor, Maul), Protocol Droids (C-3PO), Astromechs (R2-D2, BB-8), Bounty Hunters (the Fetts, Leia as Boussh), Scavengers (Rey), plus Heroes (Leia, Padme, soldiers for the good guys), and Villains (Empire and First Order officers and stormtroopers).  There's also an Extra category for characters that don't fit easily or can't be used well, such as some tiny droids.  As usual, the devs give you almost every character model they whipped up to use, even if the cutscene or level segment missed the cut.All characters in a class have the same abilities, with no unique additions or combos.  On the one hand, this makes it easy to remember which character can do what.  On the other hand, it also prevents the devs from giving a character a unique ability (Think both hobbitty Baggins with the One Ring.)The distribution of abilities is always a source of annoyance for fans of a property adapted into a LEGO game.  Someone somewhere is always scratching their heads over why a certain character was given (or not given) a particular ability.For example, both Bounty Hunter Fetts have a jetpack, but cannot fly with them, even though both use them as bosses.  The Jedi and Dark Side share an odd one, using their light sabers to climb walls by sticking them in the wall and pulling it up.  And Heroes, Villains, and Astromechs all have their own terminals mainly to open stuff up.On the other hand, one of the best abilities is given to the Protocol Droids.  Hub world NPCs speak several different languages.  Many characters know a few languages, but only the protocol droids, created specifically to help in diplomatic affairs, know ALL of them.The Classes each get their own set of Upgrades, and there are ones for the whole game as well.  This not a min-max system, as you can jump in at almost anywhere and can accomplish most things without getting a single upgrade.  Rather, these are simply things that make the game a bit easier or faster, such as stronger hits, a greater health bar, more shielding for ships, or bypassing the repetitive minigames for Hero/Villain terminals.The sheer size of the game world(s) gives you a daunting task if you are a completionist tackling the collectathon part of the game.Seriously, the galaxy here is HUGE!  Almost a couple dozen planets to visit, some with a couple different areas to go to.  And some of the planetside areas are large in themselves, often beating the expansive Manhattan of the LEGO Marvel games.The main thing to collect are the Kyber Bricks ( of them!), a reference to the kyber crystals that power light sabers and give them their color.  This is the game's version of what are normally Gold Bricks.A chunk of them are awarded simply for completing the levels or accomplishing various things in the levels, such as for completing minikits (micro version of space ships in the game) or each of the three tiers of True Jedi money quotas.  (The partial credit is new and a nice touch; it's very difficult to reach the full amount in Story Mode.)New this game are Challenges.  Get all three for a level and you earn a Kyber Brick.  Some are easy, such as simply rolling to shake a homing missile in the flight levels.Some however, I found very difficult, such as: You have to either luck into completing the Challenges, buy the hint in the in-game menu, or just find the solution in an walkthrough.  The hints can be tricky to figure out.The hub world collectibles include more bricks, character or vehicle access (you still have to pay to fully unlock them), and datacards.There are the standard races, on land and in space.  In space, the races include Scramble Runs, in which you do not have to pass through the gates in a particular order.In space, you can destroy a Kyber Comet for a few bricks, or be offered smuggling runs to another planet.  You can even take over a capital ship (the Dreadnoughts, Star Destroyers) by destroying its defenses and defeating its captain.Hub world collectives include Datacards.  With one of these and enough money, you can unlock the Extras that in past games were earned with specific Red Bricks.  These include the traditional money multipliers and some stuff's just fun and silly, such as the Cantina Song on a loop, or light sabers looking like baguettes.Both non-flight levels and hub worlds have maps.  The hubs even have indicators for various things, including useful NPCs who will tell you about collectibles.  Some just point you to the nearby brick, others send you offworld.  Recruitable characters ask you for a favor before they will let you use them.Many missions will have you hopping from planet to planet.  There are also a couple "find all of us" missions, including hunting the mouse droids and finding a wookie tourist on every planet.The game has a shooting (and light saber toss) FPS mode.  As I don't usually play FPS games, it took me a while to figure out the controls.  A tutorial game would have helped.  There are some aim assist toggles, though, and one tap sets the gun to continual fire.  However, there is a shooting gallery (to earn a vehicle) that the aim assist doesn't work/help with.This is when I had my ragequit moment.  I had sunk a bit over 100 hours in the game ALREADY (including 10 or so on one particular level's challenge), well over the time on any other LEGO game, and still had about 30% left.  I had the satisfaction of completing the trilogy of trilogy levels, including everything in Free Play, but wasn't going get everything as I usually do in these games.  So, time to move on.But it was still a fun ride for most of the way.

author: The™ Baron
review: Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga revisits the franchise that kicked off the Lego game series as we know it by re-adapting thee first seven Star Wars films, adapting episodes VIII and IX for the first time, and tying them all together with substantially overhauled game mechanics. Combat is a bigger focus in this game with a slightly deeper hack-and-slash system and over-the-shoulder third-person shooter combat. The character system has been overhauled as well, with characters falling into particular classes that can be upgraded at large. And being a comedic Lego adaptation lets the game make the most of the movies' settings and set pieces while smoothing over the prequels' wooden dialogue and blunting the ridiculousness of Palpatine somehow returning. Ultimately, this game is no masterpiece, but neither are the films. Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is the best direct video game adaptation of the films that you're gonna get and a very fun one on its own merits, and that's all you can really ask for.

author: Oxo
review: So listen. Hear me out. When Padme and Anakin met, they were both underage: Anakin at 9 and Padme at 14. Still a questionable relationship, but not illegal or statutory rape. Furthermore, they were separated soon after meeting, as Padme went back to Naboo and Anakin became a padawan under Obi Wan. While it was obvious that Anakin was in love in episode 1, it's not really suggested that Padme was yet having sexual thoughts about Anakin. They did not meet again until episode 2, where they were both above age 18. Only then do we see Padme falling in love with Anakin. So, in conclusion, it's reasonable to assume that they never had sex until episode 2 and Padme is definitively not a pedophile.Thank you for coming to my TED Talk.

author: Vex
review: When I was a kid, one of my fondest memories was getting a PS2 with the first Lego Star Wars for Christmas 2005. That game helped shaped my childhood and my love of Lego games going forward. Lego Star Wars 2 the year after was also a great experience with many improvements over the first. The humour and quirkiness of these games set the bar for gaming that both children and adults could enjoy. The 6 missions per film with between 30 mins to an hour-ish per level gave a good amount of gameplay and despite the levels being "linear" there was plenty to build with hidden secrets to find. From illusive Minikits to Dancing Skeletons to Snow Globes on Hoth there was many a fun and unusual quirk in these levels.Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga gets rid of these big levels in favour of smaller set pieces with 5 in each film and honestly... it's a mess. I find myself running between various points in hub worlds (a cool idea in principle) to small missions that feel anti-climatic, unfulfilling, and generally clunky without the fun puzzle solving that the first games had. There are puzzles but they feel hollow, samey, and erratic. By the time a mission starts, it's over and I am aimlessly wandering an open world talking to generic NPC's that I could skin how I wanted and import into any generic game.Co-op is pathetic at best. Player 2 is often on the sidelines in big epic encounters as opposed to the original games where they were an active participant to defeat the boss. I will stop rambling but all I will say is, the devs obviously worked hard on this game and had a love for Lego Star Wars but whilst it is a large game it feels unfocused and more like a spiral galaxy of ideas that sound good but just make the core gameplay feel rushed and unfulfilling. The plot goes by at lightspeed and I feel as if I am not able to take in the story of these amazing films. Honestly, if you love this game then I am happy for you but for me, I recommend the original Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga to fill that nostalgia with a more focused and fun and satisfying experience that honours the narrative of Star Wars more.

author: eden
review: I enjoyed the first lego star wars game on the wii when I was younger, but playing it again in recent times left a bitter taste in my mouth, it didn't age well at all. The levels were long, the combat was too easy and really the only thing that the original game had going for it was the sheer amount of unlockables.This game fixes almost everything that's been wrong with the lego games, the combat is fun with a new combo system and lightsaber throwing, movement feels good, there's a free third person camera, the graphics are beautiful, and it doesn't ask for hours and hours of your time per session. The way they tell the story in this game is just like the older game, it's quick and only touches on what it really needs to. There are so many collectibles in this game and I've been having a good time going around collecting them all, most require you to switch to a specific character type, or solve cute well designed puzzles :)There are a few criticisms I have concerning the flow of the gameplay loop mainly in the prequel episodes, it feels like episode one and two specifically never leave you alone to explore. It was overwhelming, it asks you to travel to a new area what feels like every five minutes leaving you no room to breathe. While I like the fast progression of story in this game, for some reason it just goes WAY too fast in the prequels.The one other thing that's a little lame is that there are 'puzzles' where you walk up to a device with a specific character and perform a series of actions to open a door or power something. These are never built upon, it's always the same throughout the entire game and they feel arbitrarily placed around the game with no rhyme or reason. But honestly that's where the bad stuff ends.Finally, do not play this game in fullscreen. Play in borderless windowed. This game does not want you to tab out and trying to tab back in after doing so will either result in the game being scaled down to 800x600 and you having to set it back or the game just not focusing again. you have been warned.Overall this game has been a blast so far and i'm excited to keep going. It brings back the same emotions I felt when playing the original as a kid and sometimes i find myself smiling at just how immersed i am in a silly lego game :) There are a few poor trends this game follows but they don't outweigh the pros at all. play this one

author: Cheeseburger
review: After completing the game at 21 hours, I'm finally ready.I remember the nostalgia of playing the Complete Saga on the Wii when I was 10. It was amazing, all six episodes in the same game with every character.Now with the sequel trilogy, and a beefy computer, this game made me realize that lego games are just good fun.I wish the levels were a bit longer, but they did remove some of the more tedious levels from the older games, and I thank TT for that. I know most people wish the levels were longer, but for me, it keeps the story moving along at a pace I can enjoy.Everything and everyone is in this game and it is amazing to see the world they built and how graphically amazing it looks for legos walking around.I just wish they had online co-op. It stopped one of my friends from buying it. Could you imagine space battles or doing levels or helping with kyber bricks or datacards, it would be good fun. I wish TT can add this into the game, or maybe the next one.Overall solid game, nostalgia was brought back in full force, and overall, a fun game and a $50 well spent, especially in today's gaming market.7.5/10

author: Troubled_Zoru
review: To put this as simply as I can I'm disappointed. If you're getting this game for just an open world star wars game you're in the right place but if you're getting it for a Lego star wars game, don't bother. The good: The open world is amazing being able to travel between different areas on Coruscant or moving to Tattooine is great I love wondering around in this game and finding all the small details in the open world. The stories [at least the stories we got] are funny at the very least they were able to keep the lego game aspect even within the open world. Datacards I love the concept of Datacards and how they are essentially the red bricks now make them feel more star wars like.The Graphics are amazing I love wondering around this game and exploring these locations with such great graphics. The cities look amazing even the movies we dont speak of have good looking areas that fit them they feel alive.The Bad: The story is lack luster half the time when I've been playing this I am playing a mission only for it to be like... Thats all? I'm already done...? Iv spent more time collecting Kyberbricks on the planet than actually doing the actual story of the game. I wish we got more story even 1-2 more missions per movie would of been great but they went with only 5. I would of sacrificed some of the open world for more story honestly. Split screen is terrible, iv tried playing with a friend and if you even remotely try aiming the aim circle is placed right behind your head half the time and its unplayable to even look around properly. Custom Characters removed, Honestly the removal of custom characters is a big thing for me. Its sorta the key factor of a Lego Star wars game and its just removed. Taken out... makes me sad to see this feature leave us. Ray is the first character we hear when we boot up the game... not even a skywalker.. why? They could of done Anakain... or Luke even ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Ben... but they picked... Rey.... not even a skywalker.Characters are no longer unique, R2D2 can no longer hover. Palpatein cant shoot lighting, Darth Vader can force choke but every other dark side character ALSO has this ability. This game is missing so much in terms of unique characters. Honestly I would of given up a good 100 of these characters in this roster for unique characters and custom characters to come back. The platforming in this game feels clunky and incomplete some of the time just falling off do to my character refusing to do the proper taskThe enemies are way to easy I only died once in a boss fight and that was to maul and my own mistake. Dosn't help if you farm kyberbricks you can get not 1, not 2 but 4 health bars making it almost impossible to die. Ship combat is way to easy I understand this game has kids in mind but honestly really? Conclusion: If you want a free roam star wars game, go for it, but if your buying it for a lego star wars game. Don't bother its not worth it. It dosn't even feel like a Lego game anymore. Unique characters are gone. The levels are short and there are few of them. The collectibles are outside the levels now. Custom characters are gone. Just to many negatives that overwrite the positives. The only thing this game really has going for it is the free roam is great.Edits and Corrections: Something else I will add the combat system upgrades are amazing. Don't get me wrong on that, the issue I have is again characters just feel the same and dont have anything special going for them.Also for the split screen comment about how its "Not needed" a big part of any lego game in my opinion is the ability to go and play it with a friend. Just cause you don't play it with a friend dosnt mean others won't try. Split screen in this game just needs to be improved.For those thinking palpatein can shoot lightning he can briefly use it in his combo. There is nothing for long lasting actual lightning like he does in cut scenes. Iv also just played to confirm I see no traces of them actually using their abilities that people say they have so my point still stands. Little traces of it in a combo does not count cause they are still the same as any other character. Their unique abilities are gone and that is what im upset about. Not the fact palpatein has lightning in his combo.Correction:  I was wrong about force choking not being in the game but literally ANY DARK SIDE CHARACTER can use it which still proves my point about no unique characters.

author: Sinico
review: The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.StrategyHis fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distractedA very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

author: Lamp
review: This game feels like a husk of a Lego game: The developers went with a very formulaic design instead of trying to make the game actual fun:* Most "missions" involve walking from A to B, talking a bit, sometimes a cut scene, and being dumped back in the hub area, just to walk to the next mission. There is usually one 5-10 minute mission per 1h hub area.* Lots of loading time... made worse by the mission design which loads a new level for 30s of walking.* Many missions are uninspired: You are not doing anything interesting, varied, ...* Some missions were clearly not tested / designed in co-op, with the 2nd player not being able to do anything for some time* Hub areas are littered with collectibles that require little to no thought to collect.... just enduring the tedium. less than 5% of the tasks actually require some though. With more than 1400 things to collect it is all quantity, no quality.* Inconsistent UI/controls, and in general lack of polish and streamliningAltogether it feels like they were just doing the game by-the-numbers, instead of iterating the design, and much to the detriment of fun missions, and puzzles. It's a shame, but it seems the developer do not really know what made some of the older ones fun (Lego Lord of the Rings is still one of my favourite)

author: TheMaid™
review: TL;DR: The game isn't the best LEGO game, it has it's pros and it has it's cons. If you want to buy the game for the star wars story, don't bother but if you want to play the game for all of the LEGO collectables then this is more than worth it's price. VVV Pros and Cons VVVPros:- Graphics- Collection of Characters- Space Mechanics- Most Combat (not covering fire)- Has Darth Vader (That's pretty cool)Cons:- Buggy- Designed not around base mechanics, but designed around assuming you have the assists on- Lackluster main missionsI am giving the game but only barely and honestly, out of bias, this thumbs up. In all honesty, the game has been a small mess to say the least. I've read a lot of really positive reviews all saying that the game is great, bugless etc. but this isn't true unfortunately.I'll start with the good things first. The obvious is the vast improvement to graphics and overall quality of the game. I've had great performance running the game on 1080p, max settings for what it's worth and I only have a GTX 960 graphics card, I'm pretty sure integrated graphics could run it if anybody is concerned about that. Anyway moving on, the game has a large collection of characters from each Episode varying multiple classes and this feature is really cool, you can upgrade each one and use each class to complete the few puzzles that exist, I'll get onto puzzles later. There are also various different ships that you can actually fly around space and onto different planets though flying is limited to space. Space battles are another cool thing, while travelling between planets you can get pulled out of hyperspace and be dragged into a space battle between 2 clashing factions. There are small scale ones where you destroy a few fighters and then there are larger ones that include the games capital ships. I love the combat, I'll say that, the new combat is really nice to use especially and mainly as a Lightsaber user. With blasters, it was very hit or miss, sometimes i'd have a blast using the different blaster types and just destroying all of the enemies that had gathered behind a single bit of cover or simply spraying across a crowd, lightsaber/melee combat just hit differently though. The new combo system is small but still cool, you have to start it with a regular attack and from there you can either use the force, go into the air then slam or just continue attacking. Pummelling Darth Vader in the corner with constant step backs, combos and lightsaber throws has to be the most satisfying thing I have ever done in a LEGO game. While the main missions leave a lot to be desired, the open world of the game doesn't, you can explore every planet from the 9 main movies and most of them really in depth too, all containing a large amount of collectables on each planet, I'm currently on Utapau and about half way through completing the planet. Large planets I'd say takes a good few hours to complete while the smaller ones just 1 or 2, but that all depends on how you play. Each planet also has Ships and Characters you can unlock by completing their respective side-mission which you may use rumors to assist you. Rumors are small hints that you can either buy from the menu or find with certain NPCs spread throughout the galaxy.Onto the negatives. The game is just buggy, there have been multiple times where I've had to reset levels because I have been unable to complete the objective which sometimes left a pretty sour taste in my mouth after it happened the 3rd or 4th time. There have also been times where i have flat out just fell through the floor on multiple occasions and I'd be left falling in a loop since the floor is also the last 'safest' place to reset. In some levels where you control a vehicle, mainly speeder and space fighters, I would just be thrown to the left or right for no reason, a complete 90 degree turn which resulted in frustration. Another thing with vehicle control, mainly in space, if the mission requires you to be going straight ahead and pushes you that direction while also giving the player free range, it just doesn't end well. If you turn too much to either the left or the right, the game would take control and instead of turning you back to the objective or simply resetting you, it decides to just turn in every direction it can which often leads to confusion and frustration of losing control of what i want to do. The next thing i want to bring up is the way the game is designed around the assist settings. The game has options to toggle on or off Aim Assist and playing with this off has led to a few rough levels, specifically the speeder chase on Endor. This level without aim assist is out right impossible, your shots would more or less always go into the ground unless your speeders front part got lifted by a bump on the level or something but other than that, there was absolutely no way to control it. The end result was me turning on Aim Assist for the first time and realising how much the game seems to function just a small bit better, with correct hitboxes and hitting targets. Next is level design, I know this is a controversial thing to say because "It's a kids game" but that doesn't justify the lack of puzzles and/or challenge to the game. If you look at previous LEGO titles, there have been puzzles galore and personally it was my favourite part of the LEGO games, trying to find out which pieces fit where in a grand scheme of bricks and layouts to unlock a mini-kit or some more studs was just exciting, in this game, that wasn't there. You'd maybe come across a room that requires you to move some large bricks into place so you could access a terminal to unlock a door which would grant you a kyber brick or ship. The next is levels, levels are so short and do not engage well with the player, most of the time you'll watch a cut scene, shoot some guys, finish the level and then another cut scene, they are also incredibly short and have at least one of the get behind cover and shoot mechanic in all of them, which after a couple episodes, starts feeling dull and I began to run right through them. The last thing with levels are bosses. Overall they're alright, they get introduced in a cool fashion but then you get a pretty mediocre fight. The fights go like this, Hit boss, boss runs, you fight troops, you chase after boss and then that loops 2 or 3 times depending on who you're fighting, it got boring pretty quickly. The last thing I want to talk about is the story, obviously it's going to follow the star wars story and that's cool, it's a reason i bought the game. However, I feel like the developers had more of a joke with the game and didn't take many things seriously, every small bit no matter how serious, includes a joke and it won't even be something small, it would just be something that ruined the scene for me.This is my first review so i'm sorry if it's a bit drawn out but i felt passionately about this game and thought id provide a few insights for anybody scrolling through the reviews, this may not be well received but it's just my unfortunate experience while playing the game. Either way I hope it helped.i am still going to be playing this a lot and will 100% it!!

author: unclebenzos
review: I‘ve been waiting for this game since the first trailer came out and I was extremely hyped. Now, after all the delays I have to say, its not the game I was hoping to play for the last 3 years. At first I thought I had fun while playing, but it was actually just the built up hype that wouldnt let me accept that this game is 0 fun. You just play through the levels and they all feel and play the exact same, for 45 levels. The Story is boring as f****. There are 4 types of levels: -) run around till you reach your destination and shoot enemies who literally deal 0 damage, even if you stand still-) drive around till you reach your destination and shoot enemies who literally deal 0 damage, even if you stand still. -) try to find a card or a key or another random object, you will need to progress further in the story. Those objects are extremely poorly hidden.-) fight bosses, who feel the same in every single bossfight and also do 0 damage. The prequels are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in level design, 0 puzzles and no difficulty. At least the original trilogy and the sequels don't feel that rushed, but still, TCS levels were 1000x better. The gameplay is actually good, it feels so much better than in the old games and the combos are fun to use. Problem is, you can’t fully use it because of the AI. It is impossible to die in this game, even if you are a child or a person whos bad at videogames in general. It is literally a challenge to die. The graphics and the open world *design* are pretty damn good. Very detailed and nice to explore. But after you‘ve seen every planet and completed the story missions (which takes like 10 hours max if you’re not collecting every single stud.) you have the open world missions left. Those missions are complete trash and not even a little bit fun to play. Over 1000 collectibles and over 300 missions to unlock the option of buying a new character. They all feel and play the same. Its repetitive asf. Its a shame that people defend TSS by saying the level design has simply „evolved“ and they had to break the „old formula“ for something better to come. I mean, they kind of made the game more modern, by applying the boring open world formula most triple A games have these days  I really tried to like the game, but its just bad. Even a remake of TCS would have been so much better. If you like to spend 100 hours in a game doing the same missions over and over again, just to complete it 100%, this is the right game for you.

author: Djhatt
review: This game exists solely to generate profit for Warner Bros. Games. The launch was a mess, and it took way too long for game breaking bugs to be fixed. Warner Bros. didn't even care enough to put up an announcement during the steam awards, yet they somehow won the "Sit Back And Relax Award." (Lego Brick Tales is 10x more relaxing and actually has a active developer team) Additionally, I bought the game with the deluxe bundle, which promised that it would include all DLC. They have since released a "Galactic Edition" which has more DLC that is NOT included in the deluxe edition. I will not be supporting any future Lego games made by this team if this is how they treat their players. I really hope that the developer team behind Lego Brick Tales can get the opportunity to make more Lego games, because their game is 10 times better and has already fixed many bugs right after launch.

author: MARK_RON72
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: ✞ 50 Caliber ✞
review: Look how they massacred my boyLike many others, I played the original lego star wars a child, and have a lot of nostalgia around it. I wanted this game to be a HD remaster, but i was open minded for a new style of game and would have been happy to accept a change on the format.Gameplay: This game has been simplified to the point of being boring. Lego games have never been hard, but theyve always been cute and ingenuative. It was fun to see the different ways they Incorporated a beloved franchise into a lego world, all the refrences, the humor. This game has none of that. The missions are bog standard, 90% of it is just running from place to place sitting through the loading screens. For some reason they designed the mission lay out to play out in the "open world" itself, meaning each section of a level is inside a part of an explorable planet, taking you out of the story while you run around looking for the huge glowing ring that lets you play the next section. Audio: Instead of using the original voice lines, they hired voice actors to imitate the original lines, some of which sound like the character but none of them are delivered half as well as they were in the movies. Gone is the charming grunting and gesturing, and theres no nostalgic rush to be had. Its just mediocre voice acting. I assume this was done to be able to easily add in lines that arent said by the original actors, but i didnt hear any of that, and even every side quest being voiced wouldnt make up for how badly done the lines themselves are. I prefer silence to cringe.Story: Its.. just.. why. The story is incredibly condensed, making every scene feels rushed and the dialog feel spliced and jammed together. Fun parts are skipped and replaced by mindless walking. Remember the naboo infiltration mission? No you dont get to play that. Instead, spend 5 minutes walking around the gungan city and sitting there "escaping" a monster where all you have to do is press a button when prompted. Remember in attack of the clones when obiwan finds out the location to kamino? Yeah you actually play that in this. Youre dropped into the world and have to run to dexters, once there you have to wait tables till he fixes his robot, only to sit down and have a 20 second conversation, then you have to run all the way to the jedi temple, into the library, then play a minigame to unlock the archive, then run all the way to your ship to fly to kamino, THEN you play an assasins creed follow mission and WALK from the kamino landing pad through boring hallways while listening to the kaminoin drone on about nothing till you get to the room. You spend like 20 minutes to get through what was a single cut scene in the first game. It adds nothing to the game but bloat, none of it is fun, 85% of it is running from location to location. This takes time away from story development and fun gameplay, because the developers spend their time on 20 minutes of nothing instead of adding to the world. Like much of modern cinema, its empty fluff to padd out the gameplay time. This was done in a single cutscene which was more endearing and gave more information than 20 minutes of banging my head into a desk. All of the cartoon humor has been sucked dry, I smiled a total of three times in 2.7 hours. At one point, general grevious dabs. As if he hadnt been made a mockery of enough in the clone wars, they made him do an already extremely dated dance move to further sap him of any and all intimidation he could possibly have. W h yCharacters: The characters are just boring. Its cool to see them in such high quality, but all of them feel the same. They have classes now instead of abilities. We have a new menu to change characters, instead of holding down Y and getting the whole list, you have to go through the menu to find a character menu, to find the class menu to scroll around looking for the character. None of them have noticeably better jumps, the astromechs cant glide, Jet packs are pointless. All of the classes combat comes down to spamming the button to do the exact same moves as everyone else.Co-op: Just painful. There is no dynamic split screen like in basically every other Lego game, it will be vertically split no matter if youre right next to each other or on opposite sides of the map. This leaves you with only half a screen, which makes it hard to enjoy the look of the level or even see what you need to be doing. Every, single level selection requires both players to hold down the select button at the same time, which sometimes just wont work. when youre in a ship youre likely to fly into your target while waiting for the other person to get positioned. Since theres no online play (in a game made in 2022), i have no idea why you need to agree to the level in the game, youre probably not going to be playing with someone you cant get along with.Im summary: I wanted a remaster, but i would have been happy with a good game that was different, i got neither of those. I got a boring, uncreative, uninteresting, clunk fest of a game for twice what the original cost on release. My very first video game that I, myself, owned was a lego game, its how i learned to use a controller, and how i learned my basic video game "skills". Ive been a fan ever since, but this will probably be the last lego game that i purchase. There hasnt been a good Lego game since Jurassic park, and this is no different. Rey Palpatine is at the very top of the menu in a game entitled "the Skywalker saga"0/10

author: Zagreus
review: Sadly i cannot recommend the game right now, even though i really want to.The cutscenes are great, the Graphics are fantastic.But the missions are just bad. A normal mission is just:you start in free world ---> run to the mission ---> cutscene ----> solve some puzzle ----> cutscene ---> boss fight ----> cutscene ---> free world ----> repeatnow as i said the cutscenes are well done and look great but theres just to many, and they sometimes do the fighting for you, if i wanted that i'd watch the movies again.If your lucky you get to fight some enemies before or after the boss fight, which is nice because i really like the new fighting system, especally the combo system, that is very well done just like the space battles which seem a bit underwhelming as there isnt much going on (only 10-12 fighter at most and 2-3 capital ships which dont shoot) but the ship controls are very good. Overall though the game also seems to easy, i have been playing this with a friend and its been really easy.So sadly i cant give this a positive review, i have only gotten to episode III after that i just didnt want to play the mission cycle for the 50th time again, maybe it will get better, i certainly hope so and if it does i will change the review but right now i would jsut buy the old lego star wars games as they are by far better.to summ it up:pro- Great Graphics- Great Cutscenes- Great new Control systemcon- Terrible mission design- Kinda boring Hubworlds- Only very short side missions in Freeplay

author: löli
review: Best and biggest lego game made to date. Combining all star wars movies into 1 big open world game.It's great to experience all the movies all over again (with MEMES) in lego form with it's humor and explore all the planets just like the protagonists. There is so much to see and experience, from Tatooine in first movies to Exegol in last.24 planets380 playable charactersand 1200 collectables will give you hours of playtimeOnly the side missions (which there are hundreds) such as escorts, space shootouts and delivery are VERY repetetive and monotonious. Also the loadtimes  when you are told to go to a diffrent planet than the quest giver, you do the thing and then you must go back to him, and every time you jump back into your ship you must wait ~10 seconds to be transported with hiperdrive. Gets a bit annoying at the end when you try to do everything left.

author: Rednegade

It takes the tried and true formula of old, updates it with better mechanics and gets some good laughs in along the way. Worth every penny.

review: The game looks, sounds and feels great. While the levels may be short and it's bloated by a lot of uneccessary characters it's very enjoyable and what we've been waiting for for a long time.Unfortunately made by greedy devs.Bought the deluxe edition with the promise of all DLC but more packs released for an extra £20 that Deluxe Edition owners do not receive.Shame.

author: Your C Drive
review: I actually do really like this game but I would recommend just waiting for some of these issues to be resolved before buying it, hence the reason I have the review set as negative. TT Games isn't really known for updating their games.Solid and very fun but definitely has some issues that no doubt must be resolved:1. Random performance issues. I noticed this a couple times but from what I played so far, it is especially significant in the Droid Factory level, where my average fps was just above 10. Yeah, 10. In most gameplay I get above 60 and sometimes fps can range up to 140, so the frame dips to 30 in certain moments and as low as 10 in others must be fixed.2. Some levels are quite buggy. Specifically on the Zam Wessell chase, my bolts would sometimes shoot randomly backwards into the air and worse, sometimes actually get stuck on and damage my own speeder.3. The hit-box on some characters don't match the model and blaster hit consistency is low in general. I think the hit-boxes are tiny or something, but the only work around is homing shots. But, you can't configure the homing shot sensitivity or have separate toggles for when you are or are not flying a ship. So you can either choose to never hit anything or to lose the skill ceiling of aiming unless you micromanage the option.4. There are options for most things that need options, but many of these options only have a single adjustable variable, meaning you can't customize options with specific variables in mind. I'm poorly wording this but essentially, you can't set certain setting specific to whether you're flying, aiming, using a mouse vs controller, etc. The options are all locked to either player 1 or player 2 and the player will again just have to micromanage the settings if they want them to be different based on how they're playing or what they're doing.5. there's no option to switch which side of the screen players use in co-op, which can be frustrating, no explanation needed.6. Sometimes the menus are fiddly. Specifically the character selection menu is really annoying and slow to navigate because you can't scroll quickly like in old Lego games and the menu resets every time you open it, meaning you have to spam the scroll button a LOT to test out new characters. You can actually select from your current character but that only works from within their character class. In general, the character selection menu is inefficient and clumsy.7. Camera is sometimes very claustrophobic and, importantly, can sometimes work against you by zooming in randomly and stuff.8. Sometimes your crosshair and the target you're attacking can get muddied behind the mess of effects and HUD. It can make combat and pursuit levels frustrating.There are also a few personal tidbits I want changed:1. Add custom characters. It takes development time, I know, but before this was confirmed to have been removed as a feature before release, I was quite excited to see a new character customizer even more complex and in depth than the ones in the most recent games. And it's just not here.2. There are so many fun mechanics in this game but most of the time they're slow, removed despite appearing in old games, or practically never used. Remember building? Yeah, in the game based off of a construction toy? I think I've used it maybe 3, 4 times in total in finishing two episodes. R2 and 3PO panels use a minigame that it time consuming and boring. The old games made the right call to have them automatic. Frankly, they could be even quicker than in Complete Saga. Short characters' vents are removed entirely. Just a lot of the fun and unique abilities of certain characters feel underutilised in the story missions.3. The fact that 2 of the 3 main combo attack buttons are also used to jumping and using a special ability makes melee combat feel inconsistent and bizarre, because unless you have already initiated it with a standard attack, you'll just jump or use a special ability instead. Or, if you want to jump or use a special ability while in an engaged state, you end up attacking an opponent instead. Awkward and clumsy.It might seem like I'm giving this game a tough run, but because it has years of Lego games to look at as a guideline. Yes, I expect and prefer new and improved content over previous games. But it is sad to see a huge reduction and removal of some fan-favourite features in old games, like character/class-unique abilities that do have their utility but are underutilised in the story, or the cancellation of a character customizer. Sad and I hope the game improves. I'm glad it's really fun and at least the content is complete, but there are definitely issues that plague the game which would be a huge deal in a less casual game.

author: cittaMattic

author: Nicko

author: The Bagus Man
review: This game is about as far away as you can get from the traditional lego formula. Not to say that straying away from established formulas is a bad thing, but when you replace it with the ubisoft collectathon model, complete with terribly slow walk-and-talk segments, then you've got an absolute bore of a game on your hands. I had been eagerly awaiting this game as The Complete Saga was fantastic, if a bit basic at times, but it was a good start and we saw that formula improved on in games like Lego Batman 1. In the years since it seems that TT's design model has totally regressed, with walking and talking segments outweighing the classic puzzle styled levels by a wide margin. Levels (from what I played before giving up, that being episodes 1,2, and the first half of 3.) also seem considerably shorter, to the point where I was beating levels before I even realized I was in one. This is an incredibly lazy game, do not waste your time on it if you don't want a completely generic experience indicative of the homogeneous game design models of the past ten years.

author: Azrieel
review: My honest opinion about this game: Absolute DisapointmentI preorded this game on my switch and also pc and as I was playing i was left with disapointment.Here are a few reasons:Nr1: Although there is a high amount of characters you can play, none of them really feel unique. For example every sith and jedi can do the exact same which is using the force by lifting up objects, throwing light sabers, influencing the weak minded. Not even palpatine can throw lightnings nor can snoke or doku. Nr2: Duel of Mustafa. I mean wtf. If you have played the complete saga in coop you actually get to play as obi wan kenobi and anikan and fight against each other. In skywalker saga however you get to play as obi wan and the other coop partner has to play r2d2 or c3po and watch the fight from aboveNr3: Although there are 5 levels per movie they are ridicously short and between those levels you have some half-hearted follow missions where you just follow a character inside the open world and sometimes have to protect them. This mechanic feels like its stretching the total story time.

author: Legionary Leader
review: At the time of writing I haven't reviewed much at all, but I thought it to be extremely important to make it clear to anyone looking to buy this game that they should not. So here is your TL:DR:This game is an utter disappointment not only as a video game, but also as a Lego Star Wars game.It has horrible optimization. The multiplayer is Co-Op LAN only (We're in 2022 folks). The level design is abysmal.The game is practically only cutscenes which are very short. There's so much on the HUD and so many menus and options for a game that it's distracting and just too much for what should be a simple Lego game.The entire game is as follows: Walk, kill 3 enemies, next level, super fast cutscene, repeat.In a slightly more detailed version:In an loose fashion, I'll talk about some of my problems with the game that specifically don't have to do with the actual gameplay but more about the devs choices such as much options, game options, bugs, and optimization.Me and my friend were looking forward to this game for years. It was clearly announced far too early, as we both agree it doesn't seem like a completed game. I thought after Cyperpunk happened, devs would be a little more careful.To start with a minor annoyance that I had personally experienced, I just thought I'd add to the list.The game obviously by default was fullscreen. When changing to Windowed Borderless and re-launching the game, it does not put the game over the windows task bar. Alt-Tabbing out and back in doesn't get rid of it, neither does doing Alt+Enter.I had to manually go into the options to re-enable full screen, and then back to windowed borderless.Upon learning that this game does not have online Co-Op in 2022 we shrugged out shoulders and said "Alright, let's do Remote Play". A great solution steam has built in, it doesn't always work the best but it does work, thanks Steam.I have 1.7 hours according to steam at the time of writing, approximately 1 hour was spent trying to figure out the Multiplayer and fixing it to work. If you want to play via Remote play with your friend, you have to use 2 controllers. As a keyboard user this was an issue for me, however I dug an old xbox controller out and got it to work just fine. If you only use keyboard, and your friend uses controller, then you're going to have to settle with being player 2 as the game does not recognize any other way of configuring between players. It prioritizes the Controller user as player 1.This issue is just silly, but it gets worse. On a 27" screen, after succeeding with 2 Controllers to enable Steam Remote Play, my friend joined the game and it activated our vertical split screen in which it was extremely hard to see the entire time. We had to just deal with it as there are zero options to change to horizontal split screen in the options. When compared to the old Lego Star Wars, where the camera would combine upon being close to your other user, this is a major downgrade. Sum up: You're forced to use vertical splitscreen, no there is no other option.Also quite a silly issue. Both I was willing to deal with if the game was a good time, as it wasn't THAT bad.Like I said, we've been anticipating this for years, I wasn't gonna quit because of some some splitscreen getting in the way.Also on my system I currently run a 1080ti for my graphics card. I played through the entirety of Elden Ring with ease and no issue. For a Lego game, the frame drops I had were upsetting to say the least, and I've read that many other people are having trouble with this as well, so be careful if you don't have a $3000 GPU in your PC.This brings me to the actual gameplay. Most importantly!The game is just  fun.The old game was so well thought out, every level felt full, and was drawn out the correct amount of time, maybe even a little long.This game is the complete opposite. We started with Episode 1, so on the trade federation ship. We blew through the halls of the ship with minimal enemies to find ourselves in a cutscene that leads to Naboo below within the first 3 minutes of playing. We got up to and finished the entire Pod Race within the next 15 minutes.The game is nothing more than a million HUD icons in your face telling you where to go or who to talk to, with a million menus for things like planets, upgrades, characters, etc. You walk 10 steps, kill 2-3 small groups of enemies, activate next level, rinse repeat.The fact that a game in today's age can be so poorly designed and uninspired is baffling to me. Nobody wants to pay 50-60 dollars to have a conversation, walk 2 feet, kill 3 enemies, and then start the next level. This $50 price tag ($60 if you want a few extra characters) is an atrocious insult to those who spent their hard earned money on games. Especially in a time where for the exact same price you can get Elden Ring, one of the most well crafted games in a very VERY long time, this game is an insult to the old game and gamers alike.Now I don't wanna go blaming the developers immediately, because we can't know what happened. But I personally suspect Disney personally ordered this game to push their trilogy once more in a new way.If you have played the old Lego Star Wars, please heed my warning and avoid this game.If you have not played a Lego game before and this seems exciting to you regardless of this review, please try it and you should see what I'm talking about.To those of you who enjoy, I'm very happy for you, however I cannot ever under any circumstances recommend a terribly optimized walking simulator that advertises itself as the remade Lego Star Wars in which costs 60 bucks.Thank you for reading, have a good day.

author: JonnyC0G
review: As a veteran player of almost every single LEGO game in the past, I must say that I am absolutely not satisfied. Why is that?Pros:Graphics: The new engine looks very nice, even a little better than in TFA. I'd love to see more LEGO games in that qualityHumor: Let's be honest, that is the most important part of the LEGO games, and they absolutely nail it. The cutscenes are gold, and there are tons of easter eggs you can spot.Cons:Open World instead of Levels: You're walking longer from one mission to another, than the actual mission has length, sometimes a level (which was ~20min in every other game) is only 4mins long and the only element is to outrun a giant fish.Performance: I've had so many crashes I stopped counting. I remembered LEGO Games as a stable gaming experience, but even that seems to have faded away.Overall Content: Since there are already games for the Prequels, Originals and TFA (and The Clone Wars as well), you could think that the game just needs to rework some levels and fill the rest of the sequels. But instead of building on top of the great existing levels, the devs decided to throw it all away and start from scratch. I can understand why such a decision is made, but I cannot understand how underwhelming the result of that process ist. This feels more like a teaser for a real Skywalker Saga game, which probably doesn't exist.No online Multiplayer: Do I even have to say more to that? It's 2022 folks. (and yes I know such things as parsec exist, but thats no excuse for not including such a feature in the game)So overall:This is an okay game. It's far from bad, but also far from the greatness of previous LEGO games.If this is your first step into exploring LEGO games, go ahead and you will have a great time.If you have played many LEGO games before and loved them, I suggest you skip this failure.

author: Gruebber
review: I will preface this that I have played this entirely co-op and that we have only played episodes 1-5 so far, I will update as we play more episodes.I'm going to be honest. I've been rather disappointed by this game. All the improvements have been wasted. Not to stay there hasn't been some good moments or jokes, but its hard to enjoy the good when faced with the bad.The new combat system is great, but the enemies don't complement it. The bosses don't even work with combos. The dog fighting doesn't control well. Co-op isn't all that great which is a crime for a Lego game. Some races hide the next objective out of view if in split screen, but are in view if playing solo. Some races are impossible co-op. Some stages just have player 1 or 2 doing nothing for awhile while the other has their fun.It feels like the game is rushing you through the story, and stages are so short. Some are done in what feels less than a couple minutes. The forced replay minikits are still rampant as well.I will say the hub maps are fun to explore, maybe even the best part. They are amazing to explore and hunt down the collectibles, but feel barren enemy wise. You may encounter a couple of enemies like droids, but that's rare. NPC's usually run instead of fight so there is no Cantina bar fights. Now I understand that constant enemies would be annoying, but a designated area or two on some hubs would of been nice.The upgrade system is nice and puts the bricks you collect into good use, but some are annoying, some overpowered, some useless. It is good that you can disable them at will. A lot of the extras/cheats/"redbricks" are mostly annoying, but some are rather fun.I want to love this game. I really do. This game has so much potential, but it feels squandered heavily. I would only recommend this game on sale.Edit: I will review the episodes that we played through.Prequel Trilogy:Episode 1:  The best of the prequel trilogy. had some good jokes and the levels were fun. All except the Gungan vs Droid battle. It was extremely short and not fun.Episode 2: Not as good as 1, but still fun.Episode 3: Sadly disappointing. A lot of the jokes don't land well, but that's a personal taste. The fight against Anakin on Mustafar was not good. Original Trilogy:Episode 4: Starts out great, then drops in quality. The trench run was extremely short with very little dog fighting.Episode 5: Best movie in my opinion, worse movie in this game.  Then the Hoth battle was disappointing. To be honest, it was better in the original game. There was no Dagobah mission, just a hub map. Cloud City felt cut in half.Episode 6: Easily the best in my opinion so far. I thought the jokes here mostly hit and made us laugh. Sadly no level to blow up the Death Star II. Sequel Trilogy:Episode 7: Mixed bag. Some parts are fun, others are not. While the Death Star and Death Star 2 did not have any dog-fighting, and DS1 had a small trench run, Star Killer Base surprisingly had a dog-fighting section and (still kinda small) trench run section. Why not also for the Death Stars? End of the day, its ok.Episode 8: It's ok. Not good, but not bad. It's just kinda there.  The last stage was quick to finish with not much going on. Not much more to say.Episode 9: Its better than the last two I guess. Its still ok. Sad that we don't participate in the fleet battle on Exegol. While there was not a mission to blow up the Death Star 2, there was a mission here that felt like it, which in turn only makes me want a mission to blow up the DS even more.  I feel like all of the Episodes would of been better with one more mission as they all felt more like a summary of the movie rather than the movie itself, even at times missing a key scene.Edit 2 : Now that I and my co-op buddy have finished all Episodes, my feeling on this hasn't changed much. Its still disappointing. I still only would recommend this on a sale maybe 50% off or more. Even if you get it on sale though, its still gonna be disappointing as its missing key moments of the saga that no sale will fix.

review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

author: XiroxisTheBeard
review: I'm a big fan of the LEGO game genre, with a few of them being in the super narrow list of "Games I've 100%'d." I'm also a fan of (most of) the Star Wars series, playing past games like LEGO The Force Awakens and the original Star Wars LEGO games, so it seemed right to hop into this one. That being said, something just didn't feel right about it.I started with Episode I and it felt rushed. Key moments of dialogue/story were removed or, honestly what may be worse, changed. I've experienced LEGO games doing this in the past, but it didn't feel as egregious as this one. Rushing along the story and prioritizing the collection of items rather than the enjoyment of the story and world around me didn't sit well. The HUD was entirely too crowded and busy, including the menu screen for upgrades and such. The pacing in LEGO LotR or The Force Awakens felt much better, where collecting was the secondary objective to enjoying the story play out. LEGO Marvel (the first one) and LotR nailed the idea of an open world with things to do while having a cool, silly and engaging story. In the Episode I track, I felt overwhelmed by the amount that I could do in the Hub locations without being able to do much with them (because of Free Play lock, which is normal for these games), while at the same time I was underwhelmed by the Story missions' substance. Trying to fit NINE movies into one game is quite a task, and it may just be too much content crammed into one space. I'd much prefer Quality over Quantity.Bug-wise, the cut-scenes were a bit jumpy and climbing up ladders was a nightmare.As a positive, the game looks gorgeous, from the locations, to the player models having dirt on them. Wonderful work on that front.Overall, I love LEGO, LEGO games, and Star Wars, but this iteration doesn't grab me. It feels off, less engaging and, unfortunately, not very fun.

author: Magic_0ne
review: So remember how FNAF security breach was just fetch quest like "go here! Now go here! Now come back! Now do that again but this time in a different order!" For me that wasn't fun at all. I didn't play it but man it looked tedious...especially with all the bugs.This game is basically that but it doesn't have the bugs so it's slightly more bearable. This game is NOT lego star wars. It's a different game with a lego star wars skin slapped on it. The levels themselves are severely lacking, very few mechanics, boss fight mechanics are reused over and over again. And the game makes you go from open to open world to open world in between levels to waste your time so you don't realize just how short the levels are. For example the very first level you're on a space ship and...oh you just hover over the trade ship and press a button...why is this here? Anyways after that you're in the meeting room just like the old lego star wars...oh wait that's a open world/hub world...ok now the level started and you're in jar jar's home...oh wait that's another open world...ok now you have to go to the chief and tal- WAIT WAIT HOLD UP FOLLOW JAR JAR while he moves ever so slowly to the chief THEN YOU CAN TALK TO HIM! Then you have to walk to the ship on the opposite site of the hub world on the lowest level. THEN the first level finally starts...and all you do is press 2 buttons while a giant fish chases you. One to shoot and one to dodge...that's it. literally a 5m level and you had to spend like 20 navigating the stupid ass hub worlds. What the actual ♥♥♥♥? This gameplay persist throughout most of the game...1) Open world is not fun and it's dryOk that's fine because the open world areas are fun right? No...not really. It's basically just an open world with collectibles and NPCs you can SOMETIMES talk to if you have the right characters that can understand the language because that's a mechanic...cool. They do have enemies but once you defeat enemies in the open world zone they NEVER EVER respawn unless you create a new save file. YEAH!! If you want an open world Lego game there's other options that do it better.2) Player 2 experience is awfulAlso do NOT play this with a 2nd player...the fight with Anakin is literally just player 1 most of the time and will occasionally switch to player 2 as R2D2 so they can press a button to activate a panel...THATS IT! Player 2 is highly disregarded a LOT and that kind of thing happens many times.3) Controller support issuesThat's once you're playing the game that is. First this game lies about "full controller support" as it doesn't support the PS controller and while it does work it gives the Xbox prompts which is mildly annoying. I had to use a 3rd party software to get it to give me PlayStation prompts. However then the share/select button that closes the holo menu didn't work so I'd have to press circle 3-4 times to close out of it...so I fiddled with the software for like 2+ hours and couldn't figure it out because the button worked outside of the game but in game refused to recognize the button press. Ok...whatever R3 isn't being used...here it is "open holo menu" let me just rebind that...surely it will rebind it for closing it too right? right!?4) Horrible button remapping with very little options...you can probably guess...it didn't. Because whoever was in charge of button remapping let me just say...they are either really stupid or they rushed that crap together in a single day. So I couldn't rebind it and also most of the button remapping option just rebind the button for like 10+ different actions instead of just one...like HUH!?! THIS GAME IS 50 BUCKS AND YOU- naaah. I had to deal with so many controller issues on a 50 dollar game that has "Full controller support" and once I played the game I literally got through episode I in less than an hour with only 10m being ACTUAL levels and the rest was just going from point A to B in the open world. Which lacked any action or anything interesting.Like I said before this is some other game using the Lego Star Wars brand as a skin. If you want nostalgia sure it works but gameplay wise it's not the same and when you beat an episode rather than feeling satisfied you are left feeling empty like "That's it?" and concerned that you'll be done and tired of this game really quick.TLDR: Player 2 experience sucks, game lacks content and is dry, does NOT actually have full controller support. I'd honestly just buy force awakens or complete saga over this game.Now that I've critiqued the game I will say this is by far the BEST looking Lego game to date as they switched to a new engine and the graphics are simply stunning. The art team did an outstanding job I will give them that so honestly that's about the sole thing that carries the open world...while it's boring gameplay wise, it is beautiful to take in.

author: ipodplayer777
review: So far:+ The graphics look great. + I actually like the mouse controls, I love being able to use my mouse to look around in a lego game. + Combat is fun, if not a little easy. + I like the upgrades. HOWEVER- The game feels scatterbrained. The cutscenes are longer than the gameplay. Blowing up the trade federation ship took all of a minute. There's too many hubs, the traveling system is very confusing at first. There's no prompts on how to unlock any of the characters. - It doesn't run well on my 3070ti. It's thermal throttling everytime there's more than 5 enemies. Very surprised. - The Remote-Play is terrible. I've been playing it with a friend and even though I'm using Keyboard and Mouse, he's always player 1 with a controller. The controls for it are glitchy. There's no Anakin vs Obi-Wan PvP Duel, player 2 simply spectates as C3PO. I would've much preferred an online co-op, I mean it's been 15 years. I'll keep updating this as I play more. It's ambitious, that's for sure. So far, a 6/10.
