author: Diomedes
review: This comes from a big LEGO Star Wars fan who spends well over a thousand Euro annually on new models as well as a lifelong gamer.  I 100% the original games and I am more likely to dust off my complete saga for PS3 than play Skywalker Saga again any time soon. This game is not fun. In short, it feels like another product which seeks to exploit the nostalgia associated with a once successful brand. It became too much of a pattern by now, especially with Star Wars franchise. Technologically it's very rough around the edges, runs on a spaghetti code and is visually uncomfortable to the eyes (subjective).  3D models are gorgeous but overall impression is ruined by the overuse of awful graphic effects and art direction badly merging photorealism with LEGO bricks. Camera position and resulting field of vision isn't nice either.  The game is a definition of bloatware. From the beginning there are too many pointless and useless collectibles and nasty UI elements thrown in my face over substantial gameplay. The latter is extremely repetitive and trivial. It just feels worse and far less appealing compared to the originals. Missions are EXTREMELY short with more cut scenes than gameplay. You are expected to fly through them and then waste time on bloatware-style free roam. Being based on what essentially is a toy and being rated E is no excuse for lack of any challenge and difficulty options.  We all know that adults and young adults are the target audience of this game. Shallow variety added to combat is pointless as you can just go through the combat by spamming a single button in whatever manner you like. There is no satisfaction whatsoever. Story is told in an extremely condensed manner and lacks cohesion. In this case devs just used dialogue as an excuse not to show and just tell instead and it had a detrimental effect. Previous games just did it better despite not using a single line of dialogue. Humorous elements are poor and feel forced. Voice acting and actor choices can get very questionable at times.  I Can't recommend it for the price they ask. I'd actually recommend doing something more productive with your time than playing Skywalker Saga. This is a soulless husk made by the next generation of hacks who fundamentally do not understand the franchises they are working with and it became a common problem across all media. Due to refund time window I had limited opportunity to see more but I wouldn't be surprised if there were instances of blatant political virtue signalling of the modern age in a LEGO game; I just get that impression from the state of this product. Just another soulless corporate product for mass consumption before getting excited for the next product. You do you if you like it. I don't. And I love both LEGO and Star Wars but it's just becoming too much. I don't even come with any expectations when it comes to Star Wars stuff any more, hoping to get positively surprised but I am getting disappointed almost every time.

author: DevilSham
review: - gameplay (like this) is fun and youll only find it in a lego game- a lot of mistakes canon/story wise which might upset "hardcore" fans- only encountered a few minor bugs  (e.g. fish phasing trough walls in otoh gunga)- combat looks fancy but its basically just spamming q and e, its not difficult at all - upgrades for classes are very boring = no new abilities, just improving the ones you already have (i would have enjoyed having sith lightning as an upgrade)- space combat/controls are janky and often the targeting systems didnt work until i switched the ship/character (even though i was not on the same team as the enemies)- side quests are the most boring ive ever seen, its just go here and deliver something or find this person and tell him that- my blaster bolts often hit a wall even though i wasnt aiming at it - game is filled with parkour puzzles which gets frustrating because parkour is awful in this game and you often fall of of platforms and other objects- interiors were very dissapointing (jedi temple only had 1 hall and 2 rooms, and the entrance to interiors is always a yellow glow which you need to step in so it teleports you inside. Other examples are the senate which only has the office of the supreme chancellor)- i havent been able to get capital ships to spawn (in free roam to unlock them) which is frustrating- ships are all practically the same (they all have the same max speed)- for some reason they took the thrusters off the astromechs- game is overfilled with npcs (for example at the lars homestead there are roaming idk how many people which makes no sense)- its filled with bad jokes that are often not funny and only a child would laugh at or jokes that only diehard fans that know everything about star wars would understand (i know this is a kids game but im sure that the majority of players is over the age of 14)- objective markers are confusing (points at one thing but youre supposed to do something at a different place)- i was dissapointed that places like varykino were left out of the game- only 5 missions per episode- kylo ren is even worse in this game than in the movies :/- a lot of the missions i was just waiting for it to end because it was just so boring (especially in the sequels)- you cant fly anywhere on coruscant (you need to take a taxi which has like 5 locations to which you can go to)overalli had fun with the game even though it has its flaws, i hope they add some clone wars stuff which everybody has been asking for  (just imagine if they take the stuff out of the comics or books that not everyone has seen on the tv show and has played in the previous clone wars games already).If you want to buy it, i would wait for a sale or get it on a key website for a cheaper price. I got the dlcs but they just give you characters so theyre not rly worth it. Im at 28 hours and i still need to complete the last episode of the sequels, so if you take your time and free roam a lot like i then this game can last you some time.I dont hate the game, Its just pretty dissapointing after getting my hopes up after seeing the trailers and teasers about it

author: Acerg
review: It's fun and improves upon the older Lego Star Wars games but it doesn't make them obsolete. The "hub world" is gone and now you have multiple roaming areas you can travel to as you progress through the story. The new perspective being over the shoulder makes it easier to aim with blaster characters but it can be too zoomed in at times and when riding animals it is too close to the screen. The fighting mechanics have expanded, however, along with the addition of skill trees.If you play on borderless window mode then the next time you boot the game up it will not be cropped right and your taskbar will overlap with the game, so you need to reset the settings. If you play on full screen then alt tabbing back and forth can cause the game to enter weird resolution settings. No true online coop mode is unfortunate, but you can still coop with share-play but the screen real estate gets tight. Visuals are nice, but there are very few settings for adjusting the graphics in game. Music has the usual classics from the franchise and the story is told in a slightly different way with unique jokes and writing. Overall, the massive content available justifies the price.

author: Devil Birdy
review: As a massive fan of the original lego star wars games, as well as the complete saga, this is everything I could've hoped for. This game is very feature rich, and the sense of humour is charming and silly as always. The time I've spent with this game so far has been extremely satisfying in terms of the gameplay, the way the episodes play out and the free roam aspect of the game, allowing you to essentially do free play at any point. However it is a much better experience to play through the story and then start unlocking the bonuses, as you'll be more than equipped to max out certain upgrades and continue having a killer time getting all the collectables. It's just overall a very fun, addicting time and I am definitely getting my lego star wars fill with this.

author: MrBoZiffer
review: What the hell is this? The first level is like 60% just an over the shoulder third person shooter. What happened to Lego games? It used to be just shoot in whatever direction you're facing and now it looks like a Roblox mod. If there was a way to turn off the gunplay in this then the game might actually be good. In previous Lego Star Wars games you would have to avoid gunfire or find a way to block it, and now you just run around Gears of War style shooting everyone? Absolutely heartbreaking seeing Lego games become just another clone.Edit: 4/21/2022 I played a little more to give it a second chance and jesus christ the performance is absolutely awful. I have a 3070 and 32GB of RAM and I'm getting 34fps when I hit things IN A CRAMPED HALLWAY. Not even rendering an outside world. Seriously?

author: Bhzzz-
review: By the time i am writing this review, i have already completed the first episode and oh boy, got a lot already to talk about.I played the original LEGO star wars back in the playstation portable and also on PC, and i remember it used to take me more than 20 hours to complete a game that only had 6 episodes and not the 9, and by the time i m writing this, i already now it will be a short game, and you're probably asking me why. (i bet the biggest level was about 7-8 mins, they're all short). Well, this is a full remake of the original LEGO game, all missions have been remade, and most of them were cut, some missions like the rescue of amidala, or even other missions are completly gone, replaced by cutscenes and just walking from point a to point b, which is extremely sad, especially for such a star wars fan like me.All is not bad, from the cut missions from the new voice acting (yes, not the original act). The gameplay has completly been changed, now you can do a lot of new stuff that enchances the experience in a whole new diferent way, it feels like a LEGO game inside a action movie and i love that part. That being said you can now:-> throw your lightsaber-> throw objects against enemies-> use special attacks-> dodge attacks-> counter-bulletsAlso there is a new sandbox style of world which feels ok, since most areas have beautiful visuals, but side quests still feel very meh and barely any sense in them. Anyways, you can also fly ships across the galaxy, thing that feels OK, because just OK... Because, well, you can only travel extremely short distances, ship battles are extremely fun though.I bought this game to play with my wife, we had a lot of fun, but sadly, like i previously said, all levels feel short.Also, split camera is worse than ever. Usually, there was just 1 screen when players were close to each other, now, no matter what distance you are from your partner, there is always 2 cameras, which is hard for exploration and in some combat situations, over the shoulder camera tho is fantastic, since you can now shoot rifles like a true shooter.All in all, it is a great star wars game, but compared to some other LEGO games, especially the original one, it feels short, in 2022 i was expecting a longer game with a lot of dedication, and i paid for a game that was cut in a half, feels like they wanted to rush for a faster release. I dont care of cutscenes replacing missions, i want a full game. I still recommend this game, but for an extremely low price. A tenner, nothing more, nothing less.unplayable, enemy is a bullet sponge, flies through buildings, lost half health after 15 minutes.SOLUTION: turning auto aim on, takes exactly the same damage in less than a minute.At some point in this mission there is some sort of optimization bug, i went from 150 fps to a low 15 for about 3 constant minutes without ever going back to normal.May the force be with you! [small edit]: what is impressive about this lego title is that they built every single scene from scratch, wide open detailed areas, and i appreciate that, but all of them are not used as they should as every mission is short and takes very little time to complete. Other thing that i also appreciate is the ship battles, most are epic and take place in wide space places, but falls short as most become repetitive and you're not as free to fly as other star wars games and other lego games. I hate that they turn it into an rpg open world, because most side quests are take this, deliver to this place and thats it, so much missed potential. LEGO star wars complete saga is the best lego game ever and the best lego star wars game still, this one is not a bad game, but not as good, not even close, id rather have a linear star wars game with long missions rather than explore skywalker saga. even though it builds a fantastic star wars universe.

author: Nova Hazing
review: A Disappointing GameI was originally excited for this game. All the Media and Trailers for the game seemed fine and great looking. The Game looks great as well. The combat aspects of the game are also a nice change of pace and much easier gun combat. Buy Easier does not mean better, the gun combat within the Skywalker Saga gets boring after a few encounters and so do the Duels. Is repetitive with no variation. Same with the Puzzles within the game most of the Lego Charm outside of cut sense has gone. For an Example in the Cloud city level where your escaping, has a whopping 2 puzzles within it, with one of them Grappling something and shooting then the next is killing an enemy to drop a key-card. You don't even need to kill one enemy after getting the key-card to complete the level you can run though the entire thing and the last part just wait for Chewie to fix the falcon. And dont even get me started on Character Variation, cus let me tell you there is none.In conclusion I would say is a mind numbing game with the Lego Charm Removed. I would just recommend skipping this one and buy an older lego game.

author: Chief
review: If you are a fan of the prequel trilogy, do not buy this game. The levels for the prequels are short, misused and have rushed cutscenes. Additionally, the developers decided to miss crucial moments in some of the films, such as the Battle of Geonosis in Episode II (every moment builds up to that battle), which I think is due to the developers not wanting to depict war and death in a LEGO game. I found that decision to be particularly disappointing because I adore the Clone War era (pivotal moment that started it was left out), and the front cover literally depicts the Battle of Geonosis.As for the combat, it feels very satisfying, whether you are using a lightsaber or blaster. The only problem is that it is heavily underused, since levels primarily require you to do repetitive side quests and hilariously easy puzzles. These problems were absent in the Complete Saga, which also had more complicated puzzles that I was able to do as a child.Overall, this game is really not for the prequel fans, as the levels are poorly designed and focus on the worst moments of the films. Hopefully, the upcoming news for this game will be TT addressing this issue, where they add more levels for the specified era.

author: Salamanteri
review: After obtaining all the achievements and finishing the game 100%, I would give this game a score of 7/10.This game isn't perfect, it's a LEGO game after all. The game does a lot of things right but some things wrong.My biggest issue with this game is the story. The levels are short and shallow. They do not have the same depth as the levels in The Complete Saga had and I get it, a lot of effort was put into the open world side of the game. I love the open world and it's something I have waited for a long time in a Star Wars game. However, open world shouldn't take away from the story. There are people who only play LEGO games for their story levels. If that's all you want to do in this game, I would not recommend you buying this for the full price. While a revision of the series shouldn't copy everything from the original, I feel like the levels don't pay respect to the ones in the older game.If you are someone who just wants a LEGO game experience and loves Star Wars, this game is still a no-brainer! The over world for the most part is incredibly fun. You will explore places you never expected to play in a LEGO Star Wars game or maybe any Star Wars game. The game has a lot of characters and ships to choose from and the best part, .

author: Ravnsburgr
review: I think this is a great lego game. 9/10 one of my favorite lego games and just favorite games in generalI really like the look of the game it has very nice quality, there are even small details when you visit certain planets that your characters will have visible dust or snow around some parts of their body to show that they could be dirty if you were to place them yourself in that place.One thing that sort shocked me when going in partially blind into the game was how much they had done with the combat. For anyone who knows how the combat is in every other lego game you have usually 4 or so hearts and each kick, punch, bullet and so on takes 1 heart. Here it's very different, having different health bars instead of individual hearts, you can choose to have health regen or having to pick up hearts to get hearts back, there are different classes essentially that has different weapons and abilities, move sets just all of it is just so different and i honestly like it a lot.There are tons of small details that make this game just so much greater than it already is, I can't remember all of the ones i found but again i remember seeing them and thinking it's great of them to add in such small stuff for those who know either if it was Star Wars or Lego related. Like different soldiers have helmets covering them and you can pop them off, if it's a clone they're all the same but if they're stormtroopers for example they look different with many different faces and hair. Of course The Star Wars story is great and cause first of all it is in a lego style it cuts down to more bit sized and also adds lots of comedic stuff into it, I feel as though cutting it down to make a 9 movie story play out. I can understand that it is necessary to leave out some stuff to make it not take too long to get through the story, but also in some places it left out crucial stuff that then made some missions not seem like they had as much impact or meaning. One thing I thought was kind of sad but can understand is that many of the voices I associate with certain characters weren't there, don't get me wrong the voice acting in this game is fantastic. Just wish for such a big game that they would have original voices for some of the characters even tho as the game progressed i didn't mind all that much.I know many might see this game as a kids game but still a lot of refrences and such that are more pointed towards adults, so leaving in some more serious points wouldn't be all that bad when it comes to actually showing the story of Star Wars in this more easy fun style!I really like the way they had you be able to fly to many different planets to both explore and do more missions and such in, there are tons of stuff to do, that can stretch from just fetching items to multiple missions with same quest giver or something that tells a longer tale, that in turn spruces up the world more.Any game no matter how much you tweak and fix it is always gonna have bugs and glitches, I can't say i have encountered many, of course all lego games have a bit of jank to them so that's to be expected. I had one bug where all character models were just gone except hair/head and weapon, of course it was a fun one to begin with seeing main menu with half weapons and such but not really many characters, this was kind of game breaking as i couldn't do certain actions but had to turn off and on it again to fix.Second big issue i had which ALWAYS occured in every gaming session was suddenly the screens would flicker a bit, and i would notice my night light which i like to have on was off, if i was watching stream through discord it would freeze the whole discord and Nvidia overlay just didnt wanna pop up anymore so have to restart pc after playing for that to work and restard discord for that to work properly.I could go on and on about how great it is and the issues it also has, but overall i'd say again this is a great game I love lego games and I love Star Wars so I am biased there, but I really like how open it is and fun side missions and quirks to main story too, but of course sometimes so much can be bad when first starting it can be jarring to see how much there is to do if you are completionist at times like me. Love how everything just fits so good together and i do highly recomend this game to any casual gamers who wants to play a good lego game, thank you for reading and hope this helps in deciding if you want to buy the game if you even read all of it. :)

author: Mega Mando
review: You wont find a better way to enjoy the sequel trilogy!Beautiful graphics, fun combat system, upgrades, character classes, open world planets, 300 characters, 100 ships, prequel memes, recreated iconic moments, fully custom voice acting, immersive lightsaber duels, Gonk droids, somehow Palpatine returned, high ground, I hate sand, blue milk and more!Buy the game, do it!

author: Lunii
review: Great game so far! I think the best thing about it is that it's an entirely new experience as far as Lego Star Wars is concerned. You could still easily go back and play the Complete Saga, and I think that's great. There's a bigger focus in this game on open world as opposed to the mission based structure of the originals, which is a positive for me, since I enjoy running around and collecting stuff.Honestly my only gripes with the game is that it can be a bit blurry at times. I don't know if it's a depth of field thing (there's no option for it in the settings) or if it's some kind of adaptive resolution scaling to keep a solid 60 (which if it is, it's working since I've had no frame drops at all) though I've heard you can edit some text files to potentially fix this. The menu can also feel a bit clunky a times, but it's probably cause I'm not used to it yet.

author: mrcipolla
review: It just lost that "thing'. My major problems (as a mega lover of all other Lego games, no matter how old I get lmao:1. The UI. Oh boy. It is Ubisoft on steroids. The UI is bad. Really, really bad - insanely intrusive, and takes up a ton of screen space telling you useless information and controls you never need to see after the very first time. The tutorial of this game NEVER ENDS. 2. The bugs. Within my first 15minutes of playing, I got an infinite black screen transitioning from a cutscene. Restart the entire game / mission. Same thing happened a few missions later. That was my point of refund. 3. The fun. I really don't know what it is about it - it just lost that "thing". I don't know if it's the UI, or the story/mission structure, or what. I can fire up age-old entries to the series and be instantly blindly entertained. Just not here - it is too.... "modern", and this does not fit the essence of what this game was/is. 4. The story structure. I miss the old hub-areas of going into a door and loading a level instance. The missions blending into the Hub world feel awkward, like a chore, and never live up to the separate instanced-levels. Also, the tutorial never ends, so be ready to have your hand held the ENTIRE GAME - even turning hints off.5. The voices.... okay - look, its an awesome idea - but it does not fit in a lego game. Not like this. The animations telling the story was what added to the comedy. Now, you have MASSIVE, non-toggle-able CAPTIONS taking over the entire bottom half of your screen in every cut-scene. Not only this, but they commit two CARDINAL sins in 2022: Black bars, mixed with MASSIVE closed-captions, with an EVEN BIGGER background on the text. It is insanely distracting, and you'll be forcefully reading captions instead of watching the scene 99% of the time - this is how the brain works. If they update to:A.) Disable UI elements - like, literally, ALL UI elements, PERFECT.B.) Disable tutorial elements / help messages / control overlays - PERFECT.C.) Disable Closed Captions - MEGA PERFECT.It's a shame. Cause I'm sure it's a fun game and having a billion things to collect and 20+ planets to explore is literally my thing. But A, B, and C make sure I will never, ever enjoy the actual gameplay - it is too distracting, unimmersive, and guided - basically, it is a nonstop reminder that I am a young adult playing a Lego game - I'm trying to forget this lol

author: Red Paradox
review: TL;DR The best collectathon of the modern age. It can be buggy, though it makes up for it.First off, this game is so close to being a masterpiece. Lego's flavour to the star wars universe has always been amazing, and it is in this. Compared to the older ones it's reinvented the wheel, giving a lot of space to touch on the lore of star wars while keeping it light and wholesome.The change to classes was executed great while at the same time making every individual unique in that class, and as a plus if you switch to a character and there is already a character related in the lore. You get a line of dialogue.The Lego flavour to the story is at it's peak, it's been done very well, while not 100% faithful, it's easy to follow and funny at the same time.The gameplay is what you would expect, but with an added combo mechanic for combat, which really changes up how you play those with lightsabers and a few others. It's unique enough and easy enough that it doesn't feel sluggish or invasive. The puzzles are nice, but while going for completionism you see them reusing a lot of puzzle and the later it goes, the less inventive they get with their names for the puzzles, (I guess the juices run dry when you have to name 1200 puzzles). In the end it is really fun and engaging.Here is where it falls short of being a masterpiece. The bugs. While not noticeable if you just do the main story with a little side stuff, while going for 100% it gets frustrating. There have been times where it softlocks from a brick which requires a game restart or if you're lucky a zone refresh but sometimes it straight up crashes. Minor bugs are there and ai freaking out. While this could be a deal breaker for a lot, the rest of the game is magnificent and is worth your time.

author: XeLa
review: It’s fun up to the first 25-40 hours for the story, but after that to actually complete the game it is a straight up non stop grind for every character, minikit and achievement. It’s undeniably better to play this game than watch the new trilogy but that’s if you’re willing to grind the “biggest Lego game ever” for the disappointing completion reward then go ahead.I finished this whole game, 100%, after 85 hour and felt obligated to spend another ten messing around because of how much I spent. Overall, you will definitely enjoy the story mode, but will end up having to replay every mission and chapter at least once to go back and get stuff you missed for 100%. Very repetitive and boring at the end. P.S. once you replay a mission and get something you missed (minitkit, true Jedi, etc) you can just leave the mission as soon as you get it and it will save.

author: 𝕯𝖚𝖙𝖈𝖍
review: Adventure. Excitement. A Jedi craves not these things. If that’s the case, then all Jedi should probably cancel their preorders for LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga, since this dazzling new entry in Traveller’s Tales’ longrunning LEGO game series has brought both adventure and excitement by the plastic bucketload. With stunning set pieces cribbed from all nine mainline Star Wars films and a surprisingly vast number of iconic planet hubs to freely explore in between, The Skywalker Saga is a brick-breaking blockbuster executed with a goofy charm that had me feeling as happy as a droid in a hot oil bath.In a dramatic departure from the zoomed out camera perspective of previous LEGO titles, The Skywalker Saga features a tighter, over-the-shoulder third-person view typical of the likes of GTA or Uncharted, and it brings along with it far greater control over your attacks. Lightsabers can be boomeranged and crates can be Force-pushed with satisfying precision, and a simple combo system allows you to launch enemies into the air for a juggling volley of saber swings with ease. Fighting as a Jedi or Sith might not have the depth of Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, but it’s nonetheless fast, fluid, and it feels fantastic.If you’re controlling a character equipped with a blaster, you now have the option of taking cover behind walls and other objects to pick your foes off from afar, and can switch between cover positions with the tap of the button. (A similar cover-based mechanic was featured in 2016's LEGO Star Wars: The Force Awakens, but only in specific sections of a level). I love the neat touch atop this system that you’re able to quickly rebuild destroyed cover (as can enemies), but outside of a couple of specific boss fights I hardly ever felt the need to actually shelter behind anything. In The Skywalker Saga, the combination of a constantly recharging health bar and the authentic inaccuracy of each Stormtrooper’s shots meant there was rarely any risk in taking a run and gun approach. I certainly still enjoyed the gunplay in The Skywalker Saga, but more for its flashy spectacle than its shallow attempts at strategy.Not only does the new close-up perspective make you feel more engrossed in the action, it also leads to a greater appreciation of how realistically rendered each individual LEGO brick is. With the paint on minifigs chipping away convincingly after extended use as though they’re a much-loved toy. Absolutely every LEGO creation looks so uncannily true to life, that when you blast an immaculately assembled 1000-piece Tie Fighter out of the sky, you can almost hear the cries of anguish from the parents who spent their whole Sunday afternoon helping their kid build it.The mission variety was very engaging too. The 45 main story levels constantly switch things up so that the action never grows stale. The Skywalker Saga is capable of delivering mindless carnage on a massive scale, like when The Battle of Naboo briefly blossoms into a thrilling game of tower defense, and you gleefully lob balls of energy from Gungan catapults to decimate hordes of Trade Federation droids and assault tanks. Yet it can also be more focused and cerebral, such as when Rey enters the mirror cave on Temple Island, and you carefully puppeteer her reflections in order to reach exit portal switches.Of course, and The Skywalker Saga does indeed feature levels designed around high-speed podracing, X-Wing trench runs and all the major lightsaber duels you’d expect. But even at its most familiar moments, the campaign is still a blast to play because it feels so smooth and is such an eye-popping sight to behold. The only occasional catch is that its strict adherence to a cinematic style of presentation can come across as a bit too rigid at times. In one of the boss fights against Kylo Ren, for instance, I’d whittled his health bar down to zero, yet the fight arbitrarily continued for another minute, all so I could button-mash my way through the remaining quicktime events.Each story mission is connected by surprisingly sizable hub areas situated on some 20-odd different planets, from the sandswept streets of Mos Eisley on Tatooine to the polished surfaces of Coruscant's Financial District, and everywhere in between. These open areas are absolutely rife with hidden Kyber bricks to collect by solving various environmental puzzles, and while you do see some repeated challenges across the galaxy there are plenty of other fun little surprises to stumble upon along the way. I particularly enjoyed the Lemmings-inspired challenge on Kamino that tasked me with adjusting a series of platforms to prevent a hapless clone from shuffling to his doom, or arranging a choir of Wookiees on Kashyyyk to angrily yawn a rendition of John Williams’ signature score.And if you get tired of exploring and action-platforming your way across the wealth of planets, you can always just pick your favorite starship and jet up into orbit for some impromptu dogfighting. There really is a staggering amount to do in The Skywalker Saga.TL;DR: 7/10

This game is the original lego starwars game, if that game was a soul-less cash grab. I bought this game expecting it to be like it's predecessor. I was wrong.Walking in an empty sandbox listening to dialogue from the lego characters is so lame, gone are the times of actually feeling like you are in each episode of Star Wars. I feel no dialogue in the original lego game did the game very well, as you didn't need someone talking to understand what is going on. Don't get me started on the most recent Disney Star Wars lego segment in this game, just playing through it feels worse than torture. I feel that segment in this game is by far the worst one, as it just tries so hard to make you enjoy the characters to make up for how much of a mess the films were. I want to puke when I see Rey standing at the title screen each and every time, acting like as if she is the reason Star Wars was good; which is not true by a landslide. I love the prologue and the original Star Wars episodes, not the new ones. Idk how Disney just expects you to get attached to some random characters they poorly slapped into the series. I mean the lore for Disney's Star Wars is an absolute joke, it's literally just a repeat of the original trilogy with even worse characters. Overall, the game is mediocre and boring. Don't play the Disney Star Wars trilogy part of the game unless you want to be tortured, just play the first 2 trilogies if for some reason you REALLY want this mediocre game, and I recommend you get it on a steal of a deal of a price when it's on sale. Who wants to pay the full price for a mediocre experience?! If you haven't played the original for some reason though, skip this game, it's not worth your time. Go play the original Lego Starwars, it's really good.

author: Guyote
review: I do like parodies of Star Wars (like Blue Harvest, which I loved growing up). I think Lego did a good job making good parodies of each film, but I also got the impression that they were done by genuine fans of Star Wars who put a lot of heart into the game. In addition, I think the open-world gameplay and space gameplay to be very fun. I enjoy travelling the galaxy and exploring as my own little gang aboard our own ship. Very fun, and let's the imagination run wild. My only complaint: no in-game character creator. LEGO games should all have this, it should be always be included. Instead, it looks like modders are picking up the slack in that regard, thankfully. Overall, I recommend this game and look forward to exploring more of the free roam galaxy.

author: Lobbo
review: What a let down.Was hoping for good quality episodic game with missions that were detailed and followed the story well much like the other Lego Star Wars games.Unfortunately this is not that. It was fun at first, and the world design is cool but it seems like 90% of the game development time was spent creating the open universe rather than actual content. It's all fluff with story levels taking just a couple of minutes to complete but about 15 minutes to get to it. It is "Lego Star Wars Universe Travel Simulator". Some missions you travel to and then it's "travel here and watch a cut scene. It's boring and trivial even for a Lego game.The UI is clunky and not intuitive.The missions are dull, and very short.If you're new to the Lego games, go play the old Lego Starwars games, or Lego LOTR instead. Much more fun.

author: Emblem Parade
review: A fun and easy romp through the worlds of the Star Wars franchise.It can be played just for the cute and funny story, but I suspect that many players would be drawn to its expansive open-world play. The amount of puzzles, collectibles, side missions, and challenges is astounding. Sure, many of these are just filler—repetitive, menial tasks—but a surprising number is delightful and satisfying. And even the menial tasks can be enjoyed for the journey itself. It's nice to just spend time in this wacky, beautiful game world. I only really started to get tired of it when I approached 80 hours of game time.It's indeed remarkably beautiful. You would think there's not much potential in brightly colored LEGO blocks, but here they are placed in realistic terrains, and even the blocks make use of superb lighting and material effects. You really need to experience this game in HDR if you can, as the implementation is often breathtaking.It's not all gravy, though. The UI is very cumbersome. The controls and camera usually work well, but they can become frustrating in puzzles that require precision 3D platforming and/or speed. Load screens between planets are long, which is very annoying when working through the many multi-planetary side missions. It's also just ...  easy. If you understand how the in-game "money" system works, you can early on become rich enough that you don't have to think about it anymore. And combat is so trivial that it's likely you will never die. Indeed, weapon upgrades are unnecessary for survival, they'll just make encounters end sooner. Finally, the mission tracker turns most missions into brainless follow-the-blue-light experiences. That said, I did enjoy the many puzzles, which require some logical thinking and observation skills. I really wish the game focused more on puzzles than combat.But what I  wish for is a challenging, serious Star Wars open-world RPG with the scope and beauty of this game. Still, this game scratches some of that itch as it's loyal, in its own way, to the Star Wars universe and its tone. And it's also loyal to LEGO. It's very funny, very lighthearted, and very easy. If you come into it with the right attitude it can be a good time for many hours.

author: Dr Bones
review: This is not the complete saga. This is a vastly different game that plays like a mix between other modern LEGO titles but with Mario Odyssey/Scribblenauts-style open world missions. If you bring an open mind, this game can definitely hit that childlike joy. I will add that this game is incredibly easy, but you can be extra and combo enemies or use creative means to kill them such as throwing objects and mind controlling. The game is also mostly stable and finished on release, which in today's industry is refreshing. I look forward to finishing my 100% saves on both Complete Saga and Skywalker Saga.To me, deluxe is worth it. I also used a third-party to buy my key, so the price was comparable to the standard edition here.Here are my 2 complaints/suggestions: 1. There are no custom characters like in complete saga, and I really hope they add them. I unironically think this is the best game to explore the SW galaxy, and it would be even better if you could play as your avatar. I also think that LEGO of all franchises not providing custom characters is a tad ironic.2. When your sprint is upgraded, you move really fast. I love that. What I don't love as much is that if you jump while sprinting, you lose all momentum. I'm a person who spams jump while I'm walking around and I would like to just yeet myself, but alas I cannot.

review: Honest to God, I LOVE THIS GAME. If you are a huge Star Wars fan like me, this game is a must have. Although this game is missing a few characters that I hope they add in upcoming DLC, the roster is very good and characters even have their own classes now. As for custom characters not being a feature in this installment is very disappointing but there is plenty of content to make up for it. I love the new combat system it's absolutely amazing combined with the new over the shoulder camera angle. Don't get me started on the open galaxy concept. There is such a wide spread of ship it's so hard to pick one. AND THE FACT YOU CAN OWN A CAPITAL SHIP! Incredible. I only wish that there were some light side capital ships. Maybe a Venator-class Star Destroyer from the clone wars, or a rebel EF76 Nebulon-B escort frigate would be nice. Overall great game. Simply a classic.

author: Kaboochy
review: The game is a huge upgrade from Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga when it comes to content, graphics, mechanics, collectibles, and more. It's a very fun experience to play through the game because I believe it unlocks the kid in all of us. But, I do have one complaint and its the fact that the story isn't told as accurately compared to the original game and the pacing does feel a tad too fast at times. Although I dont want to get into many spoilers, I will give an example since most people that buy this game have already seen the movies: In the fight against Darth Maul, Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon take down Maul together and then Qui-Gon dies comedically to a cut in half Maul. But in Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga, it stays true to the story and Obi-Wan has to finish off Maul himself with that final jump move out of the pit and then rushes to Qui-Gons last words. I know it is very nit-picky of me to make a complaint out of something like that, but I just felt like it was worth pointing out. Nevertheless, the game is phenomenal and I highly recommend it to those who have kids/friends/family to play it with, those who want some childhood nostalgia, or just any Star Wars fan since this is going down as one of the best.

author: Kyliiz
review: My initial review of this game was very positive, however I now have to change that due to a very game breaking bug with the wandering wookieeSo I've been playing Skywalker Saga for a good 100 hours now, trying to get to 100%. I'm now at 99.5% and I have to find the wandering Wookiee 13 more times. The problem is that I have already visited the remaining positions that the mission shows me and talked to the Wookiee. But that apparently didn't count. If I now return to these positions, I can no longer find a Wookiee, because I have already found him and talked to him. So I can't complete the game and get stuck at 99.5%.Very, very sad that such a game breaking bug occurs in a 60 Euro title.

author: Raging Meerkat
review: This game is AMAZING. I have not a bad word to say about it from the fighting to the size of the maps to the puzzles and references to other games and source material this game is just flawless. Makes me think of my childhood playing The Complete Saga and I am not let down by this sat all. If relaxing LEGO games and/or Star Wars are your thing you have to play this game. Can`t wait for future DLC packs to see what we get, the attention to detail is amazing. The character interactions are so perfect when idle. Completely love what they have done with the large flagships (you`ll find out when you play) adds such a new fun layer to the game that we haven`t seen before.The fact we actually have decent sized areas of 33 different planets to free roam and break and loot is awesome, so much more to do than ever before.Just wish I could get the republic gunship, But maybe a future dlc.Absolutely 10/10 to the people at TT games they have outdone them selves with this one.(Will be updating if I find more to say)

author: d3north_vr
review: Going into this expecting the same formula as traditional TT games will leave you on the wrong foot. This is not a remaster, it is a whole new remake. Having multiple returning Clone Wars voice actors (Tom Kane, Matt Lanter, Dee Bradley Baker, James Arnold Taylor) really helps the voice acting along. The traditional pseudoslapstick of TT games is back in a less overstated way, and there are lots of little easter eggs all over to satisfy even the most eagle-eyed fan.

author: Parnic
review: I've only finished the first episode so far, but this is far and away the best LEGO game I've played! The combat is fun, third-person controls feel much better than previous games, graphical fidelity is vastly improved, and the core game loop is as fun as always.

author: Kahedi
review: I wish I could recommend this game, but I can't and that saddens me. I was very hyped about it- as I grew up with the LEGO Star Wars game, and had a great time exploring the star wars universe.At the time of my review, I just completed episode IV. And to summarize:The story gets squashed and cuts at a random paze. And they try to throw in some comedy elements. But I think the attempt at trying to tell the shove the major plot points and twists into 3 voicelines just ♥♥♥♥♥ up the pace of the game.Game mechanics:As a game developer myself, it's also sad to see some overall bad game mechanics. - UI text boxes flickers on the screen, and text can flash on screen before it should. - The camera is way too far panned in when riding animals, which makes it very awkward to move around- In general, the controls just doesn't feel good to use. Maybe I'm just sensitive to doing shooting with a controller, but it was not a smooth experience. I tried doing shooting with a keyboard, and that worked better than on the controller. But I didn't enjoy the other controls on the keyboard. In the end I just preferred doing melee attacks with a controller. And it sucks that you have to change your playstyle because the controls are bad.The whole game seems almost overengineered in a way. But also underdeveloped at the same time? It's a weird combo.I have to say I went into this experience with some hope of having a nostalgic experience. And I am. But mostly just getting the urge to playing the original LEGO Star Wars game.That said, I will continue playing the game some more. Just to satisfy my inner child. As I did pay a bunch for it. But I will continue to cringe at the screen and not the smoothest game experience. I also did have a great hope to play this LEGO game with friends, but I don't have the heart to share this experience with someone.It's a 6/10 for me.

author: Aard
review: A Lego game has no right to be this good, yet it shatters expectations and every other game TT Games has ever made. At this point in time it's left a far better impression than most other Star Wars games despite its friendly appearance. I'm also pretty sure that the devs also visited r/prequelmemes a few times with the interactions many characters have while idle and swapping.It's no secret the Travellers Tales studio and its Devs went through hell while making this game, and to all those working at TT still and those who left, if this is your legacy let it be known as your greatest treasure. There is more love and commitment in this Star Wars game than any other. Anyone who plays and explores this game will come across this love, this understanding, these devs are also fans of the same franchise, not EA bots chugging out a game to sell a P2W experience for money and short term gain. I wish all those in TT both current and past a great future, you blew my mind with the Original Trilogy game, showed your love with The Lord Of The Rings, your passion with Indiana Jones, and mastered your very own identity with this game, Thank you for all the joy you have brought to me ever since I was a kidFrom the bottom of my heart, I wish you all the best

author: Squidler
review: With a 14 hour straight session of gameplay, almost finishing the story mode in chronological order this is my take on the game. The graphics are absolutely fantastic to see, the visuals as well are awe inspiring. However, in two areas specifically I saw a significant gameplay impact on my frames even with a 3060 GPU. While its not a major grievance, it certainly impacted my enjoyment in those areas.While I haven't touched a newer lego game at all, this game was definitely not hard to learn the controls and get used to them. The negatives of this is only the occasional input oddity that occurs using keyboard and mouse controls as well as once or twice with a controller. Now the story, absolutely great. Great laughs and great pacing up until the start of the sequel trilogy. By that point in the game it feels as if there's tons of gameplay thats just meant to drag itself out over time rather than being able to pull your attention and interest to make it feel as if it takes forever when it actually does take forever.Overall, the game itself is really really fun, however there are some issues with it: none of which should really be points that turn you away from this game, the takeaway should be that this is definitely a revolutionary game that is unique to itself. You'll definitely waste hours enjoying yourself, or days grinding to 100% this game. I'd also say that it has great replayability as well as being a great game to play with that one friend who really, really shares your enthusiasm about lego star wars.

author: MANDO
review: LEGO® STAR WARS™: The Skywalker Saga is one of the best LEGO games! The story, puzzles and the environment are implemented so creative and exciting. It's one of the few Star Wars games that gives you the feeling of exploring the galaxy with your own eyes, and to top it off there's classic and redefined LEGO humor with absolutely stunning graphics. I sincerely hope that the game will continue to be supported and get great DLCs for the series like The Clone Wars and Obi-Wan Kenobi or a character editor. All in all a very well done example of a fantastic game from an equally stunning franchise!

author: MonkeyBone
review: While I enjoy the game enough it's definitly a downgrade when compared to other lego titles in my opinion. My biggest issues have mostly been covered by others but I've just completed the OT and PT trilogies and they rush through them so quickly, in Revenge of The Sith you don't even get to attack the Jedi Temple (there's also no hooded Anakin to unlock which really annoyed me as I was waiting to unlock that version of him before doing Galaxy Free-Play, not to mention they also use RoTJ Palpatine for Ep3) and there's huge chunks cut or smashed together to "save time" which really hurts the game. Honestly they should have released this in parts starting with the OT, then PT, and finally the ST for the 5 people who would have bought that lol, they could have even connected post-release like the Hitman titles do to make one huge game. Unfortuently quality doesn't mean anything these days apparently so while I do enjoy it for the most part, it's not worth getting until AT LEAST 50% off as that's how much is missing from each movie in this game.

author: Banon
review: This is a game that falls short of its predecessors in just about every area and I don't just mean the other Lego Star Wars games.The Levels. The biggest disappointment, they consist mostly of brief boss battles and vehicle sections. It's telling that minikit count has gone down from 10 to 5. Because the levels are so short that if you put 10 in, you'd be tripping over them. The travel/cutscene play that takes you to the next level often ends up being longer than the level itself. They feel like an afterthought when this is the core of the game.The Story. It tells the story very well with very nice scenes and the usual lego humor. Unfortunately due to the level problem you spend more time watching the story than playing the story. I remember watching the Battle of Coruscant scene where Anakin and Obi are flying their fighters to rescue the Chancellor and I was sitting there holding my controller waiting, expecting at any moment for the cutscene to end and drop me into gameplay and it didn't. Instead I watched a cutscene of what could have been two levels worth of gameplay and was two levels in its predecessor. I understand not wanting to rehash levels from the predecessor game but come on, its meant to be a videogame not a movie and it's telling the same story, that's a poor excuse to waste gameplay potential.Open World. Over a thousand collectables spread over several open world areas. Puzzles are pretty much standard. Compared to the open world of the LOTR and Marvel/DC lego games, they feel pretty lifeless. There may be more open world space but previous lego games did open world better.Combat. Never enough enemies. They never show up in great numbers and they generally are not very threatening. Unless you fall off a ledge you won't be hearing Yoda's amusing death sound effect. The battle of naboo plains is galling, you go in expecting a big battle, maybe like the Lego Clone wars. Instead you get 18 battle droids, that come in waves of three at a time. It's pathetic. Another problem is guns, both on foot and in space, with auto aim on it's brainless, in the options you can adjust the auto aim, if you turn it all off you enter a world of hitbox frustration. They also threw in a new cover mechanic for ranged characters but its impact is completely deflated by the ease of combat.Upgrade System. A new system, I was very impressed at first but I quickly realised it's largely pointless. The only upgrade of value is the minikit detector. The game is not terribly challenging, it's lego afterall it's not meant to be hardcore, so the upgrades end up being unnecessary and lack impact on your gameplay. Another 30% lightsaber damage! Now those battle droids that I was killing in two hits without damage upgrades will be defeated in.... two hits. See the problem? It also doesn't help that primary currency for buying upgrades is also the primary collectable, kyber bricks, which results in a situation where you'll have already completed the puzzle the upgrade would have made slightly easier so you could get enough kyber bricks to buy the upgrade.In summary, I can't recommend this game. It feels like they spent so much time on the new features they forgot to make a core gameplay experience you could use these new features in. For all the shiny new stuff, it's an underwhelming effort compared to previous Lego franchise games. If you like Star Wars, get the older Lego Star Wars games. If you want an open world Lego experience, go to the Marvel/DC/LOTR lego games.

author: PeculiarPyro
review: Alright. It's over. 100%This game was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ great.The graphics look stellar, probably like what you imagined when you played through whichever original LSW game when you were younger. The amount of detail and visual fidelity is incredible. The levels are shorter than they were in previous games, but there are forty five overall this time and they still have a second playthrough in Freeplay for minikits, so I get it. Almost every planet from the main films is accessible and has collectibles and quests with most of the characters and ships appearing.As for bugs, yeah they do exist, as of right now there are sadly some critical ones some people are having that block progression. The Gonk and Porg companions for some reason were crashing my game so keep that in mind if you purchase.If you enjoy any Lego Star Wars games, or any Lego games, or even just Star Wars games you need to get this game. The DLC is just character packs with characters outside of the main nine films; no planets, levels, or ships are likely to be released.and rebel friend.

author: EternalShonen
review: Here it is, the PERFECT Lego game! Not only do I believe this to be the best Lego game ever released, I do think this is also one of the greatest if not THE greatest Star Wars game. It covers all the nine movies extremely well and even improves some of them. Anakin Skywalker in the prequels is actually an interesting and more fleshed out character in this game! The Wandering Wookiee the game introduces is so lovable and cute that I must mention his existence in the review <3The controls, music, characters and everything else are fantastic. There really is nothing bad to say about this as they have fixed all of the issues that were present at the early stages of this game's life. I do not know if any words can do justice to how legendary this release is and I am glad all the main movies are included even though in my mind there are only three movies in the Star Wars series (IV, V, VI). I cannot recommend this game enough as it is extremely addictive and fun regardless if you play it alone or with someone. A definitive masterpiece full of fun adventures anyone can enjoy!

author: RazorShader
review: Because of some disappointments in the past, I generally try not to be hyped by new games anymore. Nevertheless, this game gathered my attention and being the cheapskate that I am, I planned to keep an eye on it and buy it at a sale. But I saw some content in which the game looked really fun and properly polished, so I decided to treat myself on the deluxe edition. Initially the game was fun despite a bunch of flaws (by which I mean both glitches and more subjective flaws based on my personal opinion); fun enough for me to still wholeheartedly recommend it. But at some point the negative started to outweigh the positive, so I guess I will only recommend this game when enough of the issues are addressed. Because of many of the glitches and clunkily implemented features, I doubt the game has been properly playtested. I heard the game was delayed on various occasions because of the difficulties with implementing the open world aspects, but it seems that at some point they gave up and released the unfinished product anyway. Since I bought the deluxe edition, I would assume I wouldn’t have to feel like playing a pre-release betatester and that a developer would have the decency to complete a game before releasing additional content to rake in more money. TT games isn’t the only one to execute ♥♥♥♥♥♥ practices like this (having some Cyberpunk 2077 vibes here), but it sure sucks it seems to become the standard. Here is a list of things I specifically like and things I don’t.Positive aspects• The game allows you to explore the galaxy a lot. In many areas you’re not constrained by objectives you have to progress because you’re in a mission, so you can help people on side missions, solve puzzles to get collectibles and just roam around and have some fun.• The dialogues are really fun. In the trailer I saw for the game, many of the jokes fell flat (for me), but in context they were much more fun. There are many jokes referencing the movies (and quotes referenced in memes), which I expect many to enjoy. A protocol droid next to the Tusken village, for example, will tell you it’s “home of not just the men, but the women and children too”. Characters selected can also have some interaction; Vader will tell Palpatine he already heard the tragedy of Darth Plagueis the wise countless times. • Visually it generally looks very nice, with much of attention to detail, especially when it comes to the figures. The capes look like actual fabric, and the figures themselves even have lines from the molds and a real plastic-looking shine.• Flying freely in space in combat is very smooth, at least it is with mouse and keyboard. For me it fits perfectly between the classic and new Battlefront II, meaning it’s both easy to steer to fly and to aim to shoot. On a controller, I found steering much harder, but that’s probably also the result of me being less used to controllers.Negative aspects• It’s not always clear where freeplay starts and ends. You can complete story related objectives in the open world parts, but it’s not clear when you can and can’t select other characters to complete puzzles that require a certain type of character.• The missions that don’t take place in the open world are very short. Especially when replaying them it felt glaringly obvious how less content there is in this regard. The Sarlacc/sail barge mission, for example, has a small portion that immediately starts on deck with Luke and Lando and then cuts to a boss fight against Jabba with Leia and R2-D2. It was fun to actually fight Jabba in person, but the whole mission was very short compared to the skiff hopping and below deck objectives of Lego Star Wars II.• There is a reason I spoke about “flying freely in space combat” before, and that is that in a bunch of missions, you can’t fly freely. It really makes it feel like you’re stuck on a monorail with limited space to move. In the Naboo submarine mission this felt somewhat logical, but for others (the Millenium Falcon asteroid chase and the Death Star I trench run) it felt really limiting and annoying. In missions such as the Jango Fett Geonosis chase and the Naboo Trade Federation control ship battle you’re allowed to move much more freely, making these missions much more enjoyable.• This monorail feeling also applies to many of the boss fights, portions of which you will be locked onto the boss without being able to unlock again (locking onto bosses in games can be useful, but it’s better if you can lock onto the boss yourself and disable it again as well). The game also heavily relies on quicktime events during these boss fights, which really removes a sense of urgency and personal skill when battling them. And unfortunately, these quicktime events regularly take some time to be triggered. When battling Dooku, at some point he just kept taking a beating with the same amount of barely any health, and after my 300 combo he required multiple seconds to walk to the right place to trigger the final quicktime event.• Many interesting potential missions are relegated to cutscenes, which is very unfortunate. You get to enter Palpatine’s office to arrest him as Windu and Fisto, but not to fight him, and space/vehicle battles such as the battle of Coruscant, battle of Geonosis and the Death Star II battle are just there as cutscenes. • There are various missions causing massive framerate drops without any ‘visual justification’ to back it up. The Geonosis factory and Ewok village don’t look better than most other places, so they shouldn’t cause such low framerates.• Once a mission is started, you can’t leave it without completing it (or so it seems).• The main menu animation can’t be skipped, so you’ll have to sit through Rey’s “I need someone to show me my place in all this” and the slow zoom out every time you want to load a savegame or leave the game altogether. And as a player, you’re not allowed to show her her place in all that, which definitely is not in the center above all other characters. Jarring. • The intro animation skip also doesn’t work properly; it says you need to hold F to skip it, but you first need to tap a key (either F or another one) first. • The character selection menu isn’t user friendly. There’s a lot of character classes with specific characters, and you can’t navigate the menus with your mouse.  • The game doesn’t always seem to properly apply the character you selected. Not the one you picked altogether sometimes (because it seems to think you selected it already, although you’re obviously not that character), but also not the specific version of that character you selected. In many instances, this game just doesn’t seem to want me to play as the stormtrooper commander with the spooling gun, so I’ll keep ending up with the regular one with the regular blaster.• Even when in freeplay, it’s sometimes impossible to switch characters from your preselected ones, so you’ll have to switch with the character next to you first.• The game also seems to have a hard time remembering which characters you had selected when entering/leaving a room. And switching to the one you’re not isn’t always possible because the game seems to think you’re already that character while you’re not.• The rotating mini-map (if you select the option) forgets to rotate a lot. You can make it rotate again by switching with the character next to you (and back), but it sucks I have to keep doing it every single time I enter another area.• Enemies are sparse in numbers when compared to the large amounts of the earlier Lego Star Wars games and are unlikely to kill you. Characters with activated lightsabers will automatically reflect blaster bolts without requiring the need to hold a block button. You’re much more likely to die because of one of the next few bulletpoints.[REST OF THE REVIEW IN THE COMMENTS]

author: Lordbobomb
review: It seems that the PC port was an afterthought when developing this game, as it's controls are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrible and can not be rebound without it feeling just as bad.Jedi and Blaster characters do not use the same key to use their primary attacks and what makes it worse is that multiple actions are mapped to them. Haven't found anything on search engines for mods or ini tweaks that could help either.I could bear the terrible voice acting and the sequel trilogy being in this game.But the piss poor controls really kills it for me plus the lack of the character customizer (without mods) really doesn't help either. And before anyone even thinks: "BrUh jUSt BuY a coNtRolLer"No i'm not going to buy a controller just to have even a decent experience, it's not an excuse nor a solution for poor developer practices. Quake came out in 1996 and set the standard for PC gaming controls, and even it had re-bindable keys that weren't mapped to multiple actions. There is no excuse for any developer to have such terrible decisions made almost 30 years later.As someone who deeply loves the Original Complete Saga and really likes the Clone Wars game. (Even with it's questionable design decisions) this is a disappointment to say the least. I can only hope that maybe one day they'll put in some kind of preset keybinds that would fix my issue with it's controls but i quite frankly doubt they would.

author: Big Muzzy
review: I have replayed every Lego game in the last to years and I must admit that this game is much better than many in the entire collection. However, there were some questionable choices concerning the gameplay and the character roster. I feel like TT decided to simplify the categories of characters due to the fact that all of the last Lego Superhero games (DC, Marvel, Incredibles) had to many types of characters. I would say that the old system was confusing but the one that we have now is too simple. You could literally play through the entire game using only 4 characters. There are so many abilities in the Star Wars universe that could be utilized. Things like the gungans (and other species) being able to swim underwater or different villains (or heros) from different eras being able to use different puzzles, codes, riddles etc. (We only get the "heros" and "villains"). The point of having so many characters is to make it fun for the player to switch between them. This game has kind of turned this option into a chore. On top of that there is a number of characters missing from the roster which again would seem to be obvious picks. We get all the knights of ren but no random geonosians?? Really? No imperial spy and no Agen Kolar (this guy is even missing in the cut scene). I get that these are minor problems and thats why I would still recommend this game but it just seems odd that they would add so many characters just for "funzies" but then decide to overlook some characters that are literally on screen during important scenes. Don't get me wrong I am not mad about this, I'm just extremely confused... It would be lovely to get all the answers one day but for now let's just enjoy the beautiful game that the TT team created.Anyways, I had a lot of fun playing this and will probably play it again. I hope that the TT team gets to work on more Lego titles (under less excruciating circumstances ha ha...)

author: ajnplatinum
review: Going into this game you'll probably wanna take one thing into account:This game's goal is very different from the original Lego Star Wars games/Complete SagaWhere those games existed to gameify the prequel and original trilogy's most exciting moments for family friendly sandbox action, Skywalker Saga aims to retell as much of each movie as possible while presenting the player with an extremely detailed and vast galaxy to explore while at the same time trying some new gameplay mechanics to make the more action packed setpieces more enjoyable (especially considering a lot of the game's audience is going to be people who grew up with the originals)Much of the game's puzzles and exploration come from the open world you'll be traversing as the story and actual levels progress. This means that the actual levels are often dedicated to iconic battles or action oriented moments from the films, however that doesn't mean there aren't some puzzles or motivation to come back for free play to earn those minikits and complete mission challenges.Considering this, it's much easier to feel as though this is an evolution of the original formula. You're still exploring every corner of iconic locations to collect studs and other collectables like the original games, just most of it being separate from the more combat focused levels the game throws you in across all 9 movies' stories. Ignoring the overworld's exploration can make the game seem like a walking sim from point A to point B, so treat it all as one long hunt for bricks, easter eggs and bonus areas.(Edit: There is still plenty of combat outside of the main story. The overworld and areas within it will have hostiles spawn and special encounters such as taking over capital ships will include large space and ground battles to take on.)This also in turn makes the game come off as a very relaxing experience. There's over 1000 clear bricks to collect throughout the entirety of the game, with many areas feeling as though there's a puzzle or platforming segment to solve to grab one. There's two motives to finding these bricks: 100% completion and the ability to upgrade every character type in the game with these bricks. Each character type has some sort of quirk, with characters found in these categories often having their own little quirk as well. For a game with 300+ characters they somehow made each look and feel unique.There's so much fanservice and attention to detail in this game as well that putting it into words is super difficult. So many animations, discoverable locations, lines of dialogue and goofy jokes in cutscenes that reference all of Star Wars and even other properties as well (like Better Call Saul and Xenoblade of all things) make it hard to not smile at it all.This game is genuinely something special if you don't go in expecting something exactly like the original games or specifically Complete Saga. As an alternative to experiencing each movies' plot: this game excels. As an exploration focused title: this game excels. As a simple yet fun hack n slash/TPS: this game excels.This game was worth the wait and while your value of Lego Star Wars and the actual Star Wars properly may dictate your enjoyment of this game quite a bit, fans will love what this game brings to the table and I'm hoping some other past Lego titles like Indiana Jones get a similar type of treatment.10/10

author: David0vić
review: The Skywalker Saga ended up being a very disappointing experience. If you treat this game like a linear experience it fails miserably. All the levels are shockingly short and basic. The gameplay even for a LEGO game is so simple. At least in the original LEGO Star Wars the levels were a good length with solid level design and actual puzzle solving involved in the gameplay. There is none of that here, it is as straightforward as it gets. The constant interruptions in the gameplay with the popups asking if you want to continue the story got so annoying too. I was basically playing just to get to the next cutscene which is by far the best part about this game, the actual cutscenes themselves. All the characters are very well animated and the game is genuinely funny. I don't regret my time or experience with the game because i played it in coop and we enjoyed watching the numerous funny moments the game offers, but we would have had the same experience if we just watched all the cutscenes on youtube because we got nothing out of actually playing the game itself. The game also has a lot of performance issues in certain areas in coop. You can tell it's the outdated engine the game runs on struggling to keep up. You can also tell a lot of the effort in this game was put on the open world collectathon gameplay and not on the actual missions themselves which is the reason why i bought the game. If you plan on running around all the planets getting all the blue bricks and doing everything possible maybe it's worth getting but because i didn't bother doing that it's hard to say, i don't see the point in doing it personally. Even though i don't regret my time with the game it's not one i can recommend, especially as a straightforward journey where you are just playing through the movies. 5/10 (Average)

author: Shan Finds Pixels
review: Welcome in the World of first open world Star Wars game made in lego sense humour. Where characters are more joking than being serious. That's the sense of lego games. Specially Lego Star Wars games. If i will compare it to original, the new game has a lot shorter ,,levels'' (missions) than original games from 2006-2007. BUT we have here new addition, open world and planets! So makes sense there needed to be done some compromises in order to make things balanced. I really enjoyed everything, from fighting to collect bricks to save currency for unlocking characters. My only big issue was enjoying Episodes 7,8,9. As myself i do not consider them as part of canon either of Star Wars, that is not fault by devs but Disney. But in total i really loved go back and dive into world of Star Wars again. I could say it's the best Star Wars game made after Kotor I,II. ^^+ Story + Fun levels + Humour+ Atmosphere+ Soundtrack is just masterpiece+ Open World+ Puzzles+ Brilliant Graphic for lego game+ So much to do, impossible to do everything for me+ So many planets to explore, visit+ More than 250 characters to unlock and you can play as+ If you feel sad or angry, this game makes you smile or laugh- Some minor bugs- I had few times crash, but only like 2x times

author: Manson
review: Personal rating - 7/10If you're someone that hasn't played a LEGO game in the past 10 years like myself this game will be a lot different than what your memory serves you, but it will still be an enjoyable experience. I played this game entirely co-op and am still in the process of going back to 100% the game so I will be speaking about my experience with the game playing co-op.This game has a lot of bugs. Period. Now some aren't as bad as others, but still really annoying to have to deal with. A few that immediately come to mind that I ran into often were:- Changing to random characters when entering a building in Free Play- Characters freezing when using the force and talking to characters (only way I could fix is by restarting the level)- Important mission characters disappearing off the face of the planet (literally)I was not a fan of the menus upon menus you have to go through in order to find anything you are looking for. As someone who waiting until they were finished with the game to buy characters it took an extremely long time to go through and buy every single character, ship, etc that I had unlocked which wasn't many.Lastly, some of the levels in this game were clearly not designed for co-op. Some levels Player 2 is stuck as a droid and literally can't do anything for most of the level. There are a few things they can do, but its only little character checks for bricks or mini kits. The open world aspect of this game gives me the sense of freedom I've always wanted in a LEGO game. I love going into space and being able to LAND on an enemy ship and even buy it afterwards. Its an incredibly thrilling way to earn ships. The puzzles throughout the game are nice, not too hard and not too easy. Some might not be incredibly obvious but map markers can help steer you in the right direction which is nice. I'm putting this at the bottom because in my opinion its very minor, but I find it out that they decided to remove 90% of the character deaths. This really killed the mood for a lot of cut scenes... which there are a lot of..

author: MR JOJOLANDS
review: With 88.8 hours of playtime under my belt, 100% game completion AND 100% achievement completion, I feel like I am FINALLY qualified to give a review of this game. As I have, quite literally, experienced all content there is in this game!This is frankly speaking a new era of LEGO games. It takes a lot of the original core mechanics of the old LEGO games I grew up playing, i.e LEGO Star Wars 1, 2 and The Complete Saga, LEGO Batman, LEGO Indiana Jones, etc. and completely modernizes it. We've got the classic stud collecting, character collecting, and upgrades. What is also still here are the standard "story levels". However, this time around its all been throw into a strange open world sandbox/RPG style game, and in my humble opinion they nail it.If you're just here for some quick in and out LEGO fun, then this is definitely the game for you. The story and the levels are very entertaining and well put together experiences, and a great way to re-live all 9 episodes of the epic saga we all love! To top it all off, (I never thought I would say this about a LEGO game) this game has BEAUTIFUL graphics. Honestly some of this game is stunning! Not gonna lie, this game even made me enjoy the sequel trilogy, which I am usually not very fond of. In my experience, it took around 3 to 4 hours to complete each episode. So if you're just looking to play through the story its gonna take you around 27 to 36 hours to complete it!If you want more than just some quick in and out fun, and you want to re-live the old days of LEGO Star Wars 1, 2 and The Complete Saga, collecting every mini kit and unlocking every character. Fighting to achieve that sweet sweet 100% then OH BOY is this game for you! The sheer amount of stuff to collect in this game is absolutely MIND BLOWING! Now I wont lie, it can get a bit grindy at points if you really want that 100% game completion. But if you are a sick twisted completionist like me, then you will love every second of it! All in all, the game is said to contain around 80 hours of content if you're going for 100%. This seems about right, as I'm writing this review right after I achieved 100% and I'm currently sitting on 88.8 hours.Final thoughts:Is this game perfect? Oh hell nah, this is not a perfect game. I've run into minor bugs here and there. And as I stated, to get that sweet sweet 100% some grinding must be done.Is this game fun? Oh hell yeah! This game is A LOT of fun! I think theres something for everyone here, no matter how much time you want to sink into the game. I found myself nostalgically reminiscing on my childhood, playing old LEGO games. I found myself re igniting my burning passion for Star Wars, and in conjunction with playing the game started a marathon of all Star Wars movies and shows (The Clone Wars, The Bad Batch, The Mandalorian, The Book of Boba Fett, etc.). But most importantly, I found myself having a lot of fun with a video game for the first time in quite a while, and I could not put this game down.I hope this review helps :DEdit: Played the game again recently, it still slaps!
