author: Spome
review: "Lego Star Wars" is now something I say every day before I go to bed. Such phrases lead me to wonderful dreams I have about epic adventures throughout the galaxy. These adventures are conducted by Lego Minifigures of my favorite star wars characters, like Luke Skywalker or Darth Vader. However, my favorite Lego star wars character is either the Gonk or the Jawa, I am inconclusive about this. Though, I feel as if I can connect to these characters; I am short as both the Gonk and the Jawa and only receive any attention from girls as petty love - such love they see in a baby, adorable rather than sexy. I want to be sexy, but I am not and feel comfortable when I see others like me. I also relate much further to these characters - when the Gonk droid says magnificent words like "Gonk," it reminds me of my seemingly simple nature, but through a protocol droid, there is much more to be found. Both characters are also unable to drive motor vehicles, something I relate to due to both size and absence of license. The relations I have to these characters fill my heart with completion, as although I am not much, I can relate to these characters and see how successful they have become. They have fueled my drive for achievements like "Earn 10 billion studs," as I hope to become as successful as thy, and if not in the real world, in Lego Star Wars.

author: Denyerec
review: Bought this for the kids because they loved the original Star Wars LEGO games, but the split screen in this is confusing and disorienting, and the action is fractured and feels very disjointed, starting and stopping quite  a lot as you're thrust into menus to choose where to go next. The FOV is also quite tight, meaning in splitscreen you can barely see what's going on most of the time. Shame, because visually its really well done.It's like someone thought implementing SkyRim questing in a LEGO game would be a grand idea, IDK, can't quite put my finger on it but the kids won't touch it so it's a complete waste of money.Maybe if you're an adult who wants to play through the whole experience alone it might be worth a shout, but for this audience it's a complete washout.They spend all their time on the original SWL and Jurrassic Park LEGO series, mainly because they can see what's going on, and the dynamic splitscreen works so much better.

author: HattedSandwich
review: I wish there was a neutral option, because I don't feel that this is a bad game but it's certainly not what I would have imagined a Lego Star Wars game would be like in the 10+ years its been since I played the Complete Saga.The bulk of the gameplay takes place in an empty feeling open world. You run around, break the same objects (benches, merchant stands, boxes), collect small denomination studs, find upgrade bricks, and follow a nav marker to a story mission. You get a cutscene. Then you run around to the next nav marker. You get a mission that lasts much less time than your aimless wandering. Rinse and repeat. The worlds are very samey and lack the goofy Lego oddities that made the older games so fun, like force pulling increasingly bizarre vegetables out of the ground, building skeleton spooky bois that wander about, or a machine that gives you a top hat and moustache. Maybe those things come later in the game, but I'm already running out of steam in the early game.The game lacks curation. Like i said, my last LSW game was the complete saga many years ago. Those games had a single hub world with the same gameplay devices as the open worlds do in this game. You could cause some mayhem until you got bored, then go into a story episode. Those episodes had several missions which (generally) took anywhere from 15 minutes on up, depending on how well you knew the maps and whether or not you wanted to grab all the collectibles. The story beats were contained within the levels, and everything had a reasonable linearity to it. The nice thing is that there were extra rooms or areas dotted throughout the levels where you could have goofy encounters with hot tub troopers, or play some kind of minigame for studs or collectibles. Everything you needed to 100% the game was present in the levels, not the bland hub world.I think what I'm missing most in this title is the focus. It feels like im running around an MMO world with a LSW dressing, but without all of the off-beat humour to it.

author: NatOreN
review: Not worth the full price, honestly. There's entertainment to be had, but it feels hollow. It's like they took their LotR game and flipped the values; instead of the open world and side quests offering something a little extra between missions, now it feels more like the missions are something extra between the open world and side quests, and so far they've been little more than go from A to B, then press button for cutscene.Edit: So it does feel like things somewhat improve beyond the prequel chapters, at least enough for me to give a positive rating. Methinks they might have been a little too fond of the new combat system, which doesn't really add much to the game, honestly. Wait for discounts.

author: i_scribblez
review: The Skywalker Saga is something I've been looking forward to ever since it was announced. Compared to previous lego games, I definitely think this one tops the bag, BUT I do still have some complaints about it. Firstly, graphics, level design, combat mechanics, and open world aspects blow my mind. Sometimes, it honestly feels overwhelming to take it all in. And I'll admit, I've never been a "voice acting" kinda guy in lego games, but I actually don't mind for this one, especially since the voices are extremely close and well done to the originals. My only thing with the game is that the levels are far too short compared to the Complete Saga and that it lacks the same amount of content/effort. Building isn't all too present and the enemies and levels actually feel way easier than they should. That being said, at the same time, I still feel that there is much to explore all around every level and that something like this isn't enough to take away from the game itself. It's more personal preference, I suppose. It would be nice if we could also customize characters like previous games and even add in spin off stories/characters from other series like the Clone Wars, etc. (Yes I know dlc has bad batch and what not).Overall great game.

author: Klip
review: As someone who got this mainly out of nostalgia for LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga, I have to say that this is surprisingly good. It's actually one of the more solid Star Wars titles to come out recently, which is bizarre to me considering that this is, at it's core, a LEGO game. Of course, you'll find bugs here and there, with a few requiring a relaunch of the game to work around, but I'm fairly confident that these will be patched sooner rather than later. This review is written after completing both the prequels and original trilogy. I am currently at 18 hours of game time. My current completion is listed at 22.40%.Anyhow, introduction business out of the way, let's get into my thoughts about LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga.-Gameplay is really good, and a far cry from the incredibly basic and bare bones systems of the LEGO titles that I grew up with. It is seriously a massive leap forward, and I hope this sets a new bar for LEGO titles.-Environments are stunning, and there were a good few times I just had to stop what I was doing to look around. You can tell that TT games put a lot of effort into making every location look as good as possible, within the limitations of a LEGO game.-Voice acting is actually pretty decent. Prior to playing the game, I heavily considered putting it into mumble mode right off the bat - however, upon hearing that the characters were voiced by the Clone Wars actors, I opted to play without mumble mode enabled. It has been a decently enjoyable experience so far, although I certainly won't blame anyone for enabling mumble mode out of preference.-Levels can be a bit short, however I've found that this is well balanced by the free roam exploration. As mentioned at the end of the introduction, I'm at 18 hours and 22.40% completion. Take that as you will, everyone has a different value when it comes to dollar per hour in game. As an additional note, I do expect to get at least another 15-20 hours out of this playthrough, while I tackle the sequel trilogy, do side missions, and find collectables.My only real complaint is the lack of online co-op. Although Steam has the remote play feature, it requires a far better internet connection than what we have available in many rural areas. Native online co-op is not only significantly less demanding on an internet connection, but it also comes with nice bonuses, such as not having to play in a split screen configuration. However, I do understand the reasons for not including online co-op in the game, and I believe that the game does not suffer too much for it's absence.All in all, I give this an 8/10. If the sequels change my mind on this, I will be sure to come back and update my review.

author: Furgotti
review: So, I got this game on April 7th as a birthday present from a very close friend and I have to say this was the best present I've gotten in a long time. This is a piece of my childhood, I started playing the original Lego Star Wars game before I played the Skywalker saga and comparing both of them the developers of the Skywalker saga have done an outstanding job. They did such a great job that they even made episode seven through nine better than the movies and that's saying something. This game is a great accomplishment in video gaming industry because it shows there's still hope out there for game companies to make good games without making a bunch of false promises. This wasn't a game made by EA or Bungie or Bethesda they didn't make a bunch of lies on top of a stage about how the game was going to have 16 times the detail or that they would promise that the games content will not be vaulted or that you have to paid for skins with a ton of loot crates or an item shop and use real money. This game literally gives you everything in it without having to spend real-world money and seeing something like this is like seeing a diamond in a dirty road. It's amazing that they put in so much hard work dedication and actually cared for the community then making a bunch of false promises and lies then releasing a barely working game that they would slowly patch overtime into what they promised or at least close enough to it while only caring about how much money they made. The game is pretty good and if any negative comments push you away from the game just ignore the naysayers, they're trying to make any excuse they can to give the game a negative review at this point they'll make a negative review about the game was made on the planet Earth. This game is outstandingly great. I have been playing it and I have not seen any bugs at all or any problems with the game there have been at least one bug that I've noticed with animals that you can ride spawning into each other but that's pretty much it. One thing I will say is the Droid factory in episode 2 isn't well optimized. For frames most of the time I was getting about 120 frames per second on the entire game with no drops on the highest settings but in that one level it went down from 120 to 19 frames per second which kind of sucks but all in all this is a really great game. This isn't something that really needs a strong computer I'm using a computer with 8 to 10 year old parts in it. If you want to get it for a person who played it on the GameCube when they were a kid like me, or if you want to give it to your children as a pass me down to the new generation. This is perfect it was outstanding I love that the developers were underdogs they did so many delays and in the end they were able to make a better game than most AAA titles that come out. It's sad for big companies because it shows how much they are a joke but seeing how these guys were able to make something better than most companies it's amazing and what game has cheat codes in 2022 that's an old blast from the past which is so great

author: Glaze
review: The story tone is very weird and all over the place, partially due to the voice acting mixed with slapstick humor. This is worst in the prequel trilogy, mostly due to the focus on politics, trade agreements, chancellor elections etc.I feel like there's a LOT less building than the original Complete Saga, instead having more combat and puzzles.Hub worlds are pretty big, and you plow through them in such a rapid pace it can be intimidating to even think of how many of the 1100+ Kyber Bricks you missed, not to even mention the minikits and characters hidden throughout story missions.I wish there was proper online co-op, though. Doesn't feel like that's too much to ask in 2022.Classic Lego Star Wars, I have no clue what's going on but I get to beat up lego dudes with a lightsaber.Overall, I'd recommend it if you liked the games of the olden days. It's impossible to truly recapture the childlike, nostalgic feeling you have for the old lego games, but this game makes a very solid attempt.

author: shadow
review: Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is a tedious collect-a-thon. With over 300 characters, they’re grouped into a few different classes which now have their own upgrades. Then there’s about 70 or so extra characters which have no upgrades and belong to no class, making them completely useless. The issue is now C3PO can disassemble, so there’s no use bringing along a small character like Young Anakin or Young Boba to crawl inside spaces. Unlike previous Lego games, each character now has their own attack pattern. For example, though Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon Jinn are both Jedi, they swing their lightsabers differently and attack with their own unique patterns. The main upgrades are just the Extras from The Complete Saga like attracting studs, increasing health, and collectible detectors. Class upgrades are barely noticeable, so it’s more useful to save studs for the main core and datacore upgrades which can increase your stud multiplier. But the menu is overly cluttered and annoying to navigate. I accrued a ton of kyber bricks and studs before I wanted to spend them on anything because of the horrible menus.The combat is clearly influenced by Jedi: Fallen Order, which is out of place for a Lego game. There’s unblockable attacks you must avoid, and you can use the force by throwing objects in the environment at your enemy. You can also defend with a lightsaber, or aim with a weapon. The shooting is a problem because the camera is too close with no option to adjust FOV. Enemy health bars are too large so you’ll be shooting without doing much damage. There’s a basic cover system, but it doesn’t matter because the enemies are easy targets who can’t hit you anyway. And with regenerating health, there’s no use staying in cover and playing defensively. The combo system is especially confusing, along with the counter for simple enemies. There’s only one difficulty, and it’s not like Lego games have ever been challenging anyway. Ship combat is great. You can adjust pitch and movement, making piloting a lot easier and enemy lock-on is fast. Acceleration is accrued over time, so you can continue speeding indefinitely.Levels are completely re-worked, but most of the missions now emphasize bosses, and again their health bars encourage basic button mashing since you’ll never fight a boss without a lightsaber. I liked the older style of Lego games where the bosses only had a few hearts requiring one or two appropriately timed hits equally spaced apart. With enough damage dealt, you’ll enter into one of two QTE’s; either you’ll have to constantly mash a button to block, or quickly press a button to counter. Missions don’t encourage cooperative gameplay, either, which is probably why online coop wasn’t included. There’s a few missions such as the aforementioned boss battles where the local co-op partner is just going to stand around doing nothing. Prequel episodes particularly felt rushed, because they emphasize the most bosses out of the entire game. If you hated the Disney sequels, you’ll hate them even more here. It’s better than Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens, but not by much. Missions are short because all planets are used as hubs, so instead of revisiting the areas in levels, you explore them in the open world. These hubs are the main focus of the game, and are on every major planet totaling 24 altogether. It’s interesting to explore them for the first few minutes, but the novelty quickly wears off. Hubs are large but empty. There’s characters to interact with in order to acquire missions to unlock kyber bricks, characters, and ships, but each of them are the same between planets. And the loading screens are so numerous you’ll be spending more time loading than actually completing certain missions.  If you’ve completed one planet’s hub, you’ve essentially completed them all. Completionists will feel exhausted, mostly because it seems side missions and activities were included to artificially lengthen a much shorter game, like the developers knew the missions were too short, so they filled the hubs with monotonous extras to make players think there’s more than there really is. I experienced framerate drops in the hub areas, but also in specific missions, as well as black screens and a number of other game breaking bugs.Humor is irritating. There’s a hundred jokes about Anakin’s hatred of sand, and Luke’s love of blue milk. Cutscenes have become sterilized. One of the only reasons to play The Skywalker Saga is for the fully voiced cast, including Billy Dee Williams as Lando and Anthony Daniels as C3PO.The open world hubs don’t motivate me to 100% complete The Skywalker Saga, and despite its many features, most of them are unnecessary or included to lengthen the short missions. I’ll stick with The Complete Saga instead.

author: Iiro_5
review: I'm yet to 100% the game but so far I sincerely don't think the game is worth the price. I recommend waiting for a sale if you want to play. The game itself is alright, but is definitely missing that classic lego game feel. It's completely missing all of those elements that are present in every single lego game before it that made those games fun and exciting. It's like they are making any other game and putting lego graphics on it. I am not big on the level design so far and the combo system is pretty useless as you can just spam force attacks or grenades. The rebuildable covers you can use in a blaster battle are frankly a nuisance when they get broken because there's so much stuff laying on the ground that needs to be rebuilt and they are also useless when they're intact.  In all of the levels in the game not a single time did I need to hide in a battle. You can easily just run around shooting at the enemies not really even trying to avoid shots and you'll be fine most of the time and honestly I'd recommend doing that as it takes less time than slowly trying to snipe enemies from behind cover. Couple this with spamming grenades/force attacks and you will win. Every time. So yeah, not really worth it in my opinion. It is still a fun game despite it's flaws, so I would still recommend buying it on sale or something, just don't pay 50 euro for it. I might update and clean up this review after playing through more of the game, but for now that was all. PeaceEdit 1: ♥♥♥♥ the endor speeder level, it is ♥♥♥♥, drawn out, boring and buggy and go ♥♥♥♥ yourself if you liked itEdit 2: Bruh general grievous dabs in thisEdit 3: so far pretty much all the levels have sucked ass, except for a few in episodes 1-6 and for some reason the entirety of the force awakens so far has been pretty goodEdit 4: I have now played through all the levels. Most of them are ♥♥♥♥. I generally enjoyed the vehicle levels the most, which is surprising as usually they tend to be the worst. All the levels in the game lack content and feel like only one 4th of a full level. Usually in a lego game a level would have multiple parts to it; different areas, bossfights and puzzles, but this one only has 1 area per level. Sometimes the levels are just really drawn out and repetitive bossfights, which might I mention are in my opinion one of the worst parts of the game.

author: Mill
review: It's fun to kill time, but really disappointing after 2 years of delay. First of all, the open world is gorgeous, the animations are sick, the graphics outstanding, the diversity of unknown characters is impressive and the humor is great, but almost everything else is mediocre or boring. The game is made for kids; but it's like the game thinks kids have -1 brain cells, because the AI acts completely stupid and basically just stand there waiting for you to kill them. The new fighting mechanic is great, but very repetitive (and useless, because enemies are dead after like 3 attacks, so you can't even complete the combos). The boss fights are all exactly the same and have the same animations/attacks; and if you can't even change your character in freeplay for most of them. The story mode is incredibly boring, rushed and has 0 puzzles, it's either shooting stupid AI or following a character around the map for like 10 minutes, just for some cut scene to portray all the fun stuff from what could've been a level (for example: The battle of Couruscant, the battle of Endor, retaking of Theed). Also, it has been around 1 month from release, and there are some common game-breaking bugs that won't let you continue the game that haven't been fixed. Honestly, really sad and disappointing, because this could've been a really good game, but it cut short in every aspect possible.PD: R2 cannot fly.PD 2: Yoda's death sound is different.

author: RapTv
review: The game is mostly fun. I've enjoyed the new version of the combat which brings a bit more fun to the game. The more explore element is very nice for people who want to find everything in the game. The graphics are pretty decent and the dialogue is surprisingly good. Addition of new levels and feel of the game is great. With that, there are a few problems that makes this game fell off. For starters there is no cantina, probably one of the best parts of the original games. No custom character creation which is pretty disappointing. The levels feel extremely short. I flew through episode one in almost 45 minutes. I remember playing the episodes in the other games for hours on end and having so much fun. Sections that I had so many memories of like the Kamino mission has been cut down to a short walking section and a very easy Jango Fett boss fight. While new things have been added, it feels like they have taken a lot from the game too. It's pretty fun, but you can fly through some episodes pretty fast without even realizing.

author: Cuddletauren
review: I smash everything in sight and collect the blocks. I don't want to play like this...but this is my first lego game. Every time I start playing I wind up spending hours on the same mission smashing every piece of furniture (it respawns too, and I destroy it again.) I don't like the idea of this pastime, but every time I load the game, I forget Star Wars and become addicted to smashing brick for pieces of brick. Story is definitely better here than in the Star Wars films. Make sure to start with episode VII (Force Awakens), as you need to unlock scavenger class abilities with Rey before you can actually use scavenger abilities regardless of progress. Deluxe edition is totally not worth it--you get more characters--but they're still lego characters meant to be collected. Most characters share the same abilities as others in their class (all jedi has the same skills, astro droid, protocol droids.)

author: Alucryd
review: There's collecta-fun, and there's collecta-bloat. This game is definitely the latter, upwards of 97% of players agree according to the global achievement stats.The game can be fun at times, but it is so boringly repetitive that it quickly becomes a chore that even nostalgia can hardly overcome.Then there's the platforming, oh god the platforming. Good luck grabbing those ledges or climbing off of them, plus if you happen to use a character with a grapple, you're completely doomed. Also try double jumping with a scavenger that has the glider equipped, loads of fun. You'd think after so many Lego games one would finally not control like ass, well think again, I mean Nintendo got 3D platforming right as early as 1996, it can't be that hard can it?

author: Mr. Robot J. Rockman
review: This review is going to be a curveball review, I know it is. And it’s probably gonna be a very weak review because of that but I'm still gonna try to get my points across. Also, no spoiler warning here because I’m sure everyone who is playing this, has played it, or will play it knows what all happens in Star Wars. Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga took all original Lego Star Wars games and completely REVAMPED them with modern graphics, new mechanics, and a BUNCH of new content and features which is all incredibly amazing. However, even with all of this new and amazing stuff, this game to me personally is… Meh? Good at best? It’s honestly a debate between those two opinions and I shall now cover them. The open-world part of this game is fantastic, and I believe it is hands down the best new thing this game has to offer. The ability to go anywhere in the galaxy (as long as you have that area unlocked) at any time? Top notch stuff right there. Each area in this game is very detailed and essentially matches all the areas inside of the movies down to a T. The movement and gameplay with the characters is great and I don’t have any major complaints about it except how they removed and changed how certain characters work. For example, small characters (like Ewoks and young Anakin) used to be the only characters that were able to crawl into vents and access areas. Now, they can’t do that and instead you have to use a droid like C3PO and split him in half to enter the vents now. Why did that have to change? It removed a key feature of the small characters, and has now kinda made the game a bit harder because if you wanna access a certain area, or unlock something that involves a vent, you now have to unlock a droid and enter that mission in free roam. Another feature they removed is how droids like R2D2 were able to fly (or hover) for a short period of time which in the original games would create interesting platform sections and puzzles. In the new game they can’t, and now instead use a grappling hook or something of that sort. Again, why did that have to be removed as well?.. Ship controls can be a bit funky and wonky, especially in co-op mode. In some areas of the game, if you’re in co-op mode, both players are allowed to fly two separate ships (EX: player one could be the Millennium Falcon while player 2 could be an X-wing) which is fine, that's not an issue at all. But what IS an issue however is the other areas of the game where players are forced to share a ship (EX: the mission where you’re going through the planet core in episode I, or in episode V after Han, Leia, C3PO, and Chewbacca escaped Hoth and now have to fight their way past an Imperial fleet of Star Destroyers). One player controls the ship, the other controls the gun(s). To some this may be fine and dandy but to me and my friend who has played this game with me ever since I got it, sections like this are always troublesome and awkward/wonky because of controls. Co-op mode in this game is alright. The only complaint I have about it is the camera which is awful. Why couldn't they make it like it was in the original game where the camera was focused on both characters at all times and if a player happened to be left behind, they would just teleport to the closest character available by player 1, or make it to where if one character wanders off too far, the camera would split HORIZONTALLY and not VERTICALLY LIKE THE GAME ALREADY HAS IT (which by the way, you CAN’T change whatsoever. Unless they added the option to and if that's the case, then this complaint has been fixed) which is terrible in itself. This game pretty much nails down every episode’s storyline down to a T with comedic bits and pieces scattered throughout because it’s a Lego game, every Lego game has its comedic moments. However, with a few of those comedic events, it can sometimes go over the top a bit and somewhat ruin what was a serious scene in the movies (for example, Luke finding out Darth Vader is his father) which isn’t a major complaint, but it can be a bit iffy sometimes- The comedy aspect of it also plays into the awkwardness of the quotes. One example would be the Order 66 quote where Palpitine accidentally said Order 67 (the comedic aspect), and then corrected himself to say Order 66. But when he said this, what was supposed to be a very serious and dramatic event, ended up being an awkward moment of: “Okay.. He said the quote and the line, but all the Clone Troopers are still dancing in the background.. I don’t feel as bad, sad, or shocked at this…” Another example would be when Vader reveals he’s Luke’s father. The scene is perfect, Luke is hanging from the small platform and Vader is looking down at him, the music is playing and a scene of tension is created. Then, the line comes in which shocked everyone around the world, “Luke, I am your father..” and Luke screams and denies the claim. And then all of a sudden it’s ruined entirely by R2D2 coming in and doing his scream which causes the reaction of Vader kicking him off the platform and Luke jumping after him. See what I mean? The quotes are there, and they’re great, but the comedic aspect and sequences of the game ruins the tension, the feels, the suspense, and all those other emotions that the movie gave us when watching it, or for players that are just now experiencing a Star Wars Lego game for the first time. The voice acting in this game is God awful and I despise it entirely. The VA’s for the characters barely show any emotions when speaking in serious/dramatic events. The VA’s don’t put in any effort (or it seems that way) to convey the seriousness of the situation, and the acting is very awkward at a lot of points throughout the game. A lot of the characters sound nothing like they originally did in the movies and the fill-ins or whatever they’re called didn’t do a great job at all when it came to the voice acting of the characters- (And I know what a lot of you all are probably thinking, “What about Leia?” We all sadly lost Carrie Fisher years ago too soon, and I’m 100% willing to give credit where it’s due for the new VA of Leia in this game for she honestly did a decently good job. Also yes, I'm aware that the VA's for the Clone Wars TV series came in for episodes I - III and honestly they didn't do that bad either- Everything else though is total trash). As I finish writing this review, I’ve slowly started to realize that while I enjoy this game by myself, or playing it with my best friend, I can’t seem to find a way to recommend this game to people. This game has its good aspects, and introduces new features and some things that a lot of Lego Star Wars fans have been asking for since the first game came out. But with those good aspects, in my eyes the bad parts of it seem to outweigh the good parts of it- I can click with this game very well, and I enjoy my time playing it with friends, I really do. But with all these negative flaws, after about 30 minutes to an hour of gameplay, I just get tired of it all and go and play something else- Maybe I’m just so used to how all the original Lego Star Wars games are, maybe I’m just hooked on the “nostalgia” trip of the old games that this game gave me when I first played it and it’s causing me to not see this game in its full pride, glory, and fun and I miss how the old games are. I don’t know what the reason is, but whatever it is is causing me to feel this way and feel these things about this game. I guess what you can rule this review down to is a love-hate relationship. If you’ve made it this far in the review, thank you for reading this. It means a lot :)

author: Cheesehead
review: This Lego game has a lot of good ideas and changes up the formula a bit. Unfortunately, it seems a tad rushed or something. There's some pretty silly moments that are at least trying to be creative with the story.The character models are where you can see what the budget was mostly spent on. They are well animated and nice to look at. The "skill tree" and upgrade system got some changes. I think it's nice and well thought out.It's pretty much a typical Lego game with no challenge whatsoever. That's fine if you like that sort of thing.The biggest issue I have with this game is just the serious lack of action. Battle sequences just seem they could have been done way better. They are also pretty short. It's pretty disappointing especially when you have a bunch of upgrades that won't add up to a drop of bantha poodoo. You essentially don't need them. It's just around for completionests sake.The maps and scenery is nice. It's more of a collectible game than it is anything else. Finish the stories, and just hunt for stuff. It's not bad, but could have been better obviously.Overall, it's ok. At least it's not a complete disaster, but I was sort of expecting more. It's almost as if the group of people responsible for the action sequences where completely terrified of having too much of it in order not to offend anyone. Can't have that now, can we? We don't want to upset any of the weenies out there.Heck. We currently live in a world where one ill-advised slap causes the entire internet to go into a total frenzy. It wasn't that long ago where this would have been cool to see, and then we went on with our lives the next day.I guess the deal now is don't expect too much, and you won't be disappointed. Shut up and consume more product damn you.The Dark Side still has cookies.

author: Inzaniity
review: I was hyped from the moment I heard about the game. I preordered it, even the deluxe edition. Played the game and I cannot recommend it to someone who was hoping the game brings everything from the old Lego Star Wars games + new content. The game suffers from bugs and glitches which are ranging from texture issues to STORY BREAKING bugs. I encountered such story breaking bug myself, can't finish episode 3 because there is no mission anymore. There is also a story breaking bug in episode 7 which prevents you from progressing further into episodes 8 and 9. Currently there is no fix for those story breaking bugs and you either have to start a new save, on which you can encounter the same issues, or just don't play that episode. Which in some cases mean, don't play an entire trilogy until, eventually, it will get patched. You have 4 or 5 missions per episode which, compared to the old games, is nothing. The game could have been huge, but it feels like they narrowed it down to the "most iconic moments" in each episode. Free play just doesn't work in some instances. You have to use the mission's spaceship and can't choose which one you want to ride. But then you can often just switch characters in missions that you didn't enter with free play.There are no big battles like Geonosis, Coruscant, Endor or Crait. Mechanics that you COULD use at the very beginning (at least with the pre-purchase / deluxe character pack) are locked behind progression in the episodes (talking about scavengers)The game hides the fact that characters get killed at all costs (Jango Fett for instance).I really want to love the game, but all those facts combined and high expectations make it at best okay-ish.

author: Long, Tan, and Handsome
review: I'm writing this just after beating the game 100%.     When starting this game, I made a decision that I wasn't expecting when getting the game, which was keeping the non-mumble dialogue on. I figured this wasn't going to be a simple remake of the game I played on the Xbox 360, so there's no bother trying to pretend it was. It turns out, this was possibly the best decision I could have made before playing. As noted by most who've played the game by now, the levels aren't in the forefront. This is especially apparent after playing every level, as I have a theory on how they made the levels. It seems they intended on trying to stray away from making their levels look repetitive compared to the original game, so moments that aren't in the original game are spotlighted. For example, one of the levels in Phantom Menace takes place on the battle of Naboo as the Gungans. No level of the retaking, or even leaving, of Theed takes place. Because the levels are much smaller and less important to the gameplay, they can tend to be forgettable or even frustrating. The Force Awakens level Starkiller Queen was easily among the most poorly made boss fight I've seen in a very long time. An incredibly boring and confusing level, a significant portion of the level is finding out what move to make. And not only is the level  far too long and not nearly full enough, it's also horribly buggy.     This game feels as if it was released just a tad too early. Almost no polishing feels done, leading to many bugs. The Starkiller Queen level broke on me a few times while trying to beat it 100% due to a Stormtrooper spawning in a place I couldn't reach, not letting the next sequence continue. Other major bugs occur constantly, and I lost count the amount of times I've crashed after a dozen. (It was well above a dozen times.) Boss fights can also be notably terrible, such as the Canyon Krayt Dragon. Simply adding extra health and making attacks more frequent make for a long boss fight that adds nothing but bland minutes to the game. If the frustrating levels don't tire you, the bugs certainly will.     Over the hours of completion, I felt many of them be filled with impatience and apathy to the screen. But the other 80% of the game is pure bliss. The open world is almost entirely fun, actively rewarding you for exploring as much as you can find. Every world is fun, and it's easy to see that thought was put into the worlds. When playing through the worlds, I also found that the game had an intense charm to it. The cutscenes were hilarious, the character descriptions had jokes in them, even the mission names have delicious puns sprinkled along. And not only are the missions all names, but the level challenges, minikits, races, and even the puzzles are all named. Even the puzzles are named. That means almost every Kyber Brick in the game has a name associated with it.     Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga feels rushed, particularly in the small levels and the absent polish, but the open world (the main portion of the game) and the charm that outmatches even the original game makes it one of the more enjoyable experiences I've had in an open world game. It definitely isn't like the original, and it was a move that made the game much more intriguing than i expected. If the bugs were squashed and a post-game polish was added, I would argue this to a contender for best Lego game of all time. But for now, I will call it the best recent Lego game, and one of the better Star Wars games.

author: gregorhoot
review: I've never played the complete saga. The other Lego games I have are The Incredibles and Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures. The Incredibles is the other one I own that has voice acting. The voice acting is done well, some of the original cast is there, but here they just refuse to have anyone from the movies. The only returning cast actor I know of is Anthony Daniels as C3PO. The voice acting is unnatural, there are annoying walking sections where all you do is walk and talk. Each movie only has 5 levels, which is a little lackluster in comparison to The Incredibles and Indiana Jones, which have 6 levels per movie. When you want to put away your light saber you press E by default, that's the same keybind as a force push so you end up killing your other character(s) instead of putting away the lightsaber. The puzzles here are too repetitive and too easy, except for one level in The Force Awakens. In Lego Indiana Jones there are some puzzles that are genuinely hard to find out the solution to the first time around. The only mechanic that is not repeating in the campaign is detaching C3PO's legs. It's only ever used in the final boss of Revenge of the Sith. Mumble mode is probably one of the worst parts of this game. Not because I prefer dialogue, but the lego games before DC Superheroes were designed for that. This game has terrible lip sync in mumble mode and you have to read the subtitles to know what the heck is going on. The game also offers you a freeplay mode, which is also pretty bad. There are only enemies in space so you will find yourself just walking around and doing the same boring things. The menus are very overcomplicated compared to other lego games and hard to navigate. The game has a capital ships. This is exciting at first, but it's just a cheap way at making it look like you can control the ships but all you can do is just explore them and move them around. The bosses are incredibly bad. Everyone with a lightsaber is the same stuff over and over again. No different animations, nothing! This game's characters have few variations. All of the characters look different, but have few variations of abilities. The characters in The Incredibles and Indiana Jones are more unique and have more variation than the characters in this game. Overall, this game isn't very impressive or the best lego game of all time. But there are some things I can praise it for. The visuals look very nice and have many realistic details of lego minifigures. The characters will have a little bit of sand on them after walking in sandy planets. Also, they made Jar Jar Bink's humor better, while most of the time not rolling around laughing. They also fixed some of the things wrong with the sequel trilogy. My favorite change being removing Rey and Kylo's kiss after the final boss at the end of the game. However, this is not the best lego game of all time like people in the comments of criticisms of this game say it is. Just buy the complete saga, I've seen videos of it and it actually looks fun, but I played this game too much for a refund before I knew it was bad. Lastly, I find it disgusting that Travelers Tales forced their employees to work overtime to make such a terrible game.

author: AmbiguousOne
review: It's ok.The Skywalker Saga brings plenty of new ideas to the lego series. The game brings excellent voice acting and charming traditional lego humor that can be very hit or miss. Hub worlds are massively expansive in both size and number, and the levels often showcase different scenes of the movie than previous games. Even though the massive character roster makes everything fall into a half dozen nearly identical sets of skills, you've got plenty of options for flair. This time around, the majority of the story takes place in the hub worlds, and levels are only introduced for space battles and boss fights, with a few exceptions, at a much shorter level runtime. I rate this positively because the above concepts made for an enjoyable story mode playthrough with some minor hub exploration in between. Once you pass that point, you'll really start to notice the game's major flaws in design. So many minor irritations begin to add up over the course of full game completion. Look ahead to see what isn't great about this one.To start, expect to crash and softlock at least a dozen times, each time in a different way.It'll take you about 2 minutes from startup to actually get in game, almost none of which is a necessary loading screen.Character selection, post-level, and certain other moments do not pause the game, which will lead to you forcibly dying without any opportunity to input.Certain enemies go invincible or have massive damage resistance at awkward times.The upgrade system lets you choose what you want at little cost. Not having the limitations and surprise of  the red power bricks means you'll funnel your upgrade resources into abilities that allow you to become too strong, too fast. A separate list of upgrades allow you to take major powers (score x2, universal translation) or absolute cosmetics at massive prices with no in-between; obviously the cosmetics will end up ignored.The hubs have 30-40 puzzles each, most of which extremely simple, but having the same puzzles in multiple hubs becomes repetitive.Additionally, most of the 700 puzzles have a rumor told by a nearby npc, but having access to a detector so early means you'll end up ignoring those 5 hours of voice lines and just look for the blue circles around your screen.Most characters have their own sidequest before you can purchase them, but once again, they are all very repetitive and hardly unique. There's about 20 of the same smuggle quest where you warp to a small arena to fight off 10 baddies three times in a row. Skywalker Saga is so heavily padded with this type of content, so despite a full completion taking ~100 hours, a lot of it is developer fluff.The levels themselves are far worse, especially for free play. Boss fights are interesting the first few times, but all of them have the same patterns. There's more than a few levels with a permanent alarm blaring the whole time, which can only go away if you remove sound effects entirely. Controller rumble is far too much, especially in space battles that throw 20 enemies all firing on you at once. These game designers were completely against free play exploration - there's many no-return points in every level that have no real reason to be there, which becomes more problematic when you consider this lego game has multiple paths through each level. Even in free play, the game will autolock certain characters for some sequences, forcing you to navigate an already difficult UI screen to return to using the characters you like, if it even lets you. The three challenges they've added to each level sound fun on paper but disturb the pacing of your exploration, since for a lot of them you only get one shot to achieve it.All these small gripes simply make this game less fun than it could have been.If you're a completionist, I recommend The Complete Saga for a much more enjoyable experience. But for everyone else, story mode of The Skywalker Saga will bring you a good time. Just make sure to stop at the end of the story.

author: ABSINISTER

author: The_Cpt_FROGGY
review: LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ People of my generation were blessed to grow up with one of the most iconic movie trilogies ever made, Star Wars episodes IV, V and VI. And to be young enough to play with the first Lego figurine introduced on the market in 1979. I can still remember the day I received my first Legos set with the astronauts/space figurine as it was Christmas. So, you can imagine my smile when I had the opportunity to play the latest LEGO videogame, LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga! I simply couldn't resist feeling the force again!LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga is an action/adventure and exploration game based on the nine Star Wars movies. The game was developed by TT Games and Published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment on the 6th of April 2022 on the Steam platform. The game is also available on Nintendo Switch, PS4/PS5, Xbox One and Xbox One Series X|S.The game consists of all nine Star Wars episodes, which include a faithful reproduction of all nine movies in terms of the story, and each has 5 main missions to complete to finish an episode. Plus, a total of 140 side missions shared between 23 planets. You'll need to talk to NPCs to find these side missions. In addition, the game has a large open world to explore with a massive number of collectables to find. At the time of writing this review, with over 27 hours of gameplay, I have only completed the first 6 episodes of the game, finding on average 30% of all the collectables per episode. There is a tremendous amount of content in this game, which is very impressive. I reckon it will take a few hundred hours to complete the entire game. As you finish an episode, you will unlock the next Star Wars episode, but the episode you completed will become free to play so you can revisit it and try to acquire all the collectables. However, when you launch the game for the first time, only episodes I and IV will be available for you to play. As I am a big fan of the first trilogy, I chose to play episode IV, The New Hope. I was really impressed with the game's fluidity, from the story to the main missions and the Lego brand's humour through fabulous cutscenes. As I finished the first, second and third episodes, my thirst for experiencing the entire Saga became overwhelming. I just had to go through the next three episodes, no matter what! Even after finishing those episodes, instead of going back to collect all the items, I was compelled to play the next one, even though I am not a fan of where Disney is taking this incredible series. But being totally immersed in the game is only one thing. The progression structure is just amazing! You have core upgrades as well as classes upgrades. There are 9 classes in total, and each has 12 upgrades to unlock. Yes, it will cost you a fair bit of studs and a certain number of Kyber bricks each time you do an upgrade, but it will take you quite a while to claim all 1,100 Kyber Bricks. You also have Datacards to find.  They’re not easy to find, but when you do you can unlock very interesting upgrades.And that’s not all! There are stacks of puzzles to do. Some are fairly simple, but others are not easy, especially if you require a specific class/character to complete the puzzle. They are 100's of puzzles in this game. For me, one of the best aspects of the game is the combat system. Each of the classes has its own style, and it is easy to use and extremely fluid for both melee and distance weapons; it is just a joy to play. There is a lot to explore in this game which is another aspect of the game that I absolutely love.The graphics and animations are sensational. In terms of soundtrack, it is always a treat to listen to the Imperial March. Voice-overs and sound effects are really entertaining and true to the original movies. The gamepedia is easy to access and full of content. It's a game that you can leave, come back to when you feel like it, pick up where you left off and keep enjoying it over and over again. If you are a fan of Lego and the Star Wars series, you have to play it to experience it.I did have a few issues. Not too many, but I had to restart the game a few times as it froze while launching a cutscene. Not a big deal, but nonetheless annoying. You can play with your keyboard, but I recommend the gamepad for this one. You can play single player or co-op on the same computer if you have two gamepads (or one person on the keyboard) or via the remote play Steam feature. Positives:~~~~~~~ +	Sensational graphics, soundtrack and sound effects+	True to the movies and with an abundance of Lego Humour +	100s of characters and ships to unlock+	Well-structured progression system, both for the core play and classes+	Jam-packed with content (side missions and collectables)+	Thorough gamepedia+	Easy to play, extremely addictive and huge replayability+	AchievementsNegatives:~~~~~~~~ -	No trading cards as yet-	I experienced a few freezes with cutscenesIt’s a Saga like no other! It’s fun, addictive, has great humour all the way through, and is full of content. Experience the brick side of the force.9/10Key provided by the developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

author: BuckyKat
review: I wish I could recommend this game, as the visuals are great and it’s fun to roam about different areas from the Star Wars universe, but unfortunately it has too problems and there are frequent frustrations that previous Lego games didn’t have.MAIN STORY AND OPEN-WORLD CONTENTUnless you’re going for 100% completion and all 45 achievements, this game likely isn’t going to take long. While there are 45 main story missions to play through, as there are five story missions for each of the nine movies, there were far too many story missions that can be completed in just a few minutes. There are a few levels that can take a bit to complete like Episode VII’s “Reap what You Solo” mission where you’re switching between two character parties and solving puzzles along the way to advance. There are also a few levels, like Episode VI’s “Boarding Party”, that are a decent length in story more but then allow for more playtime during freeplay mode as selectable characters with specific abilities can unlock new areas to explore, but there aren’t many levels built this way. Finally, there are quite a few extremely short levels, like Episode VIII’s “Dameron’s Definance”, where you can easily finish it in under five minutes.While it’s not unusual to spend less time in the main campaign of a Lego game than it is collecting everything the game has to offer, going for full completion is going to take a significant amount of time. You have the normal 100% completion for each level, collecting characters and kyber bricks on each planet and planet space, but the most amount of time will be spent simply spent traveling to other planets performing fetch quests. This shouldn’t be bad, but the traveling will begin to weigh on you as you’re really just waiting for the planet’s areas to load.THE NEW CAMERA AND ACTION PROMPTSThe new over-the-shoulder camera does allow for a better feeling of being each character, but it also introduces a problem with receiving prompts corresponding to objects and actions. In previous Lego games, when your character was in range of a jump/grapple point or an object they could interact with, a prompt would appear simply because they were in the range of it. Now it’s a combination of your distance to the object and if the camera can see it. There are frequent moments where you can be under a grapple point but because you can’t get the camera to look directly up at the point you won’t get the prompt to grapple to it. This requires you move farther away from the wall or ledge in order for it be in view of the camera.A similar problem exists with objects specific to Jedi powers. If the object is above or below you and even if the camera can see it, you will spend some time trying to reposition your character so you’re in the right range to grab the object. The difficulty is not knowing if you’re too close or too far away from objects so you’ll be spending a little time moving towards and/or away attempting to find where you have to be in order to grab the object. There are also moments where you’ll be approaching the object, the prompt will appear, so you stop moving but then the prompt disappears. In moments like this I found that rotating the camera a little will sometimes get the prompt to then appear, but it generally resulted in moving my character around in order to find a place where the prompt would finally appear again.DROPPING WITH GRAPPLING HOOK CHARACTERSAn additional frustration with the jump/grapple points is the inability to drop from a hanging point when using a character that has a grappling hook. When playing as a non-grappling hook character you can press a button to let go of a jump/grapple point which allows you to drop down. When playing as a grappling hook character the drop button is used as the grapple button. While it is possible to jump away from the jump/grapple point, it only occurs if you can manage to only have the grapple prompt on screen which can be difficult because most jump/grapple points are so close together that the jump prompt is almost always available.While the first jump grapple point will generally be a grapple prompt, the game has you jump up to almost all higher or next points but grapple down or back to previous points. This really doesn’t make sense but is why it’s difficult to jump away. If you do manage to jump away from the jump/grapple point, you’ll generally land back on the same jump/grapple point as you will jump up above the point and then land right back on it again.CHARACTER SWITCHINGAnother big change is how you switch characters. Instead of a large on-screen grid showing all the characters in the game, they’re now grouped into different types such as Jedi, Scavengers, and Scoundrels. In previous games this categorization had been fairly easy to navigate as you could switch between the groups by pressing a button and the different types of characters would light up in the grid. Character switching now seems to be needlessly complex.To switch to get a character in a different group, you have to bring up the character select menu, and either move over characters in the current group until you reach the group navigation or press the back button to go directly to the group navigation, scroll up to down to the new group, move to the right into that group’s character grid, and then navigate across characters until you reach the character you want. Because of this major change to the character selection process, it takes far longer to select a different character than it ever used to.While I did say that characters are grouped into types, there is a group that does show you an entire roster of all the characters together but you can’t see every single character on screen at once. You’re also unable to sort or highlight specific character types so if you currently have Anakin Skywalker selected, it’s going to take a decent amount of scrolling to get to Wedge Antilles.OBJECT LOCATION ARROWSIn an attempt to help you keep track of the location of objectives, mission specific enemies and collectables in relation to your character, arrows appear around the sides of the screen. The arrows always point to an object and as you turn and move the camera the arrows will generally rotate around the edge of the screen as a way to help you understand where the object is in relation to the camera. This would likely be great if you only played in an overhead perspective. It becomes difficult in understanding this information in three-dimensional spaces and the game has issues with the arrows jumping around depending on where the object is and the direction the camera is facing.For instance, there isn’t a simple way to know if an arrow at the bottom of the screen is indicating that an object is behind you, below you, or possibly both. Rotating around the character won’t change the position of the arrow if the object was both below and behind you. As you clear out these objects it becomes easier to figure out where objects are, but when you are initially entering a new level and you have 30+ arrows on the screen because you’ve unlocked and enabled the Collectible Detector 3 in the upgrade tree, it’s very difficult to follow just one specific arrow to understand where that object is.This issue is further complicated when you’re flying and need to destroy enemy ships. An arrow that points to a ship can be difficult to find if it’s circling around behind you as you’re also trying to turn towards them. In these types of encounters the difficulty is in trying to figure out where the other ship is rather than difficulty in trying to shoot it down.

review: This is without a doubt the BEST Lego game ever made. And this comes from a person who played every single Lego game you can think of. When playing the first chapter (The Phantom Menace) I thought that this could the be 2nd best since Lego Batman 1 is one of my all-time favorites (played the game with my dad when I was 7-8 years old, ah those good times... I miss them.) but man was I wrong lol. After playing Revenge of the Sith, I just KNEW this game was going to be a freaking blast. If you're having doubts about the price, it's COMPLETELY worth it. I mean there are 9 freaking chapters in this saga, you do realize that, right? In conclusion, my honest opinion about this masterpiece is...10/10, in other words, perfection. Have fun then!

author: Salad
review: After 100% the game, and around 40 hours. I can't recommend this game.. While it's nice to see a multitude of characters, it becomes overwhelming very fast, you beat a level only to be flooded with 8 characters unlocked, some of which you've not played in the level. The puzzles are painfully bland, in just about every mission the only puzzles that exist are panels in which are either slow, or annoying to control because of a pause between actions. The charm that previous LEGO games had during the levels in practically gone, cut scenes still have them which is nice, but there's no fun animations or surprises to really be found during gameplay. Level design is horrendous, levels are either way too short, or way too long, there's no good in-between, and a majority of it is just a walking simulator, as well as constantly light-speed jumping to other planets, or taking a vehicle to different parts of the map in a long boring back and forth. Dark side characters are boring cause the only distinct thing about them is that using the force on someone is changed into a force choke (I've later discovered Palpatine has the ability to use lightning. This is still pathetic as it's a melee and not actually a beam like older games). Character specialties are boring and annoying because in free play rather than being able to do multiple things with a character that is later in the franchise, you have to switch back and forth from different characters. An example of this is Rey.. Lets say a free play puzzle has a net puzzle, some lightsaber parts, and a grapple part.. If you were to use Rey only, you would have to switch between 3 different versions because even though an episode 9 version of Rey has been through the previous situations and episodes, doesn't matter cause right now you're playing Yellow lightsaber Rey who doesn't know ♥♥♥♥. The removal of character abilities being gained through progression just makes everything tedious and is an excuse to shove more characters into the game for no reason, of which a majority of characters is just different clothing. DLC characters are very lacking, sure it's fun to have access to more characters but also there is hardly unique dialogue, interactions, or abilities. I bought the Deluxe Edition for $60, and have only played a few DLC characters once, and that was to look at them. The removal of a custom character creator makes the creativity and fun of it, there is something so exciting and fun to be able to mix and match character parts to make a unique character, and that being removed really brought it down for me, other than the disappointing nature of the game itself. UI is clunky and distracting, it constantly gets in the way, the combo meter can be fun sometimes but it's really unnecessary. Combat is fine, just the barricade system is useless and dumb, they break after like 2 hits, and serve no purpose other than to save you 2 shots that don't entirely matter.I know this review is all over the place, but overall... the game is bland, boring, and a waste of time, watch someone play it on YT if you're really that interested. If I could get a refund I would, but I spent so much time hoping and praying that even after a painstakingly dreadfully long ascend to 100% I would like the game, but I don't.. Uninstalled after 100% cause what else is there to do, nothing is really fun.

Overall I don't think its worth the money at all, if you can get it half off go for it then

author: Enemy of the People
review: Game is a mess from a technical standpoint, which only detracts from the experience. And the experience itself isnt all that great to begin with. And now they are announcing DLC without patching the game for a month since release. So, they went for the Mario Odyssey-like approach to collecting stuff. Dozens of short missions in every location. Smaller rewards instead of big milestones. Means a single brick is meaningless in a long run, besides getting that 100%. Not my cup of tea, but a matter of preference. Open worlds themselves are fine, although a little glitchy. Character controls are fine, although camera is awful especially when aiming weapons. Menus are the absolute worst, slow and awful to navigate. Having to hold buttons to confirm something is some of the worst user experience you can go for. And there is a LOT of menuing. How you play the game is also allright. Its quite slow as they swapped normal actions into QTEs that are tied to animations, meaning climbing went from jump-jump into press B, wait for the animation to finish, press B. Takes about three times as long, and is less fun. Just why. The combo system is fine, controls are a bit iffy because animations are a mess but it does its job. Shooting is fine, although lacks weight behind shots. Presentation is great. Sometimes the scenery makes me want to stop and just admire it for short few moments. And whenever the designers utilize the LEGO assets as replacements its charming and fits well. The music is John Williams, enough said. The problems start with the voice acting. I dont know if its because they wanted to get additional lines to fit the writing, or because (((Disney))) forced them to rewrite history before their buyout, but multiple characters have been redubbed. You dont hear Harrison Ford as Han Solo, you hear that le Marvel ecks dee dude from that movie noone watched. The advertised Mumble mode wouldve fixed that problem, but it doesnt work......and thats just the tip of the iceberg. Mumble mode despite being the only saving grace from not hearing mr.no-charisma every 5 seconds, completly breaks the game. Cutscenes might not progress, scripted sequences might softlock, you might not get written dialogue. And the game is riddled with glitched like that. Doing the smuggling missions in space? Prepare to get spawned INSIDE the model of your capital ship. Dogfighting in space? Enemy markers disappear, have fun looking for BLACK fighters on SPACE background. Models disappearing? Objects breaking on their own? Random long loadtimes? Yep, its all there. And more.If you're gonna buy it, do it on sale. And wait for patches. And dont get the completly pointless DLC with disneyverse characters noone cares about. Its an allright game, but i'd play the originals over this any day of the week. Its a muddled mess with some redeeming factors but a lot of things that just piss you off which culminates in you closing the game and going to play something else. Or watching paint dry, at least you dont roll your eyes because of the voice acting.

author: Drosophila Melanogaster
review: Ok I would never recommend anyone pay full price for this game. I got it on sale for $25. That is fine, it is worth $25. It is not worth 50 or 60 or whatever the regular price is. It is SO GLITCHY. And that is even more inexcusable knowing they delayed this game three or four times .... to do what, exactly?? THE BADGlitches I have experienced after doing episodes 4-6:Darth vader just froze during a battle so I had to restart the levelCrashes when triggering an explosionTried to open a weapons cache at the top of a set of stairs while on the stairs and my character got stuck in the running animationStuff blowing up when it isn't supposed to, or not blowing up when it is supposed toThis game is also super hand-holdy. Expect an on screen prompt about what button to press every time you need to grab a switch, use the force,  or build something. You are not smart enough to figure out or remember that the jumping bricks mean you should build. You will get this reminder forever. All of the movement when you are doing anything other than walking around feels so weird. Flying feels weird although it is better than the previous game because now you have 3 axes of movement instead of two. But flying is jank. Speeder bikes are jank. Being in the AT-ST is jank. There are so many things i am shocked didn't get fixed for QOL. When you are in the AT-ST every time another AT-ST shoots you, your vehicle jerks and the camera snaps around to the center. Why?Why is the camera so far up my backside when I'm running around? It took forever to get used to this and makes it hard to see where studs are going when I blow stuff up, because they are behind me and I CAN'T SEE. I walked backwards into a lot of pits at first. I was getting stuck in corners in corridors and the camera was going nuts, all over the place.I have not finished the game by any means but should I really be 60% done with Episode V when I sped through it to finish the store and didn't make an effort to get any collectibles in particular? Plus there are only 5 minikits in each level now instead of 10. No red bricks. This game is all about the collectibles. LEGO Lord of the Rings had a fully open world with 10 chests in every level. They are also cheating a bit by having True  Jedi split into segments and that giving you three Kyber bricks just for getting True Jedi.Padding. You now have to do a minigame every time you want to use a wall panel. Why is  this? Were we really upset before about just pressing E and waiting one second? it is so boring. The little minigames don't require any thought or skill. They are just there to artificially lengthen the game.THE GOODThis game is so funny. I have seen people saying it doesn't "feel right" because of the voice acting but I think this one is funnier than the last one. And I didn't think it was too obtrusive or in your face. The voice actors are very good approximations of the real characters and you will probably barely notice unless you just got done watching the films. There is more "stuff" to do. You can do Jedi mind tricks, for instance,  which is full of chaotic possibility. You can throw your lightsaber. Combat is still too simple to be interesting but it is way better than the endless button spam of the previous one. Moving stuff with the force is better because you can move things any way you want and throw objects to fight instead of like before where objects moved in a predetermined way.QOL improvements. C3PO no longer does a painful shuffle. R2D2 has fighting abilities. Your companions damage other enemies and do not just charge blindly into danger although you'll have to do much of the fighting yourself. The flying levels are way better; they took the worst stuff from the  old game and improved it.VERDICT: Do not buy at full cost. I'm going  to beat it but then I'm probably just going to replay LEGO LOTR again because that game rules.EDIT AFTER BEATING STORY: So I played through all 9 episodes in story mode and absolutely nothing in my mind has changed other than that I think this game really shines in the side content. There are some truly delightful side missions in this game that I think most people are going to miss because they're going to get bored. Notably the achievement you get for finishing all the episodes is only owned by 19% of players. Less than ONE IN FIVE players finished story mode in this game and it's been out for a long time. What do you think the percentage was on the original? more than that. One of my friends pointed out that the reason why I hate this game is that there is no platforming and he is correct. Gameplay is entirely "run to this glowing light, press buttons, run to this one."

author: Kumi Creami
review: First off, I just wanna say that I’m more than glad that this game exists. The Complete Saga was just a very fond childhood memory of mine on the PS2. And this one would probably create another good memory for me. Its visual is stunning, and the gameplay was a massive improvement; there’s actually something to it rather than just spamming buttons. My only minor complain I have for the game is the fact that its comedy was sometimes too over the top(?) I was a big fan of the subtle humour in the Complete Sage back in the day with the mumble voice, which yes, I am aware there’s an option for that here, but still. Other than that though, this game was not only a fantastic nostalgia trip, but also a very well-crafted game with lots of love put into it. 9/10

author: Pls may i gave some more lasage
review: Giving this  a negative review because despite the fact that I think it's a good game, it has way too many things going against it for me. Imma keep this short though.1: The game has awful optimization. I can't use a controller no matter what I try to do. No matter what, my leftward movement is disabled.2: The DLC is a deceptive cash grab. There's unfortunately no additional levels in these DLC's, unlike Lego TFA, and the characters that included HAVE NO VOICE LINES, unlike the entire base game cast. Even the special extra characters like Sith Rey had a bunch of funny voice lines. For a franchise that forced voiced characters in their games so many times, having the DLC miss that is ridiculous. All they had to do was rip lines from the films and shows they were based on, but they were somehow too lazy to do that.3: Only around 1/2 of each film is replayable. The rest of the film is experienced in a one-off exploration sequence that can't be replayed. A lot of the most iconic parts of the films aren't in the levels either. What's more, these levels aren't even of a superb quality, they're only a bit better than the Batman 3 and Marvel Superheroes levels, and those were terrible.Overall this game isn't bad, but there is questionable quality and consistency. The sequels unexpectedly shine here, because the dialogue jokes about the flaws of the films, but without being weird and cringey, like some Reddit user. They also succeed tremendously in pointing out the high points of them.I absolutely wouldn't buy this on PC though. The trend of Lego games sucking on PC is unfortunately continuing with this entry. The fact that they fail to have proper controller support for a game designed to be played with one is unacceptable.

author: sawah
review: This game doesn't know if it wants to be an RPG or liner and level-based game. What you get is a cluttered mishmash of both and a clunky UI. The game wants you to explore, find side missions and lego pieces, build out your talent tree, talk to other characters, etc., but then essentially annoys you into progressing the story line. There's a constant feeling that you're racing against the clock. Want to try to stay with the Gungans and explore? Well you have Jar Jar yelling in your ear that we need to go, "Disa way!" and a bright spark guiding you every 5 ft towards your main objective. Nothing from the RPG aspect is straighforward. Because you are constantly being directed to work on your main objective, you don't get the time to familiarize yourself with your glorified Smart Watch, which makes the game extremely clunky and an overall headache. Don't even get me started on the absurd camera angle or the sloppiness of the controls.

author: samuelv1029
review: I have played Lego star wars when I was younger and this game has topped the others. Even though I am only 15 I have memories of playing Lego games on my DS and Wii and this game is so much more than I expected. I love the quality, the animations, and the dialogue. I also love how they added an open world aspect to the game so you can explore the planets and galaxies as any character you want flying any ship you want. The last thing is I have played this game for about 5 1/2 hours at the time of writing and have only finished the 4th and 5th movie! There is so much detail and things to complete you can spend hours playing a single movie.

author: Fisty Dollars
review: A very visually impressive game that also manages to feel very, very empty. There's so much side stuff to find and unlock, but there's only 5 actual levels per episode, and some *major* things are reduced to cutscenes. I was heartbroken when I realized they really weren't going to do the Space Battle over Endor, but were just making it a quippy 20 second cinematic. The open world levels are neat, and fun to play around it, but I wish more time had been spent making the actual game and not padding it with Assassin's Creed Valhalla levels of unnecessary "stuff" to do and find rather than having actual fun playing the actual game. What a huge disappointment.

author: Frysbe
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis the Wise? I thought not. It's not a story the Jedi would tell you. It's a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life... He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful... the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. It's ironic he could save others from death, but not himself.

Not a lot of replay ability, most of the fun from this game comes from the story mode, and the couch coop(please add online, i beg). If you are a perfectionist and need to get that 100%, this game offers tons of characters and collectibles to hunt. overall this game at its core is a really good game, hopefully in the future TT games add something to get us to come back to this game. 9/10 will make your summer.

author: 69_Yoda_420
review: From the perspective of the second player:Visuals? Great, very nice to look at.Cutscenes? They have the funny.Puzzles? Garbage, mostly just using panels or moving an object into place and spamming a button. Dark side doesn't exist in this game.Parkour? Nonexistent, you have to look at something and press a button.Combat? Actually quite nice, unless you start to progress. If you continue to progress, you will do less and less combat.Aerial combat? quite bad, just fly and shootBosses? All the same, either shoot or spam lightsaber attacks or get out of the way. Darth Maul was the best fight because it worked in 2 player and because it was the first boss fight.Character Roster? Too much, and the categorized characters are just too similar to each other. Jetpacks and gliders are too short, and many characters like mandalorian characters and dark side characters just don't have the abilities that they should. For example, many dark side characters that should have had lightning just don't have it for some reason, and no mandalorian character has any gun other than their blasters.Collectibles? Too many of them, and some upgrades are just too expensive and not worth it.Upgrades? Many of the great and original upgrades from the clone wars and TCS video games were scrapped, and the new ones can't even be obtained in levels. Fun upgrades like dual wielding, super speeders, actually fun super gonk, and dark side were completely scrapped.Multiplayer? Horrible, not only does this game not have online multiplayer, but the second player's (my) gameplay is honestly insulting in most levels. Usually, the only thing I can do is do the chores while the first player defeats the boss.Final Review: Boring; don't buy this game unless you really like star wars or lego, or have some sort of nostalgia. It looked and felt good at first, but the moment that I started thinking about it, I just found this game kinda boring.
