author: Jub
review: Overall a really good game.I enjoyed it a lot. The worlds look great, so do all the assets but I was expecting more still.Especially when it comes to the missions and space combat.The missions are SUPER short, very rushed and the fact that battle over coruscant is literally just a cutscene... That hurt. Space combat is very limited, them advertising how you'll fly around in your capital ships.. Yea no. - When it comes to optimization, I did not experience a single crash nor stutters. (I do have a powerful rig though, so I don't know what it's like for others)- Visually great. I love the graphics. The detail is amazing and everything is made with care.- Gameplay is fun but don't expect too much out of it. It is kept quite limited.- The combat feels great! Especially the lightsabers.- Vehicles are... Barely existent. I still recommend the game 100%. Especially if you have a friend or partner to play it with.If you want to play it with an online friend, either use the Steam Together feature or whatever it's called, or use Parsec Gaming. I personally recommend Parsec. I have had my fair share of issues with the Steam one.

author: The_Iron_Minotaur
review: The price alone is simply criminal. Because this game is freaking good to the point where dare I say "price it in any way possible?" -- and when I mean good; I mean in sheer scope, volume, dialogue, and visuals. There is literally so much to do in this game that it is baffling that crunch was needed to make this game. I mean hello?! side activities? SIDE QUESTS?! so much exploration in a sandbox area it is truly baffling and will be baffling on any point or entry in the saga. And also let me just say on the record that this game alone has made the prequel and sequel trilogy much more tolerable to watch (no joke). There are only two downsides that might actually affect your opinion on the game 1) No online co-op. Yup, we are couch co-op baby! And ummm it's a bit ♥♥♥♥. Like no joke, the split screen becomes so intolerable that you really want to go full on "I AM THE SENATE" mode.2) Crunch. Let it be said that no developer in the world should have to undergo this just to make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ video game; and this is also why games shouldn't announce themselves ahead of schedule just to delay or ramp up development just to get it on the store shelf. Yes, you might be sick of hearing it- but it is fundamentally important to understand that the developers are people too! Not the suit & ties who ball and chain them into oblivion.

author: pipo monkey
review: after finishing the prequel trilogy, this game is pretty much everything i wanted. a humorous, condensed way to experience the star wars films with large explorable planets and ships. maps aren't as big as i quite imagined, but they're large enough to be enjoyable for me. combat is shallow but flashy enough to be really fun, difficulty is easy making this a great game to turn my brain off for a few hours and de-stress. upgrade system is fun to play around with and space combat is actually fun suprisingly. if you're expecting a game like the complete saga or lego batman with linear, 20 - 30 minute levels, you might be disappointed with the game but if you love other lego games like lego batman 2 and lego marvel, you'll love this as this feels like a true evolution of those games rather than a slight improvement like they have been for a while. as of writing this (day after launch), there are some technical issues but nothing game ruining imo. there are certain levels that have serious performance issues due to driver issues (droid factory in episode 2 especially) and one time a screen effect would not leave my screen until i closed out of the game but aside from those, the game has been running perfectly for me and i have encountered no crashes. hopefully the driver issues and other minor bugs like what i mentioned will be patched out soon. i will be playing through the og and sequel trilogies soon and i expect to have good fun with those too given my first impressionstl;dr great game but whether or not you like it will be up to what you're looking for. if you want a linear game like tcs you're gonna be dissapointed, but if you wanted lego batman 2/lego marvel with a star wars skin and massive gameplay overhaul, you'll be in for a great time.

author: gamersolidwolf
review: I'm writing a positive review about this game because sadly there is no middle ground. The exploration aspect is truly amazing, but, to be fair, it is not all that matters.     The previous games did a great job at telling the whole story, and this game is lacking in that aspect. An important event, the destruction of planet Alderaan, is not shown in the game, as well as the Hosnian Cataclysm in Episode VII. Also, some deaths are portrayed in a goofy way. It is evident that this has to do with the political correctness, and sometimes it does exactly the opposite of what the developers expected. Some of the most grim scenes are depicted in a humorous way, giving it an antipathetic approach, which doesn't conveys the emotions that the movie and the original games (despite the absence of dialogues) reflected and which is capable of harvesting insensibility among children and consumers in general. I believe this is very common in nowadays content.      For me, the story is one of the most important, if not the most important, aspect of a game and this game is not loyal to the source material in many occasions. In some of them it feels very rushed. And let's not talk about DLCs, which don't have any level related with the additional characters.      Regarding technical aspects, the game does a great work for most of the time. However, there are some very annoying issues such as: low fps in certain levels, unresponsiveness in combat and some interface problems related with the minimap. If games nowadays are not capable of delivering at the moment of release due to the complexity of their nature, we should really go back to the time when we had simpler games with no bugs at all.      In general, I have enjoyed the game, but, as you just read, there are many things that I wish were different. LEGO games used to be better when they didn't have high ambitions.     Edit: Overall, this game is better than its predecessor. A while a go I gave The Complete Saga a run and realized that the episodes here are longer. Additionally, some events are not portrayed in The Complete Saga. However, the fact that important events are not playable is truly disappointing. I just discovered that you can't play the destruction of Death Star II. Draw your own conclussions.     So, in order to get a complete experience of LEGO Star Wars and the Skywalker saga in general, I recommend to play The Skywalker Saga, LEGO Star Wars The Force Awakens and The Complete Saga. The latter won't take more than 10 hours and will fill the gaps that this game has.

author: DaanLikesNaan
review: Simply put this game is incredible, and I've only played the first 3 episodes. Anybody who has played a past LEGO Star Wars game or any LEGO game to be honest has to play this game, the new take on a classic formula makes the game captivating from the start, and new mechanics as well as revised old ones make this game an absolute joy to play. Easter eggs from the films and prior LEGO games makes it especially enjoyable for people who played previous LEGO Star Wars games and are big fans of the movie. The graphical changes are absolutely stunning with this game being far ahead of any other LEGO game before it with a gorgeous open world and great attention to detail.My only current quarrels with the game are that the Droid Factory mission in the Attack of the Clones is incredibly laggy and jittery which I believe to be an issue for everyone despite what graphics card they have. Additionally it would be nice to have a character customiser, which has been present in almost every other game before.But if you can't tell I'm absolutely in love with this game, and there is still more content to come in the form of DLC packs later down the line. No matter who you are or what type of games you enjoy, LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga has something for you, trust me.

author: Nerd Of The Force
review: So far I finished one episode and did a few side missions. But I have to say, while i'm still learning the controls a bit and am still getting a feel of all the game mechanics, as well as the skill sets, I am blown away by how much you are able to do in this game. Everything is laid out very nicely and neat so you can choose skills and characters, the side missions are pretty neat and enjoyable, the combat system is also one thing i'm really loving a lot of, the humor in here is far superior compared to other lego games, and the amount of freedom you have to go to different planets and SOOOO many different places on said planets is what makes the ambiance in this game breathtaking, beyond the beautiful views and graphics. This truly dose in fact have EVERYTHING you could ask for within a Star Wars trilogy based game without a doubt.I feel the ONLY thing that kinda made me a little off edge of the game was the fact that the guidance system within the game feels a little low ended for me personally, as if I have to smash and slash up everything to find clues, unlike older lego games. However, I do believe it was intended to be that way so it may just be something I have to personally get used to. But beyond that, I would also say while cutscenes are story for story missions and you get to play more of them then what you could in 1-6, I do feel they are somewhat shorter then I was expecting. Quite a bit of Episode I for me consisted of walking around instead of hacking and slashing up droids or doing objective based stuff. I can't judge the final episodes I have yet to play so they could be different, but that's just a little something I noticed.Beyond the small cons, the pros overwhelm them without a doubt with all you can do within this game. I'm looking forward to putting A LOT of time into this and beating everything within it. This is the first AAA title I have ever bought that made me happy right off the bat. Way to go on this one WB! You have me sold! The ONE thing that I personally think would make this game FULLY complete is if they add in a Clone Wars DLC pack, or even story missions. That would be amazing!!! Hope and pray though! For now, I am happy!

author: Dune Tiger
review: I think I've got enough under my belt now to see how the rest of this is going to play out.  Yes, at 20+ hours, I'm saying "the rest of this" because this game is massive.  In fact, I'd go so far as to say that it's excessive, but to be fair, that ultimately depends on whether you're a completionist or not.  The game covers all 9 mainline movies and as to be expected with TT's Lego games, there's tons of secrets, gags, and just  to discover and if you want  of it then I suggest you get real comfortable because it is a haul.  I say that as the 20ish hours I'm sitting at right now covered only one trilogy to 100% but let's not get carried away - most of that time was spent in the hub worlds between missions.  That said, if you're the type to value your games by how many hours you get out of them, then consider yourself in the best game ever? Let's break it down.I am not the biggest fan of TT's Lego series despite having played most of them and what I mean by that is that I do not leap at the chance to get the latest and greatest one and spend two weeks getting them to 100%.  I pick them up as add-ons whenever sales come rolling round because yeah, they're a good time.  I play them when I want something mindless and casual, but they're not something I look forward to.  Part of the reason for this is that none of the titles have ever held a candle to the original two Star Wars games now bundled as the "Complete Saga". The closest they came, in my opinion, were the two Harry Potter games. So rather than focus on how much this game  the Complete Saga, the only comment I'll make on that front is that if that's what you're looking for, it's not here.Skywalker Saga is a different design philosophy than what came before it as TT has been really trying to find a way to refresh the formula and it's not all that bad. Rather than having a tiny preparation hub and a string of long missions to explore, this one flips it around with shortened levels and massive "hubs", if you can call them that.  More accurately, these aren't hubs as much as they are mini worlds to explore as they change based on the movie you're going through and some are even multi-staged.  Each film gets about 4-5 story missions that run about 10-15 minutes each with the standard mini-kit hunt among other collectables, connected by a themed in-between that is freely explorable without a time limit. For example, A New Hope is initially linked together by a sprawling Tattooine as an interstitial location to explore; in other words, you'll go relive a key segment of the movie, then you're dropped back off on Tattooine before you hit up the next mission.What results is that the game feels more focused on open-world exploration with the story missions feeling like the sideshow rather than the other way around.  For some who are looking for more action and set-pieces, this can be a disappointment.  For others, it can be the perfect casual jaunt... sort of.  The thing is, like most open-worlds, these huge maps that sit between the missions often feel rather empty.  The goal here is to uncover all of its secrets, picking up special bricks, unlocking characters and/or vehicles or simply farming Lego studs to buy a multitude of powers, abilities, 'cheats', or hints. You do this by solving puzzles or figuring out how to get to places you can't normally get to (which is a puzzle, of course) and that's all well and good, but there's nothing else to do other than collecting stuff. There is so much potential to make these segments feel alive, but it's mostly just running across tons of space to get to the next little secret section.  On the other hand, there are TONS of these little things to solve and collect and if you've always leaned more towards that than the platforming or the combat or the visual gags, then maybe this is exactly what you're looking for. I admittedly enjoy it to a certain extent, but man, I'm spending most of my time secret hunting instead of anything else and it feels... kind of unbalanced.The story levels themselves are as familiar as can be, of course. You're dunked into some recognizable part of the movie you're going through and there's tons of secrets to collect here, as well. More importantly, there are level challenges to complete, but you don't know what they are unless you buy them in the menu (or you can look them up, but that's irrelevant). Even with abilities that show you where the secrets are, you're still sure to miss out on several until you come back in free play, so it's all the same stuff you've seen before. It's the challenges that I find annoying because you have to collect studs and buy them just to know what to do. It's negligible after you unlock stud multipliers, of course, but it's still a very weird idea. It's by no means a deal breaker, but suffice to say that the real philosophy at play is "thou shalt grind." It's always been a part of the Lego franchise, but this feels turned up to 11.On the technical side, the game runs smooth for the most part with maybe some odd places where the frames drop (2080Ti for me), but there are several little bugs littered throughout that you'll encounter like toons not doing what they're supposed to be doing, UI/UX glitches, and just unexpected random things. The most glaring bug is sometimes the game just hangs when transitioning between scenes - it induces anxiety any time I want to walk through a door to an interior location and back out again.  Sometimes it hijacks your foreground so if you don't have the skills to kill the game through a cmd prompt while effectively blind, then a hard reboot might be your only solution.All said and done, whatever this game lacks in heart (and it really feels like it's missing something) it makes up for in excess. There are hundreds of characters to unlock. Tons of ships to unlock. Minikits out the wazoo to collect. Challenges to complete. Worlds to explore. Dogs and cats living together! It's at times both fun and boring, exciting and mundane, and eh, the humor is kinda weak this time around, but whatever. Franchise fans may be divided on where it sits in the Lego pantheon, but it's still a solid Lego game nevertheless and if it's your or your children's first one, you're going to love it because despite its licensing, it's still a game first and a movie a very distant second. If you enjoy PLAY, then I think this is something anyone can sink their teeth into and have a good time.

author: Fixx
review: My opinion is a mixed bag On this one. I kind of recommend it as it is fun but it has SO MANY issues.With my hours and completion rate (100%) I feel I have a decent opinion.It is a fun game with good writing if you're happy with lego-style. Namely lots of puns, references, and dumb jokes. The campaign I think is worse than the original games this is combining. There is a decent bit cut or squashed there.I really do enjoy the hub worlds though. Lots of things to do and as a completionist this worked very well for me. The missions/puzzles can be somewhat repetitive though.Now for the bad. There are a LOT of bugs/things that come from a bad port. Not entirely surprising.- I have a "double keyboard setup" that being my typing keyboard and my G13 for gaming. Whichever one is used first in the splash screens to skip will be the one the game sees. The other will be invisible (no input) until the game is restarted.- The Ewok village level has so many memory leaks that I have to transition zones once every 2min or so to stop from wanting to die (My PC is dumb strong so its not my hardware)- There is a collectable tracker ability in the game. Often it will show the effect in an area with no collectable. After a while I am fairly sure that these fake spots are possible (0,0,0) of the map and those fake collectables are actually the ones given by side quests. I didn't truly confirm but usually when I'd do a quest that's when I'd notice those fake spots disappearing- The game has a camo mechanic. So if I play as Jango Fett the "bad guys" won't attack me/be my enemies. (I always am playing either jango or a sith). If you are in this camo when a quest requires a space battle the enemy fighters will not be enemies, instead your allies will be. I understand why this happens due to the camo's programming but there should be code for these edge cases. There is no situation where killing your allies you must protect is the right thing for that camo to do.- Space flight with a mouse is terrible. If you move the mouse too far you will be semi-locked in your turn. My guess is its another port problem with the mouse exceeding the -1 to 1 bounds that analog stick input tends to be bound to.- When I was doing the last cleanup of things like the mouse droids there are cases where there are 2 targets on 1 planet but I already had 1. The quest indicator (since I was tracking the task) would not point to the one I was missing but instead the one I already got. IE it brought me to the wrong place.There were probably more bugs but I'm tired and forgetful.Overall I enjoyed my time with it even with frustration which is why I recommend it.4/7If you just want the campaign it's probably more of a 5/7

author: BigBen_Games
review: I can say with great confidence after getting through the first 3 episodes that this game was worth the wait. This is the ultimate grind for 100% completion game. The amount of stuff to do in this game is honestly kinda overwhelming at first but once you get used to the mechanics, you wish that this was like all LEGO game you played as a kid. This is everything I wanted out of this game and far far more. My only problem with the game, it looks like and feels like this game was made totally for use with console/controller. There are several bugs on the PC version of this game, for example; black screen when loading sometimes, infinite load screen, fights sometimes just stop working for a few seconds and have weird jump cut bugs that you know are not part of the game. These are not game breaking bugs but there ones that I have encountered. I would rate this game 1166/10 Kyber bricks.

author: LYNESTAR
review: This is one of the worst LEGO games I have played.What I didn't like:Characters sorted into categories, leaving no unique-ness to each character. What I love about previous LEGO character is that you can unlock certain that can do an assortment of different things. In this game, you pick a single character from each character class and that's it. You can just use those exact same characters for the rest of the game, and sometimes you're forced to use the character in each mission from story mode during certain scenes, TT! MY BROTHERS IN CHRIST! I WANT TO FIGHT GRIEVOUS WITH A CHARACTER OF MY CHOOSING. THAT'S PART OF THE FUN! Yet you can't. Extremely disappoining.Speaking on the story levels, disgustingly disappointed. I genuinely had more fun in TCS. Where you can use fight the villains without being locked into non-free play characters, and the puzzles are unique, fresh and engaging. Most the puzzles in this game are repetitive, there is nothing unique about most of these levels, you will find yourself re-doing tasks from one mission to the next so much. Why is there so many space battles, for each planet, THERE'S NO POINT IF THEY'RE ALL THE SAME! If they're all the same, have it for a few planets, no more no less. These missions aren't even fun.Non-Skippable cut-scenes, even during Free-Play. Never had this issue before, Free Play Missions before even used to just not have them at all, that's preferable and it makes sense. I'm not playing for the story anymore, discard those cut-scenes during free play.What I did like:The open worlds were engaging, large in scope and had unique puzzles and interesting quests, although they could be much and confusing at times.The combat is fun, it's probably an improvement on the mashing button of previous LEGO games, although I can't really say this isn't button mashing. There are some obnoxious parts to the combat, like the fact you can't block the main attacks, (that's the whole point of a block function, right?) Instead having to move out of the way of the attack. To conclude, I want the entire story missions to be revamped in the games to come to include unique puzzles, to be longer than 5 minutes and I'd like to see how characters are used within the games, their abilities, perks and powers to be completely re-done so that each character has a value within themselves, rather than a value as the category they are part of. I'd also like to see a lot more effort put into the story mode, replaying these weren't interesting, I wasn't going back in free play happy to finally be experiencing all the secrets I couldn't find in the story mode, it was a slog. A boring, repetitive, non-skippable cut-scene, unable to use my own characters during fights, slog.

review: decided to pre-order this game for $60. they made it out to be the best lego game since the original lego star wars saga. they promised everyone who pre-orders the deluxe edition they would receive ALL future dlc at no extra charge.the game is boring and buggy. the new deluxe edition is now $70. everyone who pre-ordered will now have to purchase either the galactic edition to receive the dlcs they were promised (which is not discounted for anyone who did decide to pre-order), or purchase the dlcs separately (about $18 individually when dlc is eventually released, or $15 for character collection 2, which gives you immediate access to two of the six dlc packs).and STILL no online multiplayer. thanks  Warner Bros.

author: (:(o):)
review: LEGO games were never supposed to be "epic" and yet they tried. By doing so they lost alot of what made the older LEGO games great. There was nothing serious about the old games and that is what made them great.  This Game is lacking in comedy and is trying to be more than "just a LEGO game". This didn't bother me for the first 6 episodes but it starts to get repetitiv and the story of the latest 3 episodes is really not enough to make you want to keep playing. Every planet is packed with collectibles but once you have two or three characters in each category there is really no reason to collect more, especcially bacause there is no character creator.There are some fun moments and i enjoyed some parts of it but for me it lacks the goofyness of a LEGO game to be fun to play.

author: polly
review: Overhyped, underdelivered.And that taunting "I need someone to show me my place in all this" when you start up the game.Empty husk of the Star Wars lego games that came before it, stripped of the very things that made them fun.1200 collectible bricks yet maybe 20 of them were cleverly hidden, while most of them was just a chore to get to. Not because of difficulty but sheer distance you had to travel from starting.Action sensitive controls.Isn't something many other people point out - while having many actions mapped to a single button is a great idea when executed correctly, this game misses the mark by a long mile - so many times have I wanted to just alt-f4 after 5 attempts to use a button how I wanted to use it instead of how the game thought I did.Shooting is just not fun.Most enemies are bullet sponges, they've added cover mechanics to a lego game for some reason, and the controls feel clunky and unresponsive eg. it takes over a second after releasing the aim trigger for the crosshair to disappear.Flying is horrific.I know that I come from great arcade and flight simulation games so i might be a little biased,however I am well aware that I could never hope for something akin to Ace Combat in a lego game, nevertheless Clone Wars did flying much better regardless how clunky it was. This games flying controls make zero (0(null)) sense. And combat consists of holding fire button and aiming in the general direction of the enemy while flying as slow as possible.It's hard to orient yourself, the ships handle like a doge hellcat on bold tires on vegetable oil covered concrete with a 1200HP tune up.Levels are uninspired.Short, lacking content. sure each level has 3 hidden challenges but they cut down on the amount of minikits per level and the ones you do collect are 95% one terminal or ability use away. And if you excluded all the walking from A to B to C to D about half of the levels would be: Watch a cinematic, listen to a character talk, cutscene of something happening, press button, kill enemy.Walking.Oh my god the walking, there's just so much of it I don't even feel like going in depth since there's no depth to it.Voiced lego characters.Make the writing really boring, most gags are haha minion funny tier of someone falling on their ass or doing a le funny face.And the director decided that we fo shoo need the entirety of important dialogue from the movies in the game so about half of each episode is just listening to dialogue while walking.I am well aware of the "mumble" extra, but it only proves how bad the game is written. When you turn it on you feel like you're wasting even more time during unskippable segments because there just isn't anything interesting going on in the background.And to remain on that topic for a little longer, the choice of actors is just bad especially for Han Solo.His VA makes him seem like a reddit moderator would think a cool guy speaks.And a big FU to the players who don't wish to play through the  sequel trilogy but still want to 100% some levels - unless you play the first mission as maRey Sue you cannot use Scavenger characters abilities so haha tough sheise.Ps. I am well aware of the grammatical errors I've committed in this here review - nevertheless I cannot bring myself to put more effort into it than was put into writing the script for the levels.Trust me you'll have wayyy more fun playing the complete saga or clone wars than this game.

author: Aero Uprising
review: The game is honestly a very fun, nostalgic return to the lego star wars world.I was skeptical about the game before release, but the game really shines.The gameplay is smooth, the levels are fun, and the voice acting is surprisingly hilarious. I am in the 20s and have busted out laughing several times, and I am only in Episode III. I will say, the actual levels are shorter than the original games, but that is only because there is more stuff outside of the main levels. There is so much to do in this game to keep you playing in the open world. There are hundreds of unique characters and it is incredibly fun, even for adults. This game is truly a masterpiece. I would highly recommend.

author: Skrapp
review: I assure those wondering, this is not an "enhanced edition" of the older Lego Star Wars games. It is a brand new take on the Saga that features that classic Lego humor. The amount of detail and added extras in the game has surprised me to the point where I have spent more than an hour exploring Coruscant alone, from the Jedi temple all the way down to the underworld (star wars cyberpunk), doing side quests and collecting collectibles, and I still need to unlock more areas!! Sure, it's a Lego game.. so it's not going to be the most challenging game you will play. The game is definitely laid back and designed to just jump in and have fun, especially with Co-op. Mission challenges are also available for the completionist and to add further difficulty, as well as the high score counter to earn "True Jedi." I still haven't delved into the "Free Roam" part of the game yet either. It's huge. The game will captivate your attention for many unexpected hours, and that’s alright!! If you enjoy Star Wars and Lego, this is a must-have!

author: Thermidor
review: It really pains me to say this, maybe I'm just in a bad mood, but this is just incredibly boring in the gameplay department; it over-complicates in the wrong areas whilst oversimplifying in the wrong areas. There was clearly a lot of hard work put into it, and areas I was sceptical about (such as the voice acting) are actually really good, but the core gameplay that the Complete Saga nailed beautifully is just absent here. The pieces are there to make a great game (no pun intended) but the combat and lack of anything resembling puzzle solving; as well as an over-emphasis on bigger = better just makes this dull sadly. Give me the simplicity of the Complete Saga over this any day.

author: Bloodied Fixer
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

author: rawWwRrr
review: Yes, I've played 85 hours and I'm going to tell you that I don't recommend this game to other players. Not yet, anyway.At the time of this review, the game is in serious need of a patch. The players know it. The developers know it. But there is no patch. There are new characters that you can purchase, of course, but that kind of defeats the purpose when you're having to deal with bugs on every play through.I've run into bugs plenty of times in other games. It's pretty common these days considering how complicated the games are, so I'm not saying that any game needs to be perfect. But this game has enough bugs for a few dozen games. I played all of the major missions and went back to 100% them all. I 100% episodes 1 through 6 with the exception of the very first mission of episode 2, A Wrestle With Wesell. First time through the mission lagged hard about halfway through causing the audio to fall far behind the action on the screen which fell to single digit FPS. Any replays resulted in a crash to desktop (CTD). It runs well at first, but right before the area where the first minikit is, the engine just slows down to a crawl, audio begins to lag, then it'll hang and CTD. Every time.Speaking of CTDs, I lost count. I could be traveling between planets, starting a mission, turn a corner on a map. Anything and everything seemed to be able to cause one. Audio lags come out of nowhere, mostly while in a ship above a planet trying to shoot at enemies. You can usually fix these by landing on a planet but the audio lags usually cause other problems like interfering with mission progress.There are more benign bugs like objects getting stuck in a map, character models not appearing, clipping through ships. And while they may seem inconsequential, they are numerous. The icing on the cake came when the game caused a CTD so I bad I had to hard reboot the computer. When I brought Steam back up it reported a mismatch between the save game on computer and the one on the cloud from 3 days ago. So I naturally chose the one on the computer because I had made quite a bit of progress that morning. Well, I made the mistake of assuming that the save game on the computer was fine. Turns out it was blank. So my 78% completed game save after 85 hours of exploring was wiped out. The game starts with me on Naboo where I left off, but the entire progress is gone. All the characters, ships, side missions, puzzles, bricks, upgrades, etc. Everything gone. So I'm done with it. Even if a patch comes out, I can't see myself dumping another 80+ hours to recoup what I lost. You can see through my achievements how far I was into the game. I was clearing the planets one sector at a time. Too bad it was a waste of time in the end.I'm not saying the game isn't fun, but without a well needed patch I wouldn't recommend anyone devoting a lot of time to it. If you're only wanting to play the main episode missions and have no intention to explore around the planets at all, save your money and wait for a sale. If you want to try 100% the game, wait for the game to get patched.-- rawWwRrr

author: GLOBAL WARMING5
review: It's ok. The level design is honestly atrocious compared to the originals. Most levels can be ran through in less than 7 minutes, many less than 4 or 5. Some of the most linear lego levels ever, who chose that awful POV for the pod racing mission (honestly ruined that mission), no fun minikits where you do weird/quirky things like drive a tractor to farm some flowers to destroy to make a minikit or dropping stormtroopers into a giant pit. I love collectathons when they have unique challenges that aren't repeated over 1,100 times. The kyber bricks in each world are basically all the same thoughtless challenges that most of the time have little character/humor; the minikits of the original games were far more fun to collect. The minikits in this game suffer from poor level design and the boring collectible aspect the kyber bricks suffer from. Half the time character swap is broken; it switches the character slot to the left of the one I selected. IE I select slot 3 and it actually changes slot 2. This means I can never change the final character slot cause there is nothing to the right of it. Also sometimes it adds a 3rd character I can play as and sometimes I only have 2. The cutscenes maintain great lego humor and there is a lot of characters. Some episodes, Episode 2 stand out, a lot of the story is running from cutscene trigger to cutscene trigger. You spend so much time just running around Coruscant not actually doing anything besides activating dialogue. Open world is rarely done well in lego and this is no exception. Go back to fun cantinas and better missions rather than running simulators in lifeless open worlds with boring collectibles. People will say any criticism of this game is elitists, but the level design and glitches of this game are objectively worse than the Complete Saga and the excessive amount of kyber bricks are not nearly as interesting than other classic collectathons. If you normally dont play collectathons you wont notice how boring and overdone the kyber bricks are in this game which is fine for you, but not die hard fans of the genre. This game is 4/10 at best, would recommend to get on a big sale, don't pay full price.

author: Haggis
review: The new LEGO Star Wars game has some great pieces, as well as some pieces that I wish were more like the original, but overall, I think the game is a great addition to the series.Pros:- The visuals are beautiful and anyone who says otherwise is wrong.- The new combat system is fun, albeit different. Sometimes I miss the original "just punch everyone until they die" system, but this one gives a bit more to do and makes the game a little more "playable" in how it wants you to interact with the combat.- The open world is fun and gives you a lot to do and explore, even the bits that the story won't take you through. There's plenty to do, if not too much to do sometimes.- There's a million characters and it's amazing, even if I still only use the same few characters every time.Cons: - The story missions are a bit too short, in my opinion. It has you run through the open world a lot to progress story pieces, which is great, but the actual replayable stories aren't super long and they don't have many of them. I do wish they had a few more of these.- I miss the heart system. The new health system is neat for the new style, but I wish the hearts were back and you just added more hearts instead of a bar. It's a minor thing, but I miss it.- They removed the character customizer, which isn't that big of a deal, but I do wish it was there. There are so many more characters that if they had a customizer, you could make even cooler characters.- I dislike the voiced characters. Some people enjoy it, but I personally don't. I miss the more physical comedy they had that came from the nature of mumbling. The mumble mode is nice, but when you turn it on you realize how little the characters are doing on screen to show what's going on, unlike the originals. Like when Vader tells Luke that one line, in the originals you had him showing a family picture, in the new one, he just says it. I wish that they had combined more of the physical with the voiced lines to give a nice mixture for the original fans, and for the newer fans.Overall, I love the game and I think it's well worth your time.

author: Stev
review: REFUNDED: I was able to beat Episode 1 & 2 in just around 2 hours. Granted I am a full grown adult, but the fact that it is so easy and light on story content is upsetting. At this rate The Skywalker Saga Episodes could be beaten (generously) in about 10-12 hours. ( Proof:  )To put that in perspective: LEGO SW "The Original Trilogy" (2006) takes about 10 hours too. The Skywalker Saga which has all 9 movies, has roughly the same story content as ONE game encompassing 3 movies. Read that again.I don't think the game is bad as a whole, but it's probably worth $15-$20. 50%+ of the content is side-quests and grinding which is pretty sad. Feels like an mmo with fetch and return missions, copy&paste sidequests, and endless walking from point A to B. The Skywalker Saga undeniably holds a fragment of what old LEGO Star Wars used to be. Convoluted with side missions that intrude constantly and shorter main-story missions than all it's predecessors combined; it's really just not the vibe unfortunately.

author: Othersister
review: An amazing game with so many details that just enhance game immersion. Semi-open world with massive maps to explore, hundreds of side quests and tasks to solve, random space battles which can earn you a capitol ship if you win, hundreds of characters to play not including DLC... It really is the biggest Lego game ever and is unparalleled in gameplay.It being a new game, there are still some bugs that need to be ironed out. However, the bugs very rarely make the game unplayable and are usually tolerable.Definitely worth the price (I preordered the premium game which includes the DLC) and I can easily see myself getting over a hundred hours in this game exploring and generally enjoying the gameplay.

author: Treetalk
review: I'm a old fan of Lego games, so it's kind of disappointing to say:The game's really, really shallow. Missions last 5 minutes at most, go to a place, fight 5 dudes, and move on, maybe a boss fight which is just QTE's and spamming attacks.Voice acting and world design is fairly neat, though puzzles are pretty basic.I'll probably pick it up again once it goes on sale, but for now I'm refunding this, because I don't believe this is worth 50 Euro.

(Maz's Castle bug)So the only way to play Ep7 and up is starting a new game and loose all my previous progress and upgrades.I wouldn't recommend the game while such bugs exists. And seems like people have similar softlocks in other parts of the game too.When the bug gets fixed, it may be worth checking out.

author: Legendary
review: Let me start off with saying I overall enjoy this game and have had fun, but instead of this being a full recommendation, its more like recommended with a *Ok, lets start with the positives:The graphics are spectacularThe free roam is very nice and the hub worlds are well designedThe combat system is a very much necessary improvement over the old gamesThe camera works very wellThe space flight is acutely implemented wellThere are lots of callbacks to the old games that fans will enjoyThere is a lot of characters and varietyOk, lets dig into the negatives now:The game was very much rushed. A lot of the content that was promised and shown was cut.The levels are far to short. You honestly get whiplash for how fast you go through the story.The replay-ability is kinda non-existent. This is sad because it was a huge staple with the old games.To elaborate on the first two points, major events are missing like the Battle of Genonosis, the Battle of Coruscant, the Battle of Hoth and more.Its a shame that the best mode that has ever been implemented in a lego game, the "war" battles from Lego Star Wars III, is not present in this game. Those were some of my favorite memories.The AI is very much dumbed down as they fail to pose any real challenge unlike the old games.The cover system is pretty much useless because of the problem stated above.No character customizationAll characters play the same, which is a shame as they used to have cool custom moves and powers in the old games. Now the only character that really has this is General Grievous, who is my favorite character in this.There are some game breaking bugs and glitches, which obviously Traveler's Tales didn't have time to fix as they were rushed by Warner Brothers.Overall, this game is fun, but not the kind of fun I was expecting. For how much hype was behind this, I wanted more, but a lot of this is smoke and mirrors. This game is definitely not the replacement for the old games that they promised, because they still have better features than this at certain points. TT needs to release some major updates to fix these problems, but most likely won't because they are too focused on releasing DLC now with everyone just giving non-stop praise instead of being critical. This game has many flaws that need to be addressed but we won't see TT fix them until we start speaking up.I want to give this game my recommendation, but until the problems stated above are solved, I can't.

author: Fignuken
review: This game seemed like it was gonna be everything I ever wanted. If this came out in my childhood I would have been crying tears of joy most likely. But, now I'm an adult and in a world overflowing with open world garbage I miss the linear levels of the complete saga. I don't like just seeing Jar Jar get saved then your 10 seconds away from the shore. I liked hopping through old temples on Naboo, fighting druids and platforming. Now I feel like the game is an open world first and a fun Lego game second. The world's are beautiful and there's lots to explore, but other than getting studs and finding secrets is there any real reason for them storywise others than just to be little hub worlds every time you're going to another mission. Maybe it's a nostalgia cloud or maybe I've grown out of Star Wars, but either way this game does not bring me any joy and much enjoyment at all. So personally I cannot recommend it.

author: EllieBean
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

author: Hypnaustic
review: This is a great game, however I think my nostalgia with "The Complete Saga" may be ruining it just a little bit. Graphics are great and runs smooth, there are a decent amount of bugs but this review is made right after game was released.  Lots of characters/ships to play as, funny and memorable quotes from all "Star Wars" movies. Levels seem really short and boss fights are kinda easy. The side quests and wondering around all the planets are my favorite feature with this game. The amount of detail is insane and makes me, a "LEGO" and "Star Wars" fan truly happy! I would rank game 8/10 at the moment, definitely would +1 when the developers fix the bugs.

author: Can't believe it's not butter!
review: I've been waiting for this game for about two years and I started it up as soon as I could. I've always been a huge fan of the LEGO Star Wars games and the biggest appeal for me was always the simplicity of the games, in which you just get to run around and destroy everything and have chaotic fun with your friends. This game isn't that for me; it feels like I'm getting drowned in usually very cool features, but which don't belong in a LEGO game in my opinion. For instance the upgrade system does not interest me at all in a LEGO game, where my only concern has always been character, gold bricks and minikits. Now, don't get me wrong, there are some new features which I really enjoy, like that you need a protocol droide to translate other languages and the huge open world, but they are just too overwhelming as of now. I also really anjoy the new way of attacking, where as a Jedi the force has really been made into a usable attack, but I really dislike the combat. The combat really feels simplistic in comparison with all the new abilities you've been given; I'd usually end up just spamming light attack.And then there are the levels. The levels feel really rushed to me, like they were trying to cram as many things in there as they could, while they only had a certain amount of play time they could use. A lot of the cut scenes also felt really glossed over to me; for instance when Finn and Poe steal a TIE-fighter and flee to Jakku, the cut scene takes about 5 - 10 seconds, while it should be really impactful. Then there are also the levels, where some feel like they took about a minute, where you did close to nothing and others feel like you've been there for way too long and you still do close to nothing.I really don't recommend to get this game if you are a fan of the old LEGO SW games, but who am I to tell you what to do.

author: SirTelamon
review: Another Great Lego game. 9/10Pros:- A massive amount of characters- Beautiful Graphics- Large maps to explore from all the movies- Fun missions especially vehicle combat ones.- Space battles against capital ships and dogfights are fun- Plenty of ships to collect- All 9 films are here- Humour at its best plenty of laughs- Get to travel to all the planets.- Good controls and combat- Can approach missions in different ways.- Can collect capital ships and fly to locations in them (they will also be in the sky when you're on a planet.- Can ride many creatures from the films.- Game is fully playable on Keyboard and mouseMixed:- First Lego game I feel there's a bit too much content 100 Hours at least to fully 100% the game- Some level challenges are just not fun and can be a chore to finish.- As this isn't a remake of the old Lego games the films levels are different so no Space battle level at the start of episode III (but important levels like the Deathstar trench is here).- Menu keyboard controls are messy.Cons:- No hub world at all so mini kits are never on display and unlocked characters don't all walk around like in the original games, instead are just behind menus.- Episode 9's levels is just as miserable as the movie (I don't blame the devs for that)- Land vehicle controls are a bit poor.

author: SGFJ
review: This game is not good. I've played every single lego game (except for lego movie 2) and this one is by far the worst. The levels are all short, boring, and uninteresting. Multiplayer (which has been a staple in every lego game) feels like an afterthought, the 2nd player never EVER does anything. A lot of important moments are cut out of this game or relegated to cutscenes such as the 2nd death star, palpatine vs windu, negotiations, a level on kamino, etc. The characters should be a highlight of this game and yet, they aren't. In the complete saga every character was kind of relegated to a class, but almost all of them had at least 1 unique thing about them. In this game there are a few classes and every character in each class plays the exact same. The only characters that really play any different are the fetts, and some characters in the extra class. Old lego games had fun and not to hard to do puzzles in each level, this game has you walk through a hallway, kill 3 enemies and then fight a boss. The vehicle levels aren't much better because all you do is shoot a target for a minute until it dies. The open world is yet again... A disappointment, there are literally no enemies on any planets, and one of the planets you cant even explore. Overall I feel like this game should have payed more attention to gameplay rather than being able to play as an obscure character that acts the exact same as every other character in their class.

That's a major disappointment.

author: kd ༮ ༽
review: Unpopular opinion: Instead of being blinded by "nostalgia" and an awesome genre, I'll say the truth.Excluding the godawful bugs that I encountered, and the beautiful graphics, the gameplay was below mediocre. I enjoyed getting the bricks sure, but I don't enjoy exploring a LEGO game even though the "enjoyable" part of the game is the exploring. The story is always just a repeat of the same things every time with just a bit of a different scenario.My main issue with this game is that it does not feel like a classic LEGO game at ALL. Its too concentrated on being a TPS game with combos and health bars, while the actual combat and battles are total letdowns since you can just press one button and beat any enemy despite it being a "much more developed combat system". Compared to the new games, the way the old games were played were essentially 100x better, smoother and more enjoyable. The game doesn't have any unique feel to it, it just feels like a lame story you try to push through to get to explore the area for collectibles. I don't care how you feel about the game, this is my take on the game. I am not blinded by the "classic" games and how they were played, I simply believe they actually stayed to the story/gameplay and were fun to progress in and not some poorly produced fighting game with the premise of being a LEGO game to sell better.The remake of the old LEGO games of the old films were also terrible in the same way, it didn't feel like a LEGO game at all.Also this is not a satire review but I'm not gonna cry too much about the money I wastedGG 10/100

author: Bananan
review: So far, I love this game. It's not better or worse than the original Lego Star Wars series, but different. I enjoy the skilling system, open-world feel to each level, and the classic Lego jokes made all throughout it. I also have found the game to be very well optimized and not very buggy for its release today. It is very unfortunate that a great game like this does not support online co-op, however. I'd love to play this with my online friends. Either way, it's easily worth $60 IMO for all the additional DLC.

author: s1aanesh
review: This game is tagged with "Multiplayer" and "Co-op". But the only chance to play it with a friend is using Share-play. From one side you need only one copy of game to do this. On the other other side only one will be able to use keyboard+mouse. And you need like really good internet if you are playing from one apartment - you will cast and pull HD picture through same channel simultaneously. And you WILL play only in split-screen, which is frustrating - the view angle is ridiculous. And the game stops being fun and pleasant, turning into something like "For the God's sake, where am I? Where is my friend?". The bright example is speeder races on Tatooine, where checkpoints appear outside your piece of the screen and you don't understand where to go.So yes, for single you may give this game a chance. But definitely not recommend it for playing with a partner.

author: Eldeeo
review: As a long time player of "The Complete Saga," this game looks and feels exactly how I remember the previous game (with obvious changes and additions). Lots of collectables, references (prequel memes as a good example), and additional content to collect, see, and experience through the game. I have a hard time really finding anything overwhelmingly negative about this game, aside from the lack of a character creator, and that's saying something in this day and age of games being pumped with DLC. Now that being said, there is DLC for the game, but nothing game breaking or pay-to-win seeing as its only character packs as I am writing this review. If they ever decide to do major DLC for this game, I really hope they go into the side stories such as Rogue One, Solo, Mandalorian campaigns, but that is a whole other topic on its own.In my opinion, if you have a chance to ever play and/or buy this game you should definitely give it a chance.

author: Wall_icarus

author: Albusfawkes
review: Honestly one of the greatest Open world lego games out there. There are still some issues that this game has: FPS issue with wrestle with wessel, keyboard bug in master code breakout to name a few. The levels feel short, but that really only comes into play when repeating the missions. Fresh play through's will make the episodes feel longer. The level amount was reduced to 5 from 6 (LSW:TCS). Alot of my game time was spent in the open world completing the other objectives. One big issue is not being able to switch ships in free play mode for some levels such as destroying starkiller bases first phase. The love the amount of characters in this game, just wished that some of the dark side characters used lightning as their ranged attack. The boss fights are really good, personal favourite is Anakin vs Obi-Wan fight. People dislike the fight for not being able to co-op fight like in TCS, but the fight is more accurate with the film. The most creative boss fight is the episode 8 captain phasma fight, since one of the challenges involves damaging her in 9 different ways.The lack of character creator is sad, but it does not make the game unplayable. With that said, it does feel strange not having a character creator in a lego game.

author: Derek Zoolander
review: I've been waiting for this game ever since it was announced and have been anxiously following every leak I could, and to say that the game didn't disappoint when it finally came out would be an understatement. You can truly feel how much love and hard work TT games put into this game especially if you've played the previous LEGO Star Wars games, there so many little references and Easter eggs to the previous games and the movies and as a huge fan of Star Wars it's wonderful to see really. The game looks beautiful and vibrant and every area feels unique and interesting (and there are a lot to them) the game has so much replayability that it will probably take me a while to 100% complete. And the new combat system is such a breath of fresh air even if it's a bit basic I mean this is their first attempt at a completely new combat system. My only complaints really are that their are some levels and scenes that suffer from massive frame drops and at times the anti-aliasing options either make the game blurry or jagged. Overall this game is a masterpiece and in my opinion, a model of how game developers should take their time to put love and attention to detail in a product. 9/10 would highly recommend to anyone.

author: JX Legend
review: As Star Wars fans, we have an abusive relationship with the franchise. Usually, Star Wars projects are cheap cash grabs trying to capitalize on pre-existing characters while introducing worse newer versions of them. I would just like to let you know that is not the case here. Using the force, I can "sense" TT Games's passion and devotion to this franchise. There are so many little details that prove they are fans and understand the franchise. It is very apparent the love and care that went into this game. I cannot stress enough the thought that went into this game, such as the voice cast (with most VA's from the clone wars making a return for the prequels) For what it is, this game is a steal even at $60 because of the sheer amount of content. If you are a fan of Star Wars, this is a must buy.

I love that this game takes the missions from previous Lego Star Wars games and enhances them with the dialouge and some funny moments. Just be warned that there have been a lot of reports of people getting their game soft-locked in different areas and there is currently no known fix for them. Hopefully this will get patched soon and I can turn my negative review into a postive one because it deserves it.

author: Kingpin ツ
review: This game is legendary. From the short amount of time I have on it I can safetly say that Is one of the best, if not the BEST lego game ever made (nostalgia put aside.) This game has shown that even something as simple as lego bricks can look beautiful if done right, with graphics which are shockingly good for a lego game, combat which includes cool combos, unique abilities for dark and light side characters and many huge planet's to explore. This game is by far one which is much worth the £39 paid for it, and I only hope to find more enjoyment In the countless next few hours I spend on it. Very fun, enjoyable and genuinely impressed with its quality.Pros:Over 350 playable characters23 HUGE planet's to exploreFun and exciting missions which give nostalgia to the moviesMany hidden collectibles and bricks etc.Cons:Some missions are very short, but typically the last few of an episode get much longerSpacetravel is lackluster and only basically possible when In space battles As you can see, pros far outweigh the cons, and cons are purely personal opinion.Great game, would recommend for sure. 10/10

review: Genuinely got me to laugh quite a few times, and I've only done Episode 1 and 2 so far, and not to mention this game is a collector's paradise, plenty of things to look for while exploring levels, I 100% recommend this if you were ever a fan of the Lego games

author: SilverOmega01
review: Legitimately disappointing. The story mode is just plain bad, with only five missions per episode and each one being incredibly short or a gimmick. The entirety of Episode 1 is just barely longer than a standard story mission in the previous lego games. The rest of the "story mode" is just boring walking place to place and the occasional boring mandatory side quest.So much of the normal Lego Game experience was butchered for the sake of a modern Open World game and it's just not fun.Wish I could refund; not worth the price.

author: thetargos
review: I loved the original complete saga. This version delivers and builds up on what Tt did.Rich, deep, enticing, exciting. A MUST for Star Wars fans. The inclusion of recent Star Wars Lore is very welcome (true, also source for discussions among fans  in regards to the original 6 movies and the recent trilogy).Amazing gameplay and play options. Unparalleled experience in local co-op and remote play, like any Tt Lego game.Graphics, controls, sound and soundtrack.As both Lego and Star Wars fan, I really love this game.

author: Dsin
review: 1. Best graphics in any lego gamer ever. Almost every interior including like the floor, walls, and ceilings are covered in legos, really makes the game feel more lego-y. Open world areas are also really pretty combined with realistic textures and legos. 2. Most expansive character list, even the most obscure ones like Glup ♥♥♥♥♥♥. However, by having such a large list, gameplay is suffered.3. Combat is improved. You can do combos with lightsabers. Hide and build covers. 4. Cutscenes and humor is executed well. Some references in the game like one mission titled "Better Call Maul."1. Level design is uninspired and boring. Lets do Ep. 1 for example. In the beginning, you walk to the meeting area with  Obi and Qui Gon and then go back realizing its a trap. Then, you meet Jar Jar and follow him to the gungan Base. Then, you follow Jar Jar to Boss Nass. Then you go across the gungan base to reach a ship to go to Naboo. So far, the only thing you've been doing is walking. In the complete saga, there is actual combat and puzzle solving in the first location. There is an actual level to play not this going from point A to point B then a cutscene crap that this game does quite a lot. 2. Sure the character list is big. But all the characters feel the same. Take bounty hunters for example, the only thing they can do is shoot or use their jetpack. Literally, no flame thrower or wrist rockets. Yes it is in the combos, but no button for it.  Palpatine also doesn't have a button to do force lightning or force choke. In DC Super Villains, every character had a special ability that they could do. In Skywalker Saga there is none of that. 3. Occasional bugs with enemies not triggering combat scenes. Not being able to move happened quite a few times and resorting to restart the level. 4. Usually the game runs pretty well. Places like the droid factory in geonosis is horrible however. 5. Important scenes are cut off and replaced with cutscenes. No Mace Windu vs. Palpatine. No battle on geonosis. No battle on coruscant. 6. The open hub areas are pretty to look at with things to collect and explore. However, once you do a little bit of exploring and collecting you will realize that many of the puzzles are recycled. 7. Co-op gameplay usually sucks with the second player usually doing nothing. Such a big mistake that the fight on mustafar is against player 2 instead player 2 controls R2 and 3PO. LIKE FOR COMPLETE SAGA SECOND PLAYER COULD PLAY AS ANAKIN.

author: Julius
review: Only just good enough for me to give it a positive review. Episode 9 made me want to kill myself.I might find it more fun to play in Co-op than Solo.If you're in for a casual experience, you might like the game. But if you expected it to be fully fledged out, with loads of content for the Episodes, you might not like it. Some story elements were completely rushed through, just featuring a 30 second cutscene, like the battle of coruscant and the Mace windu - Palpatine fight.Other people have pointed out alot of flaws and pros that i wont be going over right now, but I pretty much agree with it all. I did like playing the game from 1 - 6, i will likely replay those again.Leaving the review as positive for the time being until i figure out wether I actually like the game enough in the end.Right now I can only give it a 5.5/10 score.

author: Criscrafter
review: The game does not give you the opportunity to replay a full episode. (without starting a completely new game). After playing Episode 1, for example, there's no way to replay the first and very nostalgic scene where Qui Gon and Obi fight a bunch of droids. The first scene/level you can play again is the one called "a bigger fish." But I'm sure that wasn't the beginning. This is very sad, because Lego Star Wars the complete saga and Lego Star Wars the Clone Wars did it right!But in 2022, after so much work on the game, there is such a small detail that makes the game very bad.That could be fixed by making levels out of each tiny scene or better by putting together several tiny scenes/levels into one level. I hope this will be fixed.In the meantime I gonna play Lego StarWars the complete Saga again (a good game)

author: Kirxas
review: ~ DIFFICULTY ~✅ My 90 year old grandma could play it🔲 Easy🔲 Normal🔲 Hard🔲 Dark Souls~ GRAPHICS ~🔲 MS Paint🔲 Bad🔲 Meh🔲 Graphics don't matter in this✅ Good🔲 Beautiful🔲 Masterpiece~ MUSIC ~🔲 Bad🔲 Not special✅ Good🔲 Beautiful~ STORY ~🔲 This game has no story🔲 Like playing Temple Runners for the story🔲 It's there for the people who want it✅ Well written🔲 Epic story🔲 Imagine Kingdom Hearts but on crack~ PRICE ~🔲 Under-priced🔲 Perfect Price🔲 Could be cheaper✅ Overpriced🔲 Complete waste of money~ REQUIREMENTS ~🔲 You can run it on a microwave/toaster🔲 School computer✅ Average🔲 High end🔲 NASA computer~ LENGTH ~🔲 Extremely Short (60 minutes or less)🔲 Very Short (1 - 3 hours)🔲 Short (3 - 15 hours)✅ Average (15-50 hours)🔲 Long (50-90 hours)🔲 Extremely long (90-110 hours)🔲 No ending~ FUN ~🔲 I'd rather watch paint dry🔲 Hard to enjoy✅ Repetitive🔲 Actually pretty amusing🔲 Ride of your life~ REPLAY-ABILITY~🔲 Wasn't worth completing🔲 It's a one-time experience🔲 Only for achievements✅ If you wait a few months/years🔲 Definitely🔲 Infinitely re-playable~ WORTH BUYING ~🔲 Remove this from the steam store🔲 No✅ Wait for sale🔲 Yes🔲 You NEED to experience this gameIt *is* a good game, but it's in no way on par with other lego games, especially other lego star wars games. The game feels empty, as if they forgot to add enemies, the missions are extremely short and everything is pretty much in the open world. Now, that wouldn't be a problem if, again, it weren't completely devoid of npcs that do literally anything at all besides stand there and walk around. It could have been the best lego game of all time, but it got obviously rushed and released as a half baked product that will never be finished. This game is a fine example of what happens when you dump hundreds if not thousands of development hours into making the next big advance in the series and it doesn't quite pay off, while at the same time, neglecting the very things that made the other games great.Don't even bother with the DLC characters, they have no interactions and get old real quick, kinda like the game itself.I recommend to go play the complete saga or the clone wars lego games instead.

author: Jopguy
review: I expected more from this game and I'd have to say I'm disappointed for the price I paid.  If you are thinking of getting this game, only get it ON SALE.  Overall the game lacks the complexity of the old lego star wars games, especially in the puzzle and level design.  The combat is gimicky without practical use and the dlc doesn't include new story missions.  Below is some pros and cons if any of you want further explantions.Pros- The open world system of different planets and areas was fantastic.  It was a real treat seeing the different worlds brought to life.- My favourite gameplay mechanic was the flying/starship missions.  On the controller the movement and shooting felt snappy and smooth.  - Variety of characters to play and ships to fly.  It was especially interesting trying out the differences between ships.- Keeping with the spirit of Lego Star Wars, funny cutscenes, dialogues and character interactionsCons- I can't believe I'm saying this for a game labeled as a Saga but there is a lack of content.  Every missions is around 70% cutscene and 30% gameplay.  As funny as the cutscenes are they don't make up for playable content.  The lack of gameplay becomes really apparent when you start freeplay and with the ability to skip all cutscenes you realize how these missions become a 15 min adventure at most, in and out.- Lack of puzzle variety and complexity.  I hated doing the same R2D2 puzzle with a passion.  All the puzzles were tedious and got old real fast.- Level design was simple and lacked innovation.  The old lego star wars in my opinion had more quirky designs and more complexity.  Lots of times you had to build platforms to fight a boss or solve a unique puzzle that didn't require the same old r2d2 puzzle unlike this game.  Each level in the old game had its unique puzzle for certain sections.  In this game you just switch characters and do the same puzzle over and over to solve.- Combat was never improved.  The developers boast of different combos in fighting which is cool and all.  They even put in a mechanic to prevent spamming one move by making enemies block.  This is easily overcome by spamming the same move 5 times then using a different move then spamming again.  Seriously theres no need for a player to do different combos.  It more effective to throw a lightsaber non stop (best move in the game)- Boss fights were a snooze fest because of the gameplay mechanic.  They pose no threat even to the most amateur of gamers.  My grandma could beat any boss in this game. - The DLC is simply EXTRA CHARACTERS. THERE ARE NO NEW STORY MISSIONS for rogue one, solo or mandalorian or anything.  Seriously expected at least a rogue one story mission.  That movie connects the original movies with the prequels.  How disappointing.- The collectables of minikits and bricks are a snoozefest.  Again, no quirky puzzles to find minikits and such. All you have to do is switch characters to use their abilities to get the minikit/brick.  Minikits and bricks are also shown to you by the UI taking out the fun of exploration/mystery out of it.- Unless you have all the time in the world I don't see any fun in collecting everything.  It's for the most part tedious and a chore.  20 HOURS was the amount of time it took me to go through the whole saga at a enjoyable pace, not rushing or trying to find every collectable.- An overall dumbing down of a lego game.  So much handholding and leading in this game and so little complexity/mystery left for the players to enjoy and explore for themselves.

author: Keeok
review: This game is really good and i'm liking it more than I expected I would. Some of the best writing i've seen in a Lego game in a very long time. The game is very pretty and the cut scenes are downright gorgeous at times in how fluid the animation is.The biggest knock against this game is the levels feel very short and certain sequences I'd assume would be missions are completely missing. The space battle at the end of episode 6 comes to mind but there were others. The game makes up for it by having incredibly large hub worlds that can be explored for collectibles.

author: Grand Captain Speedy Dash
review: As much as I'm having fun with this game, I can not recommend this game for full price at the current time because of it's shortcomings.Lego games have in the past been highly replayable with you being able to replay any section of the game by selecting the right level, but that is different here with most of the cutscenes happening outside levels as such are only once per save file. Another more serious problem is that of the boss battles that happen outside levels which are also once per save file events, such as the Luke Skywalker fight and the first Jango Fett fight.Another major problem is the number of people who end up with corrupted save files both local and steam cloud, so manually backing up the saves is highly advise for any who pick up this game.There is also other problems such a performance problems on certain levels as well as it seems that the extras can break the game such as in the last level of VII where it crashes the game with certain ones one.

author: Pugsley
review: If your looking for a return to your childhood through a remake of the old lego games, this ain't it. The "Story" mode for this game is just a series of cut-scenes followed by brief gameplay segments. After that most of your time is just running around to get to the next story cutscene. The voice acting and mumble mode are uninspired, they hired people who don't sound like the original characters. Mumble mode is a half baked excuse for what the old games did. Some of the jokes are clever but most miss the mark entirely because of the voice acting. I'd much prefer the old no dialog with jokes like before. The collection part of the game is boring and most puzzles can be skipped if u have a jet pack char, with the most annoying puzzles being locked behind needing to finish EP 7 in order to get the scavenger abilities when no other abilities are locked behind needing to complete a level. The cover shooting and new light saber melee mechanics as well as boss fights feel uninspired and lack luster. The older hearts system was fine, idk why they felt the need to replace it. All in all it feels soulless, a mockery of the older games. I do not recommend it for those who have fond memories of the older games, go back and replay those, they are better in almost every way.

author: StormZ
review: I had the goal to fully complete the game upon starting it and at the time of writing this review, I have spent 54 hours playing and have completed approximately 53% of the total game.Upon initial introduction to the game, I found the first hour to be an . The tutorial level effectively taught me the controls and the various actions that each character can perform. After completing the first level, I was able to enter the galaxy, also known as free play, and begin my . Initially, navigating a planet can be challenging as the zones are vast and . However, utilizing the map and the ability to set waypoints proved to be a valuable tool in finding my desired objectives.As I progressed through the campaign, I found myself feeling as though I was  the levels. This is likely due to the levels being shorter in comparison to other LEGO titles. Each level is designed to highlight a specific moment from the Star Wars movies and they are , featuring authentic LEGO cutscenes. The initial  were well-designed, however, they became repetitive as many of the bosses had similar mechanics.Exploring the galaxy through side-quests and puzzles was a highlight of the game for me. The ability to visit the  from the movies and  myself in the game world was enjoyable. However, after a prolonged period of time, the side-quests and puzzles became repetitive., the level design is well-done, incorporating the classic LEGO comedic elements. Exploration of the galaxy and various planets is a highlight of the game, but the side-quests and puzzles become repetitive. There were some bugs present during my playthrough, however, they did not greatly impact my gameplay experience.

author: IM USING A XBOX CONTROLLER
review: I asked ChatGPT to write a review as Yoda:"Ah, yes. Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga. A game it is, full of action and humor, hmm? Play as your favorite characters, you will, in any order you choose. Explore new locations, command powerful vehicles, and use The Force to defeat your enemies. A great game for fans of the Skywalker Saga, it is. Upgradable abilities and Kyber Bricks to unlock, hmm? A game to be enjoyed by younglings and old masters alike. A game to try, I recommend.But beware, dear friends. A challenge it is, to play as little Lego figures and defeat giant capital ships. But fear not, for with The Force on your side, victory is certain. And if you happen to be defeated by a group of Stormtroopers, just remember, size matters not.And if you happen to get frustrated with the game, just remember, do or do not, there is no try. And if all else fails, call on the wise and powerful Yoda for guidance. Just don't ask him to do the driving, hmm? That is a skill he has yet to master.Overall, Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is a great game for fans of the series. May the bricks be with you."

author: N_Chilada22
review: Pros:LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is a refreshing take on the childhood classics that I grew up playing. It's so different, yet so familiar and I find it very charming. If you grew up with the first LEGO Star Wars games like I did, you're likely to enjoy at least one thing in this game. Some people might be turned off by the open-world aspect, but I love that it gives me the opportunity to explore these rich Star Wars planets at my own discretion without having to be dragged through a linear level with many, MANY boundaries instead. Although the NPC interactions/side quests are quite goofy, it doesn't take away from the amount of detail put into these planets and their environments.Cons:The combat is a little weird, but I kind of expected that with a modern LEGO game. The device interactions are boring and feel arbitrary. Waiting for an arrow key to slowly make its way into a box to press it is not engaging for me at all. Even the Astromech device interaction where you rotate the circle is straight up boring. I skip those just so I don't have to do them. At least in The Complete Saga, it was just a cute animation that we got to see the characters do. I liked the direction of them wanting to implement the device interactions as a mechanic, but to me they just weren't engaging enough. The diegetic nature of some of the devices are cool. The arrow key device shows the screen in the game world and makes it look like the characters are actually interacting with it. Unfortunately, that did not save how bland I feel that they are as a mechanic.I will admit, I'm a bit mad at the "Galactic Edition" shebang as well. That kind of ruins the point of pre-ordering a deluxe edition and getting the benefits from that if I just have to end up buying even more content after the game releases. I myself will just choose not to buy it because the game can still be played without it. I've spent enough. Deluxe Edition lets me play with over 300 characters, but Galactic Edition lets me play with over 400? Okay, but the story and gameplay is still the same. If they planned on adding separate side stories from Rogue One, Andor, Mandalorian, etc, then I would maybe consider purchasing the pack, but as of now it just seems like a character pack cash grab for fans of Star Wars.TL;DRThis is a great game for Star Wars fans, but the Galactic Edition is a cash grab.
