author: ACE+
review: I went in with low expectations. The game exceeded them, and then fell below them. Basically, I grew up on Lego Star Wars TCS. I loved it and 100%ed it a few years ago. I didn't know what I loved about it, but I do now. It's the character and soul of the game. It's funny and cute and charming. Skywalker Saga meets this easily. It's got just as much soul and character, without feeling like a rehash.The problem is, I wanted to 100% this game too. I did. DO NOT DO THIS. It turned a fun 15ish hour game into a slog of an 80 hour checklist. If you do 15 or so side missions, and get 30 or so Kyber bricks, you will have seen all of the side content. Almost every mission is just a recycled generic objective. Every kyber brick has the same solution. Just do yourself a favor and play the story and move on. Maybe get the minikits, those are fun. Don't bother with the galaxy exploration though.

author: SweatyPyro (PLC][
review: I figured Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga would be a silly walk through of the Star Wars films in Lego comedy fashion. And I was right! Having only played one Lego Star Wars previously, I found myself enjoying the play of The Skywalker Saga again. Basic combat, puzzle solving and exploration means players of all ages can enjoy this game! The references to small side characters throughout the movies, the space combat, and special instances of story missions were some pleasant surprises too.I was also very surprised to see just how much they put into this game. I've now clocked over 100 hours attempting to 100% the game. Gamers, there are so many side quests and things to do upon finishing the main story, it is honestly ridiculous. Star Wars fans should definitely play this game. There won't be many other games where you can play as Max Rebo and a Wampa side by side, beating up stormtroopers.

author: Kahlemviir
review: The Skywalker Saga as a LEGO game is a solid experience, but as a Star Wars LEGO game I find it wanting. The gameplay and mechanics are well crafted and smooth. The combo system is a surprise to be sure, but a welcome one. The long list of characters and added character types gives a lot of replayability that this game otherwise would not have. Despite the solid nature of this game I find it lacking compared to its predecessor. There are big stretches of missions that are just not present in this game compared to the Complete Saga. Side by side an individual mission in the Complete Saga is a much longer and more fleshed out experience. I know there are three extra episodes now compared to before but they had a very easy template to follow that was tried and true. One that they did not follow, much to my disappointment. That combined with the lack of a character creator makes me long to play the Complete Saga over this game.That being said and disregarding the previous game, this is a must buy for LEGO game fans. Despite my nostalgia getting the better of me this game is by no means a bad one. In fact part of me wishes I had played this first, just so I could appreciate it more. You can get a lot of time out of this and being at $50 full-price is a steal, and a must buy on sale. There are things this game offers that the Complete Saga doesn't and vice versa, so definitely check it out.

author: davocado
review: TL;DR: A lot better on controller, graphics are awesome, the gameplay is nice, the levels are a bit short.Initially, I was somewhat disappointed with this game. The mouse + keyboard controls are kind of frustrating to use, since the game has baked-in mouse acceleration which cannot be deactivated. Even after decreasing my pointer speed (DPI), the camera control was still kinda whacky and would sometimes spin around way too quickly. Rotating the camera too fast also causes frame drops, so playing with mouse and keyboard made the game stutter every time I turned around.Playing with a controller is a much smoother experience and the controls feel better designed as well.The game is quite grindy (as you'd expect), but the open-world puzzles and missions are not too monotonous, with a lot of fun puzzles and easter eggs.Having played Lego Star Wars TCS a bunch of times, the pacing of the episodes feels weird at times, even though it correlates more closely with the movies than the older games did. The level designs are nice, nothing too special, but good fun.To me, the story levels feel quite short, definitely shorter than the original trilogy levels in the old game. The game still has plenty of content, but I would have preferred more story content (longer levels, across larger areas and with a few extra cut-scenes) over the open-world stuff.

author: spooky scary skeleton
review: this game truly feels like they put the control scheme on the bottom of their priorities. visually this game is great, most of the voice actors deliver a good performance, etc. the controls are some of the worst i've experienced with a lego game.this new mechanic they've added where the characters try to grab the edges of platforms and such, breaks the ability to double jump onto them in some instances. i have not finished the Rise of Skywalker episode yet, because i am physically unable to get to an area in the deathstar ruins. alongside that, the combat in this game feels a little clunky but i can understand that it might be user error, since the mechanics are so vastly different to previous games, but it's still worth mentioning.Overall, yes this game is fun and most of the time it's well worth the purchase. but when a game gets to a point of breaking itself it makes it hard to recommend. if you're ready for the possibility of struggling with some janky platforming, i still say go for it

author: Drexarch
review: TL;DR: A decent game carried by it's license and a mountain of content.Positives- Charming visual presentation that does justice to both Legos and Star Wars- An amazing selection of playable characters and vehicles that also doubles as a comprehensive encyclopedia of Star Wars lore.- Literally hundreds of bite-size, generally fun side activities where there is a constant flow of new things to do and you're never hung up on any given task too long. - Competent ranged and melee combat that is just deep enough to maintain interest.- The abridged nature of the story mode makes The Last Jedi and Rise of Skywalker more bearable by leaving many of the divisive bits on the cutting room floor. Negatives- Abysmally bad performance in certain areas. The ewok village often dipped to below 20 fps on an RTX3090. Outside of these moments the game ran perfectly fine and did not tax my system at all. - Frequent glitches and bugs. I didn't encounter anything game breaking, but quest markers were often in the wrong location, quest givers would sometimes disappear, and certain random events would refuse to spawn for hours at a time. Most of these were fixed by restarting the game, but still annoying nonetheless. - Bad climbing mechanics - climbing tries to split the difference between free control and using button prompts to mantle onto ledges, but just ends up being awkward. Button prompts frequently disappear or change suddenly, causing me to miss a jump and fall to my death. If you go very slowly everything generally works fine, but it never feels as reliable as it should. -Bad reward scaling - most of the side activity rewards come in the form of Kyber bricks, the game's upgrade currency. The problem is that almost every task rewards you with just a single brick, no matter how complicated it might be. Some bricks require solving intricate, multi-part puzzles to get to, while others are just lying around in the open. Dealing with the game's more complex puzzles starts to feel not worth it after a while given you can just go somewhere else, break open a random trash pile, and get the same reward.Tips- Use your data cards to buy stud multipliers first. You will need millions of studs to unlock certain things, and having the multipliers allows you to accumulate currency way quicker. Multipliers also factor together as you acquire them, as in 2X and 4X combined will give you 8X. - Play Episode 7 first. It's the only place you can get scavenger gear, which you need to solve certain puzzles on every planet in the game. You can unlock scavengers in other episodes, but they don't get their tools until Rey crafts them early in The Force Awakens.-Jedi and Sith characters can force lift droid characters. A lot of platforming and box stacking challenges can be bypassed completely by force lifting a droid character up to the destination. Even floating bricks can be acquired by lifting a droid into place then switching to them. -The scoundrel class has an ability that can halve the cost of hints and applies to all characters across the board. Hints are crucial for finding certain collectibles, so buying this ability early will save you studs in the long run.RecommendationThis game works best as a collect-a-thon, and that's where most of it's value lies. If you only intend to play through the story mode as directly as possible, the core gameplay mechanics really aren't deep enough to make that a satisfying or interesting experience. If you really dig into unlocking all the characters, ships, and class abilities, you are looking at about 80-100 hours of content. I had a good time with this one overall, and would definitely recommend if you are that kind of obsessive completionist.

author: JonnyCheats
review: Truly truly one of my most disappointing purchases ever on Steam. The levels are insanely short, the open worlds are empty of anything to interact with, and the puzzles are so simple and repetitive that it all feels tedious. And with 1200 blue bricks to collect, it feels tedious fast - it all feels like filler.Actual levels are few and far between tedious fetch quests and "walk here for another cutscene" tasks. I'd had enough when you are tasked with escorting Padme to her apartment on Coruscant, while she walked at 0.5x normal walking speed and would not move along unless you were right next to her. It became very clear that this game is a very polished but hollow shell - it looks gorgeous, but it is devoid of any of the charm of its predecessors. They designed incredible backdrops with no real content to sink your teeth into.The game is very pretty, but unfortunately behind its glossy surface lies a buggy empty mess. You don't need nostalgia-goggles to see its predecessor is the superior game despite being 20 years older.

author: Difficulty Tweak
review: Back in about 2007 or 2008, I saw an ad for the Complete Saga on TV, and it blew my little child brain away. I actually got so excited over being able to mix and match stuff from different eras that I actually screamed at my mom to buy me the game. Complete Saga got a lot of hours out of me and many fun memories, but as time marched on and LEGO games became more advanced, it did actually get left behind.When the Sequel trilogy (ew) finished, it was basically only a matter of time until a new Complete Saga came out to update everything, and that's what Skywalker Saga is.For those of you expecting a one-to-one update of Complete Saga, I'm sorry to disappoint, but it's not. There's quite a handful of changes that were made that put distance between Complete Saga and Skywalker Saga, some good, some bad, and here's a short list:-The Cantina is gone completely and has been replaced by an open world/galaxy map, which I feel is a bad thing since you lose that visual reminder of your progress as the Cantina fills up with people. This also means custom characters are gone as well.-Episode 1 actually adds the Control Ship as a level in the episode, as opposed to it being cut content in the original game and an extra in Complete Saga.-Episode 2 doesn't have a gunship battle, but it does have a chase with Jango in the asteroid field which I don't remember being in either the original game or Complete Saga.-Episode 3 completely skips the Battle of Coruscant's space section and starts on the Invisible Hand.Many parts of Complete Saga that were full levels have been either merged into the open world, turned into cutscenes, or those that were retained as levels were heavily truncated into much shorter missions. The first level of Episode 1, the Theed levels, and the Invisible Hand were all significantly cut down compared to how they were in Complete Saga. I imagine the case is very much the same for the Original Trilogy and the Force Awakens.The game is good - very good. It's just that I think a lot of what made Complete Saga good (the longer linear levels as opposed to the open world with short missions, for example) being lost has harmed the game quite a bit.

author: mullanliam
review: At the time of my review, I have 100%ed the game in all possible content. Every minikit, level mission, sidequest, kyber brick, all done. If DLC comes out that adds extra content, consider this outdated.This game is what every remake and remaster should strive to be. It builds on the original content without dampening the nostalgia or it's legacy in any way, whilst also bringing the game up to 2022 standards and polishing out the rough areas, whilst  adding three new films worth of content. Seriously, it's a gold standard for remakes and shines a harsh light on other remakes we've had recently that weren't created with the same level of commitment or sincerity as this. It took me 81 hours to 100% the game, but I could probably have finished quicker if I gave a bit more effort. For the price, this game is an absolute steal.

author: Dagothur
review: One of my most hyped games in YEARS and it's one of the most disappointing games I've played through in a long time. The entire game is boring and  repetitive, There's constant trailing missing and walking from point A to point B.The combat was hyped up for being more in-depth than any lego game we've seen, in reality, its just as simple as lego star wars the complete saga, You just press X over and over again and you can't lose.The graphics and sound design are my main complements to the game. Episode 4 was the only one that felt like they had put any effort into designing fun puzzles and game mechanics and even then episode 4 had a lot of issues from other episodes carried over. Player two constantly gets the worst characters to play as, For example in episode 9 when Rey goes to luke skywalkers island (which is a trailing mission by the way) player one gets Rey, and player two get some random islander frog-person with a sweeping brush. The most fun we had playing was after we finished episodes 1-9 and went to unlock yaddle and klaud so we could see them together. By the way, the side missions were better than story mode but still a lot of walking involved. my final consensus is this game is not worth the price and I wholeheartedly believe it's extremely over-rated and I give it a 4/10

author: SirGbaby
review: While LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga makes many significant improvements in graphics, combat, open world design, and overall presentation, it all culminates in a project with much less heart than the complete saga. Many additions in this game were either unnecessary or actively made the game worse. The overhauled combat system and new perk system were a welcome inclusion to the series. Each jedi and sith had unique animations that matched their movie counterparts. The game also introduced combos, counters, and ADS, which were all wonderful additions to a previously lackluster combat system.Unfortunately, since the game is so easy, these perk upgrades and combat system can be largely ignored. This ties into one of my biggest problems with the game, the boss battles. All boss fights play out in the exact same way, with locked camera angles, identical enemy moves, and absolutely zero variation. Additionally, they are made for one player, so if you are playing co-op, the second player essentially just watches and does little to get involved. This is most egregious in the Obi Wan vs Anakin battle in episode III where the one character plays as Obi Wan and the other plays as C3PO and does not engage in the fight whatsoever. Other levels I found disappointing compared to the original were the Battle of Geonosis, the first level of episode III and the Darth Maul fight. I found many of the flying levels of the original to be more nuanced and challenging. The flying levels and fighting levels of this game all played out the same. Besides the samey feeling of the levels and the awkward transition between story and open world moments, the game was great. The open worlds were fun to explore and offered thousands of puzzles to complete. Many become derivative after a while, but there are plenty to keep you interested until you grow tired of them. The voice acting is also very well done. Not only is it true to the movies, the game is also really funny. The slapstick visual humor and poking fun it did to the movies was amusing. Of course the music was amazing since it is a Star Wars game. The game also has hundreds of characters to unlock, many of which have unique dialog depending on which combination of characters you use. Unfortunately it does not include customizable characters. Ultimately this game is a well packaged compilation of the Skywalker Saga. It does a fantastic job at presenting the charm of the movies with its humor, world design, and massive catalog of characters and Easter eggs. The charm can begin to wear thin near the end of the game as it becomes clear that the developers were lazy when it came to their level design and especially their boss designs. Still the game is worth playing. 6/10

author: Rubbik
review: Me and my friend have been playing through this game together in our spare time. We have been mainly getting sidetracked with killing ourselves or each other in the game, due to the lack of intelligence we have, and can barely co-operate. My friend is a huge, I'd say, a huge Star Wars fan, and knows a lot about the movies and all. So I can say he is quite delighted at this game. I know a bit about Star Wars, but was never that into it to begin with. The game over all is a fantastic collection of all the movies into one action/comedy packed game. You can't go wrong with Star Wars games... Games graphics are sometimes it's downfall due to either frame drops or just bad animation, but it's not that noticeable per say. Gameplay is amazing, some characters are more fun that others, but the vast majority of them are very fun and enjoyable. Story and cutscenes, I have no complaints about. They're very funny and well animated. If you've somehow stumbled across this review, skeptical of buying the game, then I give you my advice, play it, with a friend or alone, the game is a blast. Might you find this review helpful, I'd much appreciate you liking it, to help others help decide on whether or not to buy the game. Not much of a critic, but I love the game, so I strongly recommend it to anyone who is interested in LEGO games or Star Wars games. And even if you're a new comer. Thank you for your time

author: Sevotius
review: As someone who grew up playing the original LEGO Star Wars games, it pains me to leave a negative review for The Skywalker Saga. Now I'm not saying this is a terrible game or even a bad one but it most certainly is not good. Let me explain:1. SO. MANY. BUGS. I've had characters getting stuck, characters phasing through levels, missions becoming impossible to complete forcing me to restart, texture problems (space encounters were permanently bugged as once I unlocked a capital ship, the entire battlefield was just consumed by massive low resolution ship that you can't interact with at all making it pretty hard to see what was going on), enemies becoming invincible or bugging out and a lot more. The state this game is in, while not unplayable, is also not acceptable.2. Missions are super short. Some of my fondest memories of the Complete Saga were playing through a wide selection of the scenes from the movies in full scale levels. Here it feels like everything's on fast forward with entire sections being just cutscenes. Some missions could easily be completed in 5 minutes with very little replay value.3. Building on the previous point, SO MUCH of this game is just collecting this and collecting that. Sure, it's a LEGO game and there's a lot of stuff to collect, I get that. But the ratio between levels and the open world collectathons is very badly skewed towards the latter. I'm guessing it'll take around 80-100 hours to get everything based on the progress I had. I spent ONLY 10 hours beating through all the levels and getting the goodies there. The rest of the 54 hours (!!) I played was just me going from Point A to Point B and grabbing something. This type of MMORPG busybody work is SO unfulfilling.4. Collecting all the stuff in the game wouldn't have been as vexing if the open world was actually fun or the puzzles/missions were interesting. It's really not. The open worlds are beautiful but so empty (and so numerous). The puzzles/missions are just copied and pasted. Maybe there are around 20-30 unique mission templates. Not bad, right? Well, there are literally over a thousand puzzles/missions here. Doing the same thing over and over again is NOT my idea of fun.5. On the other hand, the combat is actually fun! So why is this a con? There's barely any opportunity to actually enjoy it. Beyond the missions, the open worlds have very few combat encounters. It baffles me why so much effort was put into combat and RPG development (which I love) but then there are barely any combat encounters.6. The boss fights are incredibly uninspired. All of them basically have the same attack patterns, same rush attack, same AOE etc.7. There are TOO MANY SPACE ENCOUNTERS. At least reduce the time it takes for a space encounter to start OR, failing that, STOP THAT DAMN ALARM. It going off for over 10 seconds for the 50th time was torture.8. Strange how a LEGO game has barely any building in it. I really liked the idea of choosing what you can build but only the (very short) main missions have a precious few instances of it. Why?9. Obtrusive UI. It's all coarse and rough and irritating. And it gets everywhere. Seriously, why can't I turn off the tutorials for when Jedi/Sith attach to walls? Why do notifications on the character screen keep refreshing? Why is the character screen so unintuitive to use?10. The DLC characters don't have any voiced lines. Considering people are actually paying for this, why can't there be actual dialogue from them?11. I'm not a big fan of the new datacards system. Once I collected the stud multipliers, and subsequently got billions of studs, I had no reason to a) get new datacards beyond 100%ing the game and b) had nothing to spend my studs on.There ARE redeeming aspects to the game: great character models, funny gags, nice cutscenes and enjoyable combat. But the sheer mountain of bugs, tedious filler and boring open worlds make this game, frankly, just plain unenjoyable for me.

author: Sleepy
review: The people downvoting this game seem to have forgotten what a LEGO game is by its very nature.Yes, this isn't the Complete Saga all over again. There's been nearly a decade full of LEGO games produced since, and each one brought a new development to the series.By this point, TT Games began experimenting with entirely new engines, which culminated in this game not even using the original engine. Instead, this game alternates between a God of War-style beat-em-up combat and an over-the-shoulder shooter combat, alongside more puzzles on-brand with the LEGO games. This game is a bit more cinematic, a bit flashier, and the levels are a bit shorter, but this is still a full experience with tons of stuff to do and see.I get people being upset that it's different, but this game is trying not to step on the toes of TT's previous work, meaning Complete Saga is still a completely valid game to pick up and play after the release of this one. There are a few things this game does worse-- notably, the computer puzzles take way longer, but the ability to dump your Kyber Bricks (this game's version of Gold Bricks) into an upgrade tree and unlock things like panel skips and stud magnets right away makes this game a lot more simple in the "quality of life" department.This game, at the very least, is as strong as the Complete Saga, if not stronger. Ignore the naysayers, I think a lot of them just forgot how easy these games tend to be when they're not buggy. This is the Star Wars game young me would have wanted to play, a shame it took so long to finally exist.

author: FinnGregorioFanglorious
review: Hooooo boy... This is a sad one. After waiting through the delays and counting down to the final release, it was awesome getting to finally strap in. The game was great starting out, some changes from what I liked as a kid, but the spirit was there. It wasn't until the final level of Episode 3 when I ran into "the High Ground Glitch". You get halfway through this level and the game doesn't load the next objective. You assume you did something wrong so you save and exit, only to then realize the game is broken, and you can't go back into the level. I tried jumping to the later trilogies, but I was lying to myself while I kept playing. A nagging feeling that puts you down the path of the dark side, all because you don't have "the High Ground". It's been over a month, please don't buy the game until they patch and fix.

But pretty much everything is still fun so it doesn't take away from the experience.However the level challenges and side missions feel very much like padding rather than well thought out content. 'Having' to manually check each level's challenges before replaying in free play was incredibly tedious and hopefully not something that's continued in future games. Likewise the 140 side missions would have been much less repetitive had there been half as many in total.100% reached though :)

author: thefutilevariable
review: I want to get the one negative thing about this game out of the way first. I think that the weakest part of this game are the story missions. A lot of the episode missions and cut-scenes either feel too rushed or messy for them to feel fun or enjoyable. And the level challenges are some of the roughest content that this game has to offer. Many players have noted some bugs in relation to the level challenges as well, so for those who are looking to 100% this thing, good luck!That being said, I cannot recommend this game enough. In an age where games release with far too little on launch day, the Skywalker Saga is overflowing with content that will keep you engaged for hours upon hours.Like I had previously stated, there are elements of the story missions that are a bit of a downer, but that's not where the game shines, in my opinion. It's in the open exploration areas and the side missions. There's so much content in this game by you just running around and exploring. The space battles, unlocking space ships, capital ships (), and the CHARACTERS. Good absolute ♥♥♥♥ does this game have a roster of characters to unlock.Oh, and this game gets an automatic point for being a Lego game with this much content, and a Star Wars game with this much content. It seriously has no business being this good.

author: Dexedus
review: Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is probably the most impressive Lego game I've ever played. And the most fun I've had with one since the first Lego Batman game. Included is all 9 episodes from the Star Wars franchise, with each episode taking a little over an hour to complete. However the game is chock-full of side quests and collectibles and characters to unlock. Not to mention, the game spans an epic open world where you can visit many planets and iconic locations in free play as any character you like. Each planet includes a space region that you can explore in various ships from the movies as well. The graphics are gorgeous and the revamped combat system feels modern and smooth, albeit, for a Lego game. (Combat is not too complex). And the humor is great at times, accompanied by some good, and some bad, voice acting.But that's about where the good ends. As for the negatives, the game is buggy. I am still awaiting a patch for the issues i encountered, as I know many others experience the same as me. Choppy frame rates in areas where it really shouldn't be choppy. The game, sometimes, launching at 16 FPS requiring a whole restart of my system in order to be able to launch it in 60 FPS again. Which is frustrating, as I cannot find a fix for this. As I mentioned, the voice acting is bad in places. The worst of note is from Kylo Ren, sounds nothing like him. I couldn't help but laugh every time he spoke without his mask on. The majority of the voice acting is good though. And while the combat system is revamped and feels smooth, the lack of complexity makes it become stale after a few hours of play time.The game is also incredibly easy. It's literally impossible to fail quick time events and even in combat you take so little damage you could beat the game blindfolded. I know it's targeted at kids, but a higher difficulty option feels necessary here. Too bad there isn't one. And even if there was I doubt it'd do much to help the shockingly terrible AI of both enemies and your companion. it's extremely rare when the AI companion even attempts to help you in combat. Unless you are playing split screen, you're doing all of the work. At times I forget my companion is even there until I need him for a puzzle. The difficulty of this game is still the easiest I've seen out of any game in a long, long time. But the game is full of things to do and is very faithful to the franchise. I appreciate how full the galaxy feels and its still an incredible feat to pull off something of this magnitude. But you'd really think after all of the delays that the AI wouldn't be this bad and the Launch wouldn't be so buggy. But nonetheless, I recommend the game if you are a fan or Star Wars or Lego games in general. It's a great family game but if you want a fleshed out challenging open world star wars sandbox then maybe this isn't it

author: ThunderPhanterini
review: WOW major nostalgia from this game. First off, the open world is beautiful- if this is the formula for future LEGO games, they've completely transformed these from solid, fun, kid-friendly AA games, to super relevant and exciting gaming releases, especially considering this is easily one of the best Star Wars games of all time. In Complete Saga there were 6 level per film, here that is down to 5, but there are some story-related sections while traversing between levels. Honestly, these sections were super hit-or-miss, often filled with slow-pace escort missions. Far and away, my favorite part of the game is the open world galaxy exploration; I spent dozens of hours flying around the galaxy collecting bricks, unlocking characters, and of course, becoming a stud billionaire.Completing the main story is very enjoyable, and my time spent in galaxy free roam was full of amazing times. However, it became very clear why this game had been delayed so many times, and honestly could've used more delays. I certainly played this game more than most will, as I was going for the 100% achievement completion, but wow did I encounter some bugs. Everything from UI elements missing in fight missions, side quests being forever locked, many crashes, my resolution randomly turning into popcorn, characters being stuck in walls and many more. Another mixed feature for me was the new free-play format. In the old games levels had 10 minikits available, here levels only have 5, but there are mission quests. This may be an unpopular opinion, but I did not enjoy the mission quests, they made free-play feel like a chore, and the mission quests often require you to play levels in free play two or even three times. There were also occasions when mission quests could only be completed in story mode, with zero indication that was the case. So yeah, there are a lot of issues with this game, despite it being a massive jump for the LEGO games, and a wonderful Star Wars game. I don't like ending on a low note though, so... I'd like to talk about the vehicle levels. In previous LEGO games vehicle levels are some of my least favorite (and from what I've heard from others, nearly everyone seems to agree). That completely changes here- particularly with the flight missions which are so fun (although the textures in space are often pretty bad). Another positive feature is level variety. They could've easily redid, or modernized the levels that were used in the Complete Saga, instead there are completely new levels focusing on different levels of films that we've already played LEGO games for, which may hurt the nostalgia factor for some, but there is still plenty of nostalgia trips to experience. Another thing worth mentioning is the class system- characters are all organized into classes (jedi, sith, droid, etc.) that have special class abilities. There are some characters within their class which are more unique, such as there only being a few bounty hunters that have jetpacks. Ultimately, I had a really good time playing this game, but the longer I played the more I got annoyed by the constant bugs. I think they've created a great formula that still needs some perfecting on the technical end, bud the experience here is still unique and enjoyable.

author: rob
review: Perfect story. If you owned The complete saga, this game is a must. However, there are some things I have ran into that made it annoying to play. As a kid, I would grind TCS and got 100% like 2-3 times. Naturally, I wanted to do the same for this game. There are little bugs and things that make is so frustrating. Ill just start to list some that come to mind, individually they dont mean much but all of them together make it seem like a crappy game. the first "bug?" I ran into was trying to put in cheat codes. I had found some on instagram or something and wanted some free stuff, so I went to put in the code, and It was configured as If i was on controller. I couldnt just type out the could like "SIDIOUS" for example, I had to use my WASD keys to move to each individual letter and press space as if I was on a controller.This was on my first day, and I was trying to see the border for space, so i just kept flying out. I Got to the end and It turned my ship around, but it just kept flipping me and flipping me. not allowing me to open my map or menu or anything. This has happened multiple times and each time I had to close my game because of it.On a particular mission, the one with the gonk droid on kef bir, I had done it as one of the first missions I did because I wanted to unlock the gonk ship. after completing the story, and trying to 100% the game, I made my way to each plannet and completing them fully. However, on kef bir, I still have that gonk mission on the map, even though I have already completed it. I go to the spot where it is located, and there is no kind of NPC anywhere and I cant 100% kef bir, and in this case, the whole game, because of this bug.Another bug I have ran into is character selection. I am an OCD kinda guy when it comes to this stuff, So i want each of my fav characters from each class in order, but when trying to do so, it just does not save, or the character I want in that certain slot goes out to my current party, and then dissapears when I enter a cut scene. say I have my characters 1, 2, 3. I want to change my 2 character to someone else. I go to change it, and 2 stays the same, but 1 changes to the character I want in 2. I then try to change it back, and the character I want ends up going to my party and then dissapears after some time. SO. ANNOYING.there is also a place in the forbidden valley that I ended up flying over a fence with boba, and ended up not being able to go back, with exits no where else. for some reason, I was not able to travel to any other planets either, so I had to close my game.I dont know if this is just apart of the game or not, But I have gone through each (!) new thing when that protocol droid tells me he has hints, or just throgh the menu. I have gone through each character, each mission, each side mission, each ship, each puzzle, each everything! and instead of being "marked as read" or whatever you want to call it, whenever I close my game and go on it again, the little orange/yellow dot (!) shows up at the corner of every single thing I just went over. super. frustrating. how am i supposed to know where new things I have unlocked are? stuff that I have unlocked on day 1 show up as "new" everytime I log on.one of the more gameplay parts that are quite literally unplayable, are the droid factory mission, and most parts of endor.  I have a $2000 pc and the frames I get on those levels are in the negatives. theres not much I can say about it, but the fact that even when i put all of the graphics to low, it is still just as laggy, and looks crappier. All in all, I am glad this game has come out after all of this time, but I just wish some of these little things werent so $h*tty and annoying. I would recomend, but def dont spend a single penny more than just the base model of the game. Unlike me who preordered the deluxe and the quality of the game did not meet my expectations.(9.5/10) if these things are fixed(4/10 in the state the game is currently in for me, and probably for others too

author: Patch
review: A mismatch of many borrowed features that not only don't need to be there, but aren't even used to their full potential. I went into it expecting something akin to the older games, but instead was met with something entirely different, and entirely new. Massive explore-able worlds filled with side quests are paired with short, uninteresting and uninspired story missions that often skip over the exciting parts of the films. Fleshed out combat and upgrades systems are there next to new features like cover and counter attacks that I have never once considered using. You'll often spawn on a planet that's meant to be a war-zone, being directed to a mission start beacon, and yet the map is almost entirely empty if you walk around it. Even after my short time with the game, I feel as though I can say pretty solidly that whilst there's a lot to do in the game, it's debatable whether any of it is actually fun.

author: Mikey
review: Probably the best Lego game I've played from TellTale games. The levels and hubs are huge with a lot to explore, the level of detail and faithfulness is crazy as well, really feeling like the movies and the locations. Collecting and puzzles are also interesting, not as simple as the old TT lego games but not complex. The combat is the best change from previous games. It's so fun and engaging, stringing combos and using cover and different abilities. The game has tons of charm that feel like the old game as well. A must buy for fans of Star Wars and Lego games for sure. I haven't even come close to completing the game and that's probably the only real downside, there's SO much to do.

author: Soggy
review: There are many worlds to explore and many special blue bricks to collect but it all just feels empty. All of the worlds have the exact same toddler level puzzles scattered everywhere you go. You do not get anything other than kyber bricks and some generic characters for completing them. The only thing you can use kyber bricks for is character class upgrades that hardly do anything. The levels are fun but if you expect an exciting open world experience then this game is not for you. It is not currently worth the price but it will be once it gets cheaper and there are sales.

author: Ctoad73
review: I know that this will not be well written, but I'm just going to go on a sort of rant.Let me get all of the bad things out of the way first. The game was a buggy mess. While playing it, my save file completely disappeared, and I got it back only thanks to the steam cloud. Other than that, every time that I would change the graphics settings they would revert back in an hour or so even when I applied them, which was a real annoyance. Also while playing the speeder level, I would fall off of the map after a little while sending me into an infinite death loop, which happened about 3 times. In addition, some of the levels in this game are completely unplayable without aim assist (especially the speeder level which has no crosshair). Regarding the gameplay, most of the boss battles felt pretty repetitive and honestly kind of boring. You could just continue throwing your lightsaber at them, while they don't attack you for the most part, and they almost all followed the same attack patterns which were attacks that you had to doge, and then ones that you had to press keys on you're keyboard for. Regarding the story, the game prioritized minor story events over the major ones, which is kind of a new spin on lego star wars, but one that I did not like. Regardless of all of the bugs and things that I said above, I thought that It was very good, and brought back some memories of watching StarWars and playing the old lego trilogy as a kid. There is so much stuff to do, and I think that it was worth the 50 dollars that I spent on it. Overall, I enjoyed this game, although I wish that they would take more time releasing it to polish it up more.

author: fmoo
review: The most visually polished Lego game to date, but still plagued by softlocks that will keep you from getting 100% completion, or in some cases, prevent you from finishing the game.  Also recent patches seem to have messed with the default camera and FOV settings that makes the game more difficult to play.Multiple patches have dropped and the game has been out for many months.  As of August 2020, and there are still many suck or softlocked quests, such as "Pod Chasing".  I will not be able to 100% this game, and I will not be purchasing another LEGO game until this mess is fixed.

author: Prodicle
review: The Game:The story is really good with how accurate the lines are to the movies along with the voices, the combat has significantly improved compared to the Complete saga. I love how they kept in the silly jokes from the previous LEGO games and done them even better in this one, i was really worried that they would of made the jokes crap and stupid, but im very happy that they are good.The Multiplayer problem:So far.. very fun game to play in the evening with a friend... but im annoyed due to the fact you cant do online coop and have to resort to coop, which isn't the worst thing in the world for me as my friend would never buy the game even though he really enjoys playing it, so if your in the same position as me then just simply turn on remote play and do it that way, remote play has recently gotten some serious improvements with them connecting their controllers to your game with ease. If you don't have good WiFi or a bad PC then your gonna have to sit though the lag or tell them to come over to your house etc.OVER ALL:Good game sticking true to all the previous LEGO games but not just a copy and paste of the Complete Saga, I would say its worth it for the price due to all the little details added into the characters and how similar the voice actor are to the movies.

author: Turri
review: It's good but it's far away from perfect.As in all Lego Star Wars games I went for the 100%. I've achieved this in round about  70h.Sadly the main missions take you around 5-6 h and probably 5-6 h more to collect all minikits / 3 mini missions. So you have to spent another 55-60h in loading screens and free roam missions and challenges. This is just full BS. They should have created more main missions for sure. If you have seen the movies, you will notice that half of the story is missing or has been shorted. Also there are some bugs. Sometimes you have to restart missions or the whole game. In the end I enjoyed the game but I really hope that they will include more story missions in the next game. ♥

author: Xadus
review: Up until a few minutes ago, this would have been a very positive review. I rarely dedicate so much time to a game that isn't an MMO anymore, but "Lego Star Wars - The Skywalker Saga" kept me sucked in for hours. I love Star Wars, I love Lego, and I loved the old LSW games.I was ready to just say this game has some weird bugs that aren't game breaking and can just be annoying to deal with, but that was until I got hit with a bug that has rendered me unable to 100% it. There is a challenge called "Where's the Wookiee?" where you have to find and talk to a wandering wookiee NPC around the galaxy on pretty much each planet. I was at 26/33 and all of sudden, it reset back to 0/33. I went to see if he had respawned, and he had not. I can't complete it now meaning I can't 100% the game. This has existed for weeks now and nothing has been done.The game is great past that. Combat is simple but fun, platforming is fast and plentiful, and the comedy is on point. It's what I expected and more, but sadly marred by a game breaking bug and other technical issues that make me wonder why this game was delayed so many times?If they release a fix for aforementioned bug, this review will be edited and switched to positive for sure, but with the lack of communication from the developer, I don't see that happening unfortunately.

It might work for you, it doesn't really click for me.I would give this game a thumbs up if this was the only "issue" i have.But, my brother in christ, you can't delay a game for 2 years and when it releases it is still bug-riddled.I can name 4 game breaking bugs at the top of my head that will stop you from continuing the game.And if that wasn't bad enough there are still a gazillion bugs that are not game-breaking, but may force you to restart a level, quit out of the game, etc.And the best? It's been close to a month and NOTHING is fixed yet but they still release dlcs, nice.

author: coregarbage
review: I had 100% every episode (except for sequels bc i refuse to acknowledge that they exist), got around 400 kyberbricks, turned off my PC one night, only to find that my save had been removed. I haven't found a fix for this, so if anyone has pls lmk. I've spent 30 hours on this game, loving every single moment of it but the replay value has gone down significantly after this. I feel no motivation to go back and do this once again, and it's utterly disappointing :[ Other than that, great game. Love the OG star wars references sprinkled all throughout the game, the new combat style, the dialogue is way better than i thought it would be (and i thought i'd be using the mumbling instead), the gameplay is VERY rewarding and ultimately super satisfying.I could recommend this game to you, but i spent 60usd on it only to lose all of my progress. so ig purchase at ur own peril.

author: Magindoe
review: I love Lego star wars, but this game is...rather lacking, the levels are extremely short and the stories are done super quickly, i know they have a lot to cover but i would've greatly preferred more. but that's not the reason i'm not recommending it, no the reason i don't recommend it is the BUGS i have softlocked levels by accident at least 5 separate times, such as killing Kylo Ren as BB-88 causing Rey to be eternally in a quicktime event without my ability to switch to her to complete it, or the worst one, on the endor speeder section, (where i can barely shoot due to no tracking on the blaster bolts and their impact point always being below the speeders i'm targeting) where it took me so long to kill through them i ran out of terrain and fell into the void and died repeatedly forcing a restart.   this is frankly atrocious that there are this many ways to break it even using the upgrades  can nearly break things, like sprinting faster than NPCs causing them to bug out.  frankly heartbreaking to have to negatively review this :(

author: step-stein
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got the game from his uncle for his birthday, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: gaweldon
review: What a fun game!  You don't even have to be a Lego fan or a Star Wars fan to enjoy the heck out of this game!  With the story lines from all 9 Star Wars movies combined into a single game, you can expect to have many hours of action and fun.  The REAL benefit to the game, though, is all of the challenges, secrets, character unlocks, and puzzles (oh, the puzzles!) that are also in this game.  You could spend 100+ hours if you're a completionist, searching all the maps in Free Play mode, trying to find all the game's secrets in order to hit a perfect 100% find rate.  For adults, there's plenty of fun to be had and a lot of challenges to overcome.  (Plus, the game's not that hard to play, so this is the perfect video game for when you just want a relaxing evening in front of the computer.)  For kids, there's a HUGE number of items to smash, and the Star Wars story is fun to follow.  This game has something for everyone.

author: TurtleCube
review: Honestly one of the best LEGO games I've ever played. 9.7/10Pros: The story is super fun to play though, and it takes you through the open world as you go. It runs super smoothly with minimal bugs (compared to previous LEGO titles)  And the open world feels so alive! It so fun to explore!Cons: The levels themselves are very short. Like, super short. (at least for Ep I - III) In previous LEGO games you would have hours in the levels themselves and then the open world is unlocked after, in this games the levels last 5 - 15 minutes each, and there are only 5 per episode. I could stand for longer levels. Overall, this game is SUPER different to any LEGO game in the past, but I say it's 100% worth it. I just hope for the next LEGO game they keep the amazing open world and make the levels slightly longer.

author: < blank >
review: - klasyczna oprawa graficzna dla gier lego       - rozbudowany system walki      - zawarcie wszystkich 9 filmów      - duża ilość detali otoczenia gracza      - duża ilość grywalnych postaci oraz statków kosmicznych      - rozbudowane drzewko umiejętności      - duża ilość łamigłówek do rozwiązania       - fabuła gry trwa około 20 godzin      - istnieją DLC zawierające stary wygląd postaci, postacie z serialu Mandalorian oraz z filmu Łotr 1,         niestety nie istnieją DLC zawierające dodatkowe poziomy z seriali Mandalorian, Wojny Klonów oraz z         filmu Łotr 1      - Momentami kamera może zostać w poprzedniej lokacji podczas walki z bossem      - Kamera w niektórych lokacjach wychodzi poza obszar i pozwala nam patrzeć przez ściany      - Na Coruscant możemy spotkać Yaddle, której to głowa odchodzi od reszty ciała.  Kupiłem grę ze względu na dobre wspomnienia z czasów dzieciństwa gdy grałem w LEGO Star Wars. Spodziewałem się czegoś w rodzaju zwykłej gry LEGO w której będą śmieszne scenki, głupie teksty i milion łamigłówek do rozwiązania. Miałem rację i gra wypadła pod tym względem bardzo podobnie do innych gier z tego rodzaju lecz wyróżniła się bardzo przyjaznym dla młodych odbiorców sportretowaniem historii z całego kanonu filmowego oraz posiadaniem bardzo (jak na gry lego) zaawansowanym systemem walki. Ogólnie rzecz biorąc, gra jest idealna na wieczorne granie przez długi czas (oczywiście jeśli chcemy uzyskać 100% ukończenia gry) zarówno dla najmłodszych jak i dla tych starszych.

author: jdragon7
review: *The following guide pertains to the state of the game as it is on the date of 4/21/2022 and thusly does not refer to any future updates or patches. Also, there will be occasional references to The Complete Saga, as I'm strongly familiar with it and want to view the game both as a comparison and as its own thing.Launch day came- I was waiting a long time for this one, and even though I was trying to watch my funds I instantly purchased this game along with the deluxe pass to get all the dlc (Mando alone was enough to convince me). I played briefly through episode 1 with a friend and I've played through the story all the way through episode VI on my own since. I would love to be able to say that the game is everything I could've wanted and more, but the game is riddled with so many speed-bumps and bugs and downright strange design decisions and it gave me enough pause to reconsider my opinion. Thus, I'll break down both the bad and good parts of the game as I see them, beginning with the bad.THE BAD: I'm not going to lie the actual movie levels leave a lot to be desired. This certainly doesn't apply to all of them, but a multitude of the levels such as the endor bike battle and the gungan vs droids level just seem very devoid of interest or creativity and it makes enjoying the levels as a whole a lot more difficult since the consistency of quality just isn't anywhere to be found. Certain ways the movies and levels were interpreted are a lot more creatively bankrupt than their TCS counterparts were, and as someone who grew up with that game, it was very difficult for me to move past. Also- this is where the current date part comes in- the game has an extreme lack of polish. You cannot go two levels without discovering one infinite-death loop or even the occasional complete crash, and several of both main missions and side quests are quite bug-prone as well. The worst example I've seen doesn't even seem to be a bug- the endor bike level can LITERALLY RUN OUT OF WORLD if you can't kill the speeder clones fast enough (I had to turn on the aim-assist because of how awful shooting things with the speederbikes is, and you really shouldn't need something like that if its really meant to be optional.) At the very least I'm hopeful that the bugs will be fixed, and if they are, I'll feel a lot happier playing through it. THE GOOD: Free play has NEVER, EVER been better. It'sa so good. The ability to explore all 20 something worlds and each and every nook and cranny within them to hunt for collectibles is great, and I adore the fact you can pick whatever ship you like and dock anywhere or just fly around in space if you so wanted to. The moment I saw the Uscru district I was hooked, and besides some of the blander worlds like Geonosis feeling like more of a drag, I have no complaints about it. The combat system is amazing too- it hits that green zone between not being brain-dead but also not being difficult, and I love this game's spread of characters and their skills as well as how they can be applied in battles. In a similar vein, most every story level involving a major character you must fight is a slapper. High octane and fulfilling but never too long, and they all feel quite distinct from one another. I also very much love the hoth radio tower level- its just very fun to journey across this vast tundra looking for goodies. Would I still recommend this game? YYYYeah. My thumb's not all the way up but its certainly above the middle point. If this game got some much needed polish, it would sit just right with me. It will never be perfect, the inclusion of sequel content alone has ensured this, but I would firmly call it worth the wait.

review: Wait for bug fixes. Game can be a buggy mess and can be very inconsistent. Biggest issue I've had is how if you're playing as one type of character (such as a villain), the game will not lock on to villain ships. To give an example, I'm in the process of trying to 100% the Destroying Starkiller level on free play. Here's how it's gone.- Had to restart due to game giving me villain character and not letting me switch characters during the starfighter base attack at the beginning.-Restarted again due to being given a villain.-Restart for same reason.-Actually given a hero this time. Had to restart after switching to Darth Maul while fighting Kylo when it got to the scene where Kylo and Rey fight with the force over the lightsaber and it kept me in control of Darth Maul without letting me switch.-Restart due to being given villain character.-Restart for same reason.-Restart for same reason.-Got hero character and decided to stick with playing as Rey and Finn until I can get to the area with the first minikit available during the Kylo fight. Game crashes.-Restart the entire game and it crashes at the same point.-Game let me pick back up right at the Kylo fight. Restart due to crash at same point.-Game crashes again at same point.-Message about new DLC at beginning of game is labeled DLC_TITLE. Game crashes again.As far as gameplay goes, levels are way shorter and puzzles are way easier than previous lego games.

author: Roz
review: Don't get me wrong this game has its fun parts. Being able to relatively seamlessly fly from planet to planet is really great, and the graphics are amazing. There's not a whole lot of content though, which kind of makes me wonder what they did for the 2 years it was delayed. The upgrades are a nice concept but collecting 1000 kyberbricks... why, just why? The story is pretty bad most of the time, because its very compressed and you'll find most of it happens through cutscenes. There is no Coruscant space battle (happens in a cutscene), no battle of Geonosis, the death star trench run was pretty disappointing personally. As for the 2nd death star, you don't get to blow it up, don't get to fly carefully through its tight spaces to reach the reactor, that's all done in a cutscene. The co-op is nice but vertical split screen makes absolutely zero sense, especially considering you can play online not just locally, and because its vertical it severely limits your fov.Being able to explore the vast open world is great, the devs have done a good job there, the maps all look stunning. The only issue is that you're going to be spending that time completing fetch quests which more often than not have you travel to another planet, or collecting some of the 1000 kyberbricks like I mentioned earlier. The capital ships are honestly a really cool feature but the potential is just wasted completely. The selection also leaves something to be desired, for example you literally get to walk around on the Home One briefly but you can't buy it as a capital ship. They are nice to explore, sure, but the only thing to do is collect kyberbricks and maybe unlock some characters.This is by far the most buggy lego game I have ever played, I don't know how or why it was released in its current state. There are a lot of game breaking bugs, which prevent you from progressing the story. I had one in ep 4 where I had to get to yavin, but because most of the time smuggling missions are bugged I kept getting pulled out of hyperspace after killing all the fighters, and eventually I was stuck in a loop. I've lost count on how many times I've had to restart the game just because I couldn't grab something or equip something just to progress through the mission.Suffice it to say this game is a big disappointment, and for a game with no real content outside of the main story, the story still leaves a lot to be desired.

author: Oh Brother
review: Love this gameCannot get enough of this game, there are so many elements that make it fun, however after 52 hours of blood sweat and tears into collecting all possible collectibles, my game crashes during an empire strikes back replay mission, and BANG my entire save is lost, It now wont even let me select the save file as a game... I have tried changing files and restarting numerous times but still to no avail. I could look past the dodgy missions with bad FPS, I could deal with the whole world of endor running at 15 fps for the most part, but I draw the line at starting over because of one crash.++++++++++ 57 hours laterAfter taking some much needed time for meditation and self reflection upon my actions and words towards this game, I returned less than a month later and began the journey again, I was lucky enough to somewhat restore a save and only reduce my completion to a mere 20%. The grip this game has on me has been ungodly ever since, each waking moment I long to collect more bricks. After many updates the game has been almost perfected with only a handful of irritating bugs remaining such as not being able to use ANY OF MY CAPITAL SHIPS.....Nevertheless this game is amazing and I much enjoy collecting digital lego collectables and bragging to peers.Would recommend , just don't forget to make a copy of your game save.

author: Tony Spaghetti
review: Despite the performance issues (Ewok Village was a slideshow), bugs, and crashes Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is not just the ultimate Lego Star Wars game, it is one of the most complete Star Wars games ever made.Every major planet from the films is included and you can fly between them at will. It's the type of Star Wars wish fulfillment I've been dreaming of since childhood. Plus, there are tons of sidequests and puzzles to take on after finishing the short selection of story missions. 100%-ing this game is not recommended because of all the filler, but I will likely replay this game someday for the split-screen multiplayer potential.

author: Movmov
review: Firstly, I want to say I find the Star Wars MOVIES boring and every time I try to watch them I fall asleep, this game made me appreciate the Star Wars universe.This game is everything a Lego game could aspire to be, although there are some issues that prevent it from being a perfect masterpiece. I'm highlighting the cons because this game has a chance to get even better and become the ultimate Lego game to date.  Pros:*The scenery, graphics, music, combat, and Lego humor all fit perfectly into the perfect Lego Star Wars game and the best Star Wars game in general.*Plenty to see and do.*The ultimate Lego game.*The ultimate Star Wars game.*Exploration is splendid and I truly enjoy searching through every nook and cranny to find more goofy dialogue.Cons:*Levels are a tad bit too short (I actually enjoy the fact that most content is in the open world)*Character variety is a little bit weak in my opinion (A lot of characters are same-y & Porgs aren't playable :(  )*Open world is far too dense for vehicles and loading screens are plenty.*No character Customization which was a must in every single Lego game up until now.*Some animations are glitchy and/or missing audio.Overall, 9/10Bring Porgs as playable characters and make camera zoom out an option and I'll buy a Obi-Wan Kanobi minifig to put on my desk.

author: stamina10090
review: The game is meant to be played by exploring the planets and getting collectibles in-between campaign missions. If you try to "speed run" the campaign, you are going to run into constant traveling between planets with only cutscenes or only dealing with a few enemies at a time. There are too many parts in the campaign where your just following a slow character that's giving you dialogue (and if you try to run past them, the character will stand still), repetitive airspace battles, and too much game padding. The collectibles make the game really fun to play as some of the puzzles are challenging, unique and different. You can tell the developers tried to make every planet a unique environment. And Anakin's battle on Mustafar will always be iconic.

author: Taka.
review: If you were like me and LOVED the complete saga growing up as a kid you'll 100% love this one too. Its like the complete saga but updated and opened up a little more than previous Lego titles. I was a bit skeptical of the characters talking instead of their funny mumbles but the voice actors are nothing less than stellar. I think they might have gotten the actual voice actors from TV shows or the movies themselves which is a great detail. They do give you the option to turn it back to the 'no dialogue' like the older games too. It's also nice that they didnt copy and paste levels out of the older games into this one so it gives that new feel still. Also a new addition that i was a little worried about once i discovered it was the entire Upgrades section that gives different classes of characters better abilities and damage or whatnot. I havnt seen any balance issues or anything OP so far and im 4 episodes in.  TLDR: If you liked the complete saga you'll love this one. Worth the 60$.

author: Jared
review: I was honestly expecting a lot more from this game. Remaking one of the most beloved games from the ground up with a fresh coat of paint, new gameplay mechanics and a massive open world sounds a like recipe for success, especially since by the now the Lego format has been ran into ground about 30 times over. However, the game is so obviously rushed and is marred with glitches. One of which won't let me get 100% completion on Episode 3 because I'm simply not allowed to collect the last Minikit. I've had to reset the game a few times because when I switch tabs for a minute and switch back, I'm given a pure white screen. During one of the dogfights, the game was targeting other X-Wings instead the TIE fighters, which made it nearly impossible to hit them. So, I had reset it again. The controls straight lock on you. There are about a million instances where I've had to spam the acceleration or fire button to get them to work (no, it's not my controller. the buttons work perfect with other games). These issues can be forgiven if the game was fun but it's not. The game suffers from the video game equivalent of dead air. There are times where you have to slog through egregiously long walking sequences. Who's idea was this? Also, having to run long distances to your vehicle in order to start the mission. Why? The Speeder chase from Return of the Jedi is particularly bad in this instance. Holding the fire button while occasionally veering to the left or right. Even thee trees hardly do any damage to your vehicle. Just awful. There are some odd choices of scenes that got made into missions. For example: they left out the second Death Star dogfight from Return of the Jedi (it's only a single cutscene here) but they drag out Rey looking for Luke at the end of Force Awakens. It's so bizarre. Even the humor is pretty off here. There are more than a few occasions where the joke is LOL Random XD or just X character is dancing for no reason. The final lightsaber battle from Revenge of the Sith starts with Anakin just dancing. I just have no idea what's happening here. The game is massively disappointing. If you're inclined to buy this, just wait for a sale.EDIT: Almost forgot to mention the AI. Simply put, it's abysmal. Whenever you're pushing an object, they make sure to stand in your way and force you to switch to that character in order to move them. Whatever happened to just being able to just push the AI characters outta the way? Also, there are times where I get pretty far into a level and the AI is standing in the beginning area. Absolute trash.

author: thatoneguy
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: Beefnbean
review: This is a very fun game and it has something for everyone. Young, old, casual, hardcore, we all get that same dopamine rush from collecting Kyber Bricks. Solid .* The new open-world aspect where you can go anywhere you've previously discovered is really cool.* The new combat mechanics reward you for doing combos instead of button mashing (though button mashing is still pretty effective!)* Speaking of new combat mechanics, when turning off the auto aiming parts of aim-assist, guns feel  good. Knocking helmets of storm troopers to then 1 shot them is incredible.* While it may not be everyone's cup of tea, the voice acting is top tier along with the jokes and delivery.* The puzzles are great fun and at times can even be challenging to solve.* The story missions are the same great fun they've always been. It makes me want to watch the movies after finishing an episode.* The jokes and references are as hilarious as ever for both kids and adults alike.* The visuals are stunning! The textures on some of the non-Lego objects rival most modern games.* The sound design is on point. Whether its ambient noise, music or blaster fire, the developers put a lot of effort making sure everything sounds great.* Quite a few bugs. From a simple controller not responding to entering a cutscene only to be met with a black screen that must be Alt+F4'd. They aren't too frequent but hopefully they prioritize fixing them.* Alt-tabbing (or even sometimes using the steam overlay) while in full screen mode will force the resolution back to your native, but capped at 24 frames. Can be fixed by editing config files but shouldn't be happening.* The options are lacking. Particularly the display options, no brightness setting and very little graphical control.* Forced camera angles at random points in the game are between annoying to down right infuriating. Want to explore a boss area for minikits? Best we can do is a forced target lock on the boss. Trying to do this jumping section? Let me change your camera to a static wide angle mid-jump so you die.* . While overall this has been a blast to play with my fiancee, there are a myriad of small to bigger issues surrounding coop that we've found. When one player swaps characters, it will force the other player's character select open and ignore any inputs until they close it. No horizontal split-screen which makes certain activities like timed races where you can't see the next checkpoint very annoying. The excess party members will decide to randomly follow a player with no way (that we've found) to assign them, making some puzzles much more difficult if you decide to split up. No way to turn friendly fire off in a game that has wide swings and where you fight bosses in 2v1 scenarios is pretty silly. There are more but these are just the ones that comes to mind.

author: Nicostar
review: The Lego Star Wars series holds a very special place in my heart. I played the complete saga back in 2007 and was hooked on it since I was introduced into Star Wars in 2005. When I say I lost my mind when the first trailer for this game came out would be an understatement. This game has been an absolute joy to play. It's everything I could have wanted in a Lego Star Wars game, but that isn't to say the game doesn't have issues.Performance in the game is relatively flawless most of the time. I easily get over 100+ fps while dipping below that threshold in some areas, but I would rarely drop below 60. There are definitely a few noteworthy areas that need some optimization. The Droid Factory level in episode 2 and the Ewok village on Endor are the two biggest contenders for some optimization updates. Ewok village is arguably the worst area in the entire game in terms of performance. Due to the unnecessary amount of lighting elements and particles effects, it absolutely tanks your framerate. Not to mention the falling leaves everywhere and the fact the entire area has multiple floors as well adds to the decreased performance. I genuinely am not going anywhere near this area until it is optimized because it is absolutely awful to walk through and try to solve puzzles. I usually get 15 fps in that area and no matter what settings I change it stays the same. Safe to say I won't be going anywhere near that area for the foreseeable future.On top of "minor" performance issues, there are also some small, but quite infuriating bugs. One thing is the character select menu is extremely buggy. I'll go to swap out Han Solo for Padme but then Luke gets swapped for Padme instead of Han. It's extremely annoying as I like to have 1 of every category of character in case I need them in Free Play. Additionally, at times when you come out of a story mission after completing it in Free Play, your character roster will be randomized and you'll have to swap in the characters you were using before.Another small bug but something major that could be a hindrance to an unaware player is a bug involving space battles. Essentially whenever you're in space and join a space battle, whatever faction your character is  a part of will put you on one side of the battle. I play as Kylo Ren (a villain character) often so it puts me on the side of the First Order and has me fight rebel ships. If I were to play as Padme (a hero character) It would put me on the Republic side and have me fight against the Separatists. There are several side missions in the game that require you to do space battles. What will happen is if you're doing a mission-based space battle, depending on what faction your character is you won't be able to attack enemy ships. Usually you would receive aim assist and be able to lock on to enemy ships in order to keep track of them. Because I usually would play as a villain character (Kylo) I often wouldn't be able to see enemy ships or be able to track them. This made mission-based space battles almost impossible as it was extremely hard to destroy enemy ships, and it was almost impossible to keep track of them. The only way I found the counter to this bug was because of a YouTube video covering the mission I was playing. The fix is you have to play as a hero character for mission-based space battles. It's a small bug but if a player is unaware of it they would likely assume their game is broken, which isn't a good experience for any player.There are a few more bugs I haven't mentioned but my goal isn't to write an essay. I may sound nitpicky but I absolutely adore this game. Like I said earlier it's everything I could have wanted from a Lego game. Stellar graphics, good voice acting, great level design, fun combat, etc. I haven't gotten 100% completion in the game yet but I'm getting pretty close with almost 60 hours in the game so far. The game is definitely a grind but getting every collectible on a certain planet is extremely satisfying. On top of that some of the side missions are really fun and the dialogue and voice acting are an absolute treat. The game is hilarious, and die hard Star Wars fans will notice the love and attention that was put into this game.I'd honestly recommend the game to any fan of Star Wars or Lego games in general. I'd honestly suggest waiting a month or two for some patches to come out that address some of the major issues in the game, but other than that it's been an incredible experience so far and TT Games did not disappoint.

author: Jumpy
review: Star War The Third Gathers: The Backstroke of the West (often referred to as Star War Episode: The Backstroke of the West or shortened to Backstroke of the West) is a bootlegged version of Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith. The bootleg contains hilarious English subtitles translated poorly from Chinese. Due to the language barrier, many of the words and phrases were translated either literally or with alternate meanings, and thus the original meaning was lost. Most likely, the broken English is the result of being machine translated from the Chinese script. The subtitles were translated from Chinese rather than using the original English script. There are however several lines added that indicate it was not from a machine translator. For example, "Just as Count Dooku predicted" becomes "Kill these two republics bodyguard" and "Have the protocol droid's mind wiped" becomes "The protocol droid is my wife."

author: UThrewMySandwichAway MY SANDWICH
review: Most of these reviews are being funny so I'm going to write one real quick that might help a few people. First off i would like to praise the game by saying that it is beautiful and the gameplay (especially with blasters) is much better than previous games. I enjoy the combat and the exploration quite a bit as there are so many great planets to just run around on, the character choices are great and I think it is definitely worth playing if you have been excited for this game like i have been.However I have a few frustrations with how they tell the story. It took me roughly 30 hours to casually play through all 9 movies which is a solid amount of time for a lego game but i think the way they did it could've been better, for instance unlike TCS they do show all of the important scenes in each movie through one of 3 ways: A level, story locked freeroam and cut scenes. I think their choices for what scene should be what story telling device was picked poorly. For example, Revenge of the Sith had two major movie scenes that were cut scenes in the game: the battle over Coruscant and Mace Windu vs Sidious while Yoda and Chewy escaping Kashyyyk which was a 5 second scene in the movie, was an entire level, while it could've easily been a freeroam event. This happened in a few other parts of the Saga and bugged me quite a bit. About 50% of the levels seemed very short and didnt seem like there was enough time to find all the collectibles. As I am part of the group of adult players who enjoyed the original lego star wars games as a kid, I feel like my expectations for this game were through the roof and in some ways it met them but in other ways it did not. For kids today, I'm sure they will have an absolute blast playing this game, but for adults who have nostalgia for the old ones, even though it does have flaws, I still would highly recommend it, but I would also recommend to lower expectations a tad to fully enjoy it and not get mad at it. I had fun and I'm going back in to find all the Kyber bricks and 100% it as grindy as it may be because it is a great game to just play. 8/10.
