author: KillerRexxx
review: A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.A vast sea of stars serves as the backdrop for the Main Title, followed by a rollup, which crawls into infinity.War! The Republic is crumbling under attacks by the ruthless Sith Lord, Count Dooku. There are heroes on both sides. Evil is everywhere.In a stunning move, the fiendish droid leader, General Grievous, has swept into the Republic capital and kidnapped Chancellor Palpatine, leader of the Galactic Senate.As the Separatist Droid Army attempts to flee the besieged capital with their valuable hostage, two Jedi Knights lead a desperate mission to rescue the captive Chancellor. . . .PAN DOWN to reveal a REPUBLIC ATTACK CRUISER. Continue to PAN with the Cruiser as TWO JEDI STARFIGHTERS enter and head toward an enemy Battle Cruiser. TRUCK with the Jedi Fighters as they maneuver in unison, dodging flack and enemy laser fire. R2-D2 is on Anakin's ship. R4-P17 is on Obi-Wan's ship. A giant space battle is revealed as the tiny Jedi ships continue their assault in a synchronous ballet.2 INT. OBI-WAN'S STARFIGHTER COCKPIT-SPACEOBI-WAN bounces through the flack with a frown. His ship rocks violently.3 INT. ANAKINS STARFIGHTER COCKPIT-SPACEANAKIN smiles as he blasts a TRADE FEDERATION DROID DROP FIGHTER.ANAKIN: There isn't a droid made that can out fly you, Master, and no other way to get to the Chancellor . . .OBI-WAN: Look out, four droids inbound . . .4 EXT. CORUSCANT-SPACE BATTLEThe TWO JEDI FIGHTERS swerve in unison as FOUR TRADE FEDERATION DROID DROP FIGHTERS attack. After several clever moves by the Jedi, two of the FEDERATION DROID DROP FIGHTERS collide with each other in a ball of flame.5 INT. OBI-WAN'S STARFIGHTER COCKPIT-SPACEOBI-WAN struggles to maintain control of his ship.OBI-WAN: We've got to split them up.ANAKIN: Break left, fly through the guns on that tower.OBI-WAN flies to the left of a huge tower on a REPUBLIC CRUISER. The TWO DROID DROP FIGHTERS follow.OBI-WAN: Easy for you to say . . . why am I always the bait?ANAKIN: Don't worry. I'm coming around behind you.OBI-WAN deftly maneuvers around a large Starship's superstructure, but the TWO DROID FIGHTERS stay on his tail, BLASTING him with intense laser fire.OBI-WAN: Anakin, they're all over me!ANAKIN: Dead ahead! Closing . . . lock onto him, Artoo . . .ARTOO BEEPS his reply as ANAKIN swoops in for the kill. ANAKIN BLASTS one of the DROID DROP FIGHTERS. It EXPLODES.ANAKIN: (continuing, laughs) We got him, Artoo!ANAKIN BLASTS away at the second DROID DROP FIGHTER as ARTOO BEEPS an angry warning.ANAKIN: I copy, Artoo.OBI-WAN: I'm going down on the deck.ANAKIN: Good idea ... I need some room to maneuver.OBI-WAN dives toward the surface of one of the larger TRADE FEDERATION BATTLESHIPS and is forced to fly through a maelstrom of laser flack. He skims the surface, followed by the DROID DROP FIGHTER, which is followed by ANAKIN.ANAKIN: (continuing) Cut right. Do you hear me?! Cut right. Don't let him get a handle on you. Come on, Artoo, lock on! Lock on!ARTOO BEEPS. The crosshairs merge on the DROID DROP FIGHTER.OBI-WAN: Hurry up! I don't like this!OBI-WAN flies through a narrow gap between two towers on a Battleship. The DROID DROP FIGHTER hits one of Obi-Wan's wings with a laser blast, and parts of the ship go flying around Obi-Wan's Astro Droid, ARFOUR.OBI-WAN: (continuing) Ouch!R-4 BEEPS a blue streak.OBI-WAN: (continuing) Don't even try to fix it, Arfour. I've shut it down.ANAKIN: We're locked on ... we've got him . . .ANAKIN drops in behind the DROID DROP FIGHTER and blows him apart. ARTOO SQUEALS with delight.ANAKIN: (continuing) Yeah! We got him . . . good going, Artoo.OBI-WAN: Next time you're the bait . . . Now let's find the Command Ship and get on with it ...R-4 BEEPS a blue streak.ANAKIN: Lock onto them, Artoo. Master, General Grievous's ship is directly ahead.ARTOO BEEPS a reply, and it reads out in Anakin's cockpit.ANAKIN: (continuing) The one crawling with vulture droids.6 INT. OBI-WAN'S STARFIGHTER COCKPIT-SPACEOBI-WAN: I see it. Oh, this is going to be easy.Ahead is a TRADE FEDERATION CRUISER with batlike DROID VULTURE FIGHTERS stalking around on the hull. The VULTURE FIGHTERS transform into flight configuration, lift off the CRUISER, and attack the JEDI STARFIGHTERS.ANAKIN: Come on, Master.OBI-WAN: Not this time. There's too much at stake. We need help. Odd Ball, do you copy?ODD BALL: (OS) Copy, Red Leader.OBI-WAN: Mark my position and form your squad up behind me . . .7 INT. ODD BALL'S FIGHTER COCKPIT-SPACEODD BALL: We're on your tail, General Kenobi. Set S-foils in attack position.The protective ray shield lowers on the main hangar of the TRADE FEDERATION CRUISER, and six new DROID TRI-FIGHTERS emerge and join the DROID VULTURE FIGHTERS heading toward the Jedi. The JEDI STARFIGHTERS extend the stability foils on the ends of their wings.8 INT. ANAKIN'S FIGHTER COCKPIT-SPACEANAKIN: This is where the fun begins. Ten Vulture Droids straight ahead, coming down the left side.ARTOO BEEPS a worried message.OBI-WAN: Add five Tri-fighters on the right . . .ANAKIN: I'm going head to head. See you.OBI-WAN: Take it easy, Anakin.Four Clone Fighters move into formation behind the Jedi.ODD BALL: I'm on your right, Red Leader.ANAKIN: Incoming!!ARTOO SQUEALS as five DROID TRI-FIGHTERS pass by at high speed on the right.OBI-WAN: Five more on the right!Four more VULTURE DROID FIGHTERS pass at high speed from the left. All hell breaks loose. OBI-WAN and ANAKIN continue to fly in unison, backing up each other. ARTOO SQUEALS.ANAKIN: Here we go.The Jedi ships split up and make a quick loop around the DROID TRI-FIGHTERS, ending up behind them. BLASTING away. The DROID TRI-FIGHTERS EXPLODE.OBI-WAN: I'm going high and right.ANAKIN: Hang on. There are four more of them.OBI-WAN: Stay with me . . . swing back and right . . . help me engage. Back off ... Let them pass between us.ANAKIN: I'm coming around. I'm coming around on your tail.OBI-WAN: All right, engage . . . and hurry. These droids are all over me like a rash.In one incredible move, ANAKIN swings in behind the DROID TRI-FIGHTERS, blowing them away one by one until there is only one left. ARTOO CHIRPS.ARTOO lets out a HOWL as ANAKIN accelerates past the last DROID TRI-FIGHTER, slams on his brakes, flips the Fighter around, and BLASTS the Fighter from the front. ARTOO BEEPS frantically as they fly through the debris of the destroyed ships. ANAKIN looks behind him.ANAKIN: How many back there. Artoo? (Artoo beeps) Three . . . (continuing) Four . . . that's not good.OBI-WAN: Anakin, you have four on your tail.ANAKIN: I know. I know!OBI-WAN: Four more closing from your left.ANAKIN: I know. I know!OBI-WAN: Break right and go high.ANAKIN: I'm going low and left.Obi-Wan shakes his head.OBI-WAN: (to himself) He still has much to learn.ANAKIN swoops low and skims across a TRADE FEDERATION BATTLESHIP, dodging flack as ARTOO bounces along, trying to get out a sentence.ANAKIN: Hang on, Artoo. Obi-Wan, do you copy? I'm going to pull them through the needle . . .OBI-WAN: Too dangerous. First Jedi rule: "Survive."ANAKIN: Sorry, no choice. Come down here and thin them out a little.OBI-WAN drops in behind the DROID VULTURE FIGHTERS chasing Anakin. ARFOUR BEEPS to OBI-WAN.OBI-WAN: Just keep me steady . . . hold on ... not yet. . . now break left.OBI-WAN fires as he swings across the back of the VULTURE DROIDS, BLASTING four of them away. ANAKIN heads for a trench along the surface of one of the Trade Federation Battleships. He flies into the trench, which ends in a conning tower with a small slit between two main struts.OBI-WAN: (continuing) You'll never get through there, Anakin. It's too tight.ARTOO BEEPS nervously.ANAKIN: Easy, Artoo . . . we've done this before.OBI-WAN: Use the Force, think yourself through, the ship will follow.

author: STABBY
review: This game is a true love letter to all Star Wars fans, there is so much to do in this game beyond the main story that were all familiar with.Because of the “reimagination” of the Lego formula you will sometimes forget that you’re even playing a Lego game, which isn’t bad. This game is everything that I personally always wanted in a Star Wars game and the reason that it’s only a 9/10 is because they removed a feature that we all took for granted in Lego games and that is the ability to customise your character which is a bummer and they also didn’t add online coop which would’ve been perfect in this game, maybe they will add it at some point but I doubt that. Other than that this game is packed with hours of content and exploration and sometimes it even gets a bit overwhelming which I like.Anyways this is a great game for the longtime Star Wars fans and the newcomers.

author: fabula_rasa
review: I've been the Lego games' fan for many years. The old Lego games - where the characters mumble their merry way through all the cutscenes. I lost interest when they started talking, as a long with that the  was gone. And for me that, more than anything else, is a draw of a Lego game.That charm is also mostly gone here. Yeah, you can enable the mumble mode, but that fixes nothing. This game was written and directed with talking in mind, making the charakters artificially mumble does not suddenly remake the cutscenes into good slapstick.But that is my only complaint about this game. I had  playing it in coop with my husband. Being a Star Wars universe fan definitely add to that, but this game is just fun to play.There is always something immensely satisfying about smashing the whole world into a swirl of bricks and studs. :) But that's just an icing on the cake. The  is interesting and offers a wide variety of quests. None of them complicated, it's still a Lego game, but many quite amusing. There is many characters and vehicles to unlock and choose from. There are interesting locations and setpieces to find.This game is great for a bit of   - as it takes zero brain power to play (if you are not a literal child) but throws you into the world that is pleasing and vibrant enough to keep you engaged.Recommended for 'children' of all ages :).

author: Tootsalot
review: Best Star-Wars game. I was never much of a fan of some of the features that were included in earlier games like custom characters so I don't miss their inclusion. I never played the complete saga game as I only owned the individual games, Lego star wars 1,2, and 3. I feel like this is a great successor to those games even if it has no clone wars content which makes sense as it is focusing on the movies. I finished all of the content fairly quickly but still loved every second of it. I will say the character classes makes some characters less unique and makes a lot of characters feel the same, but that allowed for them to put in over 300 characters so I'm not complaining.

author: Midnya
review: I've played since release and wow, the amount of effort put into this is wild.There are some flaws don't get me wrong, the game feels a little too bloated with content, much of which is sort've copy and paste, i enjoyed the side quests in the open world and the execution of the story missions despite these issues tho. Very comedic but still loving of the movies you can tell the people who worked on it were glad to show how much they appreciate this world.Anyway, if you want to pick it up i recommend picking it up on sale, full price is well worth what you get here but sales certainly help if you're on a budget.

author: BlastDV
review: Just couldn't get myself to play it anymore.I have two huge problems with this game that to me killed the entire experience:1. The camera is too freaking close to the characters. I have played games for years, and this one made me sick after 20 or 30 minutes of play with its camera. Not to mention boss battles, you immediately lock on them and you are unable to move freely through the scenario to decide how and when to attack. If the enemy jumps from side to side, be prepared to get dizzy very quick.2. The game is insultingly easy. So much so that I had to disable all visual helps, guides and "tricks" that come enabled by default. With them, there is zero motivation for me to explore. But even without them, you just fly through the levels in minutes by simply going from point A to B. What for? Why does it have to be so easy? Is this game intended for 5 y/o kids? Previous Lego SW Games were not, they offered a fair challenge, nothing to write home about but I never felt completing a 4x4 jigsaw puzzle.Yes it looks cools, and I heard (stop caring hours ago) that there are hundreds of characters. But with the aforementioned, what for?

author: Michael
review: A solid addition to the LEGO game franchise, with all the staples you'd expect from one and more. Simple but fun gameplay, top-notch humor, and a blend of linear and open-world levels make for a fun time for fans and non-fans of  alike. Only receiving a negative review due to excessive bugs, which can prevent progression and have gone largely unfixed since release. An easy recommendation for casual players, but not until a significant bug patch is released.  is the sixth LEGO-themed game adapting the popular  franchise, this time consisting of content from all nine of the main  films, dubbed "The Skywalker Saga". It's a casual action-adventure game that takes you through the story of the films, albeit retold in a much more humorous fashion, with the ability to play as hundreds of characters from across the franchise. If you've played other  games in the past, then you have at least a rough idea of what to expect already. My only prior experience with the series was  back in the late 2000's, which was a lot of fun; and needless to say that this game has improved on its design in many ways since then. Combat is mostly a mindless button-masher, especially if you're buying character upgrades that increase health or damage. You do have the option of increasing the difficulty by disabling these upgrades at any time, as well as disabling settings like aim assist and health regeneration; but there's no strong penalty for death regardless, so it's kind of a moot point. Any real sense of challenge stems from solving puzzles or finding secrets, and even those are more about good observation of your surroundings than anything. LEGO games are designed to be accessible to younger players, so the low difficulty doesn't come as a surprise; but players wanting a challenge are better off looking elsewhere. I found it to be almost relaxing, as it let stay engaged without needing to be laser-focused at all times, letting me catch up on podcasts or talk to friends as I explored the galaxy. Whether you consider this a positive or a negative is up to you, but I personally enjoyed the more casual experience.Story missions are basically the same as they've been for previous titles: linear levels with the goal to get from point A to point B, interspersed with some easy puzzles and combat segments, as well as a handful of collectibles to find if you opt to stray just a little off the main path. Some levels will deviate from this, like starship battles or boss fights with multiple phases that have you running around the map to catch them, but none of them shake up the formula too much. Each of the nine episodes contain only five story missions apiece, but in-between them you're allowed to explore open-world environments iconic to the series, like Mos Eisley on Tatooine or Cloud City on Bespin. Each of these is loaded with collectibles to find, side missions to unlock new characters and ships, and a ton of environmental and platforming puzzles to solve, so most of your time will be spent here. The last  game I played only had story missions and a small hub to access them all, so I was pleasantly surprised to see this addition, as . It's absolutely chock-full of quality jokes: simple puns, "blink and you'll miss it" sight gags, comedic renditions of classic scenes, references to internet memes and more can be found everywhere, though never so much as to make it tiring to sift through. It's boldly unafraid to poke fun at itself, and I'm fully convinced that the writers of these games are more attuned to the franchise and its community than the writers of its official works are. I've never been the biggest Star Wars fan, but I still got a lot of good laughs while playing, and I'd wager that more dedicated fans will manage to find even more than I did.I went into this game with the lofty goal of reaching 100% completion--not for any good reason, I've just always had a soft spot for "collectathon" style gameplay. Completion is less a test of your  knowledge or player skill, and more a test of your patience thanks to the sheer amount of quick and simple tasks to do. It takes a firm "quantity over quality" approach to placement of the main collectible, Kyber bricks, ensuring that casual players can still stumble on enough of them to buy a fair few character upgrades without needing to go too far out of their way. Missions that unlock characters or ships are more involved, but even these won't take more than a few minutes each to beat. There are a few small hurdles that can make it tough to find everything on a given planet, like the collectible tracker not accounting for subareas (e.g. inside buildings), or collectibles/missions that are unavailable until you complete another objective elsewhere in the galaxy. It's far from the hardest challenge in gaming, but you need to make generous use of the built-in hint system so you're not running in circles trying to figure out what you're missing. I did eventually accomplish my goal, and while I don't regret having done it, I do admit to a huge sense of relief when it was finally over.  Explore each planet to your heart's content, but don't stress over doing every single thing unless you really like the gameplay or you're a die-hard completionist. I originally planned to list off the bugs I ran into during my playthrough to really accentuate this point, but there ended up being so many that I figured it would take up too much of my available word count to try and list them all. Most of them were minor visual/gameplay bugs, but some would force me to restart the game just to continue whatever mission I was doing (if it didn't crash the program outright), and other players have reported bugs in multiple areas that completely prevent them from progressing. It's been two months since release, and although we've seen DLC character packs and minor Steam updates devoid of patch notes, there seem to have been no updates that substantially fix the problems I and other players have had. Until this issue is addressed, I can't in good conscience recommend picking it up yet, lest you be one of the unlucky players that can't even finish the game they paid for.

author: Bluezerg
review: An open world Lego game isn't something I thought I'd ever see but here it is.Overall very good. Though I must make it clear that this is NOT meant to just be a remaster of The Complete Saga, this is it's own game. There are many things this game does very differently from the original. (Rip platforming)I like most of the side quests and puzzles, the graphics are fantastic, it's *mostly* well optimized (that geonosis factory mission could use some work lol). The combat is almost souls like but simple enough to get the hang of pretty quickly. The humor is about what you would expect from a Lego game.  The class system is not something I was expecting but I really like it, being able to upgrade specific class trees over others is pretty cool.I only have a handful of real gripes with The Skywalker Saga. While the open world is absolutely massive, the actual missions feel quite short and they can be a bit repetitive at times. A lot of the bosses felt too easy, even with auto health regen off, yeah I know this is still mostly meant to be a kids game but I would have liked a more difficult option regardless. No character creator kinda sucks but modders have already figured that out.Also no online co-op, bruh.I've seen others saying this game is really buggy but I myself didn't really encounter any major ones at all so I can't comment on that.There's a number of things I could nitpick (please give us our R2-D2 flight back lol) but the pros outweigh the cons. If you liked other Lego games you'll probably like this as well, 8/10.

author: マ カ レ ラ
review: I really wanted to like this game, but:There are no split screen settings and the game runs very poorly with steam remote play.There is not a single preorder bonus on steam. There are way too many framedrops, glitches and bugs wich literally force you to reload the level.For completion you have to collect 1000+ Kyber Bricks, wich becomes very repetitive and boring. Villains and Story Characters end up way differently than in the movies (e.g.  )In Boss fights you have a forced camera angle and the fight itself is the very same every time.The Petranaki-Arena and many other areas from the old games just seem dead due to lack of enemies.Side quests repeat themselves with travelling to many planets and through space fights only to get spawned into an asteroid over and over again wich breaks the game.The space battles and flying mechanics are a joke.And so much more.It's not all negative - don't get me wrong. The first story playthrough except for said missing loyalty to the original franchise was brilliant. There are many nice things to say about this game but after 85+ of frustration and decay of the last active braincells im done with this game. I now have completed it only to never play it again. . .wich is sad and can't be said about the original LEGO games.Compared to the previous LEGO Star Wars Games and all in all it's a good thought but (for me) became more and more frustrating the further you got in the game.60€ for this cluster of glitches, crashes and bugs - come on!Props to my friend  for sharing my suffering with this playthrough.

author: Canuck TRKY
review: I got caught up in the game's nostalgia and bought the Deluxe Edition, only to remember why I gave up on Lego games before.The gameplay is pointlessly simple and repetitive, every time you interact as R2-D2 it's the exact same 3 dial combo which gets old really fast. In any of the fighting, you just have to spam hit Q and you can complete most missions without dying.There is no challenge to any of the levels, I remember in the original version, the pod race took me so many tries to finally complete, in this version it took one try. The main levels leave you feeling dissatisfied, and there is only 5 per movie which feels a little weak.Every cool fight scene from the movies is turned into a cut scene that you don't get to interact with and all of the boss fights involve repeating the same action over and over. Spam hit Q, press buttons on command, repeat, that is every single boss battle.Some of the side missions/challenges are stupidly complex and the game gives you no clue how to figure them out even with buying the hints. The best example is the Explo-Sith challenge where you specifically have to use a scoundrel and shoot the right spot. All the hint tells you is "use the environment to kill a sith trooper", so you're left fumbling around the level, trying all the logical stuff. Challenges like this force you to google the solution which is a perfect sign of a poorly designed game. There are also a bunch of challenges that just make you waste time running from point to point, not even collecting items just chatting and then running off to the next point.Overall it just feels like a game that was partially stuck together and thrown out to the public.The worst part of this game is the fact that the developers completely ignored the Clone Wars and Rebels which adds a lot more depth to the story and should have been somewhat included in the game.

author: FOD Warfare
review: After Beating the game in its entirety now here is the Pro's and Cons that I hadPro's: Great Visuals and GameplayStory was great felt like old times when playing the Original Lego Star Wars Games. Con's: If you are a Completist then this will take you a while to get 100% and they may add more content down the lineThere were some bugs but most of them have been fixed since release date. All in all it is a Great Game to play especially if you are a Star Wars Fan.

author: Liquid_Six
review: TLDR: I am sad. Wait for a deep deep deep sale.This was the worst Star Wars experience I've ever had in a game, especially one that had absolutely zero right to screw up as badly as it did. If you have any passion for Star Wars, its stories and emotion, and you loved the Lego Complete Saga, just play that again. There is about less than 10 minutes of cutscenes or important story sequences per episode. Every serious or emotional scene has been disrespected by some need to cram humor in instead. I understand its a Lego game, I love Lego games and have played the vast majority of them to completion but this one just left a bad taste in my mouth. Everything that should have been great fell short of what it should have been. Pros:1) Visually, its fantastic. They more or less nailed the look of the hub worlds. The Uscru District on Coruscant was my absolute favorite, it felt dense, very much reminded me of the visual feel of Cyberpunk 2077 (no matter your opinion of the state of the game). Mos Espa and Mos Eisley were amazing as well. They really captured the feel of Star Wars cities.2) That is about it.Cons:1) The story chapters/missions. This should have been the bulk of the game. I know with hub worlds there would be a lot of collectibles, but they should have put a lot more into the actual story. Obviously no one is playing this without knowledge of the plots of the different episodes, but there are vast sections of story that are either missing or condensed into seconds or minutes. The actual pacing of the story and its missions are terrible. With 5 missions per episode, the game moves through the plot with lighting speed. While playing any particular episode's story, you play both the 5 story missions and also have to travel in the respective hub world to get to the next mission. I liked that concept to a degree, but they failed at recreating sections of the episodes that should have been incorporated. When R2 escapes the Lars homestead, Luke and C3P0 set out to find him. Do you use Luke's landspeeder? No. You walk. You walk for 10 seconds to tusken raider camp that is essentially your next door neighbor in terms of distance. Repeat another 10 second walk to get to Obi-Wan's home. Luke training with Yoda was an in-between sequence. It should have been a full mission. I think I spent less than 5 minutes from landing on Dagobah to leaving Dagobah. These sequences between missions showed that the developers did not care to capture the Star Wars experience. Previous titles that operated in this manner (Lego LotR/Hobbit and even The Force Awakens) absolutely got the story pacing right. The cutscenes in the missions shows this too. Qui-Gon dies after Darth Maul is cut in half. Jango Fett dies by having a Republic Gunship landing on him. The Battle of Geonosis doesn't even exist. There is no battle over Coruscant. Grievous takes selfies inside his ship as he flies away from the trade federation cruiser. Obi-Wan and Anakin have no farewell. Obi-Wan and Grievous's fight takes place entirely in the hangar where Obi-Wan drops down in. No wheelbike chase. And Grievous is killed by Obi-Wan throwing his lightsaber into his chest. I really don't want to rant and continue but every story sequence made me cringe because it was so abysmally disrespectful to Star Wars fans.2) Character selection: There are not 380 character in this game.  There is far less than that. Every costume counts as a character, so the nearly 30 characters taken up by Poe Dameron, Finn, and sequel trliogy Leia may help demonstrate the real lack of characters. There are multiple character classes and nearly all of them play the same. Jedi, Hero, Smuggler, Scavenger, Bounty Hunter, Villain, Sith, Atromech, and Protocol Droid. All these classes have abilities to upgrade using kyber bricks as a currency (there are nearly 1200 to collect in the game) and 90% of the abilities serve no purpose. There is also another category of characters called "Extra." This category of 70-80 characters is useless. They have no abilities, no weapons, and can only punch. The game does not utilize them in any capacity. There is not a single point in the game where you had to use a Sith character. Over half of the characters you can unlock in this game are duplicates. 3) Space Exploration/Combat: All ships are the same and all space gameplay was unenjoyable. A massive let down. Something like 90 ships to unlock and I lost interest in choosing a different ship after changing them 3-4 times.

review: I have long been a fan of LEGO games. And as a fan of Star Wars, I had been really looking forward to this release. I bought it on the day it came out and have played it until I reached 100% completion. Just like all LEGO games you get to complete the game with at least 2 playthroughs with many minikits to collect and challenges to complete. There are so many side quests, trials, races, hunts, and delivery missions spread throughout a vast galaxy of planets that you can explore and take you straight back into the movies. All missions have a pun joke or easter egg hidden within it or in its name. This LEGO game is by far the most fun and immersive one to date. TPS camera definitely brought the game to a whole new level. All should play this game. A true Star Wars experience. May the force be with you.

But, if you dislike open world games full to the brim with monotony that becomes a dredge to get through 100+ hours deep on your way to 100%ing, I don't recommend. A majority of the game is just that, and some of the levels are too incredibly short to be considered levels (a few of which can literally be beat in 2 minutes). They kept this game true to the original and added more things that made it even better than the original: - open world exploration- the game being fully voice acted- side quests - etc!The one thing I really hoped this game could have (maybe a potential update to consider in the future) is true multiplayer. It would have been nice to be able to connect to maybe two or three online friends to play together rather than the split screen multiplayer this game offers.

author: Mikazuki-Five
review: This isn't a bad game, but I'm bummed I don't like it.The combat in this game is actually pretty neat, and light saber duels are fun! The game also looks gorgeous and has a lot of details particular to the actual lego pieces. It's really fun noticing them all! However, my love ends there.These levels are very short. Each Episode has six chapters, and they are all pretty short, and that super sucks. Some levels are fine in length, like the final Maul and Anakin fight I remember being fine, but still. And to be fair, you do get a big open area before a new zone typically, but it's just exploring and trying to find collectibles, and also sometimes being told that you don't have the ability to get the collectible until way later- despite having the required character type for it. IMO these open areas don't make up for these short levels at all. Another issue I take up with the game is its co-op, and how terrible it feels. I always loved co-oping these games but good lord is the camera just the worst here. it just splits it down the middle vertically and is just not that fun to go through. And don't even get me started on the fact that there's no online co-op whatsoever. IIRC The Complete Saga only had online co-op in a bonus town level where you run around breaking and building stuff, and that's whatever- but how have we not gone from that to full level co-op in the fourteen years since? And yeah you can absolutely just steam remote play it together but then you have that awful camera. I think the last negative I have is this game's voice acting. This game has voice acting, and it's good! It's good, don't get me wrong, but it's dialogue and general humor isn't funny or as charming in comparison to the pantomiming of the originals. Yeah mumble mode exists- but it sounds awkward, and the scenes don't work with it. I switched off of it really quick because it really just kinda makes the game worse. I think maybe the voice acting would've been fine if the humor was just different. There's a lot of random "that's not supposed to be there haha lol" type humor here and its so constant and down your throat and not funny that it just takes me out of it everytime.To end: Growing up I loved those old games (much like anyone reading this review). I 100%'d the first three SW releases alongside the first Indiana Jones game (fell off while doing Batman. Would like to try that again some day). I hold a very special place in my heart for their fun and simple gameplay and unique pantomime humor, so I really am bummed I don't '♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ slam dunk' love this game. Again, it ain't bad, but for me, I think it's been long enough that a revisit to TCS would be a more fun time.

author: Hazzy
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: laitz
review: I only really  got really interested once I learned about the exploration aspect of the different planets and the sheer amount of characters to unlock. It felt like a real step up in ambition compared to the previous Lego games. But could it remain the charm of the older games?, How is the voice acting?, How much creativity was put into the Collection of Kyber Bricks?, Is the DLC’s worth it? The graphics were top notch, Humor was really on point and well thought out with a lot of popular references and it was clear the developers loved Star wars. I loved the Voice acting and i much prefer it to the old mumble mode, they really did a great job finding voice actors (some being the actual ones, c3po/lando for example, clone wars) The kyber bricks were at points very similar to collect, but I mostly had fun collecting them all over the galaxy. It reminded me a lot of Super mario odyssey, it of course doesn’t live up to the quality of collecting power moons :D. I enjoyed the fact that they were all uniquely named though, it was fun seeing all the puns. :In my opinion this is the best Lego game by far, It did suffer from a lot of bugs, but I was absolutely fine with it. The character roster were great with a lot of obscure characters having voice acting and unique movements. The interactions between characters were hilarious to discover and I’m sad the devs didn’t get to add as many as they had planned. As usual in these games the grind around 65-85% is a bit boring, but once you get towards the end it’s very much worth it for me :) I have 100%’d two lego games so far, this and Lego Marvel Superheroes 1!I would rate this 9/10, with the former a 8/10! A really great game overal

author: ItsJackLads
review: LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga's story pacing is the absolute worst but when it comes to the open world, it's a lot of fun and has a great level of detail. I'm currently working on grinding out my way to 100% completion and oh boy does it take some time! Supposedly there is roughly 90 hours of content & after just getting to 33 as of writing this review it certainly seems that way. I'm glad the game is this long but I feel it's starts to get boring during these end game grind hours. Challenges are a lot of back and forth missions repeating similar tasks such as traveling between 2 planets but getting ambushed 3x times (this happens a lot for side quests) with only a few key challenges having something that feels relatively unique. They bragged about the character count being so high, but do I really need 16 different versions of an astromech droid in alternate colours or rebel soldier/pilot with different names? Not really & most of them felt like filler characters just to bulk up that roster. Don't get me wrong the option is nice but I would have much rather seen bonus popular characters from TV shows as a replacement for half of these recolour/slightly different skins characters.This game as of current has a lot of bugs. From NPC's getting stuck behind objects, which in turn locks your camera at a set angle if the quest is waiting on them to get to a position to talk to, Capital ships showing up in the middle of space quests having you clip inside them and do space battles inside of their model (even when you don't have a capital ship active), random crashes, really bad optimisation in some set pieces such as the dreaded droid factory (rip my fps I get about 20 in there) for lower end devices and sometimes a quest NPC just isn't where it is meant to be or is invisible.I've been rather negative in this review but it's worth a play if you're a Star Wars fan & I still recommend giving it a try, though Lego Star Wars A Complete Saga is still in my opinion an overall better experience as the story feels less rushed and the game isn't trying to be a grind for the sake of padding it's run time. At best i'd probably give this a 6/10. It hasn't impressed me but it is still a decent play through.

author: RetroTiara6756
review: This game has so much content and is a major step up from The Complete Saga. Not saying TCS is bad, but the controls and level design were a bit wonky. These controls feel tight and the open world is, well, open. It's great to explore all these planets and their many biomes as a large cast of characters and ships. As of writing this, I have just over 100 hours in the game and I'm not even halfway through the campaign because the open world is so diverse and packed full of content. You can tell the creators put a lot of care into this one, even going as far as to include 'Mumble Mode' for us long-time fans. Except the Sequel Trilogy. It feels rushed (just like the movies) and seemingly lacks the collectibles of the Lucas Films. Nevertheless, the Skywalker Saga wouldn't be much of a complete Saga without them. And other than those nitpicks, they are alright. A true Lego Star Wars experience will be found in the Original Trilogy and ESPECIALLY the Prequels. I know, a surprise to be sure, but a welcome one.Overall, a great game for both children and nostalgia-chasers alike. Would definitely recommend to players looking for a fun adventure or a chill universe of discovery.

author: sumysoomie
review: While I completely recommend the game when it is at it's best, I can't really recommend playing the game now while the amount of bugs that are present are still unfixed.I have personally had many bugs and it's probably the single most buggy game I've ever played. I felt as if I should warn people about what they may possibly encounter in the game's current state as of April 16th, 2022. I could remember the following 4 off of the top of my head.1. I had my lightsaber just completely disappear during the fight against Kylo Ren in the forest on Starkiller Base, so I had to punch ren to beat him.2. I struggled to get past the speeder chase level in ROTJ where I would just run out of map to fly down, meaning I would eventually just fall into a black pit over and over again. It's impossible to beat the level without turning aim assist on.3. The most annoying one is when I would go into each combat zone during a smuggling mission, I would be spawned inside the droid control ship's mesh and that would take up the entire screen; I think it was because it was the last ship I had boarded for a majority of the game? Just a giant eyesore which happened 100% of the time in those missions. / Annoyingly, the droid control ship would also just sit there in the sky when I was on the surface of all planets.4. A couple times, movement absolutely ceased to function along with a fair few other controls. It wasn't the settings being messed up or my controller being the problem, both the keyboard and my controller were unable to move the character.There were very few crashes fortunately, too few to make them consistent or linked to each other.I still highly recommend the game, it is a load of fun and has tons of content, maybe too much but I still think it's worth full price.

author: Solace
review: Ok the game is fun, like its really fun, the combat is just fantastic, the visuals are amazing and its got some hilarious jokes but for me, its an 8.5/10. The reason why is becuase after a while it feels so bland, i feel like the devs focused more on exploration rather than fighting, which is such a shame cause the new combat system is great, when im fighting droids or clones its really fun.Space combat is awesome, i feel like a badass taking down one of the capital ships, which is why i like flying in space more than running around on the planets. Another issue i have with the game is the lack of really important scenes, now i know the game is big, i get it but i still think cutting some of the most important scenes is bad, not to mention that the dialouge sometimes sounds so weird at times, someone says something and you're waiting for another character to respond but the scene is already over.I also feel that the bugs that I and several others have experienced should've been noticed long before the game even released, the mission Endor the Line when the map stops loading and you fall for like 5 minutes, should've been discovered by playtesters(if they even have any, tbh idk at this point).Now the biggest issue for me is the lack of a customizer. Now yes i know the game has like around 380 characters to play, but lets be real who is going to play every version of a battle droid, a clone, a stormtrooper or any of the other characters with 50 different variations, or any of the characters that were on screen for like 2 seconds. Now its cool that we got a lot of characters but we're not going to play half of them and even saying that we're going to play half of them is generous.Im pretty sure this is the first of the major lego games to not have a customizer and its such a shame, the biggest lego game doesnt have one of the most important features, i know some people dont use it but i always did, i loved making my own Sith lord or Jedi master and go mess around.So yeah to me and to a lot of people, it was a big deal.now would i still recommend it? Absolutely, like i've said, the game is really fun and if anyone is debating on buying it then i hope this review helped you. Oh and to anyone that bothered to read all this, you're all a bunch of legends, take care everyone.

author: Piss Man™
review: Through the hours spent playing with my best friend I have to say this game is quite fun. The jokes and references are quite hilarious and the interactions with the characters always make me smile. The open world is great and very cool to go around and explore doing all the side missions. The only problems I've had are a bug with the trade federation lucrehulk appearing during cargo missions, the game crashing on a rare occasion, some (previously locked) areas not being able to be accessed after going in them once... Mainly the B1-Breakroom/Dance Floor, and the major concern of the main episodes being fast paced and having a lot of major plot points being unplayable or shown for a split second. Other than that it's a wonderful game that keeps the satirical humor of the Lego series as well as the nostalgia of growing up with Star Wars. All hail the mighty Gonk

author: Dazed N Blaized

All of my progress was lost when I got to the main menu. The only option was to start a new game. This is unacceptable. This has never happened to me with any game I've ever played in my life.Steam will not allow a refund as well not even though this game has become unplayable for me to progress. This is sad because I was really looking forward to a game this refined since my childhood. Buy Lego Star Wars The Complete Saga if anything. You will have a much better experience guaranteed. This product feels rushed and unfinished. Levels lack length, depth, and charm found in the original games. I really wish this turned out differently. :(

author: Toevahkiin
review: First off i would like to state that i am 26 years old so nothing inside this game is a "challenge" from combat to puzzles. So unless you eat lead paint for breakfast you should easily find this game enjoyable and playable. The HUD in this game can get a little messy so you might have the need to pop some adderall so stay sane but its fine. In general if you're 6 or 60 you will enjoy this game. If you're a star wars fan you will enjoy this game. if you're someone who is a completion ♥♥♥♥♥ who doesn't want to see the sun for about 7 days you will enjoy this game. The only downside i see this having is no online co-op but it does have steam play, so i guess there's that. I know i don't have very many hours on this yet but from what i have done so far solo and with a friend using steam play i can easily see myself logging some serious hours into this game to try to 100% it. Buying it now at the $50 price point is a steal for how much content is inside, waiting for a sale is a even smarter approach for getting the ultimate bang for your buck. Truly this is the best star wars experience I've had in years!

author: TotallyNotDelta
review: Pros:-Best looking LEGO game released yet. The minor details such as reflections or dirt on individual bricks is fantastic.-Combat and puzzles are enjoyable enough. It's obviously a kid's game first and foremost, but is still able to provide entertainment for adults.-For those interested, the open world provides hours of content beyond the nine episodes.-The humor is absolutely brilliant. There are many references to very popular memes.-The sequel trilogy is finally given the respect it deserves. That is to say, none whatsoever. Rise of Skywalker in particular is treated as though it were a Spaceballs-esque parody.-For the most part, performance seems to be solid enough. Individual problems are listed as negativesNegatives:-When the game runs slowly, it really slows down. There were two levels when I dropped from 144 to 50 FPS on average.-Fullscreen support defaults to 24 hz. This resets every time you alt-tab out of the game.-Controls are a mixed bag. The game played well enough with a controller, but the keyboard/mouse inputs cannot be fully rebound.-Pacing is extremely inconsistent. Some minor sequences in the films are given full levels, but major set pieces such as the Battle over Coruscant or the attack on the second Death Star are relegated to cut scenes. All nine episodes suffer from this to an extent, though the prequels and Return of the Jedi feel worst off. This is actually my biggest issue with the game, and the reason I don't recommend it.

author: Poprocket
review: I don't think I can properly express how much joy this game brings to me. I played so much of TCS growing up, and this game is everything I could hope for as an ultimate edition to that and more. First off, the game boasts 45 levels (5 for each film, no shorter films like in TCS) but that's only the basics of the game. Each planet has one or more large hub areas to explore that are flush with gags, side quests, and challenges. This game is absolutely brimming with content! Of course, to 100% the game you'll need to play through every level on story mode to grab all of the extra Kyber bricks and minikits. Now, onto the gameplay. The combat has been improved, by a lot. No more isometric camera, it follows your character sort of behind and over-the-shoulder. Lightsaber characters have 3 attacks, plus a slam and a lightsaber throw, as well as counters. The game also features a hit-combo system. This being a family game it is of course viable to just faceroll and spam the basic attack to kill everything, but the flashy combos are more efficient and reward you with more studs. Blaster shots are all aimed (the game has a togglable aim assist and soft-target locking) and along with the two lightsaber-using classes there are four (typically) blaster-wielding classes as well!Visually, the game is quite pretty. It's not going to completely blow you away, but you weren't expecting that. The important thing is it runs like butter, and I've heard it even runs well on lower-end PCs to boot.Of course, the game has a few things missing and some changes longtime fans won't like. There is no more Cantina hub, as you now activate story missions by travelling to their respective planets and areas. Also conspicuously absent is a custom character creator, which I would love to get my hands on with the massive roster the game features.Overall I'd give this a 9/10 so far. It's a blast to play alone or with a friend, partner, kid, little sibling, whoever. Just go enjoy it

author: James Fox
review: I've put around 10 hours into this game, so I think I have a pretty good idea how I feel about it. As someone who grew up with the older LEGO games, my hopes for this game were very high. Thankfully, this game delivers the experience I was after. The differences that stand out the most is the overhauled combat system and open world like areas you can explore outside of the main story levels. The amount of things to collect is staggering, and I think I'll be spending many many hours searching every corner of these environments for hidden goodies. I also think the graphics are quite lovely. There were several times where I stopped what I was going just to take in the visuals. In regard to the graphics, the textures were the real standout aspect here. The LEGO bricks in the environments as well as the characters themselves are brimming with detail and look like real life LEGO pieces. The modeling for many of the ships and environments look like real LEGO sets I could sit down and make if I had the right bricks.I do have a few critiques though. For one, I think the cutscenes are too short and rush through the story a little too quickly. Also, the camera can sometimes bug out and get stuck on things. I kind of wish an option was there to make the camera follow behind your character at all times. I found fiddling with the camera in certain areas to be a pain. Also, I did encounter a few bugs here and there, but nothing that took away from the overall experience. One such bug caused the game to freeze and activate my controller's rumble. I had to close the game to get it to stop.Overall, this game is well worth your time and money, especially if you are a longtime fan of the old LEGO games. It's nice to see modern games actually living up to the hype, and I hope this game sets a new standard for future LEGO titles to come.

author: Xenago
review: Great overall for superfans, but has some major issues that absolutely need to be fixed. Seems a bit rushed even with the delays. If any of these bother you, you should avoid this game completely:- Terrible CPU performance/optimization, it's heavily single-threaded and can absolutely chug- DX11 only(?), no vulkan or DX12 - see above point about CPU performance- No online co-op (WTF!)- In local co-op, vertical splitscreen is forced- No FOV adjustment (it's way too low)- Exclusive fullscreen mode doesn't work properly so you have to use borderless, which means VRR/gsync don't work either- Studs (coins) don't look as nice as the old sprites, these look lifeless and dull- Checkerboard rendering artifacts are everywhere- Chromatic aberration can't be disabled on its own- Mouse and keyboard input is not fully supported in the menus- Plenty of bugs

author: Reijvi
review: I want to first make it clear, this game is a decent overall game, but, personally I ended up being quite disappointed with it. Both from a Star Wars game and as a Lego game.My main issue with the game is it's level structure. They are really short and messy. You do hub mission in-between the levels which almost feels like it could be a part of the level but it's not, it's just a set up to the next level, and aren't even replayable, which makes the actual levels really short. They are so short that infact, instead of the iconic 10 minikits per level, it's been cut down to just 5.Some key moments are even put into these "hub missions" which means, fighting Jango Fett in episode 2 or boarding the seperatist ship as Obi-wan and Qui-gon in episode 1? Yeah, that's a one time event that you can't replay unless you start a new save. Other key moments like the battle of Genosis, blowing up the death star 2 and the opening battle of episode 3 aren't even playable events at all. Other cutscenes like the death star blowing up a planet is outright missing.Now, as a lego game. It just misses a lot of that classic vibe, when going back to levels in freeplay, there simply aren't many fun quirky secrets. Compare episode 4 in TCS, you had some stuff like a room that was an optical illusion, an infinite silver stud dispenser, a hat dispenser hidden away plus a bunch of buildable cars, a room where u grew plants, another room whose sole purpose was just to shoot out stormtroopers into the vacuum of space, and of course let's not forget, the hot tub stormtroopers. What was the reason for all of this? Just silly fun, nothing more, nothing less.Now, in TSS this same level you get to find the hot tub stormtroopers again, but now for some reason there is even an invisible wall not letting you join them, because no fun am I right? But that's about it in terms of fun hidden quirky stuff, it doesn't have the same fun reason to re-play and explore played levels.Talking about replaying played levels, you can't even switch ships in most ship levels in freeplay mode, and a lot of the ship levels are actually possible to 100% without even going into freeplay to begin with, not that it had much reason to exist to begin with, if you can't even switch into playing custom ships, which is freeplays main reason to exist usually.Other weird things are also a lot of characters feel more samey now. All characters can now double jump, and it seems like also all characters are able to fight aswell, R2D2 can't even hover anymore. Sure there are some minor things, like hey this character fights with these animations, or has this different sound effect. But otherwise, their core gameplay is quite similar. Are there unique characters? Yes, but not to the same degree or core gameplay anymore.In TCS, you had characters that could pretty much triple jump like Jar Jar, Jedi could double jump, other characters could either roll or single jump, others couldn't even jump at all, and some could float with jetpacks.In TSS, all characters can now double jump, and some like Boba Fett can use their jetpack to float for a few seconds. That's about it.As an open world game however, it's fun, it has many areas to explore and collect simple collectables, but yet again, compared to TCS or even The Clone Wars lego game, there aren't many enemies to mindlessly fight. You can find one-time encounters in the world, but after that, those areas are gone, forever. Most hubs actually have no enemies at all to fight after u complete all the encounters, which aren't many there to start with. Which is a shame, because the combat in this game is truly really fun, even if too easy at times.Even in hubs where the npcs should logically fight you, they don't. You have unlocked the death star as a hub, with dozens of stormtroopers? Well shoot them and they'll just run away. You've unlocked a big seperatist ship as a hub? Same story. The city planet Courosant or Kamino with a bunch of clones walking around or even posing as guards? Guess what, they'll run away if you even shoot remotely close to them.A side note I also wanted to mention, you can't even make custom characters anymore either.Now a more serious issue, but hopefully temporal one, are the bugs or lack of technical features like FOV.The game to put it lightly, is buggy. You may be really lucky and not experience any bugs, but if you're like the majority of us, you will experience at least some bugs, even if they aren't game breaking.For me, here's the bugs I've encountered at the top of my head. First time starting up the game, no characters had any faces, When switching to a character in a hub world it switched into a bloody big space ship and constantly crashed and hit invisible walls and got me killed. I've soft locked my game after I quit in the middle of a hub mission, this reset the hub and made me unable to complete this hub mission which was necessary to unlock the next story mission/level. (this sadly is a very common problem which render many unable to complete the story levels)I've been put into a constant walk mode, where I can't sprint.The game crashes randomly.Sometimes the game won't let me use space travel when playing in a hub in freeplay.When playing with the mouse and controlling space ships often it gets stuck and keeps flying in one direction.I could go on with a lot more personal gripes I got with this game to be honest, but I feel like this review has become long enough and I've gotten to say most of my major points.

author: shoes4wyrms
review: Honestly, most people seem to have other opinions, and maybe I just need to give it another chance, but this game seems nowhere near the quality of the old games. Sure a lot of the mechanics are more fleshed out and feels more polished, the graphics are great, and it’s just as charming; but gameplay design is the worst of any game I’ve played for years.Here’s my experience playing episode 1: everything that used to be a level in the old games is now a cutscene with mediocre voice acting and a sprinkle of decent voice acting, some gags are actually funny and overall these cutscenes are fairly charming but they are also THE ENTIRE GAME NOW. Seriously, you use your lightsaber to kill enemies maybe 4 times before the reaching the end of the episode.You get to pilot a few things but I’m fairly sure there’s no failure condition (pod race is 100% rigged in your favour). You literally spend 5 minutes walking and talking with palpatine on courescant. Why? How is this gameplay? Why was so much time spent on a level that you walk through when the entire sequence between landing on naboo (the second time) and fighting maul is a cutscene????You could make an argument for the open world areas if they were interesting, but they are for the most part vast wastelands sparsely populated with a couple puzzles and nothing to fight.The platforming sequences have been reduced to “press A to watch your character jump to the next platform”The special purposes of the characters seem to have been completely removed from the game. There are some things you can only do with certain characters, but other than the force they are not required to solve puzzles. I have not played as an astromech or protocol droid at all yet and see no need to. Anakin doesn’t crawl through little doors, jar jar doesn’t jump high. They all have unique combat abilities but you don’t fight anything so it doesn’t matter.80% of the game so far is walk to a point, press A, and watch a cutscene and wish you got to play it.The upgrade system is such a confusing choice it almost feels like it was tacked on just to encourage people to explore, dangling the stud magnet in front of you like a carrot on a stick. Most of the upgrades don’t even matter because combat is so easy and sparse it would almost be a shame to make your character more powerful. The run speed upgrade is the most powerful since most of this game is just walking to the next cutscene.I feel like this game was in development forever and I’m just surprised this is what the result was. It’s such a far cry from the absolute pure passion and love that was poured into the old games. How did Tt go from action-packed levels with somewhat tricky platforming and fun and simple Lego based puzzles where you actually built ♥♥♥♥ and interacted with it to a game with little more interaction than a visual novel?My friend and I honestly just kept asking ourselves why we weren’t just watching the movie. This game offers little more entertainment in the same amount of time.

author: boxmonkey99
review: Why no episode 3 space battle mission? It was one of the most memorable and fun missions from the previous lego star wars games, and they replaced it with point A -> B corridor sprinting simulator where they continuously babble movie dialogue into your ear for 3 uninterrupted minutes and then the mission is over. Get used to it because the entire game is saturated with this formula. The previous games never did this. Who thought this was a good use of the players time?Also, why the overly complicated controls? I used to love introducing non-gamers to The Complete Saga due to it's extremely simple and easy to learn controls, and every time they had a blast. You could literally beat the levels knowing just 2 buttons and the left stick. Even though the controls were super simple, the levels still allowed for fun and engaging gameplay. I figured this game would build off of those ideals on release but I was surely mistaken. The character now operate like a 3rd person fps game, where you now need to use both sticks to navigate the world, both left and right triggers to aim and shoot your gun/lightsaber, all 4 face buttons for melee combat, and the D-pad for their copy-paste hacking minigames. It's  asking too much from the gaming illiterate, and I witnessed firsthand as my friend struggled to mentally map which button did what action and was fighting the camera to not get it to constantly point at the back-end of a wall or corner. Again... The older lego games never suffered from this problem. The split screen camera also feels half baked... like they did a much more clever implementation in Lego star wars TCW where the camera was a single entity capturing both your characters on a single screen, and then would separate into two screens and follow each of you when you got too far away from one another. The camera would be zoomed out enough to where you could still see what was in front of you and behind you. Here it's just a static vertical line down the center, and it's so zoomed in your characters take up half the screen, so good luck telling what's happening or where you're supposed to be going. The cutscenes are all pretty chuckleworthy, and they brought back the VA cast from the clone wars tv show, which are the only strong positives I have for this game... oh and i guess it looks really pretty. The maps also feel rather empty. Sure you can gawk at the huge map, but it's really missing that classic lego charm where you would find all sorts of derpy vehicles, fun powerups, or secret hidden zones in each level. Remember the kamino disco area? Remember the movie theater on mos eisley? Remember the Lego city bonus level? Remember the force ghosts and indiana jones? Remember the hilarious death sounds? Custom characters? Unlockable cheats? It's those small touches that truly made the complete saga a classic and it's why I recommend you play that game instead of this one, especially if you're looking to play this with friends. It's just ok by itself. TL;DR 6/10 singleplayer, 4/10 in co-op. There are better lego games out there... I don't hate the game, I just know it could be so much better...

author: emperor
review: I wanted to love this game and call it GOTY 2022, but sadly it's incredibly shallow. It's very pretty and the animations are great. That's about it for positives- 1 (one) hour into the game I'm at 20% of Episode 1 story content completed with effortless True Jedi in every eligible level. But I've already beaten Sebulba, got back from Tatooine and got the Valorum vote cutscene. That's about 50% of the movie, so I don't know what is treated as story content in this game- gameplay (story mode, so for a 9-movie star wars game - bread and butter) is mostly walking from point A to B and watching a short cutscene (under 1min)- there is no Maul boss fight on Tatooine, it's a short cutscene, which in my opinion is a crime and disgrace- the game offers 0 challenge, I'd say you could play it with your eyes closed but you have to follow the waypoint-orb in the huge wasteland hub worlds to advance the story- character upgrades are limited to "you run 30% faster" or "you deal 10% more damage with lightsabers"- 731 puzzles in the game, none of which I feel inclined to complete- over 300 characters to unlock, with not much to do with them (other than tons of side content I didn't really buy the game for)- UI sound design is absolutely HORRIBLE, makes my ears bleed, switching between holo menu buttons makes the most awful screeching sound. Had to take off my headphones to check out all skill upgradesIn other words, kids will love it

author: Nessarolla
review: I love Lego games and for sure Lego Star Wars is one of my favorites. So far I'm enjoying it a lot however while I was exploring I realized I wanted to make my own character and low and behold there is no character creator.It kind of bums me out because that was just such an iconic part of the Lego Stars Wars. To be able to mix and match different parts and make your own hero. I get that we have over 300 characters to choose from but nothing beats the fun of Sith Lord Jar Jar Binks. I don't know why they chose to do without it but I hope they reconsider re adding it later on in the future.I have encountered some bugs and glitches here and there but they don't last long. I think I only had to redo a mission once because I got stuck in a void.All in all really nice remake. 9/10

I expect some repetitive game play in the LEGO series, but this was too much.

author: CptRanger
review: It sadden's me to say this (especially after Marvel Lego Superheroes 2 and Star Wars The Force Awakens, but you should not buy this game at full price. Actually you should probably wait a year or two for the price to drop and here is why.So far starting at The Phantom Menace, and halfway through Attack of the Clones.. I have built (ya know where ya build things to get through the missions) a TOTAL of 6 times. The levels have none of the "soul" of the previous games and instead are 99% non-lego with Lego display stand, and benches, and planters cut and pasted across the entire open world parts and even the missions themselves.There are no more red bricks, instead there are kyber crystalls (over 1100) all over the maps which are used as currency to purchase class (like for Jedi, Droids, etc) upgrades, or what would be use to be Red Bricks. 2x, 4x, 6x, 8x, 10x bricks are gone, and while you use to be able to hit True Jedi without them in previous games, getting True Jedi is a major pain in the backside on some levels because it now has 3 tiers.The game has no soul, and there is more to do in the original Lego Star Wars game then in this game spanning 9 films so far.I've been waiting a long time for this game, and it suffers from what I would Pandemic Game Development™ (meaning that they just put what they had in a box and shipped it, and lacks all the charm and fun of the previous lego games.If this changes before finishing the Story Mode of all 9 episodes I'll update this.

author: Tucker-117
review: Not a bad game, the free roam is quite fun, but I just have to point out some issues.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------INFURIATIONS:- UI is cluttered, and can be hard to use at times.- Bugs that require a workaround (Might be fixed in a patch).- Certain levels deny the ability to backtrack if you missed something. Certain vehicle levels are abhorrent as they force you forward and you may have to redo the level several times to get all of the mini-kits.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------MINOR DISAPPOINTMENTS:- Certain characters are not playable despite there existing official Lego Figures that appeared in official sets, including Saesee Tiin, Agen kolar, any version of Clonetrooper pilot, At-At pilot, and Geonosian Warrior. The last three listed were playable in the Complete Saga.- Certain characters are missing their unique blaster sounds, Jango, Padme, and Geonosian blasters.- Dislike of deviating from the classic Lego game UI, and certain classic sound effects.- No extra toggle for classic death sounds.- Venators are used in Attack of the Clones instead of Acclamators.- There are only 5 levels per episode, and some levels can be short.- Freeplay does not give you a random set of characters (atleast one of each class) like the original does to encourage the use of a variety of characters. You will have to fumble with the clunky UI instead of smoothly swapping through your provided characters. Player 1 and player 2 are randomized I think, but not the rest of the characters on quick select.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------MAJOR DISAPPOINTMENTS:- No replayable missions for certain parts of the films, prime examples include a space battle of Coruscant and negotiations with the trade federation, which were both full levels in the original 2005 game.- Iconic locations like Jabba's Palace, and the Petranaki Arena can only be visiting during levels, despite the game's heavy emphasis on the open world. So much for finding Jabba at Jabba's Palace. - Massive disappointment at the lack of a character creator.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

author: Monkey Bebop
review: If you grew up playing the original lego star wars games and want to bask in some nostalgia, do not buy this game. It's a huge shift in style from the originals and you will be disappointed. The developers decided it would be a good idea to make this game semi open world, but that doesn't really describe it well. It puts you in a larger than normal level where you can run around explore. This gameplay element really slows down the game due to the collectibles strewn about in the level. Although you technically don't need these collectibles and they are all optional, the collectibles give you "kyber crystals" which are necessary to unlock upgrades for classes of playable characters. These upgrades can require anywhere from 1 crystal all the way to 15, and these crystals aren't easy to come by. I also find this game quite handholdy. You could argue that this is a game for children but I remember the originals quite well and they did not take you by the hand and tell you exactly what to do and what is happening. Some of the cutscenes are unnecessarily long for whats happening so you just end up sitting there waiting for them to end so you can get back to the game. This is a personal point of contention but I do not like the voice acted lines in lego games. Never have. The humor of this game does not come through as they once did. I do not recommend this game if you are a fan of the original trilogy and sequel trilogy games. But perhaps if this is your first foray into the realm of lego star wars, you might find some enjoyment in this game.

author: leed
review: So far it's ok at best. If you want the exitement you had in "Complete Saga" or other Lego games (Hobbit, Pirates of the Carabean, Harry Potter, Indiana Jones etc) you'll be disappointed. Instead of hacking down legions of baddies, crumbling down environment and building new structures as well as solving puzzles as a team, you get a lot of boring tasks, like following NPCs, talking to NPCs and watching over rushed cut-scenes. While playing Episode I, I was looking for droids to tackle, but apart from 1-2 occasional ones, most that appeared were just in cut-scenes. At the time I would be landing on Naboo in "complete saga" I was already confronting Darth Maul in "Skywalker Saga". It hurts me to say this, as I was really looking forward to this game, but it's simply not as fun as the older Lego games were. The story is super rushed, and the action was replaced with dull open-world tasks. Also the Coop playing mechanism is rather weak. It feels more as if this was intended to be a single player game with multi-player option, not like previous Lego games that really focussed on cooperation between players.

author: Brand_One
review: Fantastic recreation of the original with added sequels making it the definitive movie to game experience. It feels amazing to just break everything for studs as usual. The jokes land even for me as an adult despite being mostly geared towards children. Level challenges often give you alternate ways to progress a level that you would have never thought of for your initial run through. Collectibles are fun as ever to collect. I keep having to remind myself when I get stuck on a puzzle that it was not made to be super complex, and often just requires looking around, and then I figure it out. A downside is that replayability of an episode cuts out the parts that are not the linear levels, which can be disappointing. Overall super fun.

author: "supreme" pooshit
review: really fun game, but a little heavy on the side content. completionist will take quite some time. feels like the classic goofy lego experience, but i found a few things make the game a little more enjoyable:1. turn off floor guides to the quest marker. this makes the game playable for people <4 years old and really shouldn't be in the game at all, or at least by default.2. turn off auto aim, or at least turn it to soft auto aim. default setting is literally just aimbot, removes the small semblance of skillful mechanic in the game. sadly though i would suggest turning it back on just for a couple space ship chase sequences where it's sooo difficult to hit the enemy ship.otherwise the game is a fantastic mix of humor and great diverse mechanics. on top of that it's the best looking lego game to date. feels like i'm playing with my own legos again sometimes with how pretty it looks.all the DLC is cosmetic, too. some folks are complaining about there being multiple "collections" but i mean, how else are they going to make a buck off of post-release content? support the company and devs for bringing us the most comprehensive L:SW experience to date. they even added characters from shows that came out 6 months after the game released. that is some dope ass ♥♥♥♥, my guy.

author: jake3433
review: Disappointed with this one, most of all with the levels. Levels are extremely short and just not very fun to play, they are missing something. The game mostly consists of walking from cutscene to cutscene, fast travelling from one hub world to the next, until you get to an actual level, which again aren't very good, then repeat. You can explore these hub worlds in between levels and are free to do side activities that are honestly not worth doing. There are lots of hub worlds and they're fun to explore but it get's boring quickly.The main focus of the game seems to be collecting Kyber bricks but I lost interest in that quickly as they are pretty easy to do and there's too many, it's too tedious/pointless. There are a lot of unlockable characters but there's nothing to do with them, they mostly all play the same. You can free roam as them but that's entertaining for only so long, replaying levels as them is not enjoyable for reasons already mentioned.The game does look really good though and the amount of areas to explore is very good as well, pretty much most locations in Star Wars can be explored. Overall the game does have a fair amount of content just not in the areas it counts the most, there is no replayability. It gets boring very quickly. I give it a 4/10.Cons:- levels are very short, not very fun and not enough per episode.-Not enough combat.- lots of characters but nothing to do with them.- Main point of game is collectables.- Hub worlds lose interest easily.- Switching character screen is very annoying to use.- no character creator.-  Just overall gets boring very quicklyPros:- Looks really good- new combat is really good, good combat system- good mouse and keyboard support
