author: Luna
review: Let's start with positives. Overall gameplay is alright if we are talking about ground exploration and combat. In space tho it's simply hold shoot button to win. Not much interesting there. All ships got pretty much the same felling and bigger ships with a lot of guns like corvettes were scale down for some reason and feature the same "2 blasters and 1 torpedo tube" layout. The only exception is ships without guns that feel a lot faster.A lot of character and ships to unlock, you will surely find characters\ships you like. Dialog and humor is okay. Graphics and attention to details is good also.Let's get to the bad part.First of all. I'm sick of Ray on the main screen. Not only they put her as a face of Skywalker family on the main screen, it also seems she got alzheimer and constantly "looking for someone to show her da way" with the only one specific voiceline everytime. No wonder people try to fix this with mods. It was pretty obvious that she will become annoying with time. Main menu screen also contains animation of her appearing with her that you can't skip so you are forced to watch and listen to her every damn time.So why only one line from the only character that not really that likable?! Was that hard to add few other iconic character with their lines or ability to skip this intro? About "screens". There are a LOT of loading screens in the game. Activating "continue play" button will take you like 6 different screens, windows and buttons to press\skip. Even when loading your save it will load narration text crawl that you unable to skip for 5-7 seconds for some reason and after you finally skip it you will get another loading screen getting you into the game. What designer\developer decided that this was a good idea? Why can't i turn off text crawl screen so i won't have to skip it every time even if it will take a little bit longer to load main game? And why do i get confirmation screen with "Loading successful" text that i also need to interact with and close it manually because game won't proceed without it?Also i found out that this game really dislikes "alt+tab" combination. For some reason it sometimes changes my screen resolution. Controls for PC are terrible and ability to customize our controls are too limited, since some buttons are responsible for 3-4 actions and you can't separate them.Player\game communication also not great. Some areas or interactable objects are limited to specific characters and abilities. So game asks for a character that you have, you select it, but you still can't interact with object because actually you have to play season 7 to unlock a special ability for this class. And game does not tell you that, i had to google it.Quantity over quality. 1200 kybercubes to collect that allows you to upgrade your character and specific class of heroes. The best source of cubes i found so far is asteroids that are limited and gives you only 5 cubes. Not only that is a lot of stuff to collect, but there are also perk that allows you to seem these cubes on your current level and when you turn it on your screen will be overwhelmed with a lot of different ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you have to collect, so you turn if off because of that making it useless. So why that many cubes? I can't see any practical reason why was it balances this way.Make it 100-200 cubes and upgrades to cost less. Why do i need this many cubes?!

author: TheKingsMan8
review: Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga. This is not your typical Lego game, it's filled with lots of content that should keep you playing for 100+ hours. I have just over 70 hours on the game and I've only finished the first six movies, meaning I still have many planets/locations, main missions, characters, side missions, ships, data cards and kyber bricks to find. So far my experience has been amazing. My background on Lego games goes pretty far. From Lego Star Wars the complete saga, to Lego Batman one and many more.You don't need to have watched the Star Wars movie in order to play and enjoy this game. However, a lot of extra conversations when exploring planets are about things only die hard Star Wars fans would understand.So, let me give you the good and bad about Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga. All my opinion of course-The bad-Bugs. I'm playing the game on a pretty good PC (steam version) and there have been some bugs i've came across so far. Here are some of them.- Random floating head shooting lasers- Clipping through walls/ground- Random crashing- Certain levels are very laggy (not because of PC specs, most people have said specifically the droid factory level on Episode two, Attack Of the Clones is laggy)- I haven't had this one happen to me personally but it's game breaking and needs to be fixed, in Episode 7, the force awakens. When you visit Maza's castle to do a main mission, sometimes the mission simply wont be playable therefor you cannot progress in Episode 7, 8 or 9. That also means you can't complete certain side quests and obtain certain kyber bricks and such.Cut Scenes.Again this is my opinion but I find the cut scenes, mainly and especially for the real meaningful moments are way to short. Example: Anakin VS Obi-Wan. In the movie it's such a heart felt moment hearing them speak to each other before they fight to one of their deaths, Anakin and Obi-Wan each give their amazing speeches/reasons to why they are with or against the republic, why they are fighting each other. In the game they say a couple words, be it from the movies which is still nice, but then they fight. Obviously it's a lego game, they shouldn't be saying word for word the entire same thing that was said in the movies but a little more dialog would be nice.Missing *certain content*So for this I highlight the word "certain content" because I see a surprising amount of people saying the game is lacking some content. The game has so much content it's amazing, now quality over quantity is what it comes to for me.A major miss and lacking piece of a mission was in the arena battle on Geonosis. In Lego Star Wars The Clone Wars the arena battle is epic. so many droids everywhere, a couple jedi but you're clearing getting overrun and it feels like you're a prisoner that has escaped their chains and has barley any help while a droid army is sent in to kill you. Even for how easy that game was you die a lot just because of the amount of enemies attacking you. In this though, barley any droids, basically just the animals trying to kill you and Jango Fett.Along with that there is a lack of Clone Wars mention. Now there are characters from it and in fact Ashoke is coming to the game May the 4th, so we know that TT games does in fact reconzige The Clone Wars in the game. But the fact there aren't many if any mentions to the show in the random conversations with NPC's, there's no Captain Rex, no Captain kruell, no Ventress, no Savage Opress, no Zero the Hutt, no Cad Bane, etc. - The Good -Now the "bad" list might be much longer then the "Good" list but that's because most of the bad will change as time goes on. Bug fixes will come out, extra content will keep coming, like I said May The 4th they'll be releasing some more characters and most likely a patch. The entire game is the good. From the little jokes and voice lines of certain characters, to the amazing voice acting of almost all 300+ playable characters. The new game play of combos, taking cover, aiming system, kyber bricks, data cards are amazing.The locations are fabulous. Yes some you can't explore that much but man c'mon. I mean look at corisont, Naboo, Endor, Mustafar and there's still many I haven't even explored yet.The graphics.The graphics are just simply beautiful, for a lego game it still feels fake, almost like someone is using mods, the game looks beautiful is every location, mission and character.To close it out I love this game. The bad is much longer like I said but that's because to explain the amazingness to the game I would just simply say it's nine movies of an amazing, beautiful, entertaining series that has brought millions of fans together to enjoy. Being able to relive some of my favourite memories in lego form in 2022 is just so fun. Seeing Anakin and Obi-Wan fighting again with the amazing music, beautiful graphics and great combat system is just so fun. 70+ hours of my life has been spent on this game I can't wait for the other 70+ to come and go. I hope this game keeps getting updates and I cannot wait to see where it goes. So do I recommend this game. Absolutely May the force be with you.

author: Fromdegon
review: Surprisingly very fun to 100% complete (at about 95% now) the game play is fun but their are a couple of small drawbacks I have.1) When in a flight story mission in free play mode, it is impossible to switch ships so if you are randomly assigned a tie fighter in a mission to kill Tie fighters your ship will target the X-wings instead and you have to fight the game just to progress or redo the mission.2) Dodging in ships should be bound to shift and C for keyboard and mouse, I know the game is better with controller but I'm poor.3) Don't randomly assign ships and characters at the beginning of free play mode. let us chose by having the currently selected open galaxy characters be said starting characters.4) More steam achievements = more dopamine5) More in general is good. 6) Bring back Yoda's proper death yell, you have plenty of memes so I don't see it being to intrusive.10/10 despite my rant the game is well designed and is a general story improvement to the sequel trilogy.

author: Ash21
review: I have been looking forward to this game ever since it was first announced, I 100%ed every single LSW game leading up to this, and now that I have finally reached 100% in this game, I thought I'd write a review like I have for the others.This is by far the most enjoyable lego star wars game out there. I enjoyed it fully throughout the whole 100 some hours unlike with past games where they got more annoying near the end. It's not a flawless game but I honestly think it's easily the best Lego Srae Wars game to date and one of the best star wars games to be released.-Really good graphics.-Well written with some amazing jokes throughout.-Very fun melee and blaster combat. Easily the most enjoyable combat system out of any lego game.-23+ large explorable hub worlds (some are smaller than others but it's still an open world star wars game with many different planets.)-300+ playable characters, most of which has voice lines and unique animations.-lots and lots of different ships to fly around the galaxy with, including tiny little escape pods and a big gonk droid.-Most of the time really good voice acting, including the clone wars cast for the prequels (and mumble mode for those who don't like voice acting in lego.)-lots of fun interesting little side quests throughout the galaxy, all with their own storylines that sometimes continues into other side quests.-A stupid amount of content, took me around 100 hours to 100%.-You can own and summon the death star and a few other capital ships.-Some great interactions between certain characters.-DLC packs for a lot of characters not from the 9 movies such as Mando, Rogue One, Solo, Bad Batch.-GONK. -Game is too easy with no difficultly options to make it harder. It's normally not a problem for lego games but in this, it gets really annoying when you have such a great combat system but the enemies die in 2 to 3 hits, Please TT add an option to give the enemies more health at the very least.-Levels are really short as most of your playtime is spent within the hubs.-Scenes feel rushed and/or skipped completely (no Tarkin in ep4, no playable battle of Coruscant, no playable palpatine's arrest, no battle of geonosis (outside of the arena,) no playable death star 2 trench run, etc.)-Bugs, including some progress blocking bugs (I luckily didn't encounter those but there's a lot who have.)-Level challenges can be annoying to figure out without a guide and force you to replay levels more than twice.-No character Customization.-Co-op is not great, as there's no online co-op, boss battles only really have 1 player fighting them, etc.-Not much replayability in the open world.-Not much combat in the open world, there really needs to be more enemies here and there.-Missing characters such as Galactic Marines, few jedi, Uncle Owen, Aunt Beru, imperial spy, etc.-Normal star destroyers and Venators are not explorable (even though a interior of a venator was seen in pre-release gameplay.)-Starkiller Base and homing one, the resistance ship from ep8, and the Supremacy are only explorable during the story.-Kijimi is not a explorable planet despite always being on the galaxy map.-EP7 Finn with a lightsaber is only playable during the story while EP7 Rey with a lightsaber is always playable.-No clone wars or rebel content (outside of Mama the Hutt and the ghost) with no known DLC for them coming later on.Overall the game is amazing but it has it's issues. I completely recommend this game to any fans of star wars whether or not you've played past Lego Star Wars games. It's a really enjoyable ride throughout all 9 movies and even if you hate the sequels, they can still be a lot fun here with good jokes throughout.This game could easily become the best star wars game ever with content from all media, if TT continues to make DLC which I really hope they do, As it would be so cool to see DLC packs in the future that adds story content from rogue one, solo, rebels, TCW, Mando, alongside explorable planets from them and even more content from the comics and books, upcoming shows like Kenobi and even legends. It would be amazing but it's unlikely they will take that route. We probably won't get anymore DLC other than what's already announced.This is easily one of the best star wars games ever released, it has it's problems but you can clearly tell there was a huge amount of work, effort, and passion that went into making this. I can not recommend it enough. Thank you TT, for making this amazing game.

author: Herr_der_wölfe
review: the best 3rd person game to come out in 2022, amazing details and the best non-RayTraced lighting i've ever seen, and the amount of physics interactions is amazing! From broken parts to weapons in their holsters swaying around, capes flutter when you move, even ragdolls when you defeat enemies (although is pretty hard to see when they de-spawn so fast)the levels are a bit short, and are even more cut up story wise compared to the complete saga, but what it makes up for it is in the jokes and the execution of the level itself. just a bit sad that some iconic parts are cut really short in this game.I really hope that some classic levels get added in the future, or even just the original level hub's from the games would be a cool throwback. oh and bring back the old pod racing level to show the new people what pain is like.Some minor gripes is just some really short LOD for terrain tessellation (its pretty distracting in some levels), and the levels that have you switch between sets of characters sometimes tanks your system extremely hard (down to 15-20 fps in the robot factory level). Other Characters get in your way a lot when your moving level objects and don't seem to get out of the way on your own.Overall amazing game 9/10, a must buy it if you can afford it.

author: austin3
review: It’s good. It’s not great, but good. I play with my seven year old. There is an enormous amount of things to do. We are 60 hours in and still finding new things and enjoying ourselves.  It is a reasonable difficulty for a seven year old while still creating some sense of challenge. Most levels are short which is fine because there are so many and any given level doesn’t get tedious.  There are many characters but it isn’t always obvious what the exact differences are or why it matters. We figured out that there are characters with rapid fire weapons and characters with sniper rifles but we generally spend most of our time with one or two characters that are effective at moving and puzzles. (Of course we switch when a puzzle requires it, but we generally switch right back.). The game somehow lacks the “magic” of the early Lego game novelty. But it is still really good and certainly worth playing.

author: valezu
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of the man who fell into the river in Lego city? I thought not. It's not a story the Playmobils would tell you. It's a LEGO legend. Man Lego was a Dark Lord of building, so powerful and so wise he could use the bricks to influence the constructions to create rescue helicopters… He had such a knowledge of building that he could even keep the ones he cared about from falling. The dark side of the LEGOs is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice threw him into the river in LEGO city. Ironic. He could rescue others from the river, but not himself.

author: FatalError64
review: Refunded.Feels nothing like the older Lego games. The older Lego games had beautiful, well-thought out level design and a nice hub world between levels. Clean User Interface, satisfying gameplay loop and sound effects, and consistent mechanics (E.G. 1 red brick per level, 10 minikits, True Jedi if I remember correctly). I am sick and tired of shallow open-worldish bastardizations of games I used to love. This game's level design is dry and uninspired. The game has complicated menus and mechanics and holds your hand excessively while teaching you little of use at all. The old Lego games had so much soul and heart put into them. I would rather buy all those again and relive those good memories than play this game even were it given to me for free. I fail to understand why they tried to change so much when they already had perfected the formula with games like Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga, Lego Star Wars III: The Clone Wars, and the Lego Indiana Jones Series.Please do yourself and the rest of us a favor by avoiding this game like the plague. Maybe if enough of us do, they'll go back to making good games again. Honestly, just replay Complete Saga. At least you'll have fun. Trust me when I say you'd rather have your pinky cut off by the Dojima clan before you see what they've done to your childhood.Will answer comments.

author: Jesse Bigman
review: So far, I'm slightly disappointed. Funny game, fun to play, nostalgic, but doesn't do the complete saga justice imo.Misses some of the most key battles and fights that the complete saga allowed you to play, instead opting for short cutscenes showing all the fun you miss out on. Revenge of the Sith in particular has no gameplay for some of the most memorable and important scenes in the movie/franchise.Also, the sheer amount of forced slow walking missions, forcing you to stand within a certain distance of the character you're following, which have been notoriously hated in gaming for years on end, make certain sections (*cough cough* Kamino) pretty irritating. The combat, despite being easy (as expected for a lego game), is a vast improvement on past games, and the boss fights it doesn't completely skip are very fun to play. Maybe I'll change my mind as it goes on, but to me it's been a bit of a letdown. The comedy is still classic lego and it's still a great game, worth buying eventually, whether 40 quid is worth it though is questionable to me.P.S. How dare Rey take Luke's place on the title screen! :'(

author: SpectralWalrus
review: Unfinished, there are no levels, this is just a shallow and boring open world game that holds your hand like you're the dumbest comatose vegetable that is incapable of doing anything. It does not reward you in any way, and you will not feel accomplished. Instead, you will feel like you just got mugged off again by Paddy McDonald, the local pikey from down the road who promised you brand new underfloor heating, and instead stole all of the copper pipes from your bathroom, took the money up front and did a runner. The only steam game I have ever got a refund for, and I loved many of the previous Lego games. This is a joke.Not fun, not challenging (I know, before you even say it, I know it is a Lego game, but even a Lego game should have some form of challenge to it), no levels, the comedy is generally awkward, and there is pointless padding. 0/10. Would rather put my hand on a belt sander.

author: Archaedrix
review: This game had so much potential, but there are fundamental problems. The good:- The game is visually appealing - There is technically a lot to do. Some of the open world challenges and puzzles are fun and interesting.- You'll be able to play as your favorite character- Characters have skins, instead of 7 copies of the same character cluttering the menu like in the previous games- Kyber Brick system. Having powerups that you can spend to upgrade abilities is fun, and allows me to skip some of the repetitive consoles you have to use. Those suck after a while. Unfortunately, the original game (The Complete Saga) is vastly superior in a lot of ways. The Bad:- Poor tutorials. The episode 1 tutorial launches you into space flight, dumps you into a hub-like zone, and wanders you through the halls for a scripted event before starting you off. The episode 4 tutorial was fine, but Episode 1, 4, and 7 have tutorials so it's odd. How to use the character swap-list in freeplay is poorly explained. - Lack of hub world. You have a hub in the pocket in your holo device, but it is clunky and can be difficult to access when you would expect it to be available. - Empty space. There is a lot of go here, go there, between missions that try to sell themselves as mission. You can buy capital ships, and they really do not do that much. - Massive framerate issues in certain areas. Sometimes the camera will force a perspective at random in one of those areas, and it's very problematic. Consistent 144 fps in all areas, but then drop to 20 in 3 zones. - Forced perspective during boss fights. It can be very difficult to collect the few in-mission items when your camera is locked on the boss most of the time. - The challenges. A lot of them are fundamentally difficult to complete due to their nature, not in terms of skill. Quite a few suffer from needing to kill characters a certain way, or kill a certain amount, and the game does not properly count them. - Mission replay-ability. As opposed to the original missions, there are 5 minikits per mission and the mission areas are fairly small. - Missions themselves. 5 missions per movie, all of which are boss fights or vehicle levels. Miss a challenge or it bugs out, you probably have to run the entirety of the boss fight to get there. - Repetitive puzzles. Requiring me to stack 5 boxes in every new zone for a collectible gets boring. - Datacards replacing red bricks. In the original game, each red brick was attached to a purchasable upgrade. Now, you can use any datacard to purchase any power up (2x studs, or higher). These are very easily accessible in the open world, no challenge. - Goldbricks were removed also. Less things to collect. I'll edit my pros and cons as I continue playing.

author: MidnightThunder
review: I don't usually review games but I feel like this game deserves one. I grew up playing The Complete Saga and now that I've completed story mode in this game, I can confidently say that if you like Star Wars, especially Lego Star Wars, you will like this game.It really is like you're in the Star Wars universe. The graphics are amazing; everything that isn't lego (obviously) is pretty realistic and I especially love the view of the planets from space. You can do whatever you want, especially in free play mode. Are you supposed to be rescuing the chancellor who you know is evil but want to slaughter the younglings as yellow-eyed Anakin instead? Go ahead! Go ride a Bantha instead of playing the sequels if you want (I do recommend those though as there are essential abilities that you get from those movies, and I personally like more gameplay). Heck, I did parkour as pregnant Padme. I'm sure that won't have any consequences....Some other little things that I really like:-There are different character classes that each have their own unique abilities, similar to The Complete Saga. You can upgrade the abilities of each class as well as all the characters as a whole.-The minikits make microfighters that you can fly! I think this is a great reference to irl legos and it gives you more motivation to collect them.-There is a great combination of authenticity to the movies (tons of familiar quotes) as well as classic lego humor.-The extras are both useful and entertaining. Some help you reach that 10,000,000,000 stud goal easier, while others turn your lightsabers into baguettes. It's great.-There are TONS of side missions. Some are shorter or longer, but most give you kyber bricks, which are similar to gold bricks from The Complete Saga. There are well over 1000 to collect, and there are hints available to help you find them if you know where to look. You can also get other rewards....I've seen some poor reviews on this game, but they're pretty nitpicky in my opinion (nothing is perfect, after all). The only thing I would add to this game is a Clone Wars DLC considering there is a Bad Batch one but something that minor doesn't ruin the game at all. In fact, I don't think the Deluxe Edition is necessary for you to enjoy the game, but I do think it is worth the extra $10 if you're interested. Overall, I think if you're a casual Star Wars nerd like me, this game won't disappoint. After all, it is Lego Star Wars.

author: REAL NAME (?)
review: As excited as I was for this game it feels like it was semi rushed towards the end. While the open world element is absolutely breathtaking, the story missions themselves leave me wanting more and further detail. Game play is the same as it ever was, run around and smash things and collect stuff. Perfectly fine but the difficulty feels, too easy? It's weird to say that for a Lego game since they are mainly for kids but I feel as though the original ones had a bit more difficulty to them that made it fun to replay. This just feels far too easy and when it does get "difficult" its not due to the game getting harder, its due to the game getting buggier. I want to recommend this game real bad but overall I just feel like I kinda wasted my money on a game that pulled a magician's pickpocket: Look over here while I steal your wallet. Overall, its not a bad game per se but its not a masterpiece by any means.

author: xXD_TT
review: Unfortunately this game has not met my expectations (which, i'll admit were very high). While I do enjoy this game, and I will continue to play it, hopefully getting 100% achievements, I do find myself bored quite often while playing.The first and most glaring issue I have is the horrible mission design, the missions are frustratingly short and uninspired. So far I have only played episode I and II, with a total of around ten levels or so. I can not for the life of me remember a single puzzle, I know there were puzzles, but they were incredibly short and easy. The only fun in any given mission is the combat, which gives you far more mechanics than you really need in my opinion.My second big issue is the lack of the Character customisation system. I have been playing a lot of Lego games since i was a child, and my favourite part of every single one of them has been the character customizer. I was so excited after playing Lego DC supervillains' incredible character customiser to see what this game would have, which is why i am so disappointed and confused as to why it is not here, hopefully they will add it in the future. Other small complaints are:Some performance issues, particularly on the droid factory mission in attack of the clonesConfusing and hard to navigate in-game menuSome jarring cuts in the story, somehow making the story feel very rushed yet also too slow at timesA very small nitpick but I feel that the characters are too cheap, I was going to safe up for maul, assuming he would cost atleast a million studs, yet when I went to check he was only 200.000, so I picked him up like it was nothing, and it didn't feel very rewarding. Hopefully Darth Vader will be more expensive :)However I still enjoy this game, and acknowledge what it has done well:It looks gorgeousI admire the experimentation with the combat system and camera view, i think it works really well and I am happy for the new generation of kids growing up with more "modern" lego gamesThe cutscenes are funny, and never quite overstay their welcomeThere are incredibly many and interesting characters i look forward to unlocking The open world is immense, and i look forward to turning of the HUD and getting lost in it :)PadmeAll in all, I don't feel like this game is worth what it's cost, and had I played for less than two hours, I would have asked for a refund. It is undoubtedly a big change in the Lego game franchise, and I look forward to seeing how the next game turns out :)

author: HecksBlade
review: As one of the many who played the previous Lego Star Wars games, i've gotta say this is fantastic. The game shines best in it's ship combat, but i was pleasantly surprised with the third-person shooter-ish  mechanics. The ability to fully explore the galaxy in free mode after beating all of the episodes is just the icing on the cake, tons of replayability, and fun with a friend. Hopefully in the future they add online multiplayer, but its absence is far from a dealbreaker

author: Myfendoren
review: tldr: If you are a fan of old Star Wars, there is a lot here to enjoy.Review:A great and fun love letter to fans of Star Wars. If you've played a Lego game then you know what you're getting here, though there is surprisingly a lot less of building as a mechanic than in other Lego games. Instead of building mechanics, fans get what they've always wanted: the ability to fly around the galaxy and visit all your favorite Star Wars locales in a variety of ships that can be unlocked while playing. There's only a few areas on every planet, but there's enough content to keep you busy for quite a while. You get to relive your favorite moments from the films with a slice of Lego goofiness, and it's a blast to run around and interact with the world.Sadly, the terrible Disney sequels are included. They are as uninteresting as their movie versions, though I am obviously biased. The missions for these episodes are not as interesting as the OT and PT episodes, the humor is not there (maybe you have to like those movies to get the jokes, but I haven't laughed once yet while playing through the disney trilogy), and at least the Scavenger class has its abilities locked behind progressing through Rey's story in episode 7. That will make a large number of collectibles from the OT and PT areas inaccessible until players progress in episode 7. Playing through these episodes so far is a chore, as they are just not as interesting as the OT and PT. Apparently I'm not the only one that thinks this, as of the time of this review only 25% of players completed episode 7, compared to the ~40-50% for completing episodes 1-6. The inclusion of the disney trilogy also serves as a sad reminder of the poor efforts disney gave us instead of all the great stories that they've put to pasture from the 35 years of Lucas Star Wars. How amazing would it have been to play through Shadow of the Empire, or the Thrawn series? Or have crossovers from Jedi Knight, Force Unleashed, or even Fallen Order? How about a trilogy of episodes set in the Old Republic? What about the Clone Wars? There's mountains of content they could mine from that series. Why not include fan favorite Mara Jade? I get that this is the Skywalker Saga, so the scope is limited to the movies essentially (though to me that's just more reason to exclude the disney sequels), but it seems there could be (or could have been) lots of potential for including fan favorite content (obviously not what disney has been trying to do for the last decade).The game looks great, sounds great, and plays great. There was some performance slowdown in some of the busier levels (ie: EPII Droid Factory), but usually it runs great. Load times are very short as well. Some more display options would have been nice, like the option to turn off motion blur, but it's fine for the most part. I don't know what replayability there is yet, but I'm not sure that there is enough to keep players coming back after a full playthrough. This game is a perfect candidate for large DLC's and expansions, though, again, I'm sure that is outside the scope of this title.Update: Playing through episodes 8 and 9 was atrocious. They were long, drawn out, and featured way more dialogue then 1-6. If you remember the dialogue in those films you know how awful it is to hear it again. Funnily enough though, the dialogue was so ludicrous that I thought the developer had finally jumped the shark and gone too far with its silliness. But then I realized that it wasn't the dev's fault, it was word for word from the movies. And that's just sad. Playing episodes 8 and 9 were definitely the worst parts of the game.

author: MeemawHustlin
review: This is the lowest quality of life of any game I have ever played and it basically wastes your time and gaslights you at every possible opportunity. Here the highlights in my 2 hours of gameplay:- A DLC screen in the center of the main menu, with the actual menu options hidden until you look at the bottom right to see that the A button will close the DLC screen and bring up the actual ability to play the game. Nice.- "You unlocked a new ship! Press [button] to view it!" followed by that menu saying I couldn't change ships and that every other feature of that entire menu was locked. Also frequently was unable to purchase things in similar situations because the game prompts you to explore freeplay specific features while stuck in story mode.- The game doesn't make it clear how story mode works and how to get out of it, making me eventually cave in and just b-line it to each objective to get the boring escort missions over with. I felt like I was on a guided tour instead of exploring an open world.- Constantly being yapped at by a breadcrumb trail thing telling me to go towards the objective instead of exploring the area (why is this open world then??). The options have no way to turn this off.- Left and right on the d-pad scroll between different characters in the character purchasing screen, scrolling through a grid that you cannot actually see and would need photographic memory to remember well enough to take advantage of this feature. On each selected character, there is a vertical column of costumes to purchase for that character. Pressing up/down on the d-pad does nothing, you have to press Y to vertically scroll. Why???????- Press down on the d-pad to open the map screen, then press down again to close it only to find that down on the d-pad now scrolls the map (which the L stick already does anyway), preventing easy toggling of the map screen. The map in general is a nightmare to navigate, with 4-5 layers of map selection, some having multiple menus within them (like traveling to a planet but not confirming yet so you can see planet progress).- The first two actual levels (which I didn't even realize were different from the not-a-level-but-still-story-mode sections) were boring on rails vehicle missions.- The pod race auto steers you (which can't be disabled) in a way that it forces you to run into everything and miss any boost pads you are trying to run over. Somehow this is even worse than the original pod race from the first lego star wars, which I didn't even know could be possible. I actually thought my controller was broken until someone told me that's how that level is.- Quitting the game makes you watch Rey's dialogue cutscene thing before showing you the actual menu options. Reopening the game forces you to hold Y to skip a series of splash screens (making it take longer than just pressing a button) and then you can't skip watching Rey's dialogue again.- A hint droid that you can walk over and talk to that opens a menu that you can open from anywhere in the game.- A ship control panel you can walk over to that lets you change your ship via a menu that you can open from anywhere in the game.- The force "puzzles" are a total chore. Gee I wonder if the blue canister needs to go in the blue frame? Why do I have to go through some 3D object placing control system to place it instead of the game just putting it where it obviously needs to go like in the old games? Some objects definitely would still need the free moving system but why can't certain things (like moving 4 of the exact same object into frames over and over) be automated so we aren't wasting our time?- Levels respawn all objects when you come back, devaluing the entire stud economy since each object drops a thousand studs repeatedly.- Purchasing a new character swaps them with a selected character of your party (that you likely won't even realize it selected to begin with) forcing you to swap that character with the original, making buying multiple characters at once or casually browsing the character store impossible as you have to carefully plan your UI movements to avoid extra work to correct your party layout afterwards. Why is the shop not completely separate from your team building screen?- The darth maul fight can be easily won by standing at a distance and spamming the lightsaber throw. I stood there for over a minute holding the lightsaber throw and darth maul just stood there looking at me. Most enemies behave in a similar fashion.Ultimately this game is a trap, taking over 2 hours for you to feel like you've experienced enough of it to have given it a chance, at which point steam will not let you refund it. There is an extreme amount of bloat both in the actual gameplay and in the overall structure of how the game objectives are organized. As much as the original Lego game formula gets criticized for being recycled for every game, they really did have a much more efficient system than whatever this is.

author: tandlægerne katrinebjergvej er b
review: If your intention is to obtain 100% (like me) or collect a lot of characters, i cannot recommend this game. If you (or your child) just want to experience the game once and collect a few characters until you're bored, I can definitely see you getting a relaxing and somewhat enjoyable experience.One of the main selling points of the game is the sheer amount of content it has to offer, but unfortunately this is done in an overwhelming "quantity over quality" way, and therefore what is a 60-90h game (for 100%), only is enjoyable for 30% of the time. For a game so collectible-focused, it is unfortunate to see how many of the collectibles that feel lazy, copy-pasted or unpolished. The platforming feels rough, and gives the feeling that you're forced to do EXACTLY as the game wants you to do, which often makes jumping around obstacles feel like a chore rather than gameplay. Every level has three level challenges, which are requirements to beat if you're doing a completionist run. In theory these challenges serve the purpose to show the player some fun details and alternate routes in every level, but in reality many of these challenges feel random, unnecessary and some very bugged (the third of which being especially annoying).  Speaking of the levels, some are very nice and have some good puzzles, but there are wayyy too many boss fights, which have no variety from one another, and therefore get very stale - which becomes much more annoying since completing each level at least twice is a necessity.Admittedly a very biased point, but a major thing that i miss in this game, that was almost perfectly executed in The Complete Saga, were the "just mess around and kill everything" moments, which albeit are present in the new game, but don't feel that great due to the weird combo-system, that feels like a dumbed-down and not-as-satisfying version of the Batman Arkham combat-system. That being said, I did enjoy the combat in space, since it allows the player to turn their brain off in a very enjoyable kind of way, which is a staple of what makes LEGO-games good.In conclusion this game isn't bad, but it isn't good either. I you're looking for some more enjoyable lego games, i'd much rather recommend the following (which I have also gotten 100% in):If you're lucky, LEGO games are often available in bundles on humblebundle, which is a website that has bundles of games for often very cheap, where some of the money goes to charity, which is money better spent than 50$ on this.

author: trinitytrain
review: UPDATE: See original review below, but thankfully I can now recommend this game! Devs have fixed the biggest glitches and now I can progress in all of my save files! There are still some issues, but overall the experience is now much more enjoyable. Now I have to actually keep track of how long I'm playing since the game won't crash me out to let me know to stop lol.--------------------------If you look at my play time, I'm sure you'll be very confused. How can I have played this game for 200 hours and not recommend?The game is BUGGY. I hit a soft lock in episode 7 that has no work around and seemingly no clear trigger. I had to start a new save file since there was no way around it. This was after finishing episodes 1-6, of course. This isn't the only soft lock that exists and hasn't been fixed as far as I am aware. I know of at least one that exists in the mid point of episode 2 as well.And these are just the bugs that keep you from progressing in the game. I've encountered so many bugs that require you to close out the game. Character select decides you can't switch characters at all, loading screens glitch out and don't end, bounties just not dying and forcing you to leave and come back several times. I could go on. My favorite glitch I have encountered is receiving smuggling cargo from an episode 3 location to an episode 4 location. I had just restarted my save file and was on episode 1.There are also several aspects of gameplay that aren't glitches, but are frustrating. Targeting in spaceships is based on the character piloting the ship. As far as I can tell, this isn't communicated to you in the game; I found this information online. I spent hours thinking I had a bugged out quest when I just had the wrong character piloting. Requiring the scavenger role to create their own tools before you can use them is cute on paper, but a nightmare in practice. You have to either play episode 6 to the battle on Endor or episode 7 until Rey has scavenged her tools before you can use this character type's abilities. Again, this isn't communicated to you as a player. I read online that the best course of action is to just play episode 7 until you unlock the abilities, then come back when you want. This isn't a problem for people who didn't buy DLC, as you only unlock scavenger characters at these times anyway, but it just made me feel kind of stupid for buying the DLC and then not being able to use this character at all.Settings somehow also have issues. Vibration is on or off, and let me tell you, that spaceship vibration from accelerating has driven me INSANE. I just turn it off now, even though I prefer the haptic feedback. I wish there was a way to just dampen the vibration intensity, not turn it off entirely. No options for how to control the force, which is the single most frustrating mechanic to struggle with. I understand that if you can change the way it functions, some of the difficulty in puzzles goes away. I don't care, it hurts my brain every time I use it and I want that option.Obviously I have enjoyed the game, otherwise I wouldn't have such a long playtime. The puzzles can be fun, not too challenging at all, and the flavor text from NPCs is really fun. I enjoy the humor that LEGO always brings into their games and how they managed to maintain that, even with changing things up from the classic style.I wish I could recommend this game. It's been so much fun to play. It's also been incredibly frustrating to play. I've had to take a break from it due to frustration. A LEGO game made me essentially rage quit due to the bugs. At the current price point and bugginess, I simply cannot recommend this game. Once it's been patched and there aren't huge softlocks preventing you from playing significant portions of the game, I would love to update this review. As it stands, I recommend waiting until there have been some major updates before spending your money.

author: Kalash_DZ
review: I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for his birthday in april from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching some tiktok videos. So i decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he showed me how to cross play on steam for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Spike
review: Big disappointment.Been looking forward to this game for quite a while and sadly there's just too many issues for me to be satisfied.Cons:They skip way too many important scenes and fun areas. This is immediately noticeable right off the bat in episode 1 where, for example, when you escape the trade federation ship, all you do is run down a few bland hallways and then leave. Then again on naboo you skip the scaling into the palace to retake it. Instead they replaced it with a walk from point a to point b. The cutscenes still have that lego fun feel, but many of the missions are just not interesting.The optimization is also horrible. I have a 2070 super and am able to run every other game I own at max graphics settings. This game in certain areas I will peak at 30 fps (specifically the droid factory I'm stuck at like 15 fps). If you have an average pc you likely will have much much worse performance. Also had a bug where every time I tried to go into the gungan city the game would black screen and be unplayable. The only fix I found was restarting the game 3 times until the 4th time going into the city it randomly worked.Pros: The gameplay mechanics of 3rd person is fun. You can also tell they put a lot of work into random details like leaving footprints in sand and lightsabers leaving burn marks on walls. The open worlds themselves are also very good looking and filled with npcs to make them feel alive. Also some of the puzzles have been fun and creative.Overall as of now disappointed. Obviously a game with this hype makes it hard to live up, but leaving out many key star wars moments leaves the story feeling rushed and bugs can be extremely annoying.

review: I first started my video games journey with lego star wars: the complete saga, so I guess I have somehow gone full circle. I enjoy this game, it's funny, it looks great, and it's stupid in all the right ways. However, WAIT FOR IT TO GO ON SALE, lego games always fall off in price by a lot after a while. It's good but if you're "a legit gamer", there are probably better places to put your $60. These games are made for younger kids and are basically toys, but they're a great way to chill out and experience star wars in a very paraphrased, non violent manner. If you're looking for something hard, go for ALL the collectibles, there's a bunch.TLDR: buy it on sale, it's fun but easy. There's plenty of stuff to do.

review: I have a hard time recommending this game. It's very polished and shiny, and it has some great LEGO humor. But it just isn't that fun to play. The story missions are incredibly short. The gameplay has a weird combo thing that it really tries to hammer into you, but doesn't really matter, so it just takes up space on screen. The open world suffers from upisoft levels of collectible bloat combined with and absolutely huge open world that isn't interesting to explore. It's pretty and well made, but there's nothing else to it.I love LEGO games and 100%ing them, but I'm not sure I'll play this one again after pushing myself to finish the main story.

author: JFK Peeked Glaz
review: If you were expecting quality missions like those offered in the other lego titles, prepare to be disappointed. The missions are incredibly short (5 minutes max was the longest one I played). Whole episodes can be completed in 40 minutes. Boss fights are okay, I much prefer the non bullet-spongey fights of the older games. It seems the main story got shortened so much because the open world was expanded greatly. The open world does not offer much in terms of fun activities. The side missions are just walk here, talk to someone, fly to another planet, talk to someone else, and then you complete the mission. A couple more issues I had with the main missions were a severe lack of building and the aforementioned boss fights not involving much but button mashing. There are no remakes or better versions of fan favorite levels from the other lego titles. Coruscant battle? Gone. Geonosian arena from the clone wars? Toned down immensely with no real battle occurring. There are many other examples of previous levels being removed or the new version being worse. Space combat is atrocious. All the upgrades seem meaningless since its a lego game and its as easy as can be. Super disappointed by this game.

author: D16hvv
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Studs are infinitely spawning in each level, meaning that there isn't a set number to find and collect like the old one. The campaign missions are primarily just running from point A to point B to get a cutscene. Graphically, the game is beautiful for sure. There just isn't a lot of substance here to be honest. I hope to return at some point, but I'll only do so when it's on sale. I just don't feel it's worth the money for the asking price.

author: Clownsparade
review: Only played episode 1 so far, here are my thoughts:Less cutscenes in less and quicker levels than in any Lego Star Wars game before. The story overall has been rushed over instead of being stretched in weird ways as before in the complete saga, but that actually has a nicer feel to itself. The focus isn't on the actual levels anymore but actually in small open world missions which almost feel like they could belong into a level while the (shortwhile) levels now actually feel more unique than ever.Now to the humour which has always been important to Lego games (at least for me):It is different than before but I really like it! It does not rely on gestic and mimic as strong as before and now strongly uses its new actually speaking star wars figures. The jokes are slap-stick and hit well (even Jar-Jar sometimes) ... Although any german speakers should change the spoken language to english.. really. Just do it.

author: bish
review: I really want to love this game, there is so much that is good, and yet so much is missing. Just as an example there is no Space Battle at the end of Return of the Jedi. It goes from defeating the emperor to just a quick cut scene and then the episode is over, it was a very unsatisfying way to end it. I was so looking forward to flying through Death Star II. There is also a lot of filler that just seems tacked on. It looks amazing, but it feels half finished. I don't regret buying it, but I wish I had known ahead of time that you don't get to play so much of the story, and I'm glad I got it on sale. I just cant reccomend this without the caveat that it' doesn't feel like a finished game.

author: HGProductions
review: Yes. I highly recommend this. There's a few minor goof-ups (in my opinion), like not calling  "Slave I", but instead calling it "Boba Fett's Starship" or "Jango Fett's Starship". Although for every goof-up there's about a hundred to a thousand things they've aced.The DLC is decent... okay, I'll confess. I have barely used any of it. Trooper Pack is great, Mando 1 is great (although the Grogu companion is annoying), but Classic ain't much. There's absolutely nothing unique or special about the Rogue One pack (Baze doesn't even have a machine gun). Solo is sort of like the Classic pack, but mainly new scoundrels. Not even giving us any mudtroopers. Aw well. I guess no shout out to the 224th? Anyway, I am kind of excited to see what the rest of the DLC turns out to be. Although, I warn you, if you didn't get the deluxe version, don't waste your money on the DLC. It seems that just like with real Star Wars, all the attention got given to The Mandalorian and everything else was just... "okay, so we have this awesome Mandalorian DLC.... what else are we gonna put in? Any idea will work because we don't have any as of yet."All in all though: Base Game: it's amazing (9.75/10), DLC: eeeaaaaaaahhhhhh (4.5/10)

author: WildcatWeather
review: This game is not better than the two original Lego Star Wars games. There are a lot of things it does better like making characters more unique, but the lack of true level design in favor of a bunch of open hub worlds really hurts this game. Rather than playing through a story, it feels like you're just on a mission to get random collectibles in every area with some cutscenes thrown in between.

author: AliCaviar
review: Fun game but after 7 hours the game will not launch. If I try run it my monitor starts saying that the "input is not supported" which hasn't happened with any game before this. I fixed the issue by changing my monitors refresh rate to 60hz but that also stopped working when I alt tabbed, so as of right now I just can't play the game. Before this happened the game would reset my the settings I changed every single time I closed the game.

author: rat smacker
review: I do recommend the game, but at the same time, I'd recommend buying it at a (heavy) discount.The first few hours were magical, the game looks gorgeous, there is tons of stuff to do (more on this later) the story is funny surprisingly quite a lot. It's an open world game with a fair bit of locations. The StoryAlthough funny and quite smooth. After a while you'll notice there isn't much game here.What almost takes the longest in this game is walking from mission start to mission start. The game constantly bounces you around from point to point and the actual missions themselves feel extremely basic and are over within a few minutes.I'm not 100% sure on this, but if my memory serves me correctly, the original games had longer story lines and used better moments on the movies.This game cucks you out of some moments which would've been awesome to play but they reserve it for cutscenes.The way Movie 9 ends is also kind of unacceptable. (But hey maybe they thought, ♥♥♥♥ movie, ♥♥♥♥ game chapter)Things to doThere are a f*ckton of things to do in this game, but 99,99% is the same with very slight variation.There's as always, unlocking different characters (within classes)You can level these classes (characters, e.g. jedi-sith-service droid-hero-villain) with Kyber bricks (collectables) which give either useless upgrades to straight up broken ones. You can also level up (boost) your player character in general (e.g. more hp, faster hp regen, collectable radar)There are a metric ton of Kyber Bricks to collect, around 1,164 is memory serves me correctly (been 2 weeks)Why I say buy it on a discount.Story is far too quick/short for its price imo (lego games always felt a tad too expensive to me though, however the world etc are gorgeous, sadly not exactly enough to do)Most of what you can do (Kyber-Bricks) is extremely repetitive and dull busy work for ADHD patients which require consttant stimuly. (so it worked perfectly for me the first ~20 hours till i realised what I was doing)Every 15 metres there's a shiny object, a Kyber-Brick, with an extremely easy (or somewhat vague) "puzzle"They range from find 4 targets to shoot, stack boxes with jedi/sith, just walk over them lmao to miniquests (which sometimes require you to move between planets)The sheer bulk of content is collecting these Kyber-Bricks for your upgrades (eventually for the 100% since you'll be OP with just the melee/ranged damage upgrade (preference) and the hp regen upgrade.) But after a while you'll get really burned out with this and then your realisation kicks in of, what exactly does this game offer me and what can I do in it.The answer is, play extremely short missions and collect boring kyber-bricks dotted every 15 metres. (from what I've seen people are saying there isn't NG+ so you can't ever fully reexperience the complete story+cutscenes, also no dedicated MP (remote play was nearly input delay free for me, so it wasnt an issue)Overal, yeah it's a good game, but unless you want to turn your brain off and just collect the shiny thing like the gamer goblins we are it kinda isn't at the same time.

author: Kronsteen
review: The game is great when it works, but there are about a thousand and one minor bugs that are a serious indicator of lack of polish. I've also managed to hard lock my progress to 100% twice with the Maz's Castle bug and the geejaw in Geejaw Hands Dirty falling off the platform of the tree city and being irretrievable. Both bugs are easily searchable on google and have been documented since week one. There have been no hot fixes or patches for the game in the month since release in spite of updates for DLC character releases. I wouldn't mind half as much if the publisher would even acknowledge the state of the game and these game breaking bugs that emerge organically from game play, but we haven't even gotten that bare minimum of "We are aware of the issue and are working on it."Stay away until it's patched.

author: Zemindarr
review: I remember playing the complete saga when i was a kid and i was obsessed with that game, there was so many things to do and characters to unlock. i loved that game and when i found out they were making the Skywalker saga with all 9 films, excitement is an understatement. i noticed it was being delayed several times but i was patient. the day i was able to download it i was just ready to play. i installed it all night and when i opened the game, the cut scenes looked phenomenal!  i started a new save and when i started, the game just blew me away on how good it looked! the combat is incredible, how everything was made of Lego in the interiors of the ships. i was so excited to relive StarWars but in a more modern, more advanced and even more realistic Lego game. i'm totally recommend this game and its defensively worth the price tag of $59.99 with the DLC's

author: Sörne
review: God I f!cking hate Maz so f!cking much holy sh!t. Holy sh!t, every frame she's in, every scene, every gif, every jpeg, she's got this painfully vacant, stupid as sh!t, f!ckass look on her stupid lumpy face. Absolutely no part of her ugly as sin piece of sh!t character design is endearing. God, I hate her. I hate her so much. So F!CKING much. Every time I see a stuffed toy Maz or an Maz gif or a sh!tty commercial, it ignites my primal rage response and I'm overcome by the need to punt this sh!tty little homunculus into the f!cking sun. "Bhurr blur, I'm Maz the f!cksh!t alien f!cker". F!ck you. F!ck you f!ck you f!ck you f!ck you f!ck you. And I know its irrational. That's the worst part. I know she's just a sh!tty f!cking side character in a stupid f!cking children's movie, I know it shouldn't matter, I know I shouldn't care. But that's part of the problem. The part where no matter the might and fury of my hatred, the locus of my homicidal intent is alltogether inconsequential. I find myself laying awake in the dark in the early hours of the morning consumed by the spirit of Wrath itself, all the force and might of a flaming hurricane directed at a bottle of piss in a ditch by the highway. The absurdity of it all burns me to my core. What better things could this energy be directed towards? And yet my disdain for this stupid, useless, insubstantial failure of character design utterly eclipses the intrigue of all other pursuits. I hate her. I hate her on a level of my mind reserved for the worst of the world's array of sinners, and I can't even begin to justify it. The f!cking. F!ck. I have no words. There is no cuss or epithet in any language that can encapsulate the height of the emotions I am experiencing. God, I hate her so much. I hate her so, so f!cking much. I want to light her ugly little dumpster body on fire. I want to punch her to death. You know that weird feeling you get, when you see a picture of something so cute you find yourself overcome with the bizarre, inexplicable urge to squeeze it? It's EXACTLY like that, except instead of cuteness it's disgust. The wordless knowledge that her existence as a fictional work is evidence of all the failures of mankind. I find myself possessed by the will of a Holy Angel gone rogue with the belief that God has made a mistake, and I alone must correct it.  What horrors must I have committed in a past life to be plagued by this torment now? I must Unmake this fictional Alien.⠀ ⠀pls fix maz bug------maz bug actually got fixed

author: Commandante Capybara
review: - Gameplay:I think they really managed to nail how gameplay should work in a LEGO game. The combat and movement feels very natural, and offers much more of a variety than previous titles, and camera control gives you so much freedom. The characters are now sorted by class, which is pretty cool as you now clearly see what your character can do, but I have to say that I probably prefer the "old" approach - that the characters have individual perks rather than class based ones, which made Jar Jar or C3PO more special in the Complete Saga. I'm also undecided about all characters being able to attack and double jump for the same reason. The class perk upgrades are probably fine, but I haven't used one of them.The only thing I would consider to be a downside is the difficulty. Even for most children this game is extremely easy. I wish they would have added settings for that. Boss fights rule now, as they should. Diverse attacks of the enemies and an actual challenge. Spaceships are better than ever and feel natural.- Graphics:Not much to say about that, except that they're even better than previous titles. Light effects and such are probably the most notable improvement.The devs (as in all LEGO games) have decided to include a bunch of details such as stances and movements that are quite adorable and in character.- Level Design/Story:Although I love the game, this is the only aspect of the game I consider to be worse than expected. The levels are way too short (5-15 minutes) and often feel rushed. In addition I don't always understand why some things are levels and some are not. Why include the travel through Naboos planet core, but NOT the battle for Theed? It's not that I find the existing levels bad, but it's a clear downgrade from previous games.Furthermore whilst I love how you now travel manually through the hub worlds like you do in most open world games, I sometimes felt bored/annoyed because I was just walking around doing nothing. This could have been prevented by including more levels. This all get's better after mid Episode II, but hasn't disappeared yet.Apart from that, cutscenes and the overall story is nice and or adorable. The first voiced LEGO game I found genuinely funny.- Open World:Some things I already covered, so I want to skip to how I actually feel about the open world in free play. Although it's certainly fun exploring the Star Wars galaxy, and the hub world system makes complete sense, I don't think this is my favourite open world of all LEGO games. It lacks either the character of the hub worlds from the Complete Saga, the Clone Wars or Indiana Jones - or the vastness of Undercover or Marvel Super Heroes. It's fine. Except that you can travel manually, and fly to space. They should stick with that, it's amazing.-Coop:It's sadly the worst Coop experience of all LEGO games. For two reasons. Splitscreen sucks, as your camera controls and movement is dependent on MORE SCREEN, YOU NEED MORE SCREEN...ok sorry, I digress. All improvements in gameplay are completely negated by Coop. Give us online coop. In addition, most levels are designed for one player. That's fine. But LEGO games were always cooler when you felt dependend on each other, especially when you look at the Clone Wars, this games Coop is just sad. Oh, and they decided to let you sit around and watch your buddy fight the Anankin/Obi duel.- Other:Whilst the unlockable characters are perfect, and you can play as whoever you want, ships and vehicles are extremely meh. You get one Jedi fighter etc.. Why? You already use a variant system for characters, it shouldn't have been to difficult to implement this system for vehicles. Also I guess capital ships aren't supposed to be playable, but it would have been nice if we got to see more of them, and actually steerable. As always, the system with a variety of collectibles and extras is fun.- Summary:It's a good entry and has a lot of improvements I adore. They generally sticked with the good parts and got rid of the bad ones.However it's not a perfect game. I understand the reasons for the shortcomings (not enough dev time mostly), but some stuff feels disappointing and or unecessary.

author: Leon96
review: My ex-girl dumped me and I bought this game to play.10/10.Better than my ex girlfriend. It even comes with a turn-off button.These guys REALLY raised the bar. They taught those Triple AAA developers how do you REALLY go next gen. It's not just about 144hz, 2000fps, ray tracing, hdr.It's about improving the whole concept, like God of War did. Like this Skywalker Saga just did.Congratulations to the Lego team, that suffered to bring us this masterpiece. That team gave us improved open world concept of lego games, improved graphics, optimized the game to be light enough so a GTX 1060 can run it AND gave us a complete masterpiece. There's really nothing bad to say about this game.Nothing else to declare. You can feel the love and blood the team put into this.

author: Watta meloons
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: SyCoREAPER
review: Update:Patch released Includes crash fixes and appears to have resolved all issues. My progress somehow recovered itself. Absolutely recommend the game now. Day 1 Review, may not apply in the future.The game itself is a good refresh of the tiring LEGO series of games. Better graphics, sound and overall gameplay. Actual dialog makes it feel more immersive rather than relying on the old slapstick humor.However, with the lack of save states, exploration is a huge gamble. Three times I've had the game crash on me without warning other than a quick lock-up and force quitting. A lot of progress lost and I've entirely lost interest for the day. Maybe I'll come back to it tomorrow, maybe not. Not interested in repeatedly finding secrets I already found.Fix the random crashes and I'll absolutely recommend this game. Until then, I say don't buy it.(An it's not my system, I have a Ryzen 9 5900HX; 32GB Dual Channel, Dual Rank RAM; and 6800m which is more than capable and has played much more demanding games than this without issue.

author: PapaJ_Shug_Mator
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Thick Thighs Save Lives
review: Disclaimer: I have only barely touched the sequels section of this game and, while I put that I would not recommend it, I wouldn't tell people to not play it.I am very conflicted about this game for a few reasons. A lot of criticism can be dismissed as "it's a game for kids" and I understand that to some degree.The Good:The game looks and feels fantasticThe combat, while easy, is enjoyableIt does a really good job of summing up the stories while also cutting out what could be considered "filler" (especially in the prequels)The classic Lego comedy is there and executed wellFunny prequels quotesThe Bad:Vehicle Controls feel bad and they always have been iffy in Lego games, however this is a result of only being able to see in the direction you are going, there is no way to look a different direction which makes flying a bit clunky.Levels are very short compared to the Complete SagaCharacters are no longer unique; every character within a preset "class" is the same as every other character in that class just with a different VA and model (with a few weapon exceptions)The game is easy, but again it's made for kids so I understand whyWhile I complained about vehicle controls, there are parts of the story that are pretty big that are cut out of being levels that were great levels in the original trilogy. The ones that I remember well are the one where you destroy the Star Destroyers and the space fight at the beginning of EP3.The game outside the levels is an open world collectathon that can get tediousNo windowed or borderless windowed in settingsThe Ugly (aka problems with Modern Star Wars leaking in):The first character you see in the game is Rey and she is the most prominent character on the title screen. I do not have a problem with strong female characters, however Luke Skywalker is, and should be, the face of Star Wars, not a character they introduced in the sequels that isn't even a Skywalker (at least by blood)Parts of the story have been retconned. Some of this is just to be more child friendly (Mace Windu not executing Jango Fett for example) but other parts I don't understand like the fight VS the Emperor ending with both Luke and Vader approaching when in the movies it was only Vader approaching. Minor things are changed as well, like Obi-Wan going to light speed without needing to use a hyperspace ring in EP2.Star Wars, and especially Lego Star Wars, was a big part of my childhood and I'm not sure how I feel about it. Change is scary, but not always a bad thing. However, there are a few things that just stand out too much for me to say that I recommend it.

I'm also not a fan of this new style of Lego games. The whole point of Lego is to be as minimal as possible. How can you put micro transactions in a Lego game?

author: Nar31
review: Took too long for me to refund this repetitive heap of nothing; levels are under 5 minutes each, co-op shouldn't even be in the game due to how awful P2 gets it, the open world is too big for how little there is to do, and every boss fight might as well be the same boss fight... because they are. This doesn't even feel like a Lego game, it feels like a generic third person adventure game with lots of shooting sections and a melee mechanic that's only fun the first few times. All the characters now share gameplay mechanics with others in their group... and there's only like, 6 or so groups, so basically you only need 6 characters to beat the whole game, but it'll take forever seeing how they made everything big just to make it big. No matter how big of a sale this game goes on, it's not worth your money; the whole game is a glorified game of "go here do that" with non-respawning hostile NPCs in the overly-sized hubs, and none of the iconic charm or puzzles or plot-alterations Lego games are known for.
