author: SubTerrel
review: Alright time for a complete breakdown. Firstly, I have completed the game with 100% on everything.  I pre-ordered it and played since it was released. I grew up with the Lego Star Wars games and they hold a special place in my heart. This game however doesn't seem to make the cut. Story:The actual story will take between 4-10 hours depending on if you rush through the levels. The levels are quite easy and can be beaten quickly. A lot of the added time will come from the Cut-Scenes. The Cut-Scenes are my favorite part of the game, adding humor and interesting changes to the story from the movies. Exploration:After you have completed the story( or you can start during the story), you are tasked with finding and completing tasks across the galaxy. Some examples include: Smuggling Equipment, Hunting Characters, and Serving Customers. It is around 1500 different challenges you will need to complete in order to 100% complete the game. I recommend completing the entire story before starting exploration since some quests will be locked until a part of the story is complete. This will take up the majority of your time and is very boring. There is some humor to be found in some of the quests but nothing that would make it worth doing. Tips: Here are some tips for those who buy the game.-Complete the Story first then Explore-Planet to Planet completion is usually the fastest.-Character and Ship quests usually take the longest since you have to travel around the galaxy-Every Smuggling quest will have 3 attack zones-Unlock the skip option for astromechs, protocols, rebels, and villains. It will save lots of time-Spend Data cards on mutipliers first then Universal Translator. Multipliers stack so once you get 2x and 4x you will make 8x the studs-Sith and Bounty hunters are usually the best at finding kyber bricks. Sith can lift characters and bounty hunters specs greatly increase damage-Focus on Core Upgrades before maxing out characters-Most Minikits require Freeplay so don't bother looking for then during Story mode(exception is ship levels)-Capital ships only offer a few kyber bricks so don't buy then until you have plently of money to spare-All Multipliers applyed equal x3840-During Freeplay you can avoid enemies by switching to Sith, Villians, or Bounty Hunters.-The character you get into a ship with will decide who is your friends. Make sure to have a rebel if you are trying to complete an attack quest otherwise you will lock onto friendlies-Only 1163 out of 1166 kyber bricks are needed to fully max out every class.-Google Codes instead of submitting forms, the codes give different character outfits-GOnk as a playable character can power GOnk stations-Collectable Detector is mandatory if you want to beat exploration the fastest.-Disable Super GNK and Porg Companion in Story as they can cause game breaking bugs.-When you reach a new planet, shoot the Kyber Asteroid first since it gives 5 kyber bricksBugs:There are way too many bugs to list hear but I will list some of the more problematic bugs.-Quests breaking mid completion    -Quest Mandatory Characters not spawning, Character's health bars reaching zero but still fighting, Items      not spawning, Quest breaks if approached from a different angle, etc.-Vehicle based challenges break if you don't have Aim Assist turned on in Settings    -Applies Mainly to Endor Speeder Chase. Shots hit too low so it's almost impossible to land a hit. After a      while the map ends and becomes a void that is impossible to escape without leaving the level entirely.-Capital Ships break Smuggling Zones    -If you have a Capital Ship called and then smuggle goods, it will become a ghost ship in the battle zone      and block visuals. It doesn't have a hit box but it does cause issues with visibility since it absorbs the zone.-Some Character purchases are listed as rumors    -The character will be listed and have the option to buy but instead of giving it's true price, the character      will be sold for the price of the rumor.-Characters can't be bought if their other skin is shown in the character menu    -Some characters have multiple outfits but a menu bug prevents the purchase of the other outfit if an      already bought outfit is shown. A temporary fix is to show the not owned outfit, click to a different class      window then back and you should be able to buy it.-Rumors providing no information    -Several rumors when bought say, "No rumor data" after bought-Super GNk and Porg Companion break Story Levels    -They both act as respawn points so they can respawn you or load you in a zone you aren't meant to be           resulting in a level restart.Final Thoughts:My main issue is the pricing for the game. For a $50-$60 game you would expect to have a large amount of content and enjoyment. This however isn't the case, if you want to get the best out of this game without buying it just look up a Cut-Scene compilation on YouTube. The DLCs only provide characters and don't add any extra levels or content. They are outlandishly expensive for what you get. The game is obviously designed to make you buy Legos as it constantly shows Set IDs and asks you if the game makes you want to buy Legos. It isn't much of an issue but they could have spent more time on the game over merchandise. I would not recommend this game, you get about 5-10% content and 90-95% filler copy-pasted quests. Spend your money on something more enjoyable.TLDR: Game too expensive for what you get.

author: Paranthropus
review: Levels less than 10 minutes long, non existent gameplay, and  superfluous mechanics added in for whatever reason. Fancy graphics are not enough to save this boring slog, not even the combat is engaging. Each mission is over so fast it has you scratching your head in confusion. Instead of tight, focused levels like TCS/ Clone Wars, you have low attention span button mashing while blankly staring at a screen.  They delayed this game for over three years and its not even really a game, its more of a huge checklist with mildly engaging activities with a coat of star wars paint. Play literally any other lego game and its more engaging than this.  An actual game for toddlers, not for "everyone." When someone plays a game, they should at least get some mental engagement out of it, this does not even provide that consistently. I'll stick to TCS.

author: Yorgul
review: Effects of the Cuban RevolutionDuring the middle of the 20th century, the world had all of its eyes looking at Cuba as its government ideals were being challenged by revolutionaries led by Fidel Castro. This revolution would ultimately prove successful as President Bautista would flee the country and Fidel would take power and implement social reforms across the country. One of the main reforms would be to seize all American owned private property in an attempt to nationalize its sugar production (Wright 28-29). This nationalization of the economy would foster unique approaches to that nationalization of key industries in various countries which includes: Chile for its nationalization of its copper industry, Peru and its nationalization of its petroleum industry, and Nicaragua for its nationalization of its agricultural industry. The 1964 Chilean election would have the marxist-leaning candidate Salvador Allende lose out to the less radical Eduardo Frei (Wright 146). Allende supported social reforms that were related to those in Cuba which include: promoting unionization, raising taxes on the wealthy, and the nationalization of the copper industry (Wright 145). Frei supported almost the same exact reforms, however wished for it to be less “statist” (Wright 145). While appearing to be on both sides of the spectrum at the time, both sides emphasized their campaign to have more control on the economy and have less foreign influence on it. During Frei’s leadership, he underwent a “Chileanization of the copper companies, gaining 51 percent government control with options to purchase the remaining 49 percent” (Wright 146). This was a big step forward for combating the foreign companies, but Frei failed to satisfy the lower classes' needs for improvement (Wright 146) and would ultimately pave the way for Allende to take power in 1970 (Wright 148). Allende, now in power, would push for extensive nationalization which included the copper economy, which gave the Chilean government “commanding heights” (Wright 151). However by 1973, while having nationalized 200 of Chile’s biggest enterprises, the Chilean economy was near collapse (Wright 158). By near the year’s end, the military had taken power and begun to slow down the process of further nationalization (Wright 160).In Peru, the petroleum industry was dominated by the American International Petroleum Company (Wright 36). The IPC were responsible for being the number one producer of Peruivian oil, and at the same time, served as a symbol of American Imperialism (Wright 125). In 1968, a series of events would unfold involving this company, which would lead to the downfall of the current civilian government and would feature the rise of a military dictatorship. These events kicked off when a document leaked showcasing the major concessions by the government to the IPC over the company’s legal status and land exploitation rights (Wright 125). Once this took place, the militaristic nationalist government would take power and as for their first action, began the seizing of IPC property (Wright 125). Unlike a majority of Latin American countries who have their civilian populations overthrow the government to bring social reforms, Peru’s new social reforms and this nationalization of the petroleum industry would be started by the military itself (Wright 126). This new military government was led by Juan Velasco who would start off his leadership by denying the United States compensations for the property seized of the IPC (Wright 136). This military government would last until 1975 (Wright 138), during which, the government would bring in social reforms, including more nationalization of other industries within Peru. Peru’s approach to the nationalization of their key industry was unique, because while the other nationalizations of key industries in these countries took place over time and by the civilian governments, Peru’s nationalization of their petroleum was the first thing that occurred by the new military government. In 1979 after a long guerilla campaign, the FSLN took power in Nicaragua. This revolution would coincide with rising Soviet skepticism in the region, and more privatization in other communist countries (Wright 178). Pair that with pressure from the United States would force the Sandinistas to become more moderate than the other countries in their policies (Wright 179). With this, the agricultural industry, which employed nearly half of the country (Wright 179) would not face much at the beginning of FSLN rule. The most notable action within the first two years was the confiscation of the land, owned by the Somozas (Wright 179). This action would bring 20 percent of the productive land under the state (Wright 179). The Nicaraguan government would implement a mixed economy that would still retain foreign investors, but also increase the amount of land held by small-and-medium sized producers to 60 percent of the agricultural surface and reduce the land owned by large producers and cooperatives (Wright 179). This mixed economy would allow farmers to continue working for the private sector or become self employed and have land to farm with (Wright 180). What is unique about Nicaragua’s approach to nationalization of its key industry, is that it didn't really bring that much land under the state. Its small amount of land is likely attributed to having constant pressure by the United States in the north and even Fidel Castro advising the Sandinistas to retain a substantial amount of land in the private sector (Wright 178). This pressure would eventually lead to the revolutionary being effectively voted out of power and Violeta Chamorro would bring even more moderate and conservative reforms.In these three cases, they all brought different approaches to nationalizing the economy. The Chileans would have a slow process of nationalizing its economy, at the hands of a government that didn’t even win a majority of the people’s votes, that would end in a military coup that would end these reforms (Wright 148). The Peruvian military were the ones to bring reforms that would nationalize their petroleum industry as one of their first acts upon obtaining power. Then the Nicaraguans would try to bring a more moderate nationalization of their agricultural industry by bringing more land out of large producers into small producers, while keeping a small amount of land for themselves. These three unique approaches to the same goal of nationalizing their economies all stemmed from the Cuban Revolution and Cuba’s nationalization of their sugar plantations. All of these approaches would oppose foreign investors, mostly from the United States, who would use funds and resources to try and undermine these governments and their reforms by supporting opposition within their countries.

The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. author: Zenger
review: I would just like to mention a few things I see commonly mentioned in reviews.First of all, this game is GIGANTIC. At the time of this review I have 17 hours of play-time, and I've only finished episodes I-VI. I still have 3 more movies to play and several planets are left unexplored. Not to mention all the collectibles that I only have about 10% of... so yes, this game is not short. The levels are not short. The cut-scenes and dialogue feel rushed, sure. But you come here to play to the movies, not re-watch them. Who cares if context is missing, or some part of the game are not playable. It still takes several hours to beat an episode, and what you don't get to play in the story is (most of the time) available in some form in the free-roam parts. Some missing moments from the movies are perhaps disappointing, but absolutely NOT a deal-breaker. As I said, 17 hours and I'm not even close to finished.I really enjoy that this game offers more types of combat options than just light-sabers and blasters. Playing as the droids is actually fun and you can do more than just open terminals like in the classic game. A specific level I see people complain about is the ending of ROTS, where you play as Obi-Wan and the droids. I personally liked this direction. Rather than copying The Complete Saga, TT-Games took a new approach and made the scene and level refreshing. I've found they did this for a number of levels in the game, which I really love.Now there are some negatives... unfortunately a bug has halted my play-through at this time. I have decided to still recommend this game under the assumption this bug will be patched soon. Occasionally if you need to exit the game (or crash) during a story mission then it locks you out of starting or completing the mission. For me, this has happened during episode 7 but I have heard others experience it in 2 and 3. There is also a ton of lag in some parts of the game, namely episode 2, despite my system requirements being well over recommended.EDIT: The Episode 7 bug was not fixed, but I found a workaround on YouTube. Having finally finished the story after about 21 hours of game time, I can confidently say this game is far larger than I originally thought when I wrote this review... I'm now 43 hours in and only 45% done. That should speak to the size of this game. It's so much fun, I can't explain how much I love this game.... could do with a character creator though, I'd love to make my SWTOR characters in here.

author: Fortnitehater012
review: This game is great, fun to play, and addicting, but here's some things it's not. There are no difficulty settings, and everything is designed to be challenging, for children. don't be fooled by the rolling and parrying mechanics that exist, If you're looking for a dark souls/elden ring combat experience, look elsewhere, you could beat a boss battle with one finger. The puzzles are fun, but as well, not hard at all. the story and freeplay puzzles are very linear and throughout my whole playthrough of the story I didn't get stuck on a single mission. However, this game is super fun for Lego fans, and even more so for star wars fans. If you're looking for a no sweat, fun to play adventure game to play in your down time, this is the game for you. There's barely any grinding, so you can just play casually and still get characters easily (once you have stud multipliers, of course) Overall, good game, recommended, I don't regret my 200 hours.

author: UMEBOSHI
review: So I spent not only the $80 CAD at launch as well the character packs because I actually had hope. I spent a while trying to get into the game, but in hindsight I wish I just refunded it, I could have spent the money on something worthwhile, like a surge protector or tape, or even just Outer Wilds again because the devs deserve it.First issue, tons of the content in the campaign is cutscenes, skipping pretty memorable scenes that could have made somewhat enjoyable levels. If they got rid of the hundreds of meaningless, copy + pasted side missions and actually filled the campaign with content I could see this being somewhat redeemable. The story missions are primarily just linear paths, point A to point B routes with occasional enemies sprinkled about. There is no failstate for most things, and so there isn't any challenge that makes playing feel rewarding. You would actually have to put in effort to make it challenging, if it's even possible (*cough cough* battle of Naboo). Enemies tend to meander about or ignore you.If the combat doesn't offer engaging gameplay, surely the puzzles will, right?There are no puzzles, at least ones that don't present the solution right away. Nor is there platforming, pretty much everything is either quick time events or walking to your next objective (I thought QTEs died out in 2012??), I would hesitate to even call this gameplay.Open world is pretty empty and feels lifeless with NPCs just existing to offer you missions, but I've heard that this is the status quo for many open world games (maybe I've gotten spoiled by Elden Ring). 380 characters is a lie. Most of the characters' abilities and movesets can be found in every other character in their class, and their fighting movesets don't make a difference because there is barely any proper combat.1/10 it looks pretty sometimes

author: adankpancake
review: It steps all over what made the complete saga good.Character customization is way too confusing, pressing a to select and swap often does NOT select or swap.  Remember how in the newer lego games, they tell you what abilities the characters have because there are so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ many of them? CONGRATS they got rid of that, have fun playing guessing games.This game loves to take control away from the player while spamming with them with audio and visual cues of where to go what to do... except in episodes 7-9 when you actually need a guide because no one in the right mind gave a ♥♥♥♥ about those awful films.Combat is terrible too, in every single boss fight the most optimal play until episode 7 is pretty much always to just throw your lightsaber.  The reason I say until episode 7 is because the godawful disney films were written by dumbasses who use the guise of "oh they don't have the experience necessary to throw their lightsaber" BRO THEY JUST FOUGHT KYLO REN WHO IS AN EXPERIENCED AND TRAINED FIGHTER THE ♥♥♥♥ DO YOU MEAN.  Every other boss fight plays out the exact same, and speaking of playing the exact same... the vehicle levels.  Every vehicle controls like ♥♥♥♥, while you can't hit ♥♥♥♥ because every enemy vehicle is faster than you meaning you flail around attempting to not die while following the objective.This is truly a disgrace and with more dlc than ever being added I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this.Play the complete saga with the modern overhaul mod or lego star wars 3 the clone wars.Dare I say, even the greed-fueled Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens is a better lego- no, just a better game fundamentally in every single aspect than this.

author: ethanahte_
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: Kharzak
review: This game is a disappointment. The graphics look really good and the sound is great, like a Blaster carried by a Stormtrooper sounds like an E-11. The Combat is better compared to previous Lego games, but there is not enough of it. Most of the time your just running around stacking crates or pulling levers. There are only 5 levels per movie and most of them feel to short and there are too many duel levels. The game is buggy as hell. It's almost impossible to play through a level or a mission without some bug ruining the experience. The comedy feels forced and unnatural, the times I laughed could be counted on one hand. The open world looks great but why are there no enemies to fight? Imagine having the option to play Battlefront style battles on Planets or Fleet battles in Space. Such a wasted opportunity.

Highly do not recommend.

author: The Legend of Peter
review: Devs apparently are concinved that more of anything is always better.The problem is: more good is better, more bad is just worse. And the "more" in this game is kinda bad.The game definitely has good things and looks great, but I don't find myself enjoying it too much for a plethora of reasons. In the end it's just... not very fun.Overall feels like a decent game that is held back by the sheer sum of small issues to a point where I can barely enjoy it.And instead of improving the core game, devs for some reason decided to litter (and I mean absolutetly cram) every location with unengaging and repetative tasks. Even more than the tasks themselves being boring, the reward for pretty much all of them is the same: 1 kyberbrick. You can use these to unlock or level skills of character classes, most of which are very boring (e.g. your throws deal x% more damage).And if neither the tasks themselves, nor the reward is interesting, why would I bother?This game puts every character into one class (rebel, scoundrel, rebellion, jedi, villain ...). I find this system to be deficient, making the characters boring and inauthentic.At the core of lego games are puzzles that can only be completed by specific charaters, e.g. characters with an explosive, or characters that are part of the rebellion, characters with a hook-shot... One of the most fun things for me always was finding characters that can complete as many tasks as possible. This is what makes unlocking characters interesting and engaging: figuring out their "skill set". E.g. finding a blaster character with a double jump and explosives, or a mini-gun character with a jet-pack, a jedi that can crawl through tunnels etc. Every class has a definitive skill-set and there's almost no reason to actually look at the characters you unlock.  Why would I care about rebellion guy with gun 24? (So far the only exception I found was Boba Fett having a jet pack.)Characters just feel more like skins than like characters. The only reason left to actually look at unlocked characters is that they might have slightly different attacks than the others - and even these attacks seem to be mostly the same within one class.Not only does this make characters boring, it also makes no sense. For example, Luke is a Jedi, so he cannot use rebellion terminals because he is not of the "rebellion" class. All villains (every stormtrooper, fleet captain, whatever) have explosives, but none of the rebels - because it's part of the villain class to have explosives. - you cannot choose which saga to play, you have to follow a linear path through the levels- no ground battles, which were easily my favourite thing to do in lego clone wars- hitboxes to interact with anything are bad. This includes: picking up items, placing down items, riding a vehicle, building something from legos- force attack hitboxes are so bad I had to make them their own point. Every single time I try to deactivate and put away a light saber by pressing b (or activate it), my character instead detonates a random flower at the end of the room, because for some reason the force auto-target reached absurdly far and cannot be suppressed (e.g. by holding down b instead of tapping it). And if I'm lucky and there is actually no item around that could be targeted, it instead targets my companion and kills him. Simply amazing. And because the control configuration is basically useless you can not rebind the force attack to not use the same button. Even better.- control configuration is both bad and bugged (provides no granularity at all and resets half the time)- jumping does not inherit velocity from sprinting, so any time you jump while sprinting it feels like you suddenly hit a (lego) brick wall- the hint-providing droid stationed at every hub location does not stop asking you to come read his hints (all of which have been displayed during the gameplay at the appropriate point in time, it's just for repeating stuff), and he has like 3 voice-lines in total, you can not disable, mute or remove him. This guy is actually insanely annoying, he makes me not wanna spent any time in central areas at all- characters just can't shut up for a minute in general- space-combat is boring and also plays terribly (and there's way too many optional "hey do this space fight which is the same as the previous 10 but with a different planet in the background)- all npc's talk too slowly for me personally, same for the text speed of their speech bubbles (to be fair, otherwise voice and text simply wouldn't match). If I skip the slow text reveal to instantly see the full text bubble,  I can read their dialog like 3 times over in the time it takes them to utter it a single time.- waaay too many blaster fights that all are the exact same- game drops inputs every now and then- you can't do anything other than slowly walking around during a light saber throw: you can't run, you can't jump, you can't attack (also throws miss half of the time). In a previous game you could still run around, jump, and attack using the force which was very fun and felt extremely fluid - now throwing your light saber just feels like a waste of time.- force controls for lifting and moving an object are just terrible- parcour objects (bars to hold on to, twirling bars etc) feel very "static", slow and unprecise- camera is kinda bad- character menu is hard to navigate- music transitions triggered by entering a specific location are poorly made- game sometimes plays 2 tracks at the same time (if you are near a radio, you will hear music from the radio + the "actual" game music), this always sounds terrible and kinda hurts my ears- scavenger class does not have its abilities unlocked initially. I was trying to fully clear the dagobah area and got stuck on a kyberbrick - the game told me to use a scavenger to collect it, but even after switching to one I could not do anything to get the brick. I wasted like half an hour before I asked google about this - turns out you need to play a specific level to unlock these abilites.This was rather annoying and didn't add anything to the game - if you play the level you will literally unlock all 3 scavenger abilites within 5 minutes. Why even lock them in the first place if you're just gonna throw them at me anyways?Bonus:When following Obi-Wan to his hutt in episode IV I had to stop and go back to him 3 times because he would simply stop and stand still if you leave a ridiculously small radius. One of these times I was literally already  at the hutt, but you cannot start the level if he's not there. I could literally  see him from where I was standing, but I still had to go back to him so he would stop waiting for me - so he could show me the way to his hutt...  just brilliant

author: Kolbi
review: TLDR: Disappointed in the game and in myself for buying it and not refunding on time. Pressing recommend to balance out my seemingly unfair judgement after playing a mere 6 hours. The whole 6 hours I played was constant struggle with emotions and when I realized I despise the game and played too much already to get a refund I started to feel remorse paying full price for it. This is a childs game and I just don't know what I expected as a 32 Y/O dumbas$. The promise of open world just grabbed my attention and star wars in general as I am a fan of the whole universe. Pros:- Star Wars storytelling for 5-10 year olds. It is okay to get children busy for a while in a friendly and forgiving environment. Anyone older just read the books.. or watch the movies.. or play any other SW game..Cons:- Gameplay is the following: Press W- Challenges are absolutely pointles, easy and the moral reward for a 100% completion is nonsense. Utter waste of time.- Story is given obviously you can't do anything just go with the flow. There are no decisions. It is alright as the game is working with a given story. The implementation is rubbish. Even the slightest sense of decision making is missing. The game forgives every mistake you make. No consequences, you cannot die or lose anything except you will to play. - Ally characters do nothing. You have to do everything, destroy every stupid droid. The gungan armies just standing there, their backline is breached and the droids take close to no dmg from the two other gungans that miserably try to defeat them for the sake of aesthetics. You need to do everything. You need to load the trebuchet because the gungan who would have only that job is standing there and well... standing there...- Even if you turn off all AIM assist and HP regen, anything that aids you (as I did), the boss fights will be still the same... NOTHING changes. During the Vader fight with Luke I got hit zero times and wrecked the ♥♥♥♥ out of the sith lord then obviously he won. That is the story right? Same with Maul vs Obi+Ani. I had bigger challenge from the very first common mob from any of the Dark Souls games.- It is seriously not funny. It is childish and the "fun" just ruins the storytelling.- You cannot kill anything other than you supposed to.- The gameplay is sooooooooooooooooo forgiving it pains me. You cannot die, you resurrect on the same spot like nothing happened. - During pod racing on Tatooine if you go to the bathroom mid-race you will see that the other contestants did the same. You cannot lose the race. - Stormtroopers' aim is worse than in the movies!! How? - The only enjoyable part of the combat is that headshot is fatal (ok first you need to shoot down the helmet which is lame cuz it should not protect from a direct hit). A clean cut from the lightsaber is somehow not... - This game was not meant for casual teenager or adult gamers by any mean. It was meant for children below 12. If anyone asking I would say I recommend Jedi Knight, Republic Commando, Empire at War, but mostly KOTOR I-II and The Force Unleashed I-II because there was no better games released under Star Wars trademark than them.I am utterly disappointed that this game was released not a new Force Unleashed type one or KOTOR... and this game sells almost the same as Elden Ring. Wondering how many regret buying it... Sorry the only reason I put recommended is because I only played 6 hours. I haven't deleted it just. I am constantly torn between "I should delete and forget, 60€ is nothing" vs "I paid for it I must at least complete the story"... And the worse part I bought the deluxe edition :'D

author: muncher of chalk
review: Even though I liked I wouldn't buy it if I were you. Sure it's pretty good but it lacks the classic Lego pizzazz.First of all the characters look really good don't get me wrong, the graphics are fantastic! But for the most part they all do the same thing. There are 9 classes to choose from, each one is unique but every character in said class does the same thing. For example Captain Phasma and a regular storm trooper both do the same thing, the only difference is weapon, looks and on rare occasion there is a unique ability that character posses, but often it is not only used by that one character.Next the content, when I bought the deluxe edition and looked at the DLC, I though I would get to play through the Mandalorian, or Rogue One, but nope, just plain old character packs. But during the main story there is only 45 missions! That may seem like alot but when I tell you the level can be completed in under 5 minutes easily that really takes the time down. But after that when going into the freeplay you see that the game has 1200 kyber bricks; this games equivalent of gold bricks. This may seem like alot, BECAUSE IT IS. But after an hour or two it gets very tedious, and I myself have not even 100% the game (which I plan to do).They are on all the planets, of which there are 24, but most of each of them is just kyber brick collection with the odd couple of side missions for extra characters, WHICH ALSO ONLY LOOK DIFFERENT.Oh and the glitches! Where do I start! To start off we have Rey's back flipping animation not completeing! How could they! I'm just kidding of course and haven't found any game breaking bugs but have found a few comical ones such as key cards clipping through blasters, hanging onto air when climbing and characters standing up whilst riding Rey's speeder. Other people did find the "child abuse flight exploit", pretty unusual name for something, eh? There were a few preventing game completion though, possibly most notably the "Hungry Happabore", which would make the game softlock you by dancing forever if you had the "Galaxy Rave" cheat on.There is also no character creator, this was a big let down, even bigger knowing that it was in production before it was scrapped. Luckily there is a mod on NexusMods that replicates the feature, this was one of the features I was most excited for but sadly TT didn't deliver with this game once again.All in all the SWS isn't a bad game per say, just not one worth the £50 price tag. if it were on sale I would recommend it but for what it is, it's just not worth it. The game may get more DLC and if that does happen I will update my review to include it's presence in it, but for now I wouldn't buy it again.

author: Ref
review: yes

author: MagicOmelet
review: So in long:Story Mode is ♥♥♥♥. It's just wasting your time with boring missions and dialogue you already know, but now it's a bad new synchro. There are only five levels per episode and they are all way shorter then in the original and you mostly just spam buttons to kill enemies. To make matters worse, your are forced to absolve running sections to get from one level to antoher. This can take up to 5 minutes just running from one mission to another, nothing else. The "story" is maybe the worst. It's like someone googled "Star Wars Memes" and just shoved everything he saw in this game. It's just key jangling, memberberries, whatever you wanna call it. Also you can tell that they are trying to justify the sequel trilogy with this. They are trying so hard to make it funny but epic with those last three films, it's just pathetic. Most jokes are just slapstick humour, but sometimes it can be funny. Though never even close to the original humour.Free Play is ok. Sometimes boring, few times really fun, mostly just ok. There is much to collect, so you're busy for some time. Some riddles are creative, most are basic but still this is a step up from the original, where almost all riddles were boring. So this is the best part of the game. The missions on the other hand are painful. It's again just the game wasting your time. Transport a cargo from this planet to this planet, but you are attacked three times by enemies, who grow in number each time. Or the missions where you have to catch a character. They run away, you shoot them, they get invincible for like 5 to 10 seconds, repeat. Sometimes they even stun you for no reason. And their healthbars are absurdly large, to make it even more tedious. Same with boss battles. Just spam a button 'til they're dead. No interesting mechanics, no character themed boss fight. Just click a button 100 times.Lastly: the bugs. There are so many. Most are just annoying, but some break the gameplay. For example my mission marker just vanished and I had to look up a video to find the person I needed to talk to. Or the person i neede to talk to disappeared when I got to close, forcing me to twitch my camera and take different approaches so they wouldn't despawn. Graphical glitches happen all the time, but that's not so bad, it doesn't get in your face that often.In summary: Don't buy this for full price. 20$ maximum, because remeber: You have to play the story to get to free play. That is like 5-10 hours of boring ♥♥♥♥ you have to endure. And if u wanna buy this, wait half a year til those bugs are fixed. If they even fix them.

review: What else is there to say classic lego fun in the star wars universe this game finally brings the previous other games all into one neat package with tons of DLC covering nearly all the spin off movies and TV series as well as the regular star wars movies. The world feels epic and large and the free roam ability means your not forced to play any particular episode in any order once you have unlocked the first level or two. Would recommend! Especially on max graphics settings the game looks very nice. With full drop in and drop out co op play available, its simple mindless solo/buddy fun. This game also adds several new mini missions that were not in previous versions of Lego star wars so it does not feel like a complete remake with nothing new to see at all.

author: BlueEagle447
review: I pre-ordered this game like most people and unlike most people, I am very disappointed in it.The lightsaber combat is horrible, no matter if you're fighting blaster wielding foes, or another lightsaber user. I can block blaster bolts left and right, but if I try to attack, I attack a direction I am not facing, or my character won't attack in general. When my lightsaber returns to me after I throw it, my character stands there for a good 2 seconds before he will attack again, usually resulting in me getting killed. Whenever I play as Yoda, after every single attack, he puts his lightsaber away and takes 3 hits before he pulls it out again.The missions are bland and I feel like I'm skipping most of the episodes when I play. There aren't many challenges in the missions to help you get to where you need to go or are super repetitive, and the ones that are in the missions are not creative. It's climb this wall, shoot this target, climb this wall, move this box, climb this wall. 2 missions later, the episode ends. (It's 5 missions per episode, but with how short they are, and how much of the movie I'm skipping, it might as well be 2)R2 and other astromechs can't fly anymore. This was probably the biggest let down IMO. I expected to be able to fly across a gap like astromechs in TCS could. They allowed protocol droids to be able to jump and build, so that makes up for it a little bit.Flying in space is buggy as well. When I turn to try to destroy an asteroid or land on a planet, I barely turn and my ship starts to fly in circles and doesnt want to stop for a good few seconds. Usually after one complete 360 degree turn.Palpatine did not say "It's treason then." nor could you fight palpatine as Mace Windu.There was no "Master Skywalker, there's too many of them. What are we going to do?"I'm not too impressed with the game, but I'm going to finish it just for nostalgia's sake. But I recommend the complete saga over this.Also Ki Adi Mundi's death scene was changed.Edit: I forgot to say what I enjoy about it.I like how the helmets of the clones (and i assume other helmeted soldiers) come off after hitting them in the head. It has a cool look to it.For non helmeted enemies, a headshot with a blaster is a one hit kill which i think is super cool and convenient. The humor is top tier. I nearly choked on some water when Jar Jar drank the hyperdrive fluid and immediately turned green and made the dumb face. Other people have said you cannot kill younglings in the Jedi temple, but you can. As commander cody, or a jedi, I have taken the lives of several children. Might be a bug on their games or mine. But I at least can kill younglings.

author: Little Pyro
review: Alright y'all...we gotta take off the nostalgia goggles for a minute, this game is fundamentally bad, the levels are extremely short and the lightsaber duels are very disappointing, the game is also just full of bizarre decisions that make no sense at all. For some reason they decided that Anakin VS Obi-Wan should be single player and the second player just gets to watch as C3PO but Luke VS Vader is co op but breaks the boss fight.The cutscenes are rushed versions of the movies and they skip a ton of possibilities for levels and content.There is no battle of coruscant, The clones don't do anything at all, Endor was over in a flash, You don't even get to destroy the second death star in episode 6.There is no character customization (Though personally I never used it anyway.) and the FPS just drops on some levels despite my specs being WELL over the recommended.The game plays more like Mario Odyssey in being that it's a collectathon more than an actual game.They seem to have had a quota for making sure all the meme lines are in the game but the context seems to be thrown out sometimes.I've only played from 1-6 and in between all the cutscenes there were maybe 1-2 good missions per movie, not to mention there were as little as 5 in each one.I got the game as a birthday gift but frankly I can't recommend, they had over 3 years to make this work out and they just didn't pull it off.It sucks but that's the truth of it.

author: AustinBoston
review: I have so much nostalgia for the original lego star wars games, especially the complete saga. I played the heck out of them on my Playstation 2, Nintendo Wii and Xbox 360 back in the day, and still play them often on my PC. When they announced this game, it is safe to say my expectations were ultra high, especially since the last time they heavily changed up the lego formula was Lego Lord of the Rings (which is also one of my most beloved Lego games). I got this game day one on my PS5 and played it the night it came out, and holy cow was I blown out of the water! I wound up getting and playing through the game on my Switch, Xbox (most of the game at least) and on my PC too. It even made me dislike Rise of Skywalker less (marginally, but hey its something). If you like Lego Games or Star Wars ones, this game does not disappoint! I would 100% recommend this game to anyone looking for a good star wars game. The base game also has an absurd amount of unlockable characters, so the DLC isn't strictly necessary, but I also got the DLC because I like the characters in it (Andor, Mandalorion, etc.) since it doesn't add new levels or challenges or anything like that, so I'd recommend it only if you want to play as those extra characters specifically.

author: clubsarah
review: This is by far the best game in the Lego series. I've been playing these games since I was a kid and they just keep getting better, so I never stopped. This has got to be the pinnacle of every Lego game I've ever played. The free roam is amazing, the gameplay is unique, and there post-story content which is something I enjoy a lot. The missions added in this game are great for post-story gameplay and the animation for characters especially is amazing. You can tell how hard the developers worked on this, and it shows how much they researched the Star Wars franchise, even adding some inside jokes that only a true fan would get. This game is better than anything EA has done for the franchise, and it's a kids game. This game shows that the love for Lego does not die with age.

author: Ollysbuddy
review: I went into this game with a kind of neutral idea of what the game was going to be likeI played the old Lego Star Wars games in the past, I have beaten both the complete Saga and the Clone Wars games 3 times at 100%Going in I expected 3 things though, and this game doesn't deliver1st.Lots of combatwhile the game's combat is actually really good, significantly more advanced and interesting then the original games...its very rare to actually enjoy it, as getting into a fight usually involves a Boss fight (the best parts of the game and really shines) or an "event" shall we call itin the original games, there was almost always enemies, varying in distance and frequency, and it was always fun, even if it was easy, to fight these enemies, it never was drawn out or too much, nor too little, i never felt like the game was a fighting game or strictly a puzzle game, it had combat as a base featureThis game doesnt feel like combat is a base feature, it feels like your shoot or slice up 10 dudes then fight a boss with another 10 dudes to fight, in all my 5 hours of gameplay, Ive probably fought as many enemies as i did in 1 level in the original game2nd.Interesting and engaging puzzlesthis is a game for children, i get it, but its like the rebels show, it doesnt know what it wants to be, either the puzzle is very confusing and doesnt tell you where the thing you need to get is at (still easy once it makes sense on what you are supposed to do), or its so easy a baby could do it accidentlyand it feels like there is no in betweenthe puzzles arn't even interesting, i was never really engaged, it was all very repetitive, buttons or build a picture or put a block on a blockthe R2 puzzles where boring, the level designs were garbage3rd.Platforminga lego game really shines in its platforming, when it takes an area and lets you explore the variety of areas and trying to find the many different ways to get where you are going, making it linear but still challengingthe clone wars does this very well, allowing you to take different routes to the same path, and its all skill basedthis game? press jumpthats it, dont aim, dont point, dont time your jumps, just, press a buttonpuzzles based on commands suck, games are getting WAYYYY too comfortable with that kinda gameplay, i get that your standard mario type platforming can be challenging for younger audiences, but when i was 9 and i got the complete saga, i was still able to beat the game fully, maybe not get the full 100%  complete that young, but i beat the gameDevs baby the player wayyyyyy too much in this, the game is extremely flat as well, offering no "real" vertical movement, its just a walking sim with a couple of fights and stupid puzzlesat the end of the day, im disappointed, i didnt expect the next big thing, but i expected more, things i didnt mention were the flying that sucks on PC, the stupidly long dialog and NPC trailing missions which make up 50-75% of the game, especially in the start(should just make the NPC's Follow you)and the stupidly long load times, and how many there was, i still have my copy of the OG trilogy, and i can boot it up, launch a level, and be in the level in under 5 min, this game takes like 15 min to get into the game, then 5 min in you get another load screeni have a gen 4 ssd, its freaking stupid how bad the load times areanyways, i know i dont have the popular opinion, cause unfortunately star wars fans have almost nothing else to play other then older titles, so at the end of the day, just remember the amazing games we had before, dont settle on quality because you worship some devs that are going out of business anyways, disney doesnt care anymore, and neither should you, buy Republic commando, Knights of the old republic 1 & 2 and the OG bf2 if you want a great star wars experiencethey are the same price, and youll have probably an extra 100 hours of gameplay over this pile of crap

author: QueenFreak877
review: so i want to preface this by saying i am a LOOONNNNNNNNNGG term lego game fan. Ive played and 100%d every lego game from Lego Star Wars: The Video Game (the original '05 one), which a blood relative bought for me brand new when it came out, all the way through The Lego Movie 2 Videogame multiple times (except Lego The Hobbit, which is because that game is utter trash and one of the few games ive ever regretted buying). I actually went back and starting replaying through my favourite most recent lego game (Jurassic World) in preparation for this game. so i LOVE almost every lego games. theyre fun, some of the jokes are still hilarious, and theyre a completionist's dream. Ive been looking forward to this game for as long as its been announced as a thing! I even made sure to buy the deluxe edition because thats how much faith i had in tt to deliver a great game....... and the final product is.. bad actually. Sure its gorgeous. the best looking lego game ever id say! and so far the worlds ive explored are lovingly detailed and winding just like a major starwars settlement should be. they feel believably huge. however, so far theres no depth to them. the collectibles arent hidden in any way and i cant even say theres any actual puzzles either. the majority of the puzzles i came across while exploring were "stack some boxes and jump up/over to the kyber brick". the rest involved switching to a character (if i had them) that could press a button and then boom puzzle is solved. thats it.and then theres the levels, or rather, the lack thereof. now it does *technically* have 5 levels per episode, but each is so brief, theyd fit right in in Lego Indiana Jones 2 (which was tt's first attempt at an open world in this style of games and was done at the cost of its levels, but was a good first attempt!). If youve playing any of the other lego games, they feel like a single section of one of those games' levels and barely take 10 minutes to complete. the majority of an episodes story is told by having the player go from point a to point b, watch some cutscenes that show the most interesting and enjoyable parts of the movies at super speed and skip so much as well that each cutscene feels like a small snippet of a scene itself! it makes it hard to follow whats going on even if youve watched that episode 100 times irl. I know others have written about this "level" already, but i think the lead up to "Better Call Maul" and its "level" are the perfect example at the games failing. leading up to the level, you escort padme and the naboo pilots through the palace section of the overworld and defeat 3 groups of about 8 battledroids on our way to the fighters that would launch to go defeat the control ship. thats it. simple escort, 8 battledroid groups, onto the next story beat. If youve played either The Complete Saga or the original Lego Star Wars game youd know that this used to be an entire level. it felt like you were actually sneaking and fighting your way to those fighters like they did in the movie! it was great. but in this game, thats all been simplified down a 5 minute walk with no real challenge or enjoyment. once you get to the hanger and start the level, a cutscene plays showing you the pilots taking off, then obiwan and quigon fight through battledroids and chase maul all the way to the area right before the red light door things that force the three to stop their fight and wait for them to open before closing again. THATS where the level begins. over halfway through the maul fight sequence. in the original and complete saga games, you actually got to PLAY through the ENTIRE chase and come to the realization that maul is toying with you like the sadistic apex predator he believes he is. but better call maul is just the room before the red light doors on and each part has been incredibly simplified. Its just so underwhelming that i think saying i was underwhelmed is a gross understatement.and i think that basically sums up. this game, which had been delayed for years and created under almost nonstop crunch, is grossly underwhelming. i feel like the tt higher ups decided to have everyone focus on the visuals and forgot to make a game before last year, then had the devs rush to throw in SOMETHING that resembled a game and called it a day. It honestly makes me wish this game had been cancelled and they focused on something else (like treating their staff better perhaps?). im only 3 hrs into the game and already 3/5ths of the way through episode one.... and honestly i have very little desire to finish this game. Im even considering looking into refunding the game, which is something ive NEVER done on steam before with any game (and i have several games like Genesis Rising which are completely unplayable in my library still because you know, i bought it. its my fault really.). but thats how lackluster this game is. i know this is a "kids game" but media for kids can be challenging and enjoying even for adults! it didnt have to be a bunch of pretty looking nothing.some other things i want to mention: i did local coop with my niece for the first hr and they got incredibly motion sick from the camera despite having motion blur and headbob turned off. I however was fine, so idk what the issue is that causes some people to be effected like that and not others, but its worth mentioning. I also had no interest in trying to do online multiplayer as the people id want to play with live with me so it doesnt matter to me. neither does character creation. by lego the lord of the rings, i only ever created for achievements, especially once the games let you just pick any character you had unlocked instead of just a small selection, so that also didnt bother me.to sum up my feelings: i wanted and hoped for a combination of the complete saga, the clone wars, and jurassic world games and got something i dont think should even count as a game. if i had to give it a percentage: 23%, and thats PURELY for the visuals, which again are amazing. i just wished they spent more time making actual gameplay.

But the only Lego games I've played are the older ones and the differences between this game and the old ones is staggering. A lot of the story is missing from the game, a lot of the good times on Tatooine in the first episode missing (you start at Naboo). This game had me excited but now I'm disappointed, I'm gonna go dig up my old DS copy instead,

author: Arkolenn
review: Little to no puzzles. Lazy mission design, boring and too quick missions.One example: Episode 2, when you get to ticopa city you literally just have to follow Lama Su for ~3 minutes and nothing else (theres some stuff to break). Then you get the cutscene of Jango and Boba and you start chasing them until you end up in a boss fight, except you literally just run like ~50 meters to get to the boss fight (unlike in complete saga, you had to do some puzzles and parkour)NOTE THAT YOU STILL HAVE NOT ATTACKED OR BEEN ATTACKED BY EVEN A SINGLE ENEMY. NEITHER HAVE YOU COME ACROSS ANY MANDATORY PUZZLE.The boss fight is not much different from complete saga, just damage sponge and then you go fight them in space.The "open world" sections are really empty, boring and not even needed. One example is when you enter Otoh Gunga in episode 1. All you do there is just run to the other side of the whole place, get a cutscene and then go back. Along that trip was only 2 puzzles (That I myself noticed). Then you later have to come BACK there, and go to the other side AGAIN just to get little bit of dialogue and run back.2nd player gets forced to play boring characters in some missions (Like R2D2 with its small range tickle) or parts of missions such as on the Obi-wan and Luke skywalker fight in episode 3, literally the only thing the 2nd player gets to do in that is just watch.You're better off with buying complete saga over this one. If you've played complete saga before, this will definitely disappoint youThe humor is not bad though, I'll give the game that at least. Still would not recommend.

author: Biohazardous00
review: Just finished up Phantom Menace, so this more an early impression than a fledged review. Am loving it so far. Feels like Star Wars and Lego in equal parts; lots of space opera spirit enforced by quirky humour. I get the sense that this is a game where you get what you give to it. There is a levelling system and I thought this would be a bit of an ADHD dilemma for me, but it's more complimentary than necessary to grind, and the extra puzzles and side quests are welcome layering to the experience. Otherwise you can just shoot straight through the main levels. My only real gripe with gameplay is the space combat. It's not bad, far from it! I just remember the on rail sections in Lego Force Awakens having a more speedy feel to them, made the dogfights slightly more intense. Lightsaber and blaster play on the other hand is balanced as fleshed out without being too character-action driven. If you're a fan of past Lego games or of Star Wars, and want to play something that has a lot of depth but not too difficult, this will satisfy.

author: Corran2015
review: It sure took a while, but the completely refreshed engine and openness was worth it. Is it Skyrim? No. Are there things we would've liked? Sure. Is it still an absolute riot to play with the girlfriend, siblings, friends, or kids? Definitely.There could be a little more to the space areas - just let us get the feeling we're moving around a bit more and give us a little more environment up there and more elaborate repeatables. That said it's still fun, and having a damn capitol ship drop out of hyperspace is a nice touch.The planets all have a lot of great atmosphere and explorability, considering there's 20 of them. This is inarguably better than past games by orders of magnitude.I genuinely would not feel robbed seeing DLC that expands this down the road. They gave us a full enough game.

author: ᵍˡᵘᵐᵖ ⁹⁰⁰⁰
review: Terrific. I've been playing the Lego Star Wars games for many, many years now, back when I the only console I had was a Wii. This is the best installment so far, with better controls, mechanics, and a ♥♥♥♥ ton of little things left to be discovered.10/10 They have Twerking Clone Toopers.

Overall, this game goes above and beyond. (Almost) everything from visuals and sound to gameplay and level design is top notch. First and foremost, however, I want to make clear right off the bat; this is  a remaster of the classic Lego Star Wars games plus episodes 8 and 9 in that same styles. This game is a brand new take on Lego Star Wars. It's very very good, but if remastered classic games is what you want and the only thing you want, then for you this game is not. That being said, this is probably the pinnacle of Lego Star Wars games, and probably the pinnacle of the main-format Lego games as a whole. The visual styling is . The graphics are borderline mindblowing, and there was very obviously a hell of a lot of care put into bringing Lego games firmly up to modern visual standards without sacrificing the visual charm that the classic (lets call them 'legacy' from now on?) games had. There are places in the game that have quite a bit of non-Lego environment meshes, and places in the game that are made almost entirely out of Lego bricks but look so damn good that you don't notice its fully Lego at first (or perhaps at all). The first level in Episode IV is a good example of this. As far as I can tell, it's almost entirely made out of Lego bricks, and I was about halfway through the level when I noticed it was not, in fact, a bunch of non-Lego meshes. That isn't to say that the non-Lego environments are less enjoyable. If anything, the absurd visual quality of the non-Lego textures and meshes is far more enjoyable alongside the Lego bits than the muddy, gross-looking non-Lego environments of the previous games. Overall, the developers would have been hard-pressed to give this game a better visual presentation. Audio on the whole is pretty good too. Its not as much of a complete package relative to the visuals, though. If you are an ardent Star Wars nerd and/or played the original games with any amount of loyalty, then you  notice certain shortcomings in the audio design. Nothing gamebreaking. In fact, its all pretty trivial. Padme's blaster doesn't have that signature Naboo blaster sound, for example. Small stuff like that. Things that were likely design , not design . If you can overlook those admittedly very small issues in the audio design, then I have very few qualms with the audio design for this game. The voice-acting, however...(Yar! Complainey opinions be ahead! Read section fully before smiting me!)(Complainey opinions over. You may now smite me.)So... with  out of the way (sorry, not sorry), onto the gameplay. It's good. It's really really good. Whatever goals in mind they had at the drawing board for bringing the legacy games into the modern era of gaming, they smashed those goals and then some. The gameplay is , and really does feel like someone pressed a magic "modernise" button on the legacy games. There's not really a need to write a lot about this section, the gameplay speaks for itself when you play it. And you  play it.Finally, and because this is a Lego game, the topic of content amount. Uh, there's a . There is a 'lot' of open world to explore, and with all the DLC there are 380 characters. Now, rather disappointingly, they were quite strict about including characters only if they were in one of the main 9 movies. That means (with some exceptions, which you can find in the DLC list) theres no Captain Rex, no Cad Bane, no Ventress or Opress, etc. I find this rather odd, since this game is meant to be "The Skywalker Saga", not "ONLY THE 9 MAIN FILMS YOU CRETIN", but oh well. It's a shame to not have really any of the fantastic cast of characters from the Clone Wars, Rebels, etc., but it's still a fantastic cast of characters. In conclusion; get this game. Just get it right now. It's beautiful, funny, super enjoyable, and retains almost all, if not all of the classic charm of the legacy Lego Star Wars games. A truly worthy modern successor of some of the best games ever made. But if you're a stick in the mud, this is not a plug-in replacement of The Complete Saga. Its a totally new game, but hopefully TT Games realises that despite this game, not a single person would complain about a graphical remaster of The Complete Saga...

author: EricCartmansLeftBigToeFungus
review: I wanted to play this game but if I can be honest, I really can't with the way it is at the moment.Firstly, most cutscenes are unskippable even if you've seen them the first time, which really sucks considering they're laggy as hell and once softlocked me before I even got to Episode 1.Secondly, the graphics, despite being very good, were absolutely taxing on my fairly modern PC, even on the lowest settings. I seriously think it's down to the expectation that everyone's going to have a PC that was at the very least built with the standard specs of 2020, which is not the case at all.Third, while I believe the voice acting and sound design are great, I can't actually prove it because even if I max out my speaker output and the in game master volume, it still sounds so quiet I can't hear a thing without subtitles. This really hampered the experience for me.And finally, the controls. Oh dear god the controls. I tried to play with a keyboard and the controls were abysmal. Nothing made sense and one of the buttons it required me to press to close the map menu wasn't a button I could press. No, I was not using a laptop keyboard or a keyboard without a numpad, the button just didn't exist. Then I tried with a controller, and although it sucked less, it still sucked. A LOT. I couldn't tell what button was what because the game assumes you're playing with an Xbox controller even though I was playing with a plugged in PS4 controller. Obviously, since I'm on Windows, it'll always think I'm using an Xbox controller, but it was still bad. The problem is that multiple actions are mapped to the same button even if the buttons are remapped. For example, you can't have jump and jump attack be mapped to separate buttons, they need to be the same. I despise when games do this because some people want to have more control over their controls instead of having their control be restrained. Also, the fact that menu buttons can't be remapped is dumb, because E should not be the back button. Esc should be the back button, not E.One minor complaint is that there is no character creation system, which is a real shame, since the Complete Saga had a very basic character creator. (though I do think that LMSH2 did character creation better)Overall, I want to like this game. I really do. But it's way too new, the controls suck, there aren't enough optimizations, and worst of all, it's really, really hard to get into. For now, until these problems are alleviated, I'm just gonna play other Star Wars games.

author: Chaos
review: If you want to play this because your a fan of the other Lego Games, or The complete Saga. Don't buy. In my opinion this game feels way more different then all the rest of the lego titles. As a fan of the lego series I'm getting really disappointed by the new directions TT Games has taken it.Playing through the game feels like spliced together content. No clear transition. I can barely tell whats a level and what isn't, and EVERYTHING is free roam. I think some things this game needs is way more customization (Oh and the character customizer is just completely cut from the Game, my most favorite feature of every Lego game). Level design almost doesn't exist the level, it just feels just haphazardly thrown into the planet's hub world. Tatooine is pretty crowded. I suppose it works as a level, but as a freeroam, freecam experience, its like having the camera run into every wall possible, especially when doing specific stuff.Some of the cutscenes feel rushed. Important details just are breezed over, and meanwhile stupid stuff is happening in the background a lot.What this game needs is a clear and defined hub world. A place to load levels and worlds without the menu having everything crammed into one place; And better organization.Whats always been a trend in more recent titles, is a constant push to do the main story and nothing else, and even then getting to the main story feels awkward.The menu is also your character selector, and your world selection, and the vehicle spawner, and the upgrade menu, and etc, its too much! On keyboard and mouse, the menu is really awkward to navigate, and some buttons do the exact same thing as well. The character selector is awkwardly sorted, I mean one wrong button and your stuck trying to get back whilst pressing the same button multiple times. All because the mouse couldn't be used. I would rather have the big menu with the characters listed on screen then trying to sort through a tiny menu. Sorting is fine just split menus apart, or make em easier to navigate, and most importantly make the window larger!Oh and a lot of menu buttons are really small, even the main menu has icons that are the main focus, and what they do needs to be explained by little text right below it.Overall this game was hyped so much, and now that its out, its really disappointing. Its like the focus was mainly on character related gameplay mechanics then everything else.Hoping the game is refined through updates. Until then I don't know how to feel about it.

author: DragonKing lDCCl
review: Poor lackluster level design, and too many CTD to count, along with too many performance issues and distracting bugs. It is a grind fest from the start to the end, and it feels like the developers was as rushed, as they make you feel like you are rushing through the episodes stories, just so you can traverse a flat and uninspired "open world" with invisible walls everywhere, and disconnected puzzles and level design. Many puzzles can be straight up skipped using the right characters, which doesn't feel intentional/right. Going for 100% so far has been a massive chore, as the very short storyline that take 5-10 minutes, have several minutes worth of unskippable cutscenes. Character selection is super busted, where the game will constantly switch out your setup of chars seemingly for no reason, forcing you to navigate the clonky menu for resetting your preffered chars. "free play" is pointless for the storyline missions using vehicles, as you almost always get forced to use the default anyway, even encountering "free play" space ship missions, where the game will chose one at random, but not allow you to switch it.Unpolished, unfinished and unstable. For the price, it seems like a lot of corners were cut, and too many new things attempted. "A" for effort, but "F" for execution.

author: amoor005
review: I wish I could give this a "Maybe" rather than a "Yes" or "No".  For the record, I am writing this after I have played up to half of Episode 3.  The graphics are fantastic and the scenery looks great.  There are lots of characters and the intro to the game hits all the right nostalgic notes.  Game play in the levels is where I'm disappointed and in that regard I think LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga has better game play per level.  The levels aren't as in depth as The Complete Saga and you finish each Episode pretty quickly.  Again, the levels are gorgeous, but they seem too short.  Heck, in some ways I miss the red bricks too.  Am I mad I bought this game?  No, just disappointed a little when compared with my memories of playing The Complete Saga.  Hope this helps and if my mind changes as I progress through the game, then I will edit this post.

author: GeT_SwErVeD
review: TLDR: For $60 I do not recommend this for adults, especially those who played the originals and/or don't like the sequels. Great for younger Star Wars fans.If you are a kid who loves Star Wars (the nine "Skywalker Saga" movies anyway) then you'll probably love this game. The graphics are amazing and the humor is funny. The prequels utilize voice actors from The Clone Wars animated series, so that's a plus. There are bugs at the moment (I've had to Alt+F4 a few times due to freezes) and PC controls feel like an afterthought, but as long as you have a controller and don't mind restarting every so often it's perfectly manageable.If you're an adult, specifically one who played the original Lego Star Wars games as a kid, this is not for you. Even more so if you're not a fan of the sequel trilogy. The Lego bit here is more of an aesthetic than a mechanic. You don't really build much, and the things you destroy mainly just drop studs. If you were to remake this game without the Lego medium, not much would change. While the originals were platformers, this game focuses on open-world exploration. I'd describe it as a cross between Assassin's Creed (or another Ubisoft title; open world with LOTS of collectibles), No Man's Sky (the space content), and The Force Unleashed (combat), all with Lego minifigures for characters. If you're here for story and substance, you'll finish the game very quickly as the actual levels are short, and there are only five per episode. The vast majority of the game's content is in the open world, and that content is comprised of fetch quests, puzzles, time trials, and other peaceful activities. Combat is practically non-existent outside of the levels, so unlocking new characters and upgrades honestly feels very pointless. You could easily "beat the game" without any of the upgrades and only one of each character. If you have the DLC you get to "cheat" anyway as you start off with multiple classes you aren't intended to have for a while. The only pain point here is with Scavengers, who you do need to play in story mode to unlock their abilities (sorry Kuill).

The voice acting is trash and when trying to see if there were unique death cinematics for messing up I swear tard controls are put into place so it's impossible to fail "quick" time events. The combat itself is so basic you don't even need to block, you can go full smooth brain. The open world is empty and you only find things in it when following the story while it holds your hand. It messes up the story by taking out stuff or adding stuff that a 5 year old thought of. The only part I liked was that it somewhat kept the humour from the original 2 lego star wars games, hell if they removed the voice acting and kept the gibberish they used to do then the game would actually be playable but no whenever a cutscene happens I have to remove my headset incase my ears start to bleed and put up a case against me in the Hauge. And before you say "hur der you only have (what ever hours it says I do) your review means nothing... I brought it just to write the review then refunded it, I waved the black flag to actually play it.

author: Jilly V.
review: TL;DR It's passable. graphically well presented with a large roster but it's missing far too much to make it worth picking up.Is LEGO Star Wars Skywalker Saga a bad game? No. Is it worth 60$? Also no. The game has serious flaws that hold it back from being what it should have been. Let's start though with the handful of positives that are here though. The game looks visually fantastic, the finer details are a huge step up from previous games. The lightsaber throwing mechanic is fun but also very unbalanced in combat. The 'wall cutting' mechanic is a fun new addition adding to the interactions with the world. The roster is absolutely packed with characters and that's great.Positives done; time for the laundry list of failures on TT's latest game.For an initial volley of faults; every planet is a HUB but they're all just excuses to stick 100 NPCs into the area and only maybe 20% of them are intractable and the only value in going back is to grid the over 1100 collectibles making the game an absolute chore to 100%. HUBs are both too big and too limited at the same time; areas are massive but they have so little to do and explore that it feels lacking. Minigames are scattered all over and NPCs issue side quests that force you to interact with one of the worst menus in any game I've ever played.Mumble mode is obnoxious and you can't fully get rid of subtitles. The game has too many 'accessibility' options turned on by default cluttering the players view of the game. The older LEGO titles had very easy to understand directions on what to do and where to go; this game slaps dozens of way points and guides the player everywhere by default because it's far too complicated.Speaking of overly complicated; the combat system is a combo-focused one that more closely resembles Streets of Rage than a LEGO game. The added complexity makes the combat more of a mess than it needed to be; the only worth while change is aiming and the lightsaber throw. Force powers aren't intuitive and break the flow of the combat if used in a fight.Split screen co-op is a mess. 2022 and 2 player co-op is still local only with Steam having Play Together functionality. It's almost unacceptable to still not have a means of 2 player story co-op. LEGO Star Wars II for the DS had better PvP and Complete Saga has better story co-op and level designs. Split screen is side by side only with no option for top bottom layout; an issue compounded by the camera being closer than any previous LEGO game making the view crushed down into far too tight of an area.Space gameplay is a horrid mix of Battle Front 2 and LEGO and has far too many issues. The space combat is a hectic mess and the environment is too open. The controls are a busted mess that handle poorly in all vehicle gameplay and are particularly bad in the 3D space gameplay.The lack of any Clone Wars content is inexcusable with the DLC having Solo and Mandalorian packs and a decade old LEGO game that stops its story at the early/middle of the Clone Wars show. The means of unlocking characters forces retreading of areas and makes the side quests a necessity to unlock the majority of content. Unlike the Complete Saga unlocks are locked behind almost anything BUT the main levels.In summation; Skywalker Saga isn't just a bad game; it's a bad game that SHOULD have been good, especially with all the delays it had. At best this is an easily forgettable 6/10 that has almost zero replay value.
