author: Blade
review: Look, dont get me wrong i absolutely love star wars lego games, even so much so i pre-ordered it to obtain all of the DLC. only for them to flip it into a way for a company to make more money off a game. this is whats killing the gaming market. espescially the star wars market. this game has great aspects such as the large space stations and space travel however the controls just feel clunky and the camera has an ever so strong desire to make you feel sick. i have seen little to no effort put into actually fixing the gameplay but its always about how to release more skins and make people pay for them becuase no one makes games for the gamers anymore, they only make games where you need to be rich to own it fully. If you want my honest and truthful opinion, its kind of just disappointing you know. i had such high hopes for this game and it still can be the most amazing lego game they have made but it just seems they dont care enough to fix the actual game. Sorry Lego star wars but you have let us down.

author: ilikerain73
review: It is not a bad game. It is not even a finished game. The developers clearly worked really hard to make this a product of love and it is just as clearly bogged down by the blatant fact that they were not given nearly enough time to make this game, and I am saddened by the idea that they might never finish this game. The modding community is fixing a tremendous number of issues that should not be present, but I am still left unsatisfied by what should have been the greatest lego game of all time. The force mechanics are good, I love first person shooting, but I can't keep this game above 30 fps and there are only seven sith characters in a game that is supposed to be comprised of EVERYTHING star wars. Content aside the newest patch didn't even fix the droid factory, a gruelingly low fps level, nor many of the gamebreaking bugs. I blame Warner Bros. and Lucasfilms far before I blame TT games, but that doesn't stop me from being insanely dissapointed. Play the other lego star wars games, but don't pay full price for this. Maybe in a year the modding community can perfect this game, but I have to ask why that's our only alternative in the first place.

author: Terminator
review: When I was 12 years old, LEGO Star Wars was the complete saga, the game that interested me most by far. It wasn’t because the graphics were great or there were so many abilities, but because the story, the individual levels and tasks were so beautifully designed that my 12-year-old didn’t want to get away from the Wii. The story in Lego humor offered so much variety and also tasks that you could spend countless hours in it.A few years later Lego Star Wars the Clone Wars came out, which I loved and played with every afternoon.This game. . . is grotesque in terms of level design. The individual levels are designed so loveless that in each level you feel like playing the previous one again. The mechanics of Clone Wars, that you play battles and try not to be overwhelmed by droids, have seemingly been forgotten.Ergo, you run from A to B, knock out two three droids, and at point B it’s either a boss fight, or you shoot targets like a moor chicken. After that, the level is over.And this is repeated every level.The new graphics and the so-called Open World were probably so present in the development that it was completely omitted to keep the player happy.In my opinion, it is almost 60€ for this game, if you buy it in the Deluxe version, well above what you get for your money. If you compare a GTA V which cost a similar amount to release with it, this is really a cheek.For 60€ I recommend everyone to buy 5-10 old Lego games and play them. Wait until the price is 15€. Because it’s worth it.Too bad TT Games, I expected more from you.And Lego, you’re on your way to becoming a meme. . .

author: DeadlyFISHYS
review: This is good game which fits in with other lego games but i cant give it a recommendation due to its design. Certain parts are quite PG but its a lego game.- The controls were quite clearly designed for controllers, this is fine if this game was released on only consoles but it wasnt. The controls are awkward. It can be seen very clearly that this was designed on controllers when you use the menus, there is no cursor ever so you have to use A and D or CTRL and ALT to navigate menus. When you press the shoot button in front of an enemy you get aim assist onto that target which is fine if it wasnt on a keyboard and mouse. - Boss fights force you to always look at the boss which makes exploring the area of getting collectables harder.- The DLC characters are just reskined characters. They dont have any new abilities, missions, voice lines, or anything really to convince someone to buy them other than the look.- Force using characters are just better than most others due to their range of abilities. A force user can throw their saber, push with the force, use the lightsaber on enemies, and influence characters whilst blaster heros can shoot, may be able to throw a thermal detonator, and hit enemies which is mediocre in my opinion. Astromechs are even worse as they can just hit targets. They cant fly, use ranged attacks.- Certain parts of the films are condensed into less than a minute of video, this is fine for some parts but others, like operation nightfall, it feels like they just didnt want to develop the levels further. - Boss fights feels very easy and there is a lack of control overall. Most of the time the boss fights devolves into just standing, shooting and dodging every so often. There are a lot of moments where its just hitting E or left click which isnt fun.- Most of the 300 characters they promote are actually just different variations of the same character. Most of the variations are the same except some like Farmer luke who doesnt have a lightsaber compared to the other lukes.- The time to exit the game is too long. If you want to exit the game then;   You have to get to a location or period in the story where you can save  You have to select the exit to menu option  You have to watch the whole assembling cinematic for the main menu  You have to press a button like you just entered the game and press space to acknowledge the saving icon  You can then go across the menu to select the exit game optionThis could be fixed by just adding an exit to desktop option ingame.This is unrelated to the review but most of the reviews on this page are worthless in that they are just saying minor things which they love and arent actually reviewing the game which i find sad but kids do that a lot.

author: [Food] Hungry Bandit
review: While the game is fun playing solo, it's a shame there's no (online) coop play. There's a way to play coop on a console, if you're both playing on the same device. However you can't play coop on PC because there's no online coop. Not even LAN. So I can't invite my brother to play with me on the same WiFi, on seperate PCs. I find this to be annoying, especially since I thought there was coop available. On the previous Lego Star Wars game (Nintendo DS), you could play coop on seperate consoles. Why they removed it, I have no idea. It was available on Nintendo DS in 2008, it's not available on PC in 2022.Edit: Yes, I'm aware Remote Play exists, but it doesn't really work for us. We can launch it, invite the other player, but he has no way to control one of the two characters. That's what prevents the coop.

author: Darth Plaegus
review: Levels are reduced to the absolute minimum, main focus is on the open world, not replaying fun levels based on the movies or the animated series.While other lego games (e.g. the later marvel and dc games) expanded on more unique character abilities, this game strips characters of all their uniqueness in favour of classes with gimmicky upgrades. R2 can't hover/fly, Palpatine and Dooku can't use force lightning outside of pathetic looking combo attacks (for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-apologists, yes, a soft class system has always been present in lego games, but it was merely limited to "use of rapid fire to destroy golden objects, explosives to destroy silver objects, astromech to open astromech console, etc.", it did not limit characters to only one kind of ability).Besides, while this is the first lego game that is playble with a mouse (how revolutionary!) and not just a keyboard, the control system is not designed for k&m and cannot be remapped in a way that would fix it (melee attack is on q, ranged attack on m1, you cannot set both to m1), and thanks to the new, freely moveable camera perspective and aiming being a "feature" now, playing with a controller also feels clunky and less than ideal, so pick your poison, input customisation has always been a lowpoint for TT games.In summary, Lego SW The Reywalker Saga is a cookie cutter open world, streamlined to the maximum degree, and a step down from lego's other more recent releases that leaned into fleshing out the abilities of the characters they were recreating brick by brick, rather than simplifying them even further. The combo system is lack luster and certainly not worth giving up core character abilities for (look up force lightning in Lego TCW and compare it to the combo attacks here). Oh, and mumble mode is a joke, and they know it, given their behind the scenes video. The original characters grunted and used visual humour, these characters either talk, with poor choices for a lot of the voice actors, or babble, like 2-year-olds.

author: BubbleBlep (Violet)
review: This game gets a thumbs down until they fix some of the ridiculous bugs. Not gonna lie, I am almost at the point of being disappointed with this game overall.First of all, the fact that this game was delayed for OVER 2 YEARS and there are still simple optimization bugs? How is the droid factory and ewok village both chugging my 2080ti to below 15 FPS?!?! I have to pause my playthrough and wait for an update because its that bad.God forbid the "Endor the Line" mission from Return of the Jedi. The shooting mechanic is terrible and its combined with your lasers literally going through enemies. Best part about it is that it takes SO long to kill those Bike Troopers that sometimes the game stops loading the level and you get stuck in a black void. So you spend 20+ minutes wasted on your first try, or are forced to restart if you are farming it for studs.Overall, the game is pretty awesome but the levels are quite short. The open world makes up for it a ton, but I do think we should have gotten many more story missions. I expected more than Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga, and although the quality is 1000% up from that game, the length isn't. Again, open world makes up for it, but this is a Star Wars game showcasing the story of the entire Skywalker Saga... It deserved more IMO.Its hard to say, but this game is both awesome and disappointing at the same time. For now, it gets a thumbs down purely on game breaking bugs at launch after 2 years of delays.Small Star Wars nerd rant... I LOVE Mandalorian, but why give it a DLC pack for each season? How does absolutely nothing get added for the Clone Wars or Rebels show...? Remember that Mandalorian wouldn't even exist without the Clone Wars TV show, so its quite insulting to ignore it for a game called "The Skywalker Saga". hopefully it means it comes in the future as a character DLC.

review: its just another lego game still fun but to me its lacking a lot from the original SWL's  the open world makes it so u have literally nothing to do but collect stuff between mission wich is a shame. i remember spending HOURS upon HOURS in the mos eisley cantina just creating  faction chaos and fighting with all of my unlocked character that were roaming around freely. same for lego star wars the clone wars. exploring the huge ships, freeing prisoners from jail, space fighting, changing systems.all of these interactions were what made those games fun for me i never cared about minikits and yet theres was still plenty there for those who didbut this one was downgraded into a collactathon ONLY game and once ur done with that well theres nothing left to do so to me this game misses the mark. tho it is still enjoyable im putting a no simply for the absolute GARBAGE way they treated DLC's. i had bought the most expensive version wich was supposed to include them all only for them to release an even more expensive one and basically tell you to go ♥♥♥♥ yourself and give em your money. its a real shame how lego games had to come to these anti consumer practices when they could make us earn those characters trough gameplay you knowlike the originals did :\

review: This is a perfectly servicable game, although I doubt that it will keep any adult's attention for long. author: JohnGhost
review: Very dissapointing. Rushed stories, comedy is boring, it's not that creative and they try to do comedy at the cost of characters which makes them annoying and obnoxious. Removed several fun mechanics like in the old star wars lego games where you could do massive battles like in geonosis where you built factories and barracks to fight against the pushing enemy lines. SO. MUCH. WALKING. BACK AND FORTH. So many annoying repetetive quests. And I was excited to use capital ships... But all they do is unlock the potential to get more collectibles and you can't even use them to move around and shoot...It would've been amazing... They are expensive and boring. Don't expect anything special about this game. All I can finish off is: If you want to grind and spend time moving around and ocasionally play on a full moon then buy it. Because trust me. You'll get more bored by the minute every time you play.The pros that i can say however: They made combos pretty fun and made grievous have the most fun melee fighting style.

author: Spicytuna
review: This game is not intended to be played on PC. To the point where I wonder why they even put it on steam other than as a cash grab. The menu controls are a weird combination of escape, tab, wasd, arrow keys, and Lctrl/Lalt. 39 hours in and I still resort to randomly pressing buttons until I'm where I need to be. The biggest problem however is the random bugs and softlocks that exist in the game. Droid Factory Frenzy is capped at 30 fps. The absolute worst level is Endor The Line, which is virtually impossible to beat without aim assist and it glitches out 80% of the time and will constantly say you need to kill more and more stormtroopers without actually spawning them in so you're stuck just flying on the speeder until you reach the end of the map and constantly falling into the void losing all your studs without any fix other than restarting the level. The game is fun albeit frustrating to play on PC. There are several other areas of maps that will softlock you preventing you from escaping an endless cycle of death losing all your studs. These glitches have existed for months and they're everywhere on Reddit and Youtube it boggles my mind how a game this expensive hasn't fixed these level breaking bugs. Pretty disappointed.

author: XDRosenheim
review: I would recommend you go try the older LEGO Star Wars games instead.Previous games had (almost) the entire world made out of LEGO bricks. This game is more a world with LEGO bricks in it. Some of the bricks do not even look like actual LEGO bricks, but some model that had to be created with a few LEGO-points on it.This game tries to the same thing that all the other LEGO Star Wars games tried to do. Visual comedy. Except the other games did so succesfully, and in this game it feels a bit too forced. Any cut-scene with Jar Jar in it, has him flying around getting hurt.A thing this game does do different, is having full spoken dialog, but a lot of the characters sound like someone just speaking into a microphone and not actual voice-acting.The menu-intro came to my mind while writing this... You have to wait for a bunch of characters to line up and display themselfs, before you are allowed to "press any button to continue". And it can not be because of loading as it takes the same amount of time each time. When you then start the game, you have to sit through the ENTIRE chapter-introduction (That classic Star Wars scrolling text one), no matter how many times you have seen it. The game does not even load during this time, but will instead start loading AFTER the intro...The combat is, fine. I don't really get the combo system, but I guess some people will ike that.

author: Dacamster
review: Wow that was incredibly bad. Got the game solely to play coop with a mate and the only way to play is with remote play? So many games have done it better with 2 people that get their own screen and just cant go more than a certain distance from eachother. This game when we shared screen and character ran ok but wasnt the coop experience we wanted, then we go splitscreen and wow the input lag is incredibly noticable. We checked our pc's, our net, it's all running smooth. The game just seems to struggle running splitscreen, then you go into a cutscene and it runs normal. Honestly we just couldnt go more than 10 minutes before we felt nautious. So disappointing.

author: FaTSaLtYnUt
review: Step 1: Prepare Baking PansNobody wants their cake to stick to the pan, so it's important to prep your pans before pouring in the batter. With the exception of angel food and chiffon cakes, most recipes call for greasing and flouring the pan or lining the pan with waxed or parchment paper.As for knowing what type of baking pan to use, our Test Kitchen prefers shiny pans for achieving a golden appearance. If you use a dark or dull-finish pan, reduce the oven temperature by 25°F and check doneness 3 to 5 minutes early to prevent overbrowning.Step 2: Allow Ingredients to Reach Room TemperatureMany recipes require cake ingredients such as eggs and butter to stand at room temperature. This allows the butter to blend easily with other ingredients and the eggs will yield a higher cake volume. (For food safety reasons, don't leave the eggs at room temperature for more time than specified in the recipe.)Test Kitchen Tip: Never use melted butter when softened butter is called for. It will ruin the cake texture.Step 3: Preheat the OvenWhen a cake bakes too quickly it can develop tunnels and cracks, too slowly and it can be coarse. Let your oven preheat for at least 10 minutes, and use an oven thermometer ($7, Target) to make sure it reaches the proper temperature. If you're using dark cake pans, you'll want to reduce the oven temperature called for in your recipe by 25°F.Step 4: Stir Together Dry IngredientsDry ingredients usually include flour, baking powder and/or baking soda, and salt. Rather than adding each dry ingredient individually to the batter, whisk ($6, Walmart) them together in a bowl beforehand. That way you know the ingredients are equally distributed throughout the batter.person beating butter for cakeCREDIT: KRITSADA PANICHGULStep 5: Combine the Butter and SugarWondering how to make a cake with a light, airy crumb? Creaming butter and sugar is the most important step. Here's how:Using an electric mixer ($23, Target) on medium to high speed, beat the butter for 30 seconds. Generally, a stand mixer requires a medium speed for this step and a hand mixer requires a higher speed.Add the sugar (and vanilla if the recipe calls for it) and beat the mixture on medium speed until it is combined and has a light, fluffy texture. This will take 3 to 5 minutes. (DON'T cut this short). Scrape the bowl occasionally while beating. Tiny bubbles will be created as the butter and sugar are combined, which will give your cake that dreamy, light, fluffy texture.Step 6: Add Eggs One at a TimeAdd eggs (or egg whites) one at a time, beating well after each. Their protein creates structure around air bubbles to maintain texture.Test Kitchen Tip: Break eggs individually into a custard cup or small bowl first. This way if you get shell fragments, you can easily fish them out of the cup rather than try to get them out of the batter.Step 7: Alternate Adding Dry and Wet IngredientsAlternate between adding some of the flour mixture and some of the milk (or other liquid specified in the recipe) to the butter-egg-sugar mixture, beating on low speed after each addition until combined. Begin and end with the flour mixture. This is because when liquid is mixed into flour, gluten begins to form. Too much gluten makes for a tough cake, so be sure to start and finish with flour, and not overmix once you add liquid.Test Kitchen Tip: Be careful not to overmix at this stage or you might get elongated, irregular holes in the finished cake.person spreading cake batterCREDIT: KRITSADA PANICHGULStep 8: Pour Batter into Pans and BakeDivide the batter evenly between the baking pans. Use an offset spatula ($9, Bed Bath & Beyond) to spread the batter in an even layer. Be sure to spread it to the pan edge. Bake your cake according to your recipe's directions.Related: 21 Essential Baking Tools Every Home Cook NeedsStep 9: Check Cake for DonenessOverbaked cake equals dry cake and no one wants that. Start checking the cake for doneness after the recipe's stated minimum baking time, avoiding opening the oven door until it's time to prevent letting the heat escape. For creamed cakes, insert a wooden toothpick near the center of the cake. If the pick comes out clean (with only a crumb or two on it), the cake is done. If there is any wet batter on it, bake the cake for a few minutes more and test in a new spot with a new toothpick.baker placing cake from cake pan on wire rackCREDIT: KRITSADA PANICHGULStep 10: Cool the CakeLet the cakes cool in the pans on a wire rack ($15, Walmart) for 10 minutes maximum. To remove from the pans, run a knife around the edges of the cake to loosen it from the sides. Place a wire rack over the top of the cake and flip the pan. Lift the pan off the cake, being careful not to tear the edges of the cake. If you used waxed or parchment paper, gently peel the paper off the cake.Allow the cake to cool completely (about 1 hour). This is a key step to letting the cake firm up, making it less likely to break apart as you frost it. (And it keeps the frosting from melting as soon as you spread it!)

author: ThunderNyan
review: Some elements of the game are incredibly grindy, with enemies being borderline bullet sponges and boss fights sometimes devolving into just lightsaber spam. This game would've done a lot better with more enemies with less health. The quality of the level design is not as good as in TCS, but the game makes it for in quality cinematics, humor, and incredible voice acting. The quality of gameplay is not consistent throughout, with the original trilogy feeling kinda skimped out upon in terms of level content, quality, and content. The prequels however, especially episodes II and III, feel incredibly in depth and even better voice acted.While it is psychotic to even suggest, the prequels really take the cake in this game if you can get past The Phantom Menace.

author: | - VOID - |
review: This game literally blew me away of how an amazing game this is! It's truly astonishing of how the amount of detail and heart that they have put out for this game! I have played every installment of LEGO Star Wars starting off with LEGO Star Wars The Video Game waay back in 2005 and I played a heck ton of it! 17 years later, this game made me experience a vietnam flashback. Anyways on to the review:---{Graphics}---☑ Beautiful☐ Good☐ Decent☐ Bad---{Gameplay}---☑ Excellent☐ Good☐ Average☐ Just don‘t---{Story}---☑ Amazing!☐ Average☐ Good☐ Garbage---{Audio}---☑ Very good☐ Good☐ Ok☐ Bad☐ Earrape---{Audience}---☐ Youngling☐ Teens☐ Adults☐ Weebs☑ Not just the men, but the women and the children too---{PC Requirements}---☑ Runs clear as water. It can literally run good if you have an old PC☐ Potato☐ Decent☐ Fast☐ Ask NASA for a spare computer---{Difficulty}---☑ Padawan (Easy)☐  Jedi Knight (Medium)☐ Jedi Master (Hard)☐ Grand Master (Extremely hard)---{Price}---☑ Dew it! It's worth it!☐ Oh not good!☐ Not as cheap☐ Never tell me the odds---{Bugs}---☑ Never encountered one single bug☐ Minor bugs☐ Can get annoying☐ The game itself is one massive bug--- CONCLUSION ---LEGO Star Wars The Skywalker Sagas delivers the WHOLE galaxy for you to explore, and experience all 3 trilogies in one game! There are awesome and hilarious moments that you won't forget!The gameplay is smooth as butter and I'm loving the combat as they have been revamped from previous titles in which they added combo attacks and with that you earn stud bonuses. Cover system is now a thing in this game in which you take cover from blaster shots and start firing your way while taking cover!There are only 5 story levels for each episode. For instance, Episode 1 has 5 main story levels and that's it. The same goes to the rest of the episodes making a total of 45 levels.Free roam is fantastic! Unlike past LEGO Star Wars games where the missions are linear and Mos Eisley Cantina being the only single hub in the past games, you now have the freedom to explore planets now. Coruscant, Tatooine, Hoth, Naboo, Geonosis, Kamino, you name it! Hell even ships too like the Trade Federation!This game runs fine even if you have an old PC so there shouldn't be any problem running it!I give this game a solid 9/10 and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone! Thus I'm just happy they included Mando S1 and S2 as DLC :'>May the force be with you!

author: GenjakPiff
review: Part of the reason the old Lego Star Wars games were so good was their simplicity. As a kid I had a couple actions to choose from; jump, attack, and interact. The timing of those buttons mattered, and the game took care of the camera, the method of interaction, the reaction, etc. It also was easy for a friend to join in without limiting screen size and visibility at all. All of the new "features" add too much control complexity to the game for my taste. Sure I enjoy being able to throw a lightsaber, but I don't want to control the camera, aim force movements and all that. I miss just highlighting an object and interacting with it. I'll definitely just play the old games unless they fix the 2player in this game, and hopefully they add a mode that let's me use the simplified mechanics of the old game.

author: Swaid
review: I was inspired to write this review earlier then I would have liked due to a bug that has softlocked me out of the last mission of Episode 3, Revenge of the Sith.Having entered the mission, it immediately became apparent there was something wrong. The B button prompt was up -I play most actions games with a controller- even though I wasn't being locked into a LEGO® Lightsaber™ clash. I could press B and the button would fill up like if I was in a clash, but also LEGO® Obi-wan™ would keep using force push while I was pressing it. Determined to win against whatever evil foe the LEGO® Sith™ had sent to assist the now evil LEGO® Anakin Skywalker™, I kept pressing B rapidly for perhaps a little too long, which didn't yield much but my thumb being a bit sore. I swapped to LEGO® C3-P0™ and the prompt was gone, likely having seen LEGO® Obi-wan™ was trying to Force Push™ an enemy that wasn't there the entire time confused beyond all belief. Since the B button prompt issue was LEGO® Obi-wan™ exclusive, I decided the best course of action was to press forward with LEGO® Obi-wan™ and hope the issue resolved itself.Going forward saw LEGO® Obi-wan™ LEGO® Lightsaber™ clashing with LEGO® Anakin Skywalker,™ bringing up the B button prompt, however, something was amiss. It was one B button prompt layered over the prior one, so I was filling up to B button prompt bars, clashing with both the real LEGO® Anakin Skywalker™ and the invisible LEGO® Anakin Skywalker™; clearly, the LEGO® Gods™ were testing my LEGO® resolve, so I pressed forward.Everything seemed to be going according to the level, until we reached an obstacle that I'm not sure was a result of the mischievous tomfoolery that is invisible LEGO® Anakin Skywalker™ forcing me to constantly press B to fight him off or a completely separate LEGO® issue altogether. LEGO® Anaking Skywalker refused to continue the sequence and just stood atop one of the LEGO® Mustafar Droid Mining Factory Arch Arm™ twirling his LEGO® Lightsaber™ and taunting me with a little LEGO® dance. Switching to LEGO® C3-P0™ or LEGO® R2-D2™ to try and continue the sequence did not work, so I had to quit the level.When I returned to the LEGO® space above LEGO® Mustafar™, there was no primary mission prompt in sight and I could not continue to the final level of Revenge of the Sith™ and now I just don't feel like playing anymore. How can I start Episode 4 if I haven't beat Episode 3? It's unnatural.Also side peeve, stop with Reye always saying she's looking for someone to 'show me my place in all of this' EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. WE. BOOT. UP. THE. GAAAAAAAAAME!!! If you want to make people hate the sequel trilogy even more, that's how you do it. Are you purposely trying to shove this stuff down our throats? Because its just going to get people to dislike the trilogy moreso then they already do. Instead of trying to Force Feed™ everyone the sequel stuff, do your best to prop it up with that signature LEGO® polish and let it stand on its own. When I do continue this game, this game's version of Episode 9: The Rise of Skywalker will be my first time viewing it in any form because I figured the LEGO® version would be far superior to whatever crap Disney churned out in theaters that I didn't bother to go see in any capacity.EDIT: I was going to come back to change the review to a positive, but this LEGO® Endor™ Swoop Bike™ level is a crime against humanity. Who thought going through the same bumpy terrain with a vehicle that has a static laser over and over again while trying to shoot other vehicles was a good idea? On top of that, the level bugs out and I've had to restart it three times and the LEGO® Scout Troopers™ just keep coming long after the level has worn out its welcome. The LEGO® Zam Wesell™ LEGO® Coruscant™ chase was perhaps even more grueling and a slog to get through. You do so little damage, you can't hit civilians, your laser frequent gets disabled, LEGO® Zam Wesell™ phases through buildings, and its so hard to hit the other vehicle it felt like I wanted to set myself on fire just to feel some sort of sensation again. You guys at LEGO® suck at doing chase levels, they feel like a chore to play through.EDIT 2: This will likely be my final entry for this review and I've decided to leave it at negative. The game has had tons of issues since I've got it like frame-rate drops that go as low as 10 and stay there, consistently after it builds up over time, getting lower and lower until its unplayable. Quests not completing properly. Space battles glitching out loading unrendered ships into space battles. Chase levels constantly crashing and being a pain in the ass without auto-targeting, getting soft-locked and having to restart my save file.There's also what I believe is fundamentally wrong with the game, its the same trap Bethesda falls into with a lot of their RPGs where they just increase raw numbers without providing anything of substance. While I adore the level-up system that makes it so you want to go out and get Kyber Bricks, the rewards for doing so are minor increases to damage, health regeneration, and other trivial things that due to how simple the game is, feel like they don't really add anything. Sure, I could do more damage with ranged attacks, but how does that really change how the game is played? I just have to shoot less, which means I just end up playing less overall. A lot of the options are like this and don't do anything fantastic with what they have so the level-up system feels flat and it makes it so I don't really feel the need to level-up, which means I don't feel compelled to play the game because as far as I know, the only reward for collecting all the Kyber Bricks is being 100% leveled. That would be interesting, if that meant something unique other then just hitting harder and taking less damage. The class upgrades that do provide unique functions, like giving Bounty Hunters stun grenades, were a step in the right direction, but the problem is, EVERY Bounty Hunter then gets stun grenades. Very few of the characters really feel that unique, especially when they all benefit from the same class system. While I understand the simple nature of the class system, there needs to be more done to make the characters feel individually unique not just aesthetically, but game-play wise in what they can do. Like, sure I could get Jabba the Hutt as playable, but what does he do? He's just a fun side character you'll forget about after the novelty wore off. But if you could level him up specifically, like making him be able to bribe minions to do his bidding like a Jedi Mind Trick or calling 1 to 3 Gamorean Guards to fight for him and follow him around? There could be more done here, the pieces are there, you just need to build it.

And the game itself... it's a Lego game.

author: bog beth
review: its clear they cared a lot about the movies making this game, but i don't really get the impression that a game was what they wanted to make, more that they intended to make a movie but were forced to settle for a game instead. anytime there is an instance where the player could be challenged, youre handheld so hard with no option to make it harder. a good example of this is the tightrope segments, in which they lock your camera directly forward, effectively removing any risk and making what couldve been a small challenge into a segment where you walk slowly for a few seconds with no danger. another example of this obsessive handholding is doorlocks; they include doors youre expected to shoot with a blaster, yet TAKE OVER THE CAMERA, AND COMPLETE THE PUZZLE FOR YOU; I CANNOT STRESS THIS ENOUGH, IT DOES THE PUZZLE ITSELF. ultimately i understand these games are meant to be accessible for all ages, which is great, but i dont see why they give you zero option to make the game more difficult for an older audience. another issue i take with this game is the side quests and side puzzles, as in probably 90% of them, the reward is a khyber brick, which is a currency. don't get me wrong, giving currency for side content is fine, but when nearly every quest gives the same reward, it gets stale remarkably fast. its not helped by the fact that the quests themselves often feel half finished or just poorly thought out. take for example this quest in mos espa (mild side quest spoilers ahead): you enter an abandoned hut, youre met with creepy unnerving music, and a cutscene of a creepy protocol droid starting at you. when spotted, the droid runs into another room, out of sight. you give chase, discovering that the room is a dead end, but empty except for a single key on the ground. you find a locked door in the other side of the hut, open it, and youre met with a khyber brick. this quest starts great, full of atmosphere, and when i first encountered it, i was really excited as to where this would take me. it was a huge let down for it to just kinda end, with no unique reward, no further information, no voice acting, just the same old reward youd get for anything else. i feel like at the very least, i was anticipating unlocking this droid as a playable character, realistically speaking it wouldnt have required much effort -- its really just spoopy silver c3-po, or at the very least maybe some cute, sanitized lore about the character which this quest is based, but nope! honestly, im just disappointed. like, im still enjoying my time but the world feels kinda dead, and going back to the old games it just makes me wish this had more time in the oven.

author: one_krazyMOFO
review: This game was a massive disappointment for me. There's definitely fun to be had for sure but I just can't bring myself to finish the game due to all of its problems let alone finish a single chapter. The game just didn't meet my expectations considering how long the game look to get released. The game just has way too much downtime between getting to a level and actually playing it. The game blatantly wastes your time as your forced to travel from hub world to hub world just for you to get to a mission that'll take you less than 5 minutes to complete or just to talk to an NPC that'll send you right out the door. The actual missions don't make up for the amount of time spent getting there in my opinion. The gameplay is pretty decent for a lego game and the graphics are surprisingly impressive but the frame rate issues and glitches definitely brought down the experience for me. I set the game to 1080 and while it looked nice and felt good to play the frame rate would tank tremendously when playing with a friend and the game tends to freeze up and slow down when one player triggers explosions. The game as a whole feels half-ass and tries too hard to reinvent the wheel. I'm personally more found of the much older lego games and their simplicity and while this game isn't challenging or even ask that much of you when it comes to it's combat, it feels like the devs just kept throwing different ideas at the wall to see what would sick and unfortunately none of it really does for me. I get that this is a kids game at the end of the day and while I wasn't expecting the game to exactly be a genre defining experience I at the very least wanted this game to be way more engaging and worth my time than what I was given.  5/10

review: I don't know how to write a proper review for this game, but I do know a good recipe for pasta sauce: Ingredients:1 pound sweet Italian sausage, sliced (any sausage will do)3/4 pound lean ground beef1/2 cup minced onion2 cloves garlic, crushed1 (28 ounce) can crushed tomatoes2 (6 ounce) cans tomato paste2 (6.5 ounce) cans tomato sauce1/2 cup water2 tablespoons white sugar1 1/2 teaspoons dried basil1/2 teaspoon fennel seed1 teaspoon Italian seasoning1/2 teaspoon salt1/4 teaspoon ground black pepperDirections: In a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat, cook the sausage, beef, onion, and garlic until well browned; drain fat. Stir in crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, tomato sauce, and water. Mix in sugar and season with basil, fennel seed, Italian seasoning, salt, and pepper. Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer 1 1/2 hours, stirring occasionally.

author: PatiKa02
review: I'm gonna say in advance that I only played through the 1st and 2nd film.Things I liked:- It looks really good- There's a lot of accessibility settings (although some are still missing)- They got the typical Lego Game humor right (which they could've put more of into the game)Things I didn't like:- The game often locks into a blackscreen before or after a cutscene, which can only be fixed by restarting the game- The default keybinds are bad- Characters are missing characteristic abilities (for example, R2D2 can't use his boosters to glide)- The free camera is really bad:	1. When a Jedi has to force lift something to move it somewhere, the camre ends up flipping	2. In the fight with Darth Maul, you have to change characters (when playing alone) to be able to attack Darth Maul             from behind. The free camera will look into the wrong direction (in the direction of the first character).	3. When fighting a boss, the free camera is always aimed at the boss, which can make things a bit awkard	4. If you stand too close to something, the camera doesn't know where to look (although this happens rarely)- The AI in the game has some problems (e.g. Characters regularly bumping into walls while trying to move somewhere)- Flying in general is a disaster:	1. If you steer too hard in one direction, the game will not register your input once you steer in the other direction	2. The enemy AI likes to fly through houses and asteroids- Fighting bosses as a Jedi is just simple lightsaber throwing- Guns are stronger than lightsabers- In the first mission of the first film, I got the impression that almost the entire world was gonna be made of Lego like in    this mission, but unfortunately it isn't (a matter of taste)- In the german version, which I played, they didn't use the original voice actors

review: I love the previous ones and had really been looking forward to this one. Finally grabbed it on sale. Unfortunately only lasted about 30 minutes, in 15 minute pieces. Got horribly nauseated (motion sickness) from the way the camera moves/FOV changes. Tried a program for force-lock the FOV, which sadly didn't help. Found quite a few comments from people having the same issue. No solutions to be found and nothing said by the maker. Finally gave up and got a refund. Might try again someday if I see changes the look like it's been convincingly addressed. Note this is the only non-VR game that's ever caused me this issue.Otherwise the game itself looks fun, I just can't play it.

author: Jake Mook
review: Let me preface this with I never thought I'd enjoy a LEGO game. I bought this as I love Star Wars and remember playing small amounts of the original LEGO Star Wars games as a kid.  I didnt realise the depth of this game, it re-tells the movies in a fun way, that never ever feels dull. The level design is literally flawless, every single planet and stage is designed in a way that is easy to get around, but at the same time large enough to get lost in all the details of the Star Wars world. The game's attention to detail is so surprising I'm genuinely confused why not of my friends have given it a shot. From the LARGE planets you can free roam around on and just explore. Literally no Star Wars game has has had such immersive free-roam. I would of never expected it from a LEGO game. Additionally the fun little detail of your character model getting effected by the environment (for example Luke getting dusty on Tatooine) is fun and you can tell the developers really put a lot of love into this game and it really shows.The very large amount of characters and ships that are playable is a great feature as well. I wasnt expecting almost 380 playable characters just in the base game, and I definitely wasnt expecting near 100 flyable ships. The sheer amount of content in the game is just crazy to me. The prime example being that I'm 8.7 hours in, but have only played through Episode 1 & 2. There are so many collectables, and I often find myself doing a mission then proceeding to run around whatever planet I'm on collecting side quests.This game just feels like perfect Star Wars, and although I never thought a LEGO game could do the Star Wars franchise proper justice, I was wrong. Its the perfect setting for playing through the Star Wars movies.

After showing us it is possible they still limit us to 2 characters(smh). All around I am fond of the game but by taking away the character duplication glitch and not adding a character customizer I am very dissapointed. I'd say If they added the 2 back to the game a whole lot of people would be playing more and not get bored as easily me when playing coop.

author: Ninjyte
review: I'm shocked this game isn't getting more negative reviews for the poor optimization, even worse than Cyberpunk 2077 for me.I've played through episodes 1-5 and am in the middle of 6, and so far there have been two story levels and now one free-roam level where framerate drops from 144+ fps down to 15-30 fps. The two story levels thus far are the Episode 2 droid factory mission and Episode 3 Mustafar duel, and now I've hit the Ewok village on the Forest Moon of Endor in Episode 6, which is free roam, that drops to as low as 15 fps. And while I have 64 hours in at the time of reviewing, as I've been doing a semi-completionist run collecting all the kyber bricks and characters, this 1% of of game content that has these dramatic frame drops are enough to be nearly unplayable.For clarity, I have a Ryzen 5 5600x, RTX 2070 Super, and 16 GB 3600 MHz RAM. I have been running 99% of the game at 1080p 144+ fps (144Hz monitor with RivaTuner Statistics Server 143 fps cap).And it is not just the framerate, the video display and graphics settings are severely lacking, as well as some notable bugs. There are only 5 graphics settings, and changing them all down to low does not affect framerate in the low fps segments. When launching the game the fullscreen display option automatically switches from 1080p144hz option to 1080p50hz option, and the borderless fullscreen when starting the game does not fit to the screen properly so I have to switch off and on the borderless option every time after launching. There is a V-sync option but no framerate cap for borderless window, so I have been using RivaTuner Statistics Server to cap the fps at 143. Some notable bugs are dialogue lines playing twice, some collectables on the map (when using the collectable locator unlock) not appearing, and a rare issue where I could not change characters on Tatooine and couldn't even open the Esc/Start menu to exit the game.What is especially concerning is that TT Games have only released one performance patch in the two months since launch, and it was before I started playing Lego Star Wars.The game itself is pretty fun and satisfying as a Star Wars fan, though the puzzles and level design of the prequel episodes strangely aren't as good as levels and planets in the original trilogy episodes. I have not finished episode 6 or played any of the sequel episodes yet, so I don't know if there are any more performance issues in the rest of the game. I would be more than likely to recommend Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga if these optimization issues were addressed but the developers seem to be very quiet on post-launch support.

author: Atmintis
review: BEFORE I BEGIN PLEASE AT LEAST READ THE DISLIKE SECTION OF THE REVIEW AS I FEEL IT IS THE MOST IMPORTANT PART.  IT IS THE 4TH PART OF THE REVIEW AND PLEASE SHARE THE REVIEW IF YOU CAN AS TO TRY AND HELP SOME OF THE CHANGES AND SUGGESTIONS TALKED ABOUT IN THE REVIEW HOPEFULLY REACH THE DEVELOPERS AND COME IN A FUTURE UPDATEPART 1: INTRODUCTION -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------While I have only finished the Phantom Menace through A New Hope on story mode, I can tell the amount of work that was put into the game and how great the game is already. Also within the short time I played I found several things I did not like about the game. Also please note that I will be editing and adding to the review as time goes on and may even start a Twitter thread with edits of the review and thoughts on the game. Now before I go into what I think, just to establish my credibility and knowledge of the LEGO Games, here is the list of all of the LEGO Games I have played (Minus the mobile games):> Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga*> Lego Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures> Lego Batman: The Videogame*> Lego Indiana Jones 2: The Adventure Continues>Lego Harry Potter: Years 1-4> Lego Star Wars III: The Clone Wars> Lego Pirates of the Caribbean: The Video Game> Lego Harry Potter: Years 5–7> Lego Batman 2: DC Super Heroes> Lego Batman 3: Beyond Gotham> Lego Dimensions> Lego Marvel's Avengers> Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens> Lego Marvel Super Heroes 2> Lego DC Super-Villains> Lego Battles: Ninjago *Both the Wii Game and DS Game which have different content. So I have played my fair share of LEGO games and there is really only one LEGO game that I didn’t like, which was LEGO Dimensions. PART 2: THE POSITIVES -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So let’s start with the things that I think were great in the game. I love the open world aspect and the fact that we can even have space near the planet that we can fly around in and enjoy the Star fighters. I have bought the Trade Federation Command Ship and I have unlocked but not bought the first Death Star, and I have to say, so far I am in love with the Capital Ships.  Only thing I wish is that there was a hangar that stored all of the ships that you own, and maybe like a captain's quarters/bedroom for you to just relax. I adore the change in character selection and like how it is easier to find the character I wanted when I wanted and have what type of character I need when I need it.  I also love the wide selection of star ships that are available and how you can unlock mini ships when collecting all of the Mini-kits in a level.  Next I absolutely adore the skill tree mechanic going on with the Kyberbricks.  I think it is a great addition to the LEGO games and shows much you have progressed based on how powerful your characters are.  Now the graphics.  When I first started playing I was blown away by the sheer amount of detail that has gone into the graphics.  The fact that your character can get all sandy on the sandy planets and covered in snow on the snowy planets is just mind boggling to me in a good way.  I adore the graphics, the sound design, and effects of the game.  The lightsaber fights feel so immersive just on how great these graphics are.  Now the level design is different from it's predecessor LEGO Star Wars games, and all other LEGO games that I have played with the new open world level select that there is.  It takes sort of takes aspects from both versions of the level select system from both types of the LEGO games.  The old level select system was that you had a lobby, like the Mos Eisley Cantina in the Complete Saga or the Batcave in the LEGO Batman game and there were different chapters and 6 doors in each chapter room and each door would take you to that specific level.  Now the new version is more of you go to a specific location on the open world map and that's how you start the level.  This takes both and merges them keeping the Chapter aspect and the open world level select for the individual levels.  It is very complicated to explain, but a lot easier to understand visually.Staying on the topic of levels I also adore the length of each Episode, as it doesn't feel too long but also not too short, keeping that good balance of playtime. Now I have only completed The Phantom Menace through A New Hope, so I can't speak for Empire Strikes Back through Rise of the Skywalker, but so far I enjoy how it is going.PART 3: DISCLAIMER -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I can go on and on about the praise I can give this game, but the things I do not like I feel are more important for the game than the things I love.  Now these will consist of the things I do not like or I think should be done in order to keep people playing this game and continue spending money on it. But before I begin on the negatives, I do need to state that no matter what I do not like, do not completely hold it against the creators of the game as creating a LEGO game has to be incredibly difficult, time consuming, and stressful, as the LEGO games have such a high reputation and standard that it must be very challenging to not only meet the standard, but go above it as so many LEGO games have done in the past.PART 4: THE NEGATIVES-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Now the main thing I most disappointed and worked up about is the removal of the custom character creation.  With one of the last LEGO games being centered around your custom character so much that it was the main character of the game, (LEGO DC Supervillains), the excitement I had coming into this game after all of the innovation and freedom I had from DC Supervillains to make my own custom characters to then be met with not just a downgraded version of the character customization, but to have it be removed completely, seriously took away from the experience and excitement I originally had for the game.  I bought the game super excited and had tons of plans of making a Custom Revan character and kind of roleplaying a bit with it and just embracing my inner child with this game and enjoying myself as I did with LEGO Star Wars the Complete Saga so many years ago, to have those hopes crushed by the removal of the mechanic. To be completely honest I could do without all of the other suggestions/missing mechanics that I hoped for but the fact that the custom character creation is missing just makes it feel less like a LEGO game and more like it's just another RPG.  While not as disappointing as the removal of the custom character creation, still saddening is some of the missing characters from the previous LEGO Star Wars games.  While I do not know how many are missing I can name 4 off the top of my head, with only 1 of them really having a reason of his absence.  These 4 include the 3 Force Ghost characters and the hidden India Jones character.  I understand why Indie is missing from the game as the reason why he was in The Complete Saga was to promote the release of the LEGO India Jones games, I do not see why the Force Ghosts are missing, as I was excited to have all of the Force Ghosts back and I was hoping to get a Force Ghost Qui-Gon and a Force Ghost Luke.  Now if they are hidden Characters, I do not know that they are in the game, but so far, I have no indication that they exist in the game.  CONTINUED IN THE COMMENTS

author: ndee
review: Unfortunately, a month after release, this game is still completely unplayable. Like many PC ports, Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga has been completely neglected. While console versions have received several updates, there has not been one single PC update since release on April 5, 2022, to address the numerous softlocks and glitches that completely break and prevent further progress. This does not count the numerous other bugs and glitches that cause frame drops, CTD, and prevent events/collectables from being able to be 100% completed. Tech support for the game merely suggest restarting your 100 hour savefile if you encounter any game-breaking bugs. It's pathetic that a game can be released in this day in age in such an abysmal state and not one single reviewer (paid off or not) made note of any of these tech issues before launch. At this point, I have no faith that TT has any desire to fix all the issues the game faces (especially the minor ones that are somewhat cosmetic and are annoying, but not gamebreaking, like everything you've discovered in the Databank always being marked "new" when you restart the game). It was wrong to release the game in such a state, as many of these are obvious issues I encountered only during 6 hours. Regardless of whether or when these issues are fixed, due to their lack of care for their own product and their abject failure to communicate with the community over the progression of any bugfixes, TT has lost me as a future customer, and I STRONGLY recommend you stay FAR AWAY from this game.

author: kwhite8105
review: Definitely not worth $60 or even $50. I will say first off that for a Lego game the graphics look very good and there are some things I do like such as better saber throws and combos. But unfortunately the bad outweighs the good. Just as everyone else has stated there are lots of bugs and needs major improvements. For me personally I absolutely love Star Wars and this was a huge let down and disappointment. I got stuck on the last mission of episode 3 where R2 refused to move when I needed him too. When I travel to Naboo my HUD refuses to load and often I'm not able to walk into buildings that normally I would be able to. If I try to leave the planet I get stuck in a loading screen and have to reload the game. The worst bug of all is the awful stuttering in between levels and free play. The stutter on screen is so bad that you can't barely move around or do much of anything. I didn't rule out it could be my computer but even after adjusting the graphics settings down as low as they would go it did not resolve my issue. Mind you all these bugs have happened already and I haven't even made it to movies 4-9. Also the levels are really short; maybe 15 mins tops if you're actually looking around for collectibles. They made 45 missions for 9 movies. On top of all that I have spent maybe 3 quarters of my play time just searching for collectibles in the FREE ROAM OUTSIDE of missions! I haven't even collected anywhere close to half. Not very good balance of story compared to just running around for useless characters that I know I'll never use or serve no purpose. These are just the bugs I've encountered so far so who knows what other bugs could occur later in the game. If this game was, and hopefully will be very soon, fixed AND was maybe $20-25 then yes it would be worth it. I would not personally recommend this game even after the bugs were fixed unless it was cheaper. The gameplay just isn't worth the asking price overall. Honestly for how long this game was delayed there is no excuse why this game has so many bugs. I don't expect it to be perfect but what can I say when bugs make the game unplayable.

author: gg.nadrewod
review: This game is a buggy mess, and with no PC patch in sight, it's best to avoid this microtransaction-filled cringefest.  You're better off buying the old "Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga", since that at least works without any major bugs/crashes (and as a bonus, you aren't paying for any of the Disney """sequel""" trilogy garbage).Bugs I have encountered so far:Another thing of note: despite giving players the option to complete the Episodes in any order they see fit (with first movies from the Prequel Trilogy, Original Trilogy, and """Sequel""" Trilogy all unlocked at the start, and the 2nd/3rd movies of each trilogy unlocking after you completed the movies before them in the trilogy) and being able to get an entire roster of characters with the various factions (Scoundrel, Scavenger, Bounty Hunter, Villain, etc.) with just the hub worlds unlocked from Episodes 1, 2, and 4, some of the unique abilities are locked behind the first use of those abilities in a Story episode (such as the Scavenger, which I assume is basically useless until either Episode 6 [the Jabba's Palace and/or Sand Barge scenes] or Episode 7 [Rey's entire 1-page backstory]). This wouldn't be so annoying if, when exploring the hub worlds in Freeplay, the game constantly tells you to switch to the useless Scavenger to solve a puzzle that you literally can't complete yet. There are a few Kiber crystals I've come across that are supposed to be Scavenger-exclusive which can be collected by other characters with good platforming, but for the most part, you're simply unable to complete several hub worlds until you find the right story trigger to unlock more class abilities.

author: max
review: A great game but doesn't have enough to offer for experienced players who are used to playing triple A third person or first person shooters (including myself). I know that the game doesn't cater towards that audience but i shouldn't've gotten my hopes up. For me the problems start with the aiming mechanics for blaster characters. Your field of view is extremely low by default (if your standing still). I'd say maybe 65 degrees. When you start shooting this decreases even more. To make matters worse you have quite a hilariously large crosshair (I know this game is meant to be played on consoles). Then the shooting mechanics are very simple, just like boss battles but more on that in a minute. Your recoil is low but the the hitbox of the people you're shooting at is very unpredictable. There is more luck involved in hitting a headshot than skill. After firing your first shot - and thus zooming in even further - it always (ALWAYS) takes 3/4ths of a second to zoom back out. This doesn't sound like a huge issue but imagine the scenario where you are running through a corridor (on the Death Star for example). You shoot at some crates to your right to get studs and start running again. Your zoomed in on the wall but as you run the camera slowly starts rotating, in combination with motion blur and the delayed zoom out not only does this feel like the nausea effect in minecraft. You also often find yourself disoriented in game. Everything feels very unresponsive and you really have to concentrate on what you are seeing on your screen to stay aware of your surroundings. You have to put in effort to not get lost. Looking around above you and below you requires a lot of movement and looking around. Most of the times you can't see puzzles in their entirety. Melee combat has been expanded by allowing the player to use light attacks (Q), heavy attacks (E) and jump attacks (SPACE) but it still doesn't feel like a very major addition. It still feels like you achieve the highest DPS by just spamming Q but i could be wrong.Fighters/Planes also feel extremely unresponsive, especially with keyboard and mouse. If you are in a plane, it doesn't matter which one, and you drag your mouse from the far left corner of your mousepad to the far right side. The game will register this movement but will not execute it immediately. Instead your plane will just rotate for 4 seconds straight as if it's trying to catch up to my movement. This makes flying fighters extremely annoying and borderline unplayable. Does the game just expect me to move my mouse less during flying? You can counter this by moving in the other direction but it's just stupid. You are constantly correcting correcting your movements like a metaldector stuck on a piece of metal. If you mainly play shooters like CSGO, Valorant, COD or whatever or even third person RPG's. You'll literally have to teach yourself to NOT make rapid movements when you are in planes. The only way to effectively use fighters in this game with a mouse is by roleplaying a CCTV camera.Then, the boss battles are an absolute joke. Considering the target audience for this game it is only to be expected that the game helps you in certain ways during gameplay. If you're in a plane you will bounce of walls, combat is simple and without depth but the boss battles are in a league of their own. Each boss battle shares the same concept, your opponent has one or more lives and you have to kill/remove all of them. 9/10 times you can kill the boss whilst only using one hand. As a Jedi character just repeatedly throw your lightsaber at the enemy until he reaches low health. This will stun him and do quite some damage. Unironically, this may be one of the fastest methods to kill bosses. When the enemy is low he will run towards you and you have to spam either Q or E on your keyboard to counterattack. Doing this wil remove one of his/her lives, rinse and repeat. Pretty much every boss fight follows this same recipe. Besides, once an enemy is low you can't deal any more damage with standard attacks. You have to wait for them to come close and encounter you. Once i kept running away from a boss for 2 minutes because i didn't know that was the only way to progress in the boss battle.It certainly is a fun game but if you're purely interested due to nostalgia it might not be worth it. Considering you might have grown up since the first LEGO Star Wars games, the core gameplay simply doesn't have enough depth. Exploring the entire galaxy can take countless hours which is great. The graphics are fantastic and overall it's a good game. Take my review with a grain of salt please. I'm not a LEGO Star Wars veteran at all. It's easy to bash on the negative aspects of a game :DSome general annoyances:- I neEd SOmeonE to sHoW mE My PLACe in all this- Optimization is not great (one level in the droid factory i reached an average of 20fps, regardless of video settings. I'm on a RTX2070S and R5 3600)- Fullscreen/Windowed/Borderless functions don't seem to be working properly at all times. Often windows task bar still appears.- Ally AI is absolutely 0 IQ. They will just stand there for the entire duration of a level and do absolutely nothing.- Prequel missions are... questionable. - COOP?7/10

Having my character gain a million velocity because my lightsaber forgot its supposed to be put away, and many various Soft/Hard locks playing through.and to 100% the levels within 20 hours but takes 60 hours to complete the open world that is just a bunch of lazily placed arbitrary collectibles which number over 1100 (~250 form actual levels). At least the battle mode in Clone Wars was fun to play after the game was finished. I couldn't uninstall fast enough.

author: Salty
review: Console port of the gameMoving around while flying is like you are drunk, you stop moving your cursor like a good 1-2 secs after you stop moving your mouse, making aiming while flying a pain in the butt, light saber combat is locked onto the opponent , giving you no freedom to move around as you please, making missions you need to get collectables or mini kits a pain if you have light saber duel segments.  Also if you do choose to use free roam to do collectables and challenges , if you swap out to a certain character to do a specific action that the normal regular characters in the movie cannot do like pull a platform down and there is a cutscene later on , it will swap back to the original characters for you automatically and if you happen to need the character from before, you will have to go into the menu to swap againFrequent crashes with missions and buggy parts where you can not advance.  Both documented on my stream. Stuck on endor bike mission , geonosis space battle with jango crashing and not showing mission to begin with, losing UI as well as the geonosis factory mission giving me 5 fps if not lessPractically no options for customization for game play, very basic controls and sound options as well , really selling my point of it being a console portJust too many small things about this game make me unable to suggest to others.  If you dont like star wars, for sure do not get this game.  If you love star wars like me, you might be able to bring yourself to suffer through this game just because of star wars

review: I LOVE Lego games. I have Lego Star Wars on the Wii and the PC. I have several other Lego games. I'm aware of their control...excentricities. After 4 hours playing this game, I've spent at least 1/3 of that trying to figure out the controls and dealing with crashes. Force throw needs a TON of work before it's workable and the game will randomly crash between scenes or going into/out of the menu. The team is, apparently, working on bug fixes but until some patches come out, I can't recommend this to Star Wars OR Lego fans. If this was my first experience with the Lego games series, I'd probably never pick up another one.

I really like the fact that you can speak to a lot of people, but there seems to be a bug (if it is a bug) that the dialogue icons reset (they reappear) after you restart the game. This burns my eyes; please fix it.2. There is a yellow dot in character menu (for example) and also in the missions menu (as another example) for the missions and characters not seen. author: kptmail
review: I can't recommend it for my age group. This game feels more tailored for the younger crowd as all of the puzzles and game-play are incredibly easy and there is almost zero risk to dying. Which really stinks because there is a lot of charm here in this game. I laughed more than once and you can tell the creators were Star Wars fans. But... its just not fun. Or rather its not fun if you are an adult. There's plenty to do but it is all very easy and going around smashing the upteenth block of legos does not appeal to me. I recommend it for your young children but otherwise I would steer clear. Thankfully I have 3 smaller kids and Steam allows library sharing, otherwise I would have refunded.

author: Avestan
review: (6/10) LegoPros:- Fun New mechanics and Game-play concepts.Cons:- Bugs are horrendous, constant crashes and glitches, feels like trying to run Elden ring on occasions.- The adding of Challenges is super annoying, could be because of the bugs, but had to replay levels multiple times just to complete a single challenge.- Levels are too short, supposedly because of interactive open-ish world, most the time feels chaotic and a lot of backtracking and aimless wandering, not as satisfying as just running through a list of linear levels for completionist lifestyle. Not everyone would agree with this, if your not one of them this game will be more fun for you.So far still enjoying moments in the game as I like Lego Games, but not too big of fan of just summing up movies where it feels like its a giant speed run. But overall there are some good well placed jokes and silliness. Definetly cannot wait to see what else they will do with this from here on out.Still playing the game and will update this review on completion.

While I'm streaming it, there seems to be some sorts of optimization issues.I'm trying to make this game HARDER on myself cause I CAN and you can't stop me!Fix your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

author: InterestingName
review: So, ima be real this is not the greatest game. I regret buying this and it was definitely not worth 60 dollars. It wouldn't even be worth 40.  They took away from the missions so much to develop the open world and the visuals. 5 Missions per episode and those missions are very short, taking 10 average minutes to beat first run. Go buy Lego Star wars Complete Saga and Clone Wars, save yourself money, time and get better gamesOh and I forgot to add this, the 'open world aspect'. Yeah, it took less than 10 seconds to run from Jabba's palace to the sarlacc pit. So yeah... The only place that felt open was Naboo. Which lends me to the thought of they piled all effort and content into the first and second episodes so people reach the third and later episodes and can't refund the game due to being over 2 hours.

author: Eafiee Teafiee
review: This game is simply is not optimised for PC and is unfinished. Running a 2080Ti, i9 9900k, 32gb ram and you cannot maintain a stable 60fps at 3440x1440p. Often levels run at 30-50fps on low settings with the worst being the droid factory at 10-20fps. Levels that run at 30fps would be tolerable - although not acceptable - if you could limit your framerate to 30fps, however you cannot do that with 3440x1440p as your resolution. If you are a Star Wars fan, wait for a sale but do not buy at full-price because if TT Games put this little effort into optimising this game for PC pre-release, they are not going to fix it post-release. Runs worse than Cyberpunk at launch and worse than Halo Infinite, both recent examples of lacklustre PC releases. Unacceptable in 2022.

author: Count
review: If only i could give a neutral review.TLDR: a mile wide, an inch deepon the face of it, this is a good, fun game. however:i bought this game for the story mode, given that this is an epic 9 film saga, one would expect grand scale. this is not the case. individual episodes are horrifically rushed, epic battles that took up 5-10 minutes of movie screen time are now half the size and can be finished in only 1-2 minutes. the phantom menace fight between the gungan and droid armies consists of a whole 2 waves of 10 ish b1 droids, followed by a 30 second scripted catapult shooting gallery, that's it. you're often given hub areas to explore between missions, in which you will be lucky to find even 1 optional activity that can be completed without freeplay. the cutscenes are gold, the addition of VA's works infinitely in it's favour, however due to the game dragging you through at light speed like an excited child in a theme park, these cutscenes very rarely last more than 10 seconds. the scale of scenes seems to be off as well, with certain vehicles like the corellian corvette and lucrehulk control ship being shamelessly filled in by reduced size and complexity easy build models. there is very little spectacle to this game, and what spectacle it does have between mindlessly chasing waypoints 5 seconds down a corridor is simply wasted by showing it to you for 5 seconds then moving you on to more waypoints. One admission i have to make however, is that this game, for some unknown reason, features lightsaber combat better than most other star wars titles on the market, in a lego game! go figure.

review: Massive departure from classic Lego Star Wars games. If you didn't grow up with those games then you'll probably enjoy it. Even if you did grow up with those games you might enjoy it, depends on how open to the changes you are. However, if you're like me and wanted a revamped, but classic feeling Lego game, you will be greatly disappointed. I highly recommend reading the other comments to see how this game is different from past Lego Star Wars games to see if the changes would ruin it for you like they did for me.

author: The_Tempo_Golem
review: Why, this game has made me ask this question so many times in the last 30 minwhy does the game start with a 5 min unskippable cutscene.why can i not skip the text scroll ( even though i could in conpleet saga)why are there so many times when the game takes camera controll away from me for no good reasonwhy can't i use the mouse to navagate menu's and instead have to move a cursor with wasd, like if only i had somthing attacked to my computer specificaly designed to move cursors acuritlywhy when go to exit to the main menu to close the game do i get a loading screen and then a flipping cutscene, all of this was not problems in compleet saga, and all of these are things that are known to be things that most gamer's don't like. please TT games update the game, let me skip cutscenes, let me use my mouse.

author: DooperDupinskie
review: This really is difficult for me to write, I have been waiting over a year for this game to be released.This is a LEGO movie much rather than a LEGO game. The vast majority of the story is listening to dialogue while watching cut scenes. You have intermittent combat missions that last all of 5 minutes at most. I have nothing against games that tells a story through cut scenes or non-combat game play. However, the difference is this game simply lacks combat. If you want anything like the original trilogy, don't bother. If you are looking for something similar to the lego clone wars, don't bother. This game as beautiful and well as it runs, was focused on a relatively empty open world and is banking it's success and popularity through that. I will say, this actually follows the story significantly closer than the other lego video games which I appreciate however, it doesn't make up for the lack of actual missions or combat. At that point though, I would much rather just go watch the movies.

author: FlareZ
review: Very beautiful looking game, clearly the developers spent lots of time on the environment.  But... just doesn't seem like a Lego game. The puzzles I got were good but were few and far between. Finished Episode 1 and 2 and I don't remember building any structure.The open environment is great and looks awesome but most of your time will be spent escorting an NPC or running to a cut-scene.The new over the shoulder camera game-play is great but you need a controller to play co-op, its 2022 and we still only get LAN co-op?Overall, a very good looking game but game-play is subpar for a complete saga fan.

author: Anorak
review: LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga scratches an itch I didn't realise I had. I couldn't put my finger on why I've had so much dissatisfaction from many big games today until now. This game is in direct contrast to the overall direction of the industry. It's purely an uncompromised vision from a team with passion to create an experience. Before the PC release, I was interested but didn't quite understand why it was given game of the year until playing it.Done.It's a rewarding experience, but not through the typical means. Ultimately the game is about building connections, this thread is woven into the story but also between players. The most satisfying thing to happen to me is struggling myself along a path for the first time to the next station, laying down a ladder to cross a river myself and for me to return the next day and see that same ladder was used and helped about 500 other people cross the river on their own journey.This is hardly touching on most aspects of the game, from the compelling world with the urge to try and make sense of what the LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga is, to its gear system that gives you actually useful gear to help you traverse the land easier.Overall, if you are after a chill game to kick back to at the end of the day. If you are vaguely interested in it, chances are you are going to like it. In terms of what TT Games set out to do, it delivers in all areas. Every aspect of this game was thought out and crafted to precious and it shows. It’s an experience that was made to be experienced and not just to drain your wallet.

author: Xaser
review: Great nostalgia hit, great humour, lots of stuff to do, but it's plagued by performance issues and general bad porting issues.ProsCombat is revamped heavily, combos are interesting but as usual, spam light attack and a few ranged attacks make light workCompletely revamped and tranformed levels leading in and out of major hub levelsBeautiful lighting and effects, mixed with photorealistic backgrounds and usage of studsSounds are fantastic, voice actors arent too bad eitherSlapstick humour transforms the scene, iconic lines are used to great effect with nice side jokesConsCharacters are catagorised into seven classes, each character no longer has unique or special abilities, just tied to the class the character belongs toPS4 Controllers force split screen (rendering them useless for solo play)Tabbing out of the game resets your display refresh rate, every single time. (fixed by going into the config file of the game, and using read only)Major variations in performance, more action packed scenes play better than basic scenesCutscenes are forced into what seems 24 hzSteam play together is incredibly awkward to use (Dedicated coop functionality would be better)Camera issues such as incredibly low FOV, camera zooms into body way too far and way too frequentlyShip movement is plagued by "go too far to the right of the screen and it locks itself into that direction until you move back 5x the distance)Overall a good game, with a lot to offer new and returning players of the originals, best enjoyed with coop, but due to performance issues and the incredible variations, cannot recommend currently.

author: Multitudes22
review: It seems like it would be a great game, if I could play it. It makes me so motion sick that I can't play for more than five minutes at a time. Tried fiddling with all the settings, played farther away, windowed, took motion sickness pills, nothing helps. The camera floats and swerves around so wildly. If you're prone to motion sickness there's no way you'll be able to play this. I think I might be in the minority here, so I'm not holding out hope for a solution like an FOV slider, but if that comes in an update I'll give it another try. Until then, had to refund.
