author: Gaming
review: This is prove that Lego games are well suioted to keep up with the modern gaming world, the combat has been improved immensly over the past entries and the enviroments look really beautifull whilest keeping the cham of the old games with and delivering some of the most fun cutscenes of 2022.However in terms of the game itself it adapts the worst parts of the modern gaming industry and sets a worrisome president for the future of lego games.The phares I'd use to describe this game is quntity over substance in the right parts, I currently have 15 hours on the game with most of it spent on the campaign mission of which you've seen most of after having completed the first trilogy.The other half I didn't really play much of is an immense ammount of really beautifully looking smaller hub areas which are filled with the same 20 puzzles all over the galaxy of star wars.I feel like both of these halves just didn't reach the potential the could have and allready have in past lego games that are over 10 years old by now.To me it feels like the game tried too much copying industry trends instead of building on what worked with the old games and bringing new ideas into that allready working formuly, I don't get why we need so many small hub areas that are just very bland gameplay wise instead of improving the old medium to large size hub area that have worked so well in the past.Also there is a skill tree now, I haven't even touched one because it's so boring useless and out of place.

You beat an entire episode!This is especially true when the developers decided to cut so much from what was enjoyable in The Complete Saga.Please, I beg you, spare yourself the disappointment and get The Complete Saga instead.

author: Arenus Septim Siverius
review: What is the point of making hundreds of characters if You take away THEIR UNQUE Abilities?!I have been waitfng for this game and i was watching gameplay of the boss fights and DARTH SIDIOUS . I wanted to try him only to find THEY TOOK AWAY HIS FORCE LIGHTNING same with the rest of SITH Characters. The Emperor famous for electrocuting his foes to death now NO LONGER has this ability UNDER Player control...while clearly boss fight has tons of his Force Lightning Abiltiies. This is a clear MIDDLE FINGER to all SW Fans who waited for this "ULTIMATE" Lego Star Wars Game experience.Ultimate DISSAPOINTMENT.Not only there was no PRE-LOAD for PC Steam Players . On top of that CHARACTERS are no longer unqiue and LIMITED to the BEST possible way .If you want to play as Sith YOU WILL BE disappointed.The Emperor Dooku etc they have to do do sith force lightning after you tap SQUARE/X key on the controller and then tap heavy attack. The abilitiy is NOTHING like in the moview/boss fight version. Its NOT Continous. Bobba Fett  also can not fly long anymore but very very short time... and his FLAMETHROWER attack is RIDICULOUSLY short.What else.. Levels feel like BIG ROOMS or corridors . Yes Gameplay itself feels fun but taking away characters UQNIUE stuff is A BIG NO Deal to me a modder who was fighting and modding games to unlock AI/BOSS only skills for player characters in an OFFLINE GAMES...Such a disappointment. FORCE AWAKENS , COMPLETE SAGA, Clone Wars they remain better for me.I dont suggest purchasing this game to any serious SW Fan!Glad I was able to refund it.

author: Mikari
review: A really fun, exciting and awesome game buried under countless bugs, multiple crashes, mission that dont work and can brick your entire playthrough. Lackluster shooting, awful flying/shooting mechanics a terrible POV, klunky open world to mission design and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up pre-order practice. the state this game is in, i cant recommend it, but eventually if they fix all the glitches and bugs itll truly be a masterpiece finaly people will be able to witness.Under all those huge glaring issues, this game is truly what will go down as either one of the best or the best star wars game there has ever been. the sheer scale and enormous amount of love and pokes at the most opsqure characters and places leave you feeling this game truly is designed for both new commers and hard core starwars fans alike. the voice acting(all except Kylo Ren.. my favorite character :( ), the animation, sound design is truly beautiful and the lego world shines in the fact that this game is freshly baked in a coat of modern graphics. combat feels lackluster and get combo meter feels like a quick afterthought. but its designed so that children will enjoy it aswell, so i understand the need to simplify it.

author: arya
review: Initially, I was very excited to play this game and Episode IV was off to a good start. However, once I tried playing the co-op, the repetitiveness and poorly-designed game mechanics reared their head. Most missions, only one person gets to really play while someone else is stuck as a droid. The droid challenges that are randomly dispersed through every mission are so boring and time-consuming and take away any sense of urgency from the game. To be playing the Obi Wan v Anakin duel and have to stop halfway to do some protocol droid challenge or switch to R2 for something was terrible. After playing about 15 hours of this game, I'd wished I had just purchased the original LEGO Star Wars.

author: Retro Richie
review: Its a great game and please go read some good reviews because this is a good nod to star wars in general and very funny in places. Clever game.Unfortunately it has many poorly optimised sections that can drop the in game FPS to as low as 12 fps. this is murder for streaming and playing the game. Im running a 4.25 ghz 12 core 24 thread processor and an RTX 2070 GPU with 3600mhz 32GB RAM and even with V Sync to 60 fps and turning all settings to their absolute lowest, I am still getting FPS drops in some sections.Its such a shame because the game itself is a funny, amazing looking game.

author: Bones n' worm enjoyer_97
review: I'm still only on Episode I (I watch and play Star Wars in chronological order because my parents loved me) but you can call me General Grievous because I have grievances with this game;-This game for 100% real no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around there are no jokes in this statement no sirrrrr unpausable cutscenesI get that you can't afford to get the (still alive) OG actors to record more voice lines, so I get that you get new ones in to impersonate them, re-record the scenes from the films and record new ones to fit the gameplay. But did you actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ need to also-Hire people who can't for the life of them sound nothing alike the original, Anakin, Palpatine and Padmé are the glaring examples I've encountered thus far. Padmé sounds like she's impersonating Queen Elizabeth II, Anakin sounds like he's 5 & Palpatine (SPOILZORZ ALORTEZ) use his Darth Sidious voice constantly which sounds farcical while he's pretending to be a nice boi.-The way the brown capes drapes over the model's back makes them look like wafer thin, very burnt waffles. This with all settings set to max I looked for but couldn't find a setting which could help.-Odd lack of tutorialization before you're thrown into your first combat, especially considering the gameplay (at least to me) is incomparable to previous entries.-I really wish I could customize the controls more. For Force users "Q" (using Defaults as an example) is your straight up main saber bonk, Left Click is your Lightsaber Throw. That would itself be fine if I could switch them, I've played games released during this millenium so I'm more accustomed to using L-click as my main attack, "Q" would fit lovely as an alternate attack. However Default controls for shooty-people (L-click to shoot, "Q" to melee) would then be messed up, would be fixed if I could set those controls separately.-Odd design choice to leave spend time and resources on making sure the plastic injection molding seams are visible in the game-Please fix Padawan Obi-Wan's "upside-down clay bowl" bowlcut.-Jar Jar does not have a dumptruck ass, there's not even a glimpse of a cheekI would like to put forward my final point as a rhetorical question;If you were to create a title screen featuring basically the whole ensemble of main characters from 9 films, and you would pick one of them as the centerpiece and give them their own "epic" voice line to sum up the mindset of the SKYWALKER SAGA;-The "Mary Sue"-styled disservice to women's representation as strong main characters in sci-fi which wasted the talents of a talented actress on a generic character on an even more generic "I need to find myself and become strong" journey. A good idea would also be to think her voice and delivery of declarative lines is as good is Gal Gadot, you could then give her a Daddy-issues laced line which would feel so disconnected, considering this character featured in 3 out of 9 of the main films.-The person who features in a majority of the films, who's character actually goes through a journey of growth, hardship, failure and loss before achieving their ultimate goal. Not to give away which one I'm thinking of, this game contains this character's name in its title.-The beautiful vixen of a green milk animalHere are clues to help you arrive at the answer;-Traveller's Tales picked the only wrong of these three options.-The No. 1 obvious correct choice does not even feature in the title screen ensemble.

author: BeaverEater11
review: This game is amazing. The settings are lush, large, and surprisingly full of content and detail. The control on keyboard and mouse are a bit difficult to get used to but  controller support and custom configurations makes this criticism pretty obsolete. The puzzles are very laissez-faire so there is many different ways to solve them, even if you don't have certain characters abilities unlocked yet. The one real cirtisism I have is that the game is relatively buggy. I've had 3 instances of bugs crashing my game and/or breaking it so badly I had to turn off the game and restart it. I also have had issues being able to use some of the DLC characters, where they don't appear in my roster. Cut scenes also have occasionally given me a black screen and soft locked the game which has been a bit frustrating. There are also some slight issues with optimization, especially in the droid factory level, however, that was a very elaborate level so I chalk that problem up to my hardware more than anything, although I have been playing with 120 fps on ultra high settings for every other part of the game, that made me reduce it to medium graphics just to keep a 45+ framerate. Overall, its very good. I would like to give it a 9/10, however, it would need a few more bug fixes for me to really give it that so as of april 7 2022,  its an 7.5/10

author: 2001 DVD
review: This game is great, for the right person that is.I've seen people talk about how short the levels are and I completely agree with that. However, I feel that the developers chose to make the focus of the game on the hub worlds over the story. Don't get me wrong, I get that the game is about the movies, but it really feels that they're not the main focus.It's not an open world to the extent of something like Breath of The Wild, instead, it's expansive smaller areas that make up pieces of what is a gigantic map.Every other Star Wars game has you put into a story, this Lego game has you put into the world. The audience they sought for this game were people who were interested in exploring areas and with characters you wouldn't think would be there. You can run around Theed in Naboo as Darth Vadar watching all it's people run in fear. That alone warrants conversation.There are space battles (and let me just say I did not expect the battles to be as fun as they are), the ships in the game are cool, though I've noticed that they are pretty much the same other than looking different from each other.The sounds of the blasters and, omg, lightsabers are amazing like they sound GOOOOOD. Matching that with the combat in the game is honestly blissful. Throwing a lightsaber and watching it come back and the character doing a cool spin with it... idk it's just really cool looking.One of the things that really upsets me is that you can't create a character of your own in the game. Many of the most recent Lego games have had the option to make your own character. This game does not. It's not something that kills the game for me as its completely an optional thing that existed, but the fact its not in this game is just a bummer.Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who wishes to explore fantastic worlds and play as really cool characters (300+ that is). 8/10.

author: WeaselPig
review: Needs an fov slider. The camera gives me a headache.Other than that, the game runs well and looks good. The gameplay seems fun but I couldn't play for more than an hourEdit: So, it's a dirty fix but it's enough for me to play without feeling nauseous until a true fov mod is made or the devs add an fov slider. I changed my resolution from 2560x1440 to 2560x1080. After playing for some more time, the game is fun and worth the price for star wars fans. The level design seems a bit boring, most levels are just walk from point a to b, watch a short cutscene, then back to a. Then you have space ship missions which are fun, but mouse controls are bit weird (if you flick hard, your ship will keep spinning until it catches up to where it should be). I still enjoy space missions, regardless of weird controls. Finally, there are boss fights. So far, I've only fought maul (only finished phantom menace as of writing this) and it was fun. There's obviously a ton of free play content to see so not worried about a lack of content. I still would appreciate an fov slider though.

review: I know i have only played through 4 of the episodes but to be quite honest with you, i've had enough.This game is so boring that its not even funny. I was looking forward to have some fun with the silly/ childish nature and playfulness of a lego star wars game.But ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, there is no fun to be had here. This game is insulting to my intelligence.I know the game is made for kids and man children like myself but man...   THEY LITERALLY RE USE THE SAME 3 or 4 ISH DUMBASS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ PUZZLES IN EVERY ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ EPISODE!2 OR 3 OF THE "PUZZLES" INVOLVES CLICKING  3 BUTTONS RIGHT AFTER EACH OTHER!AND THE COMBAT, OH THE COMBAT HAHAHAHAHA!IF YOU CAN EVEN CALL IT "COMBAT"! author: Nora97
review: I am just sad, and disappointed.I think the open world mechanics work great and are well designed.But a lot of why I loved past lego games is just missing from the actual missions.Often missions are super short, a lot of the story is packed into cut scenes and not playable,and each episode has only a few missions taking away a lot of the 'LEGO' experience.It is clear, that the focus of the development was on the implementation of the open world,and that part seems to have worked out, but with the way how the game plays at the moment, id rather have more and better and longer missions,with less content crammed into cut scenes.I just pray there will be updates to improve missions and the 'story' experience, but im not sure if that will happen.Initially, i had hoped there would be planet & mission DLCs for the other Star Wars Movies & Series,but with the way the story & missions are designed at the moment,i think id rather not experience that huge disapointment.

author: Minu
review: If you like actual levels, you'll hate this game. The episodes have very little content and can be completed in less than half an hour a piece.  Not the levels, the entire episode. There's also 1100 bricks to collect to upgrade your abilities, (not individually, destroying an asteroid got me 5) which is weird considering how little meat there is to the actual game. The combat is overhauled, but again, I don't see the point if you rarely use it. Non-companion AI is brain dead. Enemies should be blasting you with blasters but they just stand there waiting to be killed, even though there's now a block button. Friendlies are the same way, during the Gungan battle (in which you kill roughly 2 dozen droids, build a catapult, and then just gun down a mob with it) it's only you and the player 2 AI doing anything, despire being surrounded by other gungans.   Slapstick is back at least. Port's nice, ultrawide is actually supported. Still no online multiplayer unless you want to use steam play though. Not asking for open lobbies, I just wanna play with friends.   All the game's resources went into making hub worlds. If you want a collectathon, go for it. If you want a good Lego Star Wars game, get TCS.

author: Mr. McPerson
review: Edit: Alright, so I played through 123, 456. And it didnt get better. And this is the worst part of this game - so y'know that level where you go through the second death star in the millenium falcon and hit the core, and then have to race out as the fire is burning behind you? Yeah, its not in here. Its a 10 second cutscene. I am sorely disappointed, as I was looking forward to that alot. Its like one of the best levels in the entire series. Yeah this ones kind of a bust, and is completely lacking in content. 380 characters doesn't matter if essential levels and scenes just aren't there. Edit 2: Also, I forgot this, but at one point Luke on Jabbas barge completely bugged out and just kept running in one direction. Had to kill him multiple times to get back in control. For some reason, the in-game scenes tend to be a little glitchy, and camera movement takes way too much time. Every 5 seconds is either a panning shot to show you what to do, or just takes control away for way too much time. I know I'm comparing this to the originals, but its just overall a clunky experience.Now, I might change this. But right now, its just not fun. Like I know nostalgia and everything, but every single cutscene feels so rushed and fast and is so off putting in an odd way I don't understand. 20 minutes of this and I'm already at the Death Star? Where did the C3PO and R2D2 get sucked into the Jawa ship go? Where did the Uncle Owen buying C3PO and R2 go? There's just so much missing, or skipped. I wasn't even that hyped for this and I'm still disappointed. I know some of you are going to go "but theres more content your just not doing it". Well guess what, Lego Batman had an open world, and Lego Marvel had an open world, and those two had better and more interesting level design. This is not an open world game, this is a set of levels, with too much empty hub world between them. If the cutscenes weren't so fast paced, and characters had even a moment to breath or for there to be just a single moment where something isn't happening, it would be so much better. The original games handled the story much more elegantly, but still kept it goofty, this one just doesn't cut it

author: InexactCave8264
review: Negative Review Time.I really liked this game when it came out. Had plenty of variety, plenty to do, and was a great experience with so many characters and being able to play through all 9 movies. I haven't touched it since that first week.Upon playing through the older games like Complete Saga, Batman, and Indiana Jones, I realised the 1 core problem of this game.It is too big.Part of the charm of the old games was how they were short and simple. You could get plenty of enjoyment and fun out of them, and if you chose to, you could 100% them in roughly 16 hours. You could hop into a level and be done in 15 minutes, perfect for when you don't have alot of time. This game however, is an absolute SLOG to get through. Getting through all 9 episodes was one thing. It is after the main story that the game becomes dreadful. Each and every planet is fully fleshed out with quests and hidden collectibles to be found everywhere. I started my journey going one planet at a time. This proved a fruitless effort, as some quests were locked behind quests on other planets. By the time I hit Tatooine, I was done. I was burnt out and exhausted. Tatooine I believe is the largest planet with the most to do, and WOW do you feel it. There are also at least 2 planets that are very similar to it, being Crait and Jakku. The whole thing is extremely overwhelming with endless collectables and quests that go on for seemingly hours. Then replaying the levels you remember that there are 9 episodes, each with a handful of levels each. And many of them are extremely open, making you need to go through them with a fine tooth comb. And after ALL THAT, most of the puzzles and quests feel very empty and bland. You start to feel this generally by the 3rd-4th planet.I can't go back to this game because it looks like FAR too much work ahead of me. Theoretically it is possible to beat it, but you are going to pour so much time and effort into it. In the end, will it be worth it? Will it be enjoyable? Your answer may vary, but mine is very much No.

author: burritomuncher_08
review: OK, I liked playing this game, but at the same time, the game feels like it was made for 5 year olds, its way too easy, and there is no like difficulty meter you could change either, none of the puzzles were difficult, and all the enemies were super low health, so you couldnt hit any cool combos if you were using a lightsaber character.Also the side missions were not fun, and they are sorta useless, you only really ever want to do them if you want like a side character, but none of the side characters were as cool as like darth vader or general grievous, they were just some random dude with another blaster, or some weird alien that only punches people, there was no purpose in doing them.Again I liked playing through the main story and the lightsaber duels between some of the iconic characters was pretty fun, but most of the game is pretty boring and there is no really good content in the open world part of the gameEDIT: Ok I forgot to include bugs and FPS issues. I experienced 2 game breaking bugs in this game that prevented me from game progression: One was on the Endor mission with the speeder bikes, the objective said to eliminate storm troopers, but the storm troopers would not spawn so I was just sitting there shooting trees and just getting unlimited studs. The second was in Maz's castle, the objective portal at the entrance of the castle would not show up, and there is no fix to this bug other than to just keep restarting and wait for it to work, and this process for me took an ENTIRE IRL MONTH to get past it, really annoying bugs. And on some levels and cut scenes (not all) your game would just drop to 30 fps and it was super annoying. And no it is not because of my pc, i have an RTX 3070 and a ryzen 9 3900x, no matter how good your pc was, you would drop FPS pretty frequently due to the poor optimizationIf you are buying this game I would suggest only really playing the main story for the side missions and open world mainly just consists of breaking random ♥♥♥♥ collecting studs.

author: SkuxxMcMuffin69
review: Just 100% the game and here are my thoughts. In the area of story game-play the game feels rather short and rushed, with only 5 missions per episode and some filler set-up missions in-between. Yes I know its a Lego game and they are more focused on the collectables side but it would of been nice to see a bit more story mission game-play.For the collectable 100% side the game, It is spectacular and quite over-whelming at times. The grind is hard but its fun in the prepossess. The 750+ puzzles are mostly different and refreshing each puzzle and the side-missions are different and fun too.Overall amazing game 9.5/10 but i do not suggest to players that do not intend on attempting to 100% or play through free play.

author: Chad Champion
review: This game is fun, but I have come to find more disappointment then excitement while playing this game. Levels are short and most can be summarized by following the objective markers and killing a few waves of enemies on the way. Many key moments in the movie are replaced by cut scenes or completely skipped. There's barely any building or puzzles, and I haven't seen any of the alternate paths other than the one showcased in trailer.With that being said, I still do think this game is worth it, just not at full price. All the jokes hit and the open world is cool to explore. The combat is fun, but it is very easy and can be a bit repetitive on long sessions. All the boss fights I have had so far were pretty enjoyable, but I was kinda hoping the lightsaber duels would be a bit more challenging and had more depth.     I know this is a kids game, but considering a large portion of the people who bought this are teenagers or young adults, I think it is fair to point out. TLDR: If you want the real LEGO Starwars experience, just play The Complete Saga. In my opinion, it still remains the gold standard for LEGO Starwars games, as others have said this is just a lazy platformer with the LEGO style and modern graphics.

The thing I hate most about this game so far is the Jango Fett level, which consists of chasing him through the asteroid belt. author: Princess Muu-Muu
review: I want to start this review by saying I was one of the original Complete Saga fans and was highly skeptical of this game.Firstly, I heard a lot of bad stuff recently about TT's game development, a lot of reviews/comments were saying the that original was better, and I personally hated my first two hours on this game. Going into it, I had pretty low expectations and was even thinking about refunding it. After a while, I found myself hooked. However, there's a mixed bag of things this game does better than the original Complete Saga but also things it does way worse...*You can turn into any character in the game that you have unlocked at any time. (But... NO CHARACTER CREATION.)*The game looks really good graphically. (But... The FOV is really tight and can even be sickening at points.)*Way more exploration and collectibles than previous games. (But... The game reuses locations and crams so many collectibles in, its overwhelming. Hours of grinding collectibles amounts to nothing when there's 1000+ collectibles.)*You can aim blasters properly now. (But... Melee combat is non-existent. Enemies just stand around and let you stun lock them in combos.)*Boss fights actually feel more like free form boss fights. (But... This makes them all feel the same.)*They paid homage to cut missions from the original Complete Saga. (But... Removed some of the most fun and iconic levels to add and extend boring levels.)*They included a lot of movie scenes into the campaigns. (But... You have to travel to a mission starting point just to watch it play out in a cutscene to progress...)*They embraced Star Wars memes into the game's script. (But... They keep reusing their least funny memes over the course of episodes.)Overall, I think the new game is a net positive if you're into Lego games for the completion. If you don't like collectibles but are a fan of the Complete Saga, you probably wont like this game in comparison. This game's episode missions are often boring and short. On average I only found a scene or two, maybe an entire chapter of each episode to be fun. For me, I enjoy the collectibles. These larger maps they let you free roam have a lot of freedom and multiple ways to access collectibles. I also found some of the side quests to be more engaging than the chapters themselves. I definitely got my money's worth, I just want them to add an FOV slider as it will improve the game dramatically.

author: Lt. Nugget
review: This game kinda disappointed me. Jet packs are rubbish, there are no enemies to be found anywhere on the maps, low amount side-quests, cutscenes feel sorta rushed (even if it supposed to be Lego), the game starts with a long ass tutorial instead of a node at the bottom of the screen like older Lego games, the HUD sucks, no custom character creation, and the story mode mostly consists of walking and it only gets fun when you fight a boss, but every boss fight is pretty much the same. Also the story cannot be replayed without having to go back to the episode selector in order to play another level. Anakin's boss fight in Revenge of the Sith (EP3) has a bug where he pushes you away instead pulling you in to continue fighting him through Mustafar. You're then forced to make a new save file since you CAN'T REPLAY THE FREAKING STORY.The vehicle control in this game is awful, and you can only play the Mos Espa Classic podrace in first person. The class system is cool but feels like it fits more in an online type of game. The opening, voice acting and graphics look amazing though.The game looks great but it isn't much fun. For me, It's mainly a masterpiece from an art perspective. Only buy this game if you love Star Wars like me.

author: CONSUME PRODUCT
review: KBM controls and remapping are abysmal. Exit menu is stuck to E and if you play any other kbm scheme other than WASD it gets in the way.Combat is J and K keys but lightsaber throwing, vertical force manipulation and camera movement is stuck to the mouse. Juggling between KBM and mouse to fight is godawful.You cannot move mouse and click in menus.Splitscreen camera is terrible. Too zoomed in to see anything. Is there some kind of adjustment settings I'm missing?Why is there no online co op or some kind of friend sharing? Games like It Takes Two can do this, and TT has done online co op in the past with Indy Jones 2.So far I have only played 30 minutes of Episode 1 and the levels lack the same soul the original games did. I guess I'll soldier on hoping to find a gem in the rough but these new TT LEGO games are just so taxing.EDIT 1: Played a little bit more and explored Mos Espa. Holy moly is this camera so awful. It frequently gets stuck behind objects so that your character can't be seen when trying to perform some puzzles. The FOV in single player is still ridiculously close.

author: WoodE
review: Don't know if this is an issue for many people, but it definitely is for me. I was excited to play like everyone else, I start playing as soon as installation is done. However after less than 10 minutes, I get a BSOD (Blue Screen of Death), crashing my entire PC, needing a restart. I've even tweaked various settings to try to fix the problem, but i still get a blue screen within the 5-10 minute mark. I had 6 hard crashes, even after tweaks and checking for any updates to drivers or Windows. Damn shame because I've waited years for this game, but currently its unplayable for me, so I'm going to refund the game. Maybe when they fix the game, ill get it again when its on sale because I've seen so many good things. If only i can play and experience it myself. Damn disappointment. Don't release your game if its still unplayable. I'm playing on Windows 10, by the way.

author: ☾.⁧⁧Zubumafu
review: I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.thank you lego star wars

author: donutsquad05
review: When i first heard about this game I was thrilled. I loved playing the complete saga when I was younger and I expected this game to be a million times better than the complete saga. I mean this was created 15 years after the complete saga so my expectations weren't too much. I heard that this game would have a ton of fancy graphic options. I  load in and try enabling all of the fancy options and it doesn't seem all that different or cool. It could have just been by computer lacking the fancy technology to run the fancy graphics. Whatever. Let's talk about the actual game now. THE COMBAT IS AWFUL! When I saw the combat is awful, it truly is. I was expecting there to be some challenge to fighting enemies, but no. You could quite literally stand in front of an enemy completely still and they would kill you after like 15 minutes. The game even has barriers to shield yourself from enemy fire, but i don't see a point of that when you could just run right past all of the enemies. I understand that this maybe is targeted towards children, but I think even children get frustrated that they could just run past everything with no consequences. Then you have the mobility and parkour things. The parkour has no challenge to it at all. All you do is switch to a bounty hunter and repeatedly press the same button to jump through parkour challenges. That is super boring. I want to actually jump and time jumps so that I am successful. Not just spam A with my eyes closed and pop up at the top of the parkour challengeNow the giant fight sequences. What a joke. For example, in attack of the clones when Padme and Obi Wan are in the gladiator battle and count dooku shows up there is supposed to be a full out battle between jedis, bounty hunters, sith, clones, and droids. The complete saga did a perfect job of this, but now in the Skywalker saga you have a measly like 5 droids rendered in at a time. One would expect with all of the new innovations to technology we had in the last 15 years  we would be able to render in a ton more entities on our screen, but it seems that innovation has done the opposite and only allows us 5 battle droids. You could see another example of this on the planet Kashyyyk. Kashyyyk is the place that is home to all of the wookies in revenge of the sith. There is supposed to be a full out battle with clones now battling jedis and wookies everywhere. Once again, you only get like 4 clones rendered in at a time making the game very simple and not what I expected. The game also has some annoying features like when a kyber brick is collected, you are forced to watch your character stand still while the kyber brick counter ticks up by 1. Then slowly fades away.  Then the character says a catchphrase and you are off to play again.  This gets annoying when you have to collect all 1200 bricks. Another annoying feature is when you start up the game. You are welcomed by a 2 minute long cut scene. Good thing the cut scene is skippable. But it gets annoying that every single time you open the game, you have to skip the cutscene. Even after that is "skipped" you have to hear Rey talk for an extra like 10 seconds. I just want to get in the game and not watch a movie before I launch the game.Overall, this game just seems like everything is handed to you and you are carried all of the way through it. There is almost no challenge or parts you really have to think through. Even for all of the kyber bricks and minikits, there is a giant blue marker that appears through the walls to show you the exact location of everything. Maybe they should have implemented a difficulty feature or something so it makes it seem like we aren't just guided all the way through the game. The game is also just a disappointment to what I was expecting. i was expecting a giant improvement to combat and gameplay, but it was all just turned to poo.

author: Roberto
review: After reaching a point where I am softlocked and can not progress any further I think I'm done with this game. Every episode I had the game crash at least once with an infinite loading screen every other episode. Other times whole puzzles don't load in so there are a bunch of empty rooms for no reason until you reload the game. There are a handful of levels that drop to about 15 fps almost regardless of hardware. There are multiple people complaining of having their saves get corrupted and a few videos of people stuck in infinite death loops after space battles.As for the game itself...It sacrifices a lot of the story and levels in favour of open world areas. I feel like they really missed the mark with the open world areas. They feel so disconnected, most of the time they don't feature in the story in anyway other than walking through. On a handful of levels you might have to fight your way through but they're a rarity. Outside of that there are 5 levels per episode that aren't usually long. Luckily this means when you get to a level with poor performance (enough to give me motion sickness) you can get through it fairly quickly. The games pacing is off too. For example about half way through Episode 1 you'll notice icons with an electric drill for the scavenger class. You'll get the tutorial and first unlock of this class on Endor, towards the end of Episode 6. Most of the side quests you pick up just have you going back and forth throughout the galaxy doing fetch quests. If they were local they wouldn't be so bad but you're constantly back tracking. It doesn't help how you can only track one quest at a time. Also added to the fact the UI isn't great. You'll constantly find yourself in the wrong menus opening and closing tabs not really getting anywhere. It's really noticeable when you're trying to swap a team member with one that isn't in the quick select. All in all it feels like they've taken too much out but not replaced it with enough. Unless you're really into the trend of every game ever now being open world. I tried to power through the games major performance issues but in the end the game itself stopped me from playing it. So after that I really can't recommend it.Comments are disabled because the community members of this game are very young and are yet to develop common sense and fundamental communication skills. To the point I wouldn't trust any of them to sit the right way on a toilet seat.

author: Floymin
review: For the franchise fans out there that are familiar with the grindy mechanics, those are still there, and ramped up. The humor is also ramped up, but a little dated as they mostly reference the recent glut of fan theories (why isn't MatPat a playable character?).Besides the repetitive fetch quests to unlock characters, the biggest con IMO is the ramped-up "safety" of the story. TT makes such an extreme effort to skirt around anything remotely "controversial" that they literally erase the context of every scene they try to emulate.So... if you are a fan of social media conspiracies, be prepared for a laugh riot. If you are a fan of the film franchise, as well as the Lego franchise, be prepared for a HUGE let-down.

author: Furiel
review: Yeah... First LEGO game and overall negative impression.Cons:- Games like this require Steam to have a Mouse&Keyboard support tag. Obviously made with controllers in mind, atrocious menu layout with no mouse support, non-responsive controls and 4-5 actions bound to the same key...- First Launch of the game: "VISIT OUR STORE"... a 50€ game goes for milking from the get go.- Saw only a few levels and the design revolves around brainlessly walking around to collect 3 coins and based on a quick look at the upgrade menu... you gonna be aimlessly walking around for a long time...If you want Star Wars just go play Jedi Academy... An almost 20 years old game that has more respect for your time (lest be honest, except the graphics).

author: 631 Zach
review: After being delayed for three years and waiting patiently i expected a beautifully polished and problem free game. What I got was an abomination that looks like it didn't go through a single play test. I encountered more bugs than not throughout my game play and it completely ruined my experience. I started keeping track of the bugs in a google doc and recording all i came across but my poor 128 gb phone ran out of storage from the endless videos. Regardless of the awesome graphics the game was unplayable. I forced myself to 100% this game just so i could uninstall it with the intention of never playing it again for the rest of my life. I am at peace now that I can delete this from my steam library and play a different garbage game. If i could go back and erase my memory of this I would be rejuvenated. This game made my hair fall out. Please spare yourself the pain i endured and look for a different game to purchase. 86.9 hours of my life I will never get back

author: Lappland
review: If you are like me and grew up playing the previous lego starwars games you're gonna hate this. The combat is boring with rarely any enemies on screen, money is useless by the fact you mostly spend it on upgrades that have no purpose. Why would i need increased weapon damage and abilities when there arely is ever any fighting and when there is, its so short with just a few enemies.There is no hub where all the characters can be seen walking around nor any trophy room where you can see the things you have unlocked and yet to, the environments are very open, very petty, but very empty and have no point other than aesthetics. All of the unlocks and collectables are in a menu, and only serve to get more kyber bricks (used for meaningless upgrades).It feels like so much work has gone into this game, but none of the quality and shine of their previous games are there. Its as if Warner Brothers used a different studio and a dev team who never played a lego video game and told them to hurry up and make something to sell.And thats really all this game is, mediocrity designed to sell and barely pass as acceptable.

author: KunouNoHana
review: The actual gameplay of the Lego games has been mostly stripped out and replaced with an open world game, except said open world is largely empty spaces with breakable items on both sides of the road. Levels are stripped down to on rails sections, dogfights and boss fights, which are fun sure, but there's no real sense of exploration within the levels. It's not a bad game, but if you're a fan of lego games as actual play experiences and not just relatively easy collectathons, it's not worth the purchase.

author: Bleistift
review: At this point it's just really sad... Spiffing Brit made 1 (!) video on a few funny bugs and speedrun glitches and they got fixed IN LESS THAN 24 HOURS! Yet my Episode 7 Save is STILL HARD LOCKED because the Maz Story mission won't start. It's been almost 2 months. I should not have to write this review.  All the nostalgia in the world can't compensate for the fact that TT obviously has their priorities all wrong, and as long as this game has game-breaking bugs that, apparently, are less important than a few goofy glitches, I can not recommend this game.

author: Strayed
review: Legit go buy the 2009 Complete saga game unless you willingly want to experience """open world gameplay""", checkpoints every other minute, tiny missions, and extremely sanitisised retelling of the story.5 levels per episode, one more sterile and smaller than the other, less engaing and overall than a damn cookie clicker. The only reason I'm playing the game to the end is out of spite and buyer's remorse. What's more is that I'm palying it with my brother in slpit screen, and the only enjoyable moments are when we both are mentally exhausted from how awful the game is and start shooting the crap out of everything.What makes me seethe is also how absolutely awful the models look. What is it with having LEGO(tm) stamped all over the place? What's up with how needlessly dirty they look? My own models are cleaner than that, and I live in a very dusty place!Buy Lego the Clone Wars of The Complete Saga, stay away from this pile of garbage cash grab. I'd say it's a game made for mono-neuron children, but even then it'd be too offensive to the children themselves. This is a bona fide CIA torture method, not a game.

author: FLAME18688
review: Let me start off by saying I loved the old lego star wars games. Had a blast with lego star wars 3 and the complete saga in particular. This game, gameplay wise, has evolved and gotten better. The graphics have been improved, and more characters are unique. However, during playing the game, I grew bored quickly in the "open-world" aspect of it before each mission. The open-world is great if you enjoy doing multiple different puzzles with multiple different characters. But besides that, there were no enemies. No other challenges. Just walking from point A to point B with some optional puzzles in between. The missions themselves (for what I completed, which mind you was up to Episode 2), were not that creative. They were way too simple (including the boss fight). So yeah lack of creativity I felt. On top of that, whenever I played with my friend, I would get a headache after an hour of playing. The camera is the main cause I believe. So yeah, don't come into this game thinking it's going to just be a better old school star wars. It's not, and it's just more complicated regarding the "skill trees". (Which at least in my time playing, you did not need anything from any skill tree).

Major bummer - while it would have been fun solo, it's better together. Hopefully they'll add in full or at least PC-friendly MP so two people with keyboard/mouse can play.

author: NEEX
review: Lego Star Wars: Skywalker Saga is a rather innovative yet disappointing instalment to the previous lego star wars games. Within the first mission I found myself already rushed through Episode 1 in less than an hour for the first movie, a lack of puzzles and combat making my first impressions rather negative and the open world not really providing anything of worth via collectables. I persisted and carried on with episode 2 and 3, encountering bugs and areas that had frame rate issues, yet the lack of puzzles, any meaningful combat, lack of worthwhile collectables and the serious pacing issues did not change my stance on the matter. luckily moving into the OG Trilogy and Sequel Trilogy I found an increase in puzzles and gameplay and the story smoothed out, yet still felt rushed in many areas. The combat now included more dynamics and puzzles into it yet with the shortness of each mission quickly putting a stop to any fun, releasing me back into an empty open world with worthless collectables. Combat:The new combat mechanics are a much welcomed improvement and take me back to Lego City Undercover, with counters and combos feeling rather fun to pull off when your able to. The gunplay is the highlight for me personally in terms of the new combat, with the splash of the energy bolts and AI reactions to being hit, adding some weight and impact to each encounter. The new cover system is very much like that of Mass Effect or Gears of War, yet feeling far more polished and seamless. Yet with all the positives come the Negatives, the good examples of combat are far and few between, with most encounters finishing within a matter of seconds or ending up as easy shooting galleries without much else. The AI whilst advanced, isnt able to shine enough or provide any challenge at all. Boss battles are not a new concept yet with the Skywalker Saga, they've rewritten the basics of it. Puzzles have been removed and clunky, buggy, repetitive Quick Time Events take center stage. Every boss fight will be the same, hitting the boss until a QTE drags you from across the map to mash a button or key, with the QTE's offering no challenge once again, but against what I said above, now and then you may find a fight sprinkled in with a basic puzzle to lead to the next QTE.Overall, combat whilst fun at its core, sorely lacks anyway to shine and to provide a memorable experience or challange, relegated only to filler to bulk out extremely short missions or for boss fights.Space Combat:I dont really have much to say on this but the space combat is very good despite a view poorly designed missions (Ships flying into the back of you), overall the space combat is very fun and officers more challange.Puzzles/Building?:The main staple of the lego games have always been its well thought out puzzles and building which go hand in hand, yet in this instalment it has been utterly looked over in favour of shooter mechanics and gameplay. When you do find puzzles in the game, the developers have had the bright idea to highlight each step for you, whether that be from finding a key to unlock a door or finding parts to build a ladder, all the steps are highlighted, making these some of the worst puzzles I have ever encountered in any game. A concurrent theme throughout this game is the lack of any form of challenge what-so-ever, and this is mostly shown through the lackluster thought put into puzzles when you do get them. With the lack of any meaningful puzzles as well, also means the gameplay and levels are lacking heavily, owing to their shortness.Overall the puzzles are pathetic to what has come before and severely hamper the game.Open World/Upgrades/collectables:The open world whilst seemingly large, is rather small and empty, offering not that much in the way of content besides finding crystals to use in upgrades or unlocking minifigures through unoriginal missions. Minikits meanwhile have been reduced from 10 to 5, with most being easily obtainable through shooting galleries. The upgrade tree is practically useless and provides no benefits or reason to sink time into, with this being the main focus for the collectables in the small open worlds, it leaves areas feeling empty or providing no reasons to explore.Overall Thought/Score:When compared to its older games, TT Games have made an empty, boring game that is easily forgotten. With lacking combat and puzzles (If you can call them that), to poorly paced story telling and dreadful mission design, this is in my opinion one of the worst lego star wars instalments to date. The time they spent producing this with the content offered leads me to believe the game went through development trouble, as the final product is more akin to a months worth of work rather than years, leaving me incredibly disappointed and underwhelmed. The game is not worth the price, more content is offered from indie studios selling their games at £14.99 than this game offers.Score- 4/10

review: Honestly this game not having a character customiser is the worse thing ever. They make you use the mouse, taking awake the unique gameplay lego games provide and dont even give you the ability to go back to the old controls. And they even took away another unique feature of lego games, the character customiser. So what if there are 300+ character, u just need 1 from each class and you are done, but having a character customiser brings more to unclocking characters to use their parts to make your own lego characters. author: MozarT 👜
review: This game is not even close to the original games, it misses the details of the old games and the length of the old games. It also doesnt even give a good gaming experience because everything is super stale and bare-bones... The "jokes" are super bad and way too corny compared to the old game and the corniness of the jokes just makes them horrible. There is almost no building in this game which the older games had tons of to complete levels which made it fun and interactive but in this one it lacks it and makes it feel like a recap of the old games, "recap" in the way that its like when you start a new season of a series that took 8+ months to get a new season and they start off with a 45-75 second recap.Shooting in this game feel like a "hold a button and just shoot" there is nothing fun about it when its so lackluster in every single scenario and makes the experience fall even lower.The voice over sounds horrible and "off" because they use new voices instead of cutting the original voices from the movies into the game.The only good things about this game is the fact that you get all the games in one game, graphics and the fact its open-world, but with that said that is literally everything the game has going for it. Is it nice with 400 characters to unlock? yea ofc but that is literally just made to make the game feel long and that shouldnt be what its for.3/10 score, Do not buy.

author: Riverfurball
review: As much as I'd like to give this game a great review for what the game is overall I can't justify it due to the constant problems I've had with this game over my 30-hour run.When it comes to the base content there are easily 20 hours for the base run through and id guess roughly 50-60 hours for a 100% run. The game has an improvement in pretty much every way from the previous lego star wars games for combat, classes and the overall world to explore. The game consists of hub worlds that include areas on the world and its space is mainly used for races and challenges with the worlds themselves being large while being compact with an assortment of content and over 1000 bricks to collect. Outside of this are 5 missions within each episode that vary in quality with many being fun and improvements within boss battles while others feel a bit short and crammed in, but most of all riding/space missions are now actually enjoyable with them being scattered throughout this time around.But the main problem comes with the stability and game-breaking bugs throughout my entire experience. The first part is the fairly common crashing with my run consisting of around 18 to desktop while black screening in cutscenes happening over 15. The other problem occurs when the mission has you switching between characters in boss fights particularly in boss battles as the game seems to get stuck and won't switch the player back and instead of forcing a restart this has happened more times than this mechanic working.The final part is the overall stability that causes problems with multiple missions and hub worlds dropping below 10 fps at 1440p on high (ryzen 7 3700x, RTX 3080) such as droid factory, wrestle with wesell, a lot of the space missions for examples. With bugs including unable to build, characters getting stuck in the wall/ground, reappearing after cutscenes outside of the map and free play generally easy to break the game.As much of a pain as this game was, I stuck with it as I planned to 100% it but the final straw was my save game being corrupted after the final crash (Spend an hour trying to fix nothing suggested worked) it has killed any motivation left to complete. I'd recommend putting it on your wishlist and waiting for a few months or a year from now as I'll eventually try it again.

author: Noci
review: I have to give this game a thumb down - even though its a good game. But its kinda missing the LEGO Element.The graphics are great, controls are good (little bit fiddlely with starships) and the typical Lego Humour is there. But one big aspect is clearly missing. I played 1,5 Episodes now, with lots of extra play in the open-world parts and there is nothing to build. You can smash crates, lights, benches but they never drop parts to build something new out them - a key factor of Lego games. It has every aspect of a good game, but the best part is sadly missing or only very rare. Maybe it will get better in later episodes, if so I will update, but right now it feels like a generic Star wars game with Lego textures on top.

author: AquariusHD
review: The game was really good pre-update 1.05. It would've been top 5 games of all time for me. In the update, they removed at least 5 different good bugs. Literally any popular speed running game has 1000000 fun bugs that don't affect anyone's experience unless they're actually trying to do said bugs. Game devs typically don't remove those bugs because they only have a positive impact on their game. The devs for this game did remove them. They went out of their way and did all of this extra work, just to make their game objectively worse.You can still get old versions again, so it wouldn't be that bad, but the game crashes 3-10 times each time my friend and I play it. I had accepted that I'll just have to live with the crashing, but now they'll release new updates to make the game crash less often (maybe 1.05 already fixed it), and we can't get them if we still want to have fun while playing the game. We now have to choose between the game crashing very often or playing essentially a completely different game, a 46.5% worse and 88.3% more boring game (I crunched the numbers and that's literally what they came out to).Tldr: The game was really good despite some bad crashing issues, but the developers removed some fun bugs that hurt ZERO people's experience. You now have to choose between having fun (old version) and not crashing (new version).

author: FabelWings
review: Oh man... I do not understand why people call this the "best lego game of all time" theres a lot of things im missing and disliking, however as they are personal preferences mostly ill just tell you the following bugs ive encountered:1. crashes; 2 random crashes, 5 crashes at the exact same spot, 1 crash after a weird bug, 2 random crashes that froze up my entire pc, even task manager couldn help me.2. extreme/gamebreaking bugs; a consistent crash in freeplay during kylo, rey, and finn's snow planet battle after he pulls out the snow trooper out the snow, this was very annoying as i had to use the force on crates quickly before my camera homed in on kylo making me unable to use the force, then i had to end the mission to not make it crash. during i think episode 7 where you destroy a first order big ship, you get spawned on the ship if you play freeplay after the fps sequence when the bombers come. you could walk around on the ship but you were softlocked from there, even worse if you jump down as the fall is infinite, and you cant open your tab menu only esc. more of a visual bug but still extreme, sometimes challenges point you the wrong way which made me go insane as i just couldn find this stupid mouse droid. i think this MIGHT also happen with minikits. again the kylo, rey, and finn bossfight sequence, i switched characters at apperently such a perfect moment that the pilots from the start spawned, "lego t-posing" after i tried to switch my character it crashed my game. EDIT: i forgot to add, while you rescue padme inside the droid factory, i had a gigantic bug that i could only go around with extreme precise jetpacking. i was thrown back and all thing to climb with were broken but the big bar at the top, dropped me off as soon as i touched it. i have no idea why this happened yet it almost soft locked me. 3. very minor bugs mostly countless visual bugs; big space ships in low res during smuggle missions spawning often, twice an executor which i went inside of. a millenium falcon randomly spawning after going above a planet while being it itself, i destroyed it, nothing happened but it had a lot of health. characters keep duplicating during mini cutscenes probably because of freeplay mode. npcs sometimes clipping out of their correct position in mini cutscenes. suddendly luke used the force once, but he was A.I. the weird thing was how my camera centered to the object he used the force on. once the game showed me an enemy signal, however there was nothing and i could even shoot proton torpedos at the nothingness. a star destroyer having invisible walls behind it during a mission, even though instead of placing an invinsible wall i die from maybe restrict me from going there. while you destroy the deathstar theres a minicutscene right before you shoot a torperdo down the vent, in which the game shows you the lights emitting from the engines of lukes x wing however not the ship itself if you play in freeplay and picked another ship. sometimes when you boot up the game every character that has a face just is faceless. during cutscenes, the opening sequence, and while you play. a weird white ish font was there for a small time while starting the same mission over again in freeplay. i saw clone troopers bouncy into the air and when i came close to them they despawned. if in freeplay at count dookus hideout, you can use a jetpack to go over the cutscene trigger. during mini cutscenes the baguette extra loves to break by showing lightsaber and baguette and once only a ip in hyperspace. a geonisis monster clipping trough the floor in reverse after being defeated. on kamino theres the flying  animal things and at one specific spot theres one that keeps flying into an invisible wall, freezing in place. while driving over to the broken death star (second one?) not using the vehicle will make it steer completely out of control sometimes. a kyberbrick that was a minikit? i dont think that was supposed to be like that. i once spawned inside the air at the wrong place while wanting to fast travel to a side quest giver. with boba fett i got launched into the air twice. a lot of npc's clearly just despawning. a grappling blaster stuck in the air. obi wan once blocked grevious with air instead his lightsaber. on camino a bunch of npcs clipped into eachother. c3po and r2d2 not correctly doing the animation, instead just spawning in. the heaviest glitch here was a side quest boss spawning in randomly on camino, beating him again gives nothing but its hard and annoying to trigger the cutscene.*this game was not worth the 50 euros, no matter how fun the main missions are, 100% in this game arent only annoying trough bugs, but straight up impossible sometimes.*

author: Detective Pikaboo
review: Overall a disappointment, but has some nicer qualities.Pros:- Good graphics- Classic LEGO humor- Nice voice work- Plenty of collectiblesCons- oPeN WoRld - Little to no challenge in both combat and puzzles- VERY short levels, with many iconic levels from the complete saga skipped entirely- Lackluster multiplayer experienceYou can tell the development of this game was mostly focused on the unnecessary open world and the graphics instead of the actual fun parts of the game. While I do appreciate them trying something new, I feel like this game did not need an open world, as the fun of the classic lego games came from the fun level design. The main gripe I have is the story mode missions. They are short, easy, and lacking in fun puzzles, and to top it off there aren't many of them. Many of the story mode missions are "walk here and watch a cutscene" and that's it. The fun missions are the boss fights, with the expanded combat mechanics they are somewhat interesting at first, but quickly get kind of samey. However, the multiplayer experience during these boss fights was not fun at all. I've only played up to episode III so far, so maybe they improve later, but in the Grevious, Palpatine, and Anakin boss fights, player one gets a lightsaber character and fights the boss for most of the time, while player two struggles to deal damage and find things to do during the fight. This was especially bad with the Anakin fight, where player two has to wait around and do nothing as either C3PO or R2-D2 while player one gets to actually fight as Obi-wan.At the end of the day, this game just makes me want to play The Complete Saga.

author: Kain Klarden
review: Ever since Lego Star Wars: The Video Game from 2005 Traveller's Tales has been almost exclusively developing the Lego-licensed action adventure videogames. And they all followed the template established by that 2005 original with very few and rather minor changes. Even though the mumbling voices and original movie clips were swapped for voice acting recorded specifically for the games, even though more open world segments and different mechanics were introduced, the formula of the games was rigid and predictable. Which is one of the main reasons, I stopped even looking in the direction of these titles after The Lord of the Rings title - playing these titles became way too boring. Which meant that I've missed a rather curious attempt at making the gameplay more varied and fun in the Ninjago Movie Video Game from 2017. I still got bored with it, but at least that one had some genuinely fun ideas to it (and wasn't developed by the main Traveller's Tales studio).Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga was supposed to be a refresher of the series. Not a revolution, necessarily, but a long needed evolution. It was built on a new engine, restructured the game world, reshuffled the ideas that were at the base of all previous Lego Star Wars titles and, based on reports, had a really messy development. It is a shame, then, that the end result of this effort is the same boring TT Games' Lego title we've seen for 17 years, just with a new coat of paint.In case you haven't had experience with the these titles, TT Games' Lego games are action adventure platformers with level based structure and some hub or open world segments. The Skywalker Saga in particular is mostly the open world where story-driven content can also happen, and only occasionally the classic linear level gameplay. Also unlike many older titles, the camera in the game is mostly controlled by the players, whereas in older titles it was often set to fixed camera angles. Being a Lego-licensed game, a big emphasis is put on how almost any piece of decoration on the level can be broken into Lego pieces, and performing this act also usually grants you "studs", which is the in-game currency for purchasing upgrades and items. Though, that often requires the collection of other hidden items that might be locked behind a puzzle or a little challenge.Additionally, all characters are grouped into separate "classes", each of which have their own unique abilities that cannot be used by others. For example, only Jedi or Sith can move objects with Force, while only the "villains" have access to thermal detonators to explode items built with a specific material. This means that during each open world or linear level segment you will be coming across things you cannot interact with as part of the story-driven campaign, as the characters available to you are locked at that point, but you will be able to later revisit them in Free play mode, where you can use any unlocked character in any level. It's simple, rather intuitive and fun and can be enjoyed by players of essentially any age, as these titles are often very easy. In fact, the change to how the health and item collection works in this game, combined with less death pits and invisible damage fields, makes this entry even easier to play than before. Which is totally fine and fits the "for all ages" idea of the series.Problem is - this is all fun if you've never played any of the previous entries, but if you have, there's hardly any reason to play the new game. It has changes, yes, and some of them are good. Already mentioned player health situation is an improvement. The combat is a bit more involved too, with combo possibilities and counter attacks - nothing as fancy as that Ninjago game, but still less boring than it used to be. The abilities are, arguably, better handled and the concept of having a story-driven moment (like a boss fight) as part of the open world exploration is good, as there's no need to build a unique level just for the sake of a one-off situation. But it doesn't really feel any different. And the open world structure is only going to be fun who's not already bored with the typical open world games in addition to TT's Lego games.The entire time playing The Skywalker Saga I couldn't drop the feeling as if I was playing a game from early 2010s. Sure, the series did evolve from the 2005 formula, but to another outdated formula. The abundance of boring mini-games, the overreliance on terribly unexciting and pointless QTEs, the open world that exists just so they could have many markers with "stuff to collect" on the screen... Lego Star Wars: The Video Game felt exciting and creative but limited by the technological restrictions of what could be achieved in 2005. The Skywalker Saga has none of that excitement, creativity or freshness. It's bigger, longer and more pretty, but is nowhere near as fun as what that first game was for the time. Even as far as humor goes, it's shockingly tame and boring most of the time, with very few jokes that land well and are not simple slapstick comedy. And taking them as standalone "retellings" of the movies is still impossible, just as it was with the older titles - you have to know the originals to understand what's going on and why.Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is an evolution for the series, sure. And it is probably going to be fun for those who have never ever played a Traveller's Tales Lego game before and likes Star Wars. Oh and if you're among those who care about games packing as much "hours of content" as possible, you might find yourself doing things here for a long time. For others, though, I just don't see the appeal.

author: Lucasif
review: Just didn't do it for me. It's not even like I don't like LEGO games anymore; I just played LEGO Harry Potter a few months ago for the first time and enjoyed it a lot, but this game is just too much of a change. I liked the simplicity of the old games where it was more about exploring an area, where enemies could be defeated with one swing, where the camera wasn't following the player character so close it feels like you can see individual strands of LEGO hair.It's worth considering when buying this game that you might not enjoy it, so be prepared to keep track of your playtime so you can refund it if you get an hour or two into it and realise that you haven't enjoyed a single moment of it. It seems like a rare reaction to the game, but I guess I can't give any other opinion other than my own based on my own experiences.Such a shame too, I was looking forward to this for years. Here's hoping to anyone reading this that you have a better experience than I did.

author: Frankenslug
review: I got this game on a deal, thinking it was a bargain. I play lots of the Lego games and I thought this would be one of the best. It was fun to start off with, but as soon as you start a mission in a ship, it doesn't let you go up or down! I found this out at the end of The Phantom Menace, when young Anakin destroys the Trade Federation's ship, a level that should have taken me 10-15 minutes. Due to the steering issues, it took me nearly an hour and a half. I then hoped that it would not happen again, for it was fine when flying around planets, I started episode 2 and within the first 10 minutes of playing, I got another flying level. If you would use this with a keyboard and mouse, DON'T GET IT. This game is alright, but no way near as good as the original games which you can buy for nearly a quarter of the price on Steam as The Complete Saga. The free play worlds are expansive but lame. The game has hardly any challenge to it, with most of episode 1 being travelling. This game is extremely disappointing. If you can get this game for under five pounds, then it may be worth it but I would say, DO NOT BUY. If you want a Lego Star Wars game then get the Complete Saga, which has episode 1-6 in, or if you want a Lego game with space travel, then Lego Marvel's Avengers. All in all DON'T BUY THIS, IT'S FRUSTRATING, BORING AND DOES NOT WORK PROPERLY, ULTIMATELY LEGO STAR WARS THE SKYWALKER SAGA IS A DISAPPOINTMENT.

author: gabein8er
review: This game is bad.On every conceivable level a game could have something wrong with it, this game does. Some are less egregious than others, but the issues are not just surface level and patchable.There are many weird glitches and hiccups. I've had various visual bugs and random crashes or larger, more baffling glitches that confused us while playing. Nothing terribly gamebreaking, but the game doesn't need any help there.But the underlying game here has striking issues that can't just be patched out. I'm not going to write a full essay about everything wrong with the game, but I can give some highlights. Everyone tends to agree that lego games got worse when they started talking. The same holds here. Instead of being "Star Wars Charades" it's "Star Wars on Fast Forward." There's the occasional funny visual gag, but the majority of cutscenes are condensing, like, 10-20 minutes into 1 making sure to hit every meme line so people think it's funnier than it actually is. The combat and puzzle design aren't stellar, but lego games were never great at that. What they were good at though, was level design. To this day, I can recall exact screens and level layouts from the older lego games I played years ago, but the same can not be said about this game that I've been playing since it came out. The level and world design philosophy seems to have been "big" instead of "good" or "memorable."There are other issues that become apparent as you play, but the most significant and baffling one, to me at least, is the treatment of player 2. So frequently in story missions player 2 just has nothing to do. Lego games have always given the more important character to player 1, but they always made sure that player 2 was doing something fun and helpful. Here, player 1 will be Luke fighting Vader and player 2 will be R2-D2 that can't easily do anything to Vader and whom Vader just ignores. They can run around and break things and get past 3 things in the entire level. And that's one of the better examples.Let me reiterate.THEY DID NOT CONSIDER PLAYER 2INALEGOGAMEYou can tell from some of the dialogue and moments that are people who worked on this that legitimately love Star Wars and wanted to do what they could to do it justice. But they were drowned out, likely by corporate interests wearing mouse ears.I have enjoyed playing this game to make fun of it. It is a funny kind of bad. But you pretty much need to play with a heckling partner and that person has to be fine being basically useless for most of the campaign.I would give it a thumbs up for that enjoyment, but I do not wish to contribute to the bafflingly high rating this game already has.

author: Sr. Chan
review: Context: I'm by no means a die-hard Star Wars fan, I have watched all the films and I liked them. I'm going to go against what people are saying here. I feel the game is good overall, it encompasses all the episodes of the franchise which are detailed and show great quality, throwing in the visual gag here and there.I think that's where the positives end for me.You are thrown in at the deep-end with no real guide on how you accomplish certain tasks or what means what. Because the game is so all-encompassing and vast you spend most of your time doing other things unrelated to the game (e.g. there is >1000 Kyber Bricks to collect!), you could easily sink 500 hrs into this game for 100% completion, but that distracts you from the main story so much that it becomes demotivating to play.The gameplay within the story is quite flat, the general consensus of the playthrough is - go to this place, follow this person, fight these people, cutscene. I know I haven't played a lot of the game, but that seems like the general consensus to me. The menu system isn't perfect (it could be worse) and can be confusing to navigate at times. I think if you are a Lego/Star Wars fanatic, then you will love this game because you will get much more out of it than any other John/Jane Doe, however for a more general audience, it falls a bit flat.

author: McLovin

author: Blacknred
review: As much as I want to love this bit of nostalgia, the lack of a hub world where you can see all the characters you've unlocked and purchase things from an actual vendor is such a bummer. This open world format in a lego game isn't a step backwards or forwards, its walking off of a cliff. My heart goes out to the folks who worked on this game having to put in months of crunch time to make this happen. Some of the other new features are interesting, but frankly there's too much of this nonsense with abilities and lengthy exploration with no purpose in what should be another simple yet satisfying lego game. I will still play this since I paid for it, but this could have been leagues better if they even just copy pasted the complete saga + force awakens into this with a fresh coat of paint and a new hub world. To be clear, this isn't bad per se, its still entertaining enough, but they were clearly trying to play off nostalgia with this title and then delivered something completely different. Worth it if it ever goes on sale for 80% off.

This game is flawless.

Sure, some of the cutscenes were goofy and funny, especially when streaming the game to my friends over discord, but that's really all I can say, the entire experience I was just waiting for the next mission to end, I said in the phantom menace "the game feels like it's rushing this episode", attack of the clones felt long while not even being long, and revenge of the sith was okay, but that terrible excuse for co op in the final mission is insulting. Game was fun for a little, once the repetitive monotonous illusion faded, there was nothing for me to see.
