author: GingasVR
review: I'm more in the middle, but I'm gonna say I don't recommend this. I'm not going to write an Essay, but here's the pros and cons+ It's very pretty (even despite of the Lego aesthetic, this is a very good looking game)+ Prob the largest Open World Star Wars Game available (If you like star wars.. you can fully explore a lot of iconic areas which is pretty cool) +/- Voice acting, some of it is pretty good, particularly people like obi-wan, they also got a lot of the VA from the clone wars TV show - Missions are jarring, strange and don't really have any connection (A symptom of the new Open world format.. but if you're nostalgic for the original Lego star wars games.. a lot of these "missions" are just walking in the open world to a cut scene.. which is a let down from the sprawling puzzle filled levels of the original game)- No custom character creator (again.. one of my favorite features of the original.. yeah they have a ton of characters you can play as.. but what's the point of unlocking them if you can't use parts to make your own?)- No online coop. This seems like game that really shines with coop.. not having any option to play it online with a friend in 2022 seems like a weird decision as I feel that would increase the fun by quite a bit.- Puzzles seem too easy/non-existent.. maybe because I started with episode 1? But I remember more puzzles from the original games. -/+ it's way to easy.. YES this is a kids game.. but I grew up with the original star wars games.. and while they weren't super difficult games.. they were harder then whatever this is trying to do... They also revamped the combat system with combos ect... which is AWESOME, there's just NO way to actually fully experience the new combat system since everything can be killed in 1 hit or mashing buttons.I will say boss battles is where the system shines more.... it's still easy as hell but it at least takes slightly more advantage of the combat. If you're super into star wars you'll prob like this.. it's also a cool experience to travel around these iconic locations in an open world format.. but it just seems like a ton of stuff in this game.. but it's all so useless.. like the perk system.. IT'S Pointless... WHY bother?Whats that saying about Bethesda games? As wide as an ocean.. as deep as a puddle.. Seems like TT Games is headed in that directionEDIT:  I just finished episode Revenge of the Sith.. and honestly that one was pretty good.. way more combat sections and felt more like the  lego star wars of 2005. Clone wars was also a bit better than episode 1.. but the factory section was lagging like crazy.. and I have a 3080ti and only play at 1080p so that was a bit bizzare. Still going to keep the negative review.. but the game seems to be getting better.. episode 1 was horrible up until the fight with Darth maul though....

author: Yakov Godshu
review: My negative is primarily at the price i got it for i wouldn't recommend. maybe at the price the complete saga is at when not on sale($20) i might recommend, but not what i got it for which is $45 on sale. it doesn't replace the complete saga, but is an interesting alternative to it and i have played the complete saga recently. the positives are that the combat is fun and general exploration is nice as you can traverse the locations that were in the movies. the negatives it's crashed on me twice so far and it had hanged on me during transport from dagobah to bespin and i had to shut down the game and boot it up again. all the vehicle levels just aren't fun except for the space missions as being forced to move forwards, or backwards for the sub level, in a collectathon just doesn't work and i had crashed way too often especially when for some odd reason the vehicle decides to point downward despite me trying to go the opposite. the challenges on every mission are way too vague, way too specific and therefore annoying to do, or both like attack of the droids in the level so uncivilized in which i completed it's task but it wasn't given to me and my only guess is that the ai teammate died preventing me from obtaining it. speaking of challenges that goes to my next negative, the game feels bloated. we don't need 1200 kyber bricks having 3 attached to true jedi is unnecessary, most of the challenges are not fun and half if not more of the ones attached to exploration feel like they could be removed. when i choose free play it should auto skip the cutscenes as i'll select the level, but be forced to still watch the cutscene, even the ones that are in the middle of a level. finally, and i don't know why this hasn't been implemented since they went open world, but no full episode replay. this needs to be fixed, the ability to not only do the levels but even replay the open world aspects aka the ability to replay an episode as if it's a new game while keeping the collectibles/ without having to make a new game. my finale remark about this game is to do what i'll be doing with what's left of the game for me, just play the campaign and nothing else. which is sad to me as i think lego games want you to %100 them, but i feel like this game is telling me not to by making it a miserable experience. all i can hope for now is now that i gave up on that maybe i'll enjoy what's left of it. i hope they take the good aspects from this game when making the next lego game while getting rid of the bad aspects.edit: got to episode 9 got stuck in an infinite hyperdrive and it kept happening after restarting so i gave up. i still stand by play the story and nothing else but this game needs more work on it. also the ability to wear imperial or first order clothing is very pointless and it should have just been another character instead and stealth and lego do not mix.Edit2: i found if you accepting any hauling missions the infinite hyperdrive can happen when playing through the story and was likely what caused it to happen from dagobah to bespin so i finished that and have completed the game.

author: Airlewe
review: TL;DR:  TSS brings almost nothing new to the LEGO Star Wars franchise, or Star Wars in general, and leaves an astounding amount out. It infantilizes it’s audience in a glaring misstep for a franchise that is nearly 45 years old and has proved it can grow with it’s audience without alienating it’s many generations of fans. Normally, I’d end with a judgement on whether to recommend a game or not, but this game is special. Not only can I not recommend it, I urge fans to not play it. I urge newcomers to the franchise to stay away from it. This game butchers Star Wars to such an extent that I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game be anything approaching a first impression for a new fan. It get’s an incomprehensible amount of the movies wrong and omits an even larger, more staggering amount; and inexcusable oversight for a game that bills itself on being the definitive collection of all nine movies. Do not play this game. If you want to play the first 6 movies in LEGO form, play the Complete Saga. TSS has no reason to exist, and is actively damaging to the legacy of the movies.Full Review here: Edit: It's been a few months, and the thought of how badly this game handled both Star Wars and the legacy of Lego video games still makes me sad

The missions feel shorter and less saitsfying then in previous entries, and focus on smaller or just strange sections of the movie, but I guess it was a way to differenciate it from the Complete Saga.What's here is good, and very fun. If you're a fan, you needn't think twice. Otherwise, wait for a sale, I'd say.

author: Scp-230
review: if you're a fan the the complete saga that was released back in 2007, this game is an excellent proof of how much better jar jar was when he didn't talk.lets start with things i like, the level up system is fun, collecting cyber bricks and exchanging them for boosts is a nice way to reward completionistsbeing able to force lift objects and chuck them at enemy's is very the force unleashedthe combos and fluidity of combat animations is very fallen order, and the 6 "recreations" of the first 6 movies are interestingnow for the badthe 6 recreations, are bland, they feel empty compared to the complete saga, the complete saga had enemies around every corner, places that were damn near invisible, and it oozed charm like a stab wound oozes blood, it also didn't feel "new", i mean it is new, new areas, new voice lines, new animations, but it also feels like some of the good parts of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ star wars games got stitched together by the Hollywood algorithm,some of the open ish world locations are so stupid, aside from the people who draw rule 34 of jar jar no one cares about the place he lives, yet it was turned into an open world area, a place that was only in 2 scenes as i remember, and it gets an open world, and while i wanted new i didn't want new at the cost of charm, in complete saga you'd go through one of 6 doors to access one of 6 chapters and as you unlocked characters you could see them running about meaning the more you played the livelier it got, now you get open ish world areas with like 6-7 people sprinkled through outand don't get me started on the dumb ass idea to add dlc to lego star wars, each of the two first trilogies acted as its own lego set so to speak, with the complete saga being a lego set that has both prior lego sets combined into a bigger set with more than just the two lego sets in it. but a lego game with dlc is like buying a lego kit that was missing some of the detail pieces and in their stead was a handwritten note saying " ♥♥♥♥ you and give me the price of a lego set for the 10 missing pieces" at the time of writing this a game that only has theoretically 2/3 the content is going for 1/5 the standard price, and 1/6 the full price, aka the complete saga charges 5 dollars per set while this game charges 20 dollars per set. honestly go buy the complete saga, added bonus it doesn't contain episodes 7-9 and jar jar finally shut the ♥♥♥♥ up, aka all the worst parts are removed, and when you pay for the full game you get the full game and not just most of the game wit the last little bit costing extra.as of april 30 i bought the game played more of it, and i still agree, its bland, like white bread and a glass of water bland.

author: A Lot A Nuts
review: I've been looking forward to this game for over 10 years, I've played the complete saga over and over again and yet this doesn't capture the same magic for me.I've played episodes 4, 5, half of 6, 1, 2 and half of 3 and the levels and puzzles are just far too short, shallow and easy. Despite the voice acting, it feels like no character has any proper depth. The story is told in extremely fast increments, within a 2 minute cutscene Lando both greets you in cloud city, betrays you, Han gets frozen in carbonite and then Lando saves you, all without any gameplay. Lego Star Wars the Complete Saga was able to make two levels out of that sequence each lasting atleast 15 minutes. But it seems like the skywalker saga just wants to get it over with asap. It's fine adding all this extra content but at the end of the day we came for the skywalker saga, not "lets run around and help people without doing any of the story for 75% of this game". The levels and sidequests also have no depth and it feels like you're just running around with no real goal.The dagobah mission in episode 5 is my absolute favourite in the complete saga, you start off as Luke, unable to use the force unless you have yoda on your back and throughout the level you learn what you can do and you feel Luke learning. Puzzles are solved, you connect with Luke's struggles, and it all ends with a boss battle against vader where you use everything you've learnt. You can really feel Luke's growth. Compare that to this game where you've already seen Luke using his lightsaber on Hoth, Yoda is introduced in about 15 seconds and even though there's voice acting you get nothing like the relationship he and Luke have in TCS. He comes in like a weirdo, Luke says "I need master Yoda" and then Yoda says to Kenobi "He isn't ready". Luke says "I am ready" and then the level starts and lasts a total of 5 minutes. You jump across some logs, jump up a tree, have a minute-long battle with Vader and you're done, move on to Cloud city (which also only lasts 5 minutes). I guess the game expects you to fully explore the planet but when I want to do a story mission it's because I want a break from the constant exploring, not so I can get the story over with as fast as possible.The new combat mechanics are fine, I enjoy shooting but wish it wasn't so clunky and slow. Dodging, aiming and shooting aswell as melee combat have all been done extremeley well. The lightsaber combat is fun and I really enjoy the mindtricks you can do with force powers. The boss battles in the prequels are also extremely well done. The only issue I have is the small delay when aiming and taking cover while shooting. Having good combat is amazing, but when I can just run past all the enemies with a droid without them noticing it's a problem. In TCS no enemy would attack droids and I'm glad they kept that, but when droids can solve puzzles, push buttons, build, push objects and pull levers, there are entire sections that can just be skipped. I played through cloud city the first time by running to the end with C3PO, only stopping for one puzzle. It was only later when I decided to go back because I felt bad for skipping it that I actually enjoyed the level. I know that's my fault but when a game is that easy to run through, there's a big problem.Ship levels are slow and somehow they made the snow speeder level worse than in TCS. Not only is it shorter but they made tying down the ATATs so much slower and less destructive. In free play the ship battles are actually pretty fun but the story missions are just disgusting to fly around. At one point I got stuck in a backflip loop because my ship wouldn't turn fast enough. Even in free play there are so many issues; 3 puzzles I tried to do got softlocked until I reloaded. I got given 2 astromech missions which took away my controls until I rebooted. The character selection is slow and clunky, using the force (which was fun even in TCS) is slow and clunky, climbing up ladders is slow and clunky, pressing buttons is slow and clunky. Everything has been slowed down to this crawl and there's no way to speed it up. EVEN BREAKING THINGS HAS BEEN MADE LESS SATISFYING because your attacks barely destroy anything and guess what... they're slow and clunky.It seems like all the impact of building has been taken away, there's a soft sound that plays and your character flails their arms a bit but there's no oomf behind it. In TCS you had a satisfying clunk sound and the characters looked like they were tossing every piece. in Skywalker Saga there's barely a sound for building and the characters have no emotion while building... NO OOMFLevels and hub worlds also seem very barren, Hoth, Theed Palace, Jabba's Palace, Prequel Tatooine and Cloud City just seem big without there being much going on; while places like mos Eisley, Genosian Arena, and the Jedi Temple are full of so much detail that walking into that area seems so magical to me. It doesn't help that some of these areas are only seen for a split second in actual gameplay. While visually amazing, it lacks any kind of depth or simple problem solving from TCS. In my opinion, they replaced a lot of what TCS did right with a lot of empty open world where most of the game is spent going from quest marker to quest marker and where the puzzles are randomly scattered across the world rather than in the levels. There seemed to be a lot of "go here, pick this up and go back" with little to nothing other than very similar side quests in between. When you want a break from the samey side quests and do a story mission, it lasts all of 5 minutes and has as much depth as a small puddle on a rainy day with the cutscenes trying to fit as many references as possible into the dialogue and the missions being small snippets of a bigger pictureI honestly can't play this game any longer. It has SO MUCH potential and yet it's disappointed me at every turn. The first 30 mins to an hour of each era were fun but after that, it just got repetitive and boorish. The fact that a 10-year-old game still holds up better to me is extremely disappointing. Hopefully it gets fixed but the issues I have with it are from the game's core and it just can't be redeemed

author: Zathereth
review: The game is simply awful compared to any other Lego game in existence. Each episode is the equivalent of about one mission (exaggerated, but basically true) in any other Lego game; meaning the game is nowhere near as massive as they made it seem it would be. Playtime is 13 and 1/2 hours on average if you google it. 13 hours is perfectly fine for the typical Lego game, but not one that aspires to be 9 stories in one. That is less than 2 hours per episode, most of which you are breaking things for studs. From personal experience, episode 1 took 2 hours (most of it messing around with the new features). They basically spent all of their time creating massive, pretty environments and none on the actual game. They skip through each episode, leaving you with no character attachment and no coherent story. It was like watching a movie, which you needed to read the book to even know who the characters are. While I do see that some may flaunt going back to planets, as if the main story is just the side-gig, main story + extras is only a 23 hour playtime. So, if the main story is not the draw of the game, why are the extras only 10 hours worth of content? (Completionist at an average of 39 hours) Besides the story and game length just not being what it should be for an idea this massive, they add many new features that are simply not used AND not explained properly. You are tossed in with a whole new menu setup, getting spammed with random tutorials that pause the game, while neglecting to explain main parts of the new functions. The whole upgrade system is virtually pointless, you just run through the levels smashing everything anyway (like a typical Lego game). The puzzles have been majorly replaced with things that you button mash. There is literally a single puzzle per level, copied and pasted about 3 times. There was a single build-able in the entire first episode. What in the world am I even playing if this Lego game doesn't have any build-ables? I also didn't like how menu-based this game was. In Lego Villains you would travel by vehicle, air, foot, etc to your location (just as an example). I found that most of the time in this game I was in a menu clicking to start an episode or travel to a new planet, rather than getting in a ship and flying there or walking around the planet. It felt like there was never a break from the mission to just go around beating up civilians or running each other over with vehicles (or whatever you like doing in-between missions of a normal Lego game).Overall, my main gripe with this game is the lack of structure. I really just feel like this game is all over the place compared to the normal linear setup. I do understand that they are trying out something very new with this game, and I am interested in seeing them improve upon it; however this feels like an experiment rather than a fleshed out game. Perhaps I simply didn't experience it the way it was intended to be experienced, but that still points to flaws in their in-game communication to the player rather than my naivety when presenting something new like this.

Not only does the game run poorly, its also kinda boring after the novelty of flying between planets wears off you'll complete one trilogy and never want to pick  it up again. author: aR.
review: I have/had fun, but you shouldn't buy this or give it a good review. Levels are too short, the galaxy not interesting and rather empty. Most of all the prequels, which are the worst part of the game in a lot of ways. Ep4 to Ep9 are better, but face the same problems.  > Short levels, different from the complete Saga, but mostly downgrades.> Puzzles are (still) a waste of time - and there are a lot of them.> Very bad performance, the droid factory was at a "stable" 12 FPS most of the time. FPS instantly drop if you destroy multible things, very few levels stay at 60+ FPS. Lower Settings help, but not much. > "Free play" is the focus of the game, but has the same problems as the rest of it.> It looks good, but especially mini-figures could use better textures. It lacks the look of real LEGO and the details of the LEGO MOVIE(s).> The quests are okay-ish, nothing to be looking forward to.> A lot of Secrets/Rooms (and so on) can be entered in different ways - GREAT! - which means you find yourself in the same rooms regulary because you entered it via another "door".> You can't switch fast (one button press) between characters in free play, you have to open a menu for that and another one for more choices. (Obviously switching works, but only to characters that are already activated)> Cutscenes can't be skipped (the first time), because they've put a lot of work into them (i guess).> Quite a lot of loading screens, waiting and general lack of QoL featues.> No character creator (i don't like them and don't need them, but the community seems quite fond of them).> Most of the game seems like a base to be built on, but far away from a finished game.> Cyber Bricks are so damn boring to collect and lose all meaning if you have bought the few good skills (and Extras).The game was delayed more than once, the developers were constantly overworked and went through a development hell, the end product perfectly reflects that. DLCs cant fix these problems, neither will a few patches.  The game should receive FREE updates that fix the performance, bugs and the lacking content.> Bigger levels for the story, less focus on useless RPG elements. > Secret and Bonus levels, more customization. > More fun stuff like "gun sounds replaced by pew noises".> More ways to spend studs (the most expensive character i've seen costs 2 million, i have billions.)> Options for Splitscreen (there is only vertical, it kills my braincells)> Better AI, because they get stuck, ignore puzzles  and are pretty useless.> A menu which is easier to navigate and does not result in me questioning my life decisions.> Bring back the original Obi VS Anakin level, i beg you, it was one of, maybe even the best level.> Please for the love of Space Jesus let me zoom out the camera, it feels like playing Batman in the worst way possible.

author: tallo
review: right on the face of it, unskippable cutscenes are UNFORGIVABLE in any context.  Here are my highlights:The SW content you came here for (NewHope, ESB, RTJ) is really cool.  I did this part first.Luke especially is using original dialogue and it sounds really good to me. I think i'm spotting some EU content here and there, or maybe just other SW game callbacks which isn't much different.  Hard to be sure but it feels that way.  Like i'm pretty sure Slave I has had cannons that sounded similar.FIrst time playing an area you are limited to certain characters, Afterwards, you can come back in 'free play' and be anyone you want.  There are about 8 classes with different skills but you get at least one of each early enough so this is how you really explore the area and go for collectibles or whatever.  Boba Fett I was able to get early enough;  I like how he calls himself a jetpack mechanic.    i wasn't expecting the apparently neutral bounty hunter faction that neither side seems to shoot on site.  Stormtrooper disguises work like this, too.   Mildly confusing here though - sometimes you pick up and wear a st disguise, other times, you actually are a version of the character that just is the st version, or a non-helmeted st (han and luke in new hope are like this).The puzzles aren't overly complicated, just enough to be a bit satisfying.  At best.   getting some of the collectibles are a little challenging, but nothing so far I've wanted to research online.   its a kids game so the piloting is easy, gunplay is fairly assisted, and melee is generally a mash-a-thon.Those are the best parts.here's where i take some exceptions:Some of the puzzles are downright childish.  Press an arrow key when indicated, really?Whatever it's a kids game cant set too high of a bar here, but it could really be nice to adjust difficulty and rewards around some of these,"Free-play" in an area isn't quite.  I wasn't finished wasting ugnauts in cloud city, but something triggered and  forced me to continue the story, AND switched me to ESB Luke(?)I mentioned the unskippable cutscenes.  Plan to read the scrolling text.  every time. slowly.There are MANY sections of mandatory cinematics,  these are WAY more prominent in the disney content.  way, way more prominent.  here's the part I'm salty about:my plan was to enjoy the good movie parts and ignore the plot for the sh**ty movie parts.  just approach these like a game i don't already know the plot to:  NOT POSSIBLE.   you get force fed the disney content.  like i played the original trilogy and the cutscenes were what they were, but then i started force awakens and  this really ratcheted up.  Now it's all snap to black backdrop and dolly zoom,  it's the contrast that kills me.  Luke doesn't get this kind of treatment. I DON't want to be force-fed story-lines about rey or finn or poe or jarjar.  yet they really seem to be the focus.  Rey in particular is front and center of every startup.   Every time i start the game, she says "I need someone to show me my place in all of this."  Well i have an answer: just like cpt marvel, you didn't earn your powers, that's why your place in all of this is to be despised by many people who understand what's happening. (girl-power is chicom propaganda to denigrate masculinity and reduce western birth rates)

author: Nemo Nobody
review: All of my childhood memories stuck into an open world game. I've played every Lego star wars, and the clone wars game was by far my favorite. my only con is they didn't take the army mechanics from that game and incorporate it into at least a few missions. I really enjoy the game however. Feels like a true successor and upgrade to the complete saga, with the sequels added to fully round things up. When it comes to bugs and UI issues, I think there's a bit that can be improved on. I'm sure no keyboard and mouse player is enjoying the lack of a cursor in the entire game. The into screen is annoying because you have to listen to Rey go "I want to know my place in all of this", as there's like 10 seconds of animations between all the characters. The hit boxes on the Kyber bricks are sometimes finicky, and the camera lock for targets can get extremely frustrating. I've black screened only a couple times, with no legitimate "crashes" where it shuts the game. Overall though its a great game with lots of exploration, funny quips, unique characters and mechanics, an amazing skill tree, funny extras, while also condensing the story enough to where the pace of the game is purely on you. 9/10, 10/10 if cons were fixed, and this is a score based off of only other Lego games.

author: PiKA
review: After 20 hours of variable performance in the same areas and reaching Episode 7, I am blocked from all progress because of a bug that has been documented since release, instead of patching this problem withing the first 20 days of release they decide to add more paid DLC. The actual missions in the game are a small portion of my playtime, 5 missions each episode (all can be beaten in 7-10 minutes at most even if you are destroying everything and going for all collectables) broken up with open world travel sequences to the next cutscene (sometimes a forced walking sequence that the NPC they will not continue their path without you walking with them at a snails pace.) The cutscenes feel alien with the script being ripped from the movies but the visual gags treating you like a ADHD riddled child and having a new "joke" every second. The "new" combat system replaces the X spam with spamming the same 3 buttons because anything else would be inefficient. Bosses are just dodge the red and wail on a reskin enemy with hyper-armour, and blasters are reduced to generic cover based shooting you would usually see during the PS3 era of third-person shooters trying to be Gears. The open world part is a boring collect-athon that gives the player no real reason to do and definitely padded out most of my play time. Compared to previous Lego Star Wars games, the main levels are outdone but the much cheaper and more complete experience of The Complete Saga and the over world is outdone by The Clone Wars, with its planetary evasion mode and galactic conquest system.It's crazy to me how this was the game that they took more than their usual year to make and it feels significantly more hollow than ever, despite being the biggest game with the amount of collectables and literal play space it is by far the most vapid and boring Lego game to date.

author: smollboy
review: This was just so disappointing. The trailers hyped the game to be this amazing game that was a love letter to Star Wars fans, but instead it came out as boring, tedious, brain rotting, and down right insulting to players. The game has no charm whatsoever, the gameplay is piss poor easy, the boss fights are the same monotonous dodge then hit garbage, and there's no challenge at all. I see people online claiming how the gameplay is so amazing and unique, like what is so unique about it? All your doing is the exact same thing again and again. There's also way too much stuff that doesn't need to be. In Revenge Of The Sith, you have a mission where you need to go to Palpatine's office to confront him and you have to play as Mace Windu and Kit Fisto to confront him. Wouldn't have it been so cool if this was leading to a boss against Palpatine where you have to fight him as Mace and Kit? Well TT Games doesn't and only has that be a cutscene where both of them get axed. In the same episode, you have to play as Padme to board her ship to go to Mustafar. You know what would've been better? Playing as Obi-wan to sneak into Padme's ship without getting caught by her. In The Empire Strikes Back, you have a mission where you need to rearrange satellite dishes to find Luke, as oppose to playing as Luke and having a boss fight against the Wampa. Another thing, there is a tutorial for everything! Even when you're done learning all the controls, the game will still hold your hand like a baby and tell you what to do! But the one big sin this game committed is that it has no charm. Look, Complete Saga wasn't perfect either. In that game a lot of the times for bosses you would use your jump attack to beat them. But that game had charm all over it. All of the old Lego Games had charm. Lego Batman 1 and 2, Lego Indiana Jones, Lego Marvel Superheroes (the 1st one not the 2nd), and even Lego Star Wars 3. This game has no charm. The gameplay is repetitive and boring, the boss fights are far too easy, and there's just nothing fun about it at all. And I know there's gonna people coming to tell me "ItS a GaMe MaDe FoR kIdS oFcOuRsE iTs GoNnA bE eAsY", to that I say kids deserve better than this. Heck I've seen kids game that are challenging. Games like Fortnite, TF2, Genshin Impact, Smash Bros, Dragon Ball FighterZ, etc. I've seen kids who play these games and I have some dignity to see that some of them are quite good at those games, because the people who made those games cared about making games anyone could enjoy whether you like them or not. TT games didn't care about making a good game here and only cared about making money. And if they don't care, then why should you?

author: Shwan "Johnson" M.A.
review: I have always loved the LEGO game series and I hate to be negative but the game is quite frustrating, From gather mission to trailing mission, it all sort seems like the gameplay is not there. The combat is just mashing buttons and the blaster is just about shooting at someones head three times in a row. Personally I hate the Camera moment, I love the camera moment on the old games however it seems that will never be returining. No hub world which is quite sad, instead you get this open world which me and my friend easly exploited which was probably the best bart of the game unfortuanlly. I gotta hand it to them tho, the game looks amazing and the VA and cinematics are pretty epic too! Even funny at times! However the lackluster gameplay, wanky controls, boring mission, gamebreaking bugs and teadious battle mechanics just puts me off. Sorry.5/10, its better then most big titles that has come out the past year but it come no where near close to the classic of LEGO games like Star Wars the Complete Saga or Indiana Jones. I know a lot of people enjoy this game but it was just not for me.Update + 50 hours of play from previous review. I'm a lego 100% type of guy, every lego game I've come accros has been 100%. However this game is so buggy and broken that I have been effectivly LOCKED from completing the game!!!. I'm quite literaly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, crinyg, farting and cyming right now. This is absoluty unacceptble! When are we getting a patch bro, how are people enjoying this buggy sheehs. I know, I know most people dont do 100% runs or atleast I think so. If they where they would be fumming right now just like me. Constant crashes, bugs, slow load times even on an SSD and general instability. I've 100% game, its not a beauty. I'd rather play the original or just another title entirely. The gameplay is very stale, the most effecient way to kill is to use general grevious, spaming lightsaber throw or using bountyhunters multishot and using anything makes the boring fight take even longer. In the old games enemies where defeated super easily but that was the point! You defeat with a yoink sa ploinky puzzle and dazzle em up with anything you have. Oh an BTW the puzzles, jesus christ. Around 700 puzzles and about 70% are about opening this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ box with a kyber brick. Taking Data Cards fellt like the most under achvining thing I've ever gatherd in a video game. Its just not fun to gather 700 kyber bricks that are hidden in plain sight and you are just looking for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ target, swtich or button to press every single time. Now there are a few bangers, gotta admit that but they arent that memrabel, atleast I cant remeber them. The minikits in the episodes was the good shiz unfortuanly there is only 225 minikits but 1166 bricks. Character switching is annoying, in old games you just press a button and you could in a matter of seconds switch to your needed character, in this game if it aint in your stupid submenu then you go scroll through like two menus just to get the charactor. The game barely saves the characters you select and sometimes just switches them. Platforming was very good, it was awesome, espacily picking characters who cant use the little jedi poles but jumping on them anyways just for an extra chalange, good times. Its been three weeks and no patches only more DLC, quite sad really. I have no ill will towards the developers but this game is kinda stinky tho. Bugs, Crashes, Incorrect mission trackers and more. The most annoying is probably; if you have a capital ship and are doing mission in which you are delivering cargo in hyperspace but are being stopped by some thugs/impire/first order/CIS with only small fighters (dont know how they manage that, hell they cant even stop one ship in episod 8 even tho they have like 100 Capital Ships, sheeehs). Anyway, a very low poly version of your capital ship will always be in sight and if you picked the executar you probably spawned inside it. The capital ship which is basically in the middle of the entire fight and all 3 of them is completely ugly and you cant colide with it, nor does it help in your battle, that would've been awesome. Or maybe even capital ship and capital ship action like classic Battlefront. Also space battles can eat my stinky gym clothes, or just space flight in general is sooo stinky. Its like playing the new battlefront all over again. They should've just taking the control scheme from the classic battlefront or any real space fighting game. To put it bluntly the handling is like thorwing a disc around and hoping to that ends of said disc are facing the enemy. Instead of disc you are using your mouse and throwing it accros the room just the look behind you. Funny, you can press alt+ctrl to do a flip but not one that ends you looking backwards like older lego titles. This is a bit exagerated but nonetheless it felt bad. Overall, the game is meh and compared to older games its even more meh. It hints at being something amazing, with epic combat, puzzles and space battles (with those capital ships) but it end it is faded away into obscurity in a matter of moments. :(   ;(    :(      3/10, gonna buy the old complete saga on steam (PC) and try it out again, lets see if my view changes.

author: The UnFunny
review: Lego Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga is an example of how NOT to create a game for children, you can fill the game with all the little Easter eggs and cool details which there are plenty mind you, but in the end the core gameplay is the most important, how does Lego shake up the formula? By making the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game for the 400th time, I've played this game countless times, but it was just called Lego Ninja Go or Force Awakens or Batman, this gameplay loop is not only boring, but it doesn't have additional flavor, batman had the cool costumes, where here, there is no new stuff, the galaxy exploration isn't seamless and is a drag and the game holds your hand like crazy, it LITERALLY tells you via characters what to do, it is a game that is unoriginal about a toy that's only goal is to be creative, it is truly sad, however, if you're a Star Wars fan the humor is still amazing and hilarious, and it's worth it somewhat, if you like Star Wars pick it up since I had fun, but Steam doesn't let me choose an "In Between" option so looking how it has more cons than pros, I chose accordingly, one thing that bothers me is that they nailed a lot of stuff in Lego City: Undercover so how do you ♥♥♥♥ up 7 years later? 5/10, 6/10 for references

author: Zeus
review: I was looking forward to exploring the Lego Star Wars Galaxy, as my own created Sith character. I was longing for leveling through the Dark "Sith Skill Tree" This was what I was looking forward to."No custom character creation" is what I got.If you dont care about this. Then buy it. Its great.------------------------------------------------------------------ ----------------BUT! IF YOU DO CARE!----------------------------------------------------------------------------------To release LEGO® Star Wars™: The Skywalker Saga - without this feature is completly retarded, to a point where I question the integrity of the developers. Its like selling a car without wheels, eating Mexican food without diarrhea. I hope this is an early Aprils fool joke, and that an update with this feature will be on its way soon.

author: fjk1138
review: Overall I like it.  People complaining about short levels are probably not taking the time to explore more.+ Beautiful Graphics+ Sound and music lifted straight from the movies+ Voice actors very close to the originals in most cases+ Large level design, with lots to explore and destroy+ Same wacky Lego game humor as always- The overall interface is a bit confusing to figure out, there's basically too much to look at- Some glitches prevent level progression - I've had to repeat one level over again due to this- Lots of loading screens- Opening logos when starting up the game are long and tiresome (seriously, f*ck your logos - no one cares)Also, if you want to increase your framerate limit, do the following:- Enable "view hidden folders" in Windows Explorer if you haven't already- Navigate to C:/Users/[your name]/AppData/Roaming/Warner Bros. Interactive - Entertainment/LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga/PCCONFIG.txt- Look for "ScreenRefreshRate" and change the value to your desired fps cap

author: TheClap (Gonnorhea)
review: DO NOT BUY : THIS GAME IS A WASTE OF YOUR TIME AND MONEYHonestly this is an incredibly shallow experience. The only real marketing aspect for this game is that it has a lot of land to explore and walk around, and many lego characters to play. which is fine. but the majority of gameplay is simply following the path that the game shows you. there is so incentive to explore the game since the only prize is kyber blocks. which allow you to upgrade your characters, you quickly see that this game mechanic is UTTERLY USELESS to the actual gameplay. other than the upgrades that increase the length in which you can absorb studs. Even worse, SOME of the upgrades deal with things like character specific minigames. such as hacking a rebel terminal, or an astromech terminal, these upgrades simply reduce the time it takes to complete one, or skipping it entirely. which begs the question. WHY WOULD YOU ADD THIS FEATURE INTO THE GAME IF IT ITS TOGGLEABLE TO SKIP. This also goes for the toggle-able settings to turn off the button mashing features for certain mechanics. I played through the entire campaign, explored it a lot of it on freeplay. Got many many kyber bricks and even some of the cheat datacards you can find hidden around. Go play the older lego star wars games, if you havent. and you'll quickly realize this is a shallow and cookie cutter excuse of a lego star wars game. theyve lost touch with the whole point

author: i;m dad
review: Recommended, BUT wait for a performance patch or game-ready drivers.Even with a high end system there are some real performance issues, and the game also hangs with a black screen from time to time (usually on loading a new area or cutscene). I've also had some weird issues where NPCs or objects don't load, leaving puzzles unsolvable until reloading. Also, trying to capture/record/stream this game seems to make the performance issues even more pronounced. Some settings don't save properly, or save inconsistently, or will save but the next time you change something else and relaunch the game they'll reset themselves.Those issues aside, though, it's really nice to see a fresh take on the Lego game format. The switch to a more typical action-oriented 3rd person perspective really does a lot, and while one could argue there's no reason for this game to be open world, it doesn't particularly detract from the experience. Combat feels nice, certainly better than the original Lego Star Wars "mash attack button to win fights" combat. Puzzles are good, humor is the typical Lego games humor, which may or may not work for you. It's nice to see Tt finally perfect the Lego games formula, although it's a shame it had to happen at the same time as them losing the exclusive contract to make Lego games.It would be nice to see future DLC/expansion which includes content from the Clone Wars series as playable levels. Other pluses:- You can unlock characters from the holiday special (no Lumpy though)- You can kill younglings- You can turn off the voice acting for mumble mode (if you want)- Ghost Yoda returns

author: BlazingLegendEX
review: I played Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga so much as a kid.  I was hoping to relive some nostalgia with this game, and maybe its because I am now 22 years old playing a game clearly targeted for kids, but it just felt like this missed the mark from the little bit I played.  At first, it was alright but the game quickly got stale.  To my knowledge, there is no big hub area like the bar area in The Complete Saga.  Additionally, let me just quickly note my biggest gripes.  For starters, this is a game released on Steam in 2022 with NO NATIVE ONLINE CO-OP FUNCTIONALITY.  This alone almost turned me off of the game from the get-go.  Much of the memories I have with this franchise was playing with my brother, and I was hoping to play through this game with him and/or my friends but this is not possible outside of Steam Remote Play which can have its own issues.Also, I got to a level and could not enter it without the game crashing every single time.  This was the point where I ultimately decided to refund.  If I'm going to spend $60 on a game (I bought the deluxe version), I expect to get a lot more enjoyment than I was getting.  I was extremely excited for this game, and ultimately let down.  I will admit that once again, I am not the target audience, but this doesn't change my disappointment.  I would recommend this game for kids, but not for people hoping to relive their nostalgia like I was.

author: K̴̦̋ids Love ⁧⁧C̷iggies
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise?I thought not. It's not a story the Jedi would tell you. It's a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side, he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying.The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural.He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.memes aside only 2 hours in and i feel like a little kid again playing lego star wars TCS for the first time... great nostalgia

author: Herb
review: From what I have played so far the main story feels very short, the levels could be done in anywhere between 5-10 minutesThe Sequel Trilogy is definitely longer than the others but are a lot better than the moviesRating at this point is : 8/10After playing through all the story levels and 100% most of them and getting 60% galaxy completion it's apparent that this game is not finished, the levels are well done and lived up to my expectations however trying to 100% them has not, some missions require you to either know what you have to do beforehand or play it at least 3 times. The puzzles are also very infuriating in galaxy completion as there are more then there needs to be. Most puzzles repeat throughout playing and are just tedious to do. The lack of vehicles even featured in the cover art is also a clear sign that this game is unfinished as the cover art shows spider droids but the player is unable to use them and are only featured a few times/none. My initial rating was an 8/10My rating after completing the story, 100% a third of it and getting to 60% galaxy completion is 7/10I would still recommend but hopefully some bugs and features get improved

I was really looking forward to the Windu vs Palpatine fight and the Battle over Courescant, Neither of which were Playable. If you really want a lego Star Wars game, go get the classic on, This is not the Game you are looking for

author: RoxasUzumaki
review: This game was super hype when it came out and I think it was only because of nostalgia from the original one we had as kids. The game is very lacking in content and doesn't actually feel like its going through the whole story. Misses on some big parts for context in the movies and just always seems to have way too many goofy scenes to cover for it. The combat is also very weird. Combo system in a Lego game just seems really stupid honestly. The lightsaber combos just aren't that fun to learn or even continue to do. The game doesn't even tell you the combo system exists you just kinda figure it out. This game is almost like all modern media; taking a nostalgic or loved title and giving us the smallest amount of content.

author: ChillierSpore
review: **SHORT REVIEW:  I think it is good, but not as good as steam saying it is 94% positive. id give it:4/10 Uniqueness (Character Classes play the same... basically, and have no unique moves really..)8/10 Models and Animations9/10 Worlds and Exploration3/10 Level Design (Too Short... Lacking many parts from the ACTUAL MOVIES)10/10 Music, Star Wars OSTs are so Amazing.4/10 Bugs, there are random FPS drops in odd spots and Cut scenes being locked at 30FPS... what a Joke.3/10 Character Voices and WRONGNESS in Blaster Sounds (Jango, Boba, Han all had Unique blasters...)So yea, overall, 5/10... not great, but not terrible, it has been fairly fun so far, and It is nice to see the game in a new light.And anyone calling this a REMASTER is WRONG. VERY WRONG. It is a REMAKE not a REMASTER, nothing was Recycled from old Lego star wars games.*****************LONG REVIEW: ******************************Disappointed. I was Disappointed.So many things changed, and a lot... not in a good way.There are aspects I like, but there are so many things I really dislike.-----Let's start with a few things first.This game Looks amazing, the lighting, the characters actually have the mould lines.. like a Real Minifig would!The worlds are amazing and fun to explore. The models and animations are super well done.The Humor is back and there is Mumble-Speak, like the GOOD Lego games, I honestly HATED when they started speaking normal human talk. There are tons of things to collect and do., however the Kyber bricks... 1166 of them to collect, NO THANKS that is TOO MUCH. Lots of good characters, but most play exactly the same which is a downside...But I cannot say enough how the Open Worlds and Spaces are. Flying in Space and blasting things is just so fun!And then to go down to a planet and explore the worlds we see in the movies.-----Alright, on to the negative...-Characters Voices are not the same, a few characters do have the same voice, but it all SOUNDS SO WRONG.-Missions are SO F****NG SHORT, too short, its like TikTok long... right as I am having fun the missions end...and to go with that... there are cutscenes that cannot be skipped and take up half the mission (imo)...-Character unique blasters DO NOT SOUND THE SAME, they sound generic... EA did a better job with sound design.-The levels have TONS of cut content from them, there are sequences that wouldve been there in TCS or even the MOVIES THEMSELF... that just didnt make it in. Then there are missions where it becomes a boring rail-shooter...-Jedi Slam was Removed-Custom Characters were Removed (not a big deal, but would be neat in a game with so many minifig parts)-They renamed some characters and ships... F*** Politically Correct Culture.-FPS drops in Random Places (PITIFUL, especially since im 32GB Ram and RTX3060TI)-30FPS Locked Cut scenes, what a JOKE, its 2022... most games run in 60-120FPS on PC these days.-Certain Characters dont die how they would, why remove it if kids are just going to watch the movies and see them die? WHY EVEN CHANGE THAT?! -1166 Kyber Bricks is a ridiculous amount of something to collect, that is beyond Ubisofts crappy collectathons...-Only 5 levels per Episode, instead of 6-STUDS dont look that shiny... they look boring now-NO GOLD BRICKS?! -and personally I miss the Mos Eisley being the HUB, but I do like the freedom, so... take it as you will.My biggest offense besides some of the blasters not sounding unique anymore... especially Boba Fetts...is the level design, they are way too short... and there are scenes from the movies that were removed that had a part in TCS, and yea, call me Nostalgia blind, but seriously, short missions are not fun mission. They are Alright at best...Everything else is Fun, I still enjoy playing it here and there... but it feels lacking.I'd say, buy it, cause you will probably enjoy it. But, personally, I wouldve liked to see better levels, and blaster sounds... and characters that are the actual actors... not some Lego Batman actors. (Yea, QuiGon is voice by Com. Gordon)AND IF THEY COULD REMOVE REY's Line from the Intro, then it would be better.She shouldnt be front and center, and I say this not because she is a woman, I wouldve said the same thing if anyone that WASNT A SKYWALKER was there. She is a Solo, not a Skywalker... "Show me my place in all this", Alright.. in the tresh, GTFO Rey.

author: Startraphell
review: I bought this game out of nostalgia mostly. I was expecting something along the tines of The Complete Saga from back in the day. A compilation of either what we've had before or something that builds on it. I was not expecting a collection of hubs separated by vehicle levels. There are boss fights. There is combat. There is building. There is platforming. But all of this takes place in what we would expect to have been made into a hub for levels back in the day. I kept playing and asking "okay, how do I get to the actual levels" until I realized that this was it. This was the game. If you are, like me, here because you played lego games back in the day, don't get this. Either the formula for lego games has changed since I last played to such an extent that you can't even recognize it, or this is someone's sick, twisted joke that feed on nostalgia value.

author: joshanator10
review: To be completely honest I haven't played much so far I've only played episode 1 and i'm towards the end of episode 2 but I have got to say I'm pretty disappointed with the game, meaningful scenes from the movies are rushed through as fast as possible and the gameplay missions are too short and for some reason, there are a bunch of little changes to the story that I feel aren't needed... another thing I have noticed is that this game in the cutscenes are afraid to kill characters when they're supposed to, for example, the Naboo starfighter scene in the beginning of episode 2 and Jango's death in the Geonosis arena. Hopefully the game gets better past the prequels but the prequels is my favorite era in Star Wars and to see them rushed by so quickly i feel is extremely disappointing, tbh If I wasn't so willing to keep giving this game a try I would've refunded the first time I played it, so far its not that fun, the story is being rushed by WAYYYY to quickly and the gameplay missions feel lack luster, rushed and boring. author: cooleo48
review: As someone who has played many a LEGO game in my time, this was disappointing. Not because it's bad, but because there's SO MUCH wasted potential. From a technical standpoint, it looks and feels astonishing. However, the gameplay and story were lackluster at best, considering that it's 2022 and if I have the time to game at the end of the day, I need to feel like I'm having fun and being challenged. As far as story, a big issue is the choice to make it non-linear and open world. This decision causes the movies to be split into 'missions,' which are often placed in really weird spots. My prime example is in TLJ, where you have to chase Porgs around and go back and forth across Rian Johnson's nightmare-scape known as Ach-To Island. Why is this a level and not a cutscene? The devs/writers also seem to have lost their gift for creating that silly LEGO charm in cutscenes that keeps us all coming back, with the humor feeling bland, unoriginal, and uninspired. There are quite serious moments from the movies that they are portraying just as serious, only to make a weird joke that pulls my immersion and makes me confused as to how they want me to feel. For example, when Padme's stunt double dies and we see nothing but a gag of the old man who kept saying "I'm Padme" earlier? Aight.Gameplay wise, it's all flair and no fun. Lightsabers especially feel weird in battles, with bosses becoming repetitive and boring to defeat. Sure, it's cool to hit people up in the air and do a couple spins but at the end of the day it's the same old button spam we're all used to. Also, the missions on speeders or similar vehicles feel pretty terrible and I've encountered multiple game breaking bugs in them. There's also a lot of boring roleplay walking where companions go SO slow and you have to listen to them blab on about plot to movies we've all already seen, instead of the exposition being included in the cutscenes so there's that.My expectations were probably too high for this game but regardless I still have a better time playing something like The Complete Saga, Indiana Jones, or Clone Wars. Maybe I'll finish this game one day, maybe not.Also, and this is important, PLEASE ADD ONLINE CO-OP. I FEEL LIKE I'M STUCK IN 2007. I HAVE FRIENDS THAT LIVE NOWHERE NEAR ME AND I'D LIKE TO PLAY WITH THEM.

author: WIWA
review: I'm going to be honest, this isn't what I expected out of TT Games. I stopped keeping up with their games after they started including voice lines (raw audio ones at that, though it seems they learnt their lesson - no more background sounds from the movies) as that was a turning point for their games. Mumble mode made that slightly better, I guess.But I've seen a lot of high praise for this, saying it's one of their "best" lego games. For new audiences, maybe this is true, but for those wanting to relive the games like with the Complete Saga game which came out much more than a decade ago now, you won't see it here.What TT Games has done is apply modern game design elements to something which was already perfect, and in doing so has lost a lot of the magic the original two trilogy games had. The open world adds a lot, and everything is visually stunning, I'll give them that. But outside of a major graphics overhaul, the "overhaul" to the story missions is completely off base.Within Episode 1 alone, there are several elements of stories which are just slowly following a character from point A to point B - running ahead leads to them stopping, and you're stuck slowly following them. This is a common 'mechanic' in modern day games which is a blight on the industry; why not simply make these elements of the game cutscenes? They don't shy from cutscenes for a majority of the game.The character selection is now much more bloated, with each character belonging to a specific category which controls what their abilities do. The UI for this feels cluttered and poorly implemented, but that's just my opinion. The original games' character selection UI felt much more intuitive and let you very quickly go through all your characters. This doesn't even mention the lack of character creator, which seems to be a commonly mentioned topic in reviews.This doesn't even mention the Day 1 DLC for additional characters and story content. I despise these kinds of models for game releases personally as a member of the industry. They encourage a negative behaviour that just continues as long as companies earn money from it.

author: order me food ty
review: As much as I want to recommend this game:The first 2 movies suffer so much from clear development rush, which is a damn shame being that they had some of my favorite levels in the original game. Even putting aside them being my favorite, these are the introductory levels to the game and they are so incredibly bare bones it's not even laughable, it's just sad. For comparisons sake: In the original, level length was pretty much the same between all the levels, baring some exceptions, and every level had its own share of interesting and fun puzzles to engage in or return to in free play. In this game, any of the original levels that are here (cause theres actually VERY FEW) they don't even last upwards of 10 minutes. If you start the first mission of the game and don't worry about exploring (cause theres hardly anything to do in it anyway) you can finish that level legitimately in under a minute, not even a speedrun, just walking forward for like 30 seconds will beat the FIRST level. This trend only follows.Pacing, pacing.. Wow, the pacing is grotesque. They cut out several key story points, and threw back in some in the completely wrong spots, such as the battle of naboo happening AFTER the fight with darth maul(?????????????????????) These problems ALSO only continue...Optimization is fine for the most part, albeit I did receive massive frame rate issues (somehow??) in episode 2's factory section.Oh yeah, and they added pointless lite-open-world levels that serve no purpose other than to inflate the players time in the game looking around trying to do something, only to find out you can't do anything and have to come back later in free play. Seriously, these lite open worlds are complete garbage. Cut this out and actually make proper 1 to 6 episodes with good level length, none of this fake open world garbage.Finally, my last complaint.Voice Acting.Go watch my stream if you wanna hear me actively complain about how disappointing this game made me, I'm gunna continue to play through it & pray that these developers just HATED the first 2 movies and did them dirty on purpose, and the rest of the game is somehow phenomenal.

author: Terrifying Turnip
review: I received this as a gift and probably would not have purchased it for myself.The game does what other Lego Star Wars games did with better controls and more gameplay variety. As expected, there are plenty of jokes and pop culture references throughout. Given the limited graphics and the high initial price tag, adding DLC just doesn't seem right. At the time of writing, $35 of DLC is available through steam for this game. In previous Lego titles, any characters that could be unlocked didn't require spending anything beyond the in game currency. This is a shameful cash grab by TTGames that has no business in this title or any other marketed to children.

author: JacKaro0
review: I have a high end gaming laptop that can run most games at Max graphics with 60-100 fps. For some reason this game has beaten me. I am near certain it is trying to use my CPU or integrated graphics to play the game instead of the RTX 2070 inside my computer. When the game starts i can only get 1-2 FPS, my GPU sits idle and my processor goes up to 95% load. I've tried everything. I just want to play this silly game with my girlfriend. I've used the nvidia, display settings, 3d settings. Somehow this game keeps finding a way around whatever settings i try ot use to force it to run on my graphics card. I'm lost. If anyone has a fix or has experienced something similar let me know.

author: Voltz
review: I own quite a few Lego games. This one is ok. There are a few points where they carve out and butcher the canon story for whatever reason. If you plan to play on mouse/kb.....prepared to be frustrated. Its awful. There are lots of bugs and they have not shown willingness to get a patch out for months. There are also gamebreaking issues like save file corruption or the infinite warp load screen like I had.....which basically renders the game near useless because I couldn't progress. Once (or IF) they get the problems sorted out......it will be a good play through for about a $30-$40 price point. Even fixed......do not give the robber barons $60 for a Lego game.

author: Dino
review: The plague of the decade: Quantity over quality.A lot of content for a terrible game. The gameplay mechanics are from the last century and the level design is very confusing and poor. The scenes of the movies are tied together very poorly. The sub quest and upgrade design is completely useless and only contributes to add confusion over confusion. The fact that a game like this got so much attention really represents the very bad state of the game industry (and "critic") nowdays. The cooperative mode with the split screen is the glorification of confusion and bad level design, try it if you really want the worst out of the game.So bad that sometimes it makes you speechless, not even mediocre.Icing on the cake: DLCs available at launch.

author: MissCandle
review: Where do I even start. Spoilers for gameplay if you care.This is not a game about the star wars movies. This is a game that uses the star wars movies as a vehicle for collectables. Cutscenes and dialogue that happen in freeplay areas outside of the missions are, as far as I can tell, unable to be experienced a second time. Once you finish playing all 9 movies, the only thing left is a scavenger hunt for dozens of ships, hundreds of characters, and more than a thousand bricks.That being said, significantly more care was given to the sequel trilogy over the others, which is surprising given how bad those movies were, but not too surprising because disney didn't make the first two. The last story mission in 7 covers han solo in starkiller base, poe doing the trench run, AND rey and kylo in the forest, but there's no mission to blow up the second death star at the end of 6. (Don't come at me for saying the sequels are bad. Even jj abrams has been quoted in interviews saying that maybe they should've planned the movies before making them.)The speeder bike level in 6 is embarrassingly broken. The bike laser passes through the bottoms of enemy bikes if you've turned auto-aim off. If you kill both enemy bikes too quickly they'll end up staying behind you, and since there's no throttle control you need to restart the level. If you stay in this state too long the level will run out of track and dump you in a spawn loop off the map.Some levels, especially the droid factory in 2, have huge performance issues. They run like a slideshow when everywhere else is fine. Cargo missions in freeplay space feature a giant low-res droid battleship in the middle of the combat encounters that the player and enemies can pass right through. Combat is a slog. Missions will sometimes have you killing 30 or 40 enemies with little variation, with weapons that are sorely underpowered until you progress far enough up the skill tree.And you don't even get to customise your own character? C'mon guysIf collecting things is an itch you need to scratch, the skywalker saga will do it for you. Me, I can't believe I spent so much money on this thing.

author: Bot.3.0
review: I am personally disappointed with this game. From them not using movie audio and instead relying on voice actors who can´t capture the original actors likeness (Han Solo is my favourite character from the OT movies, but I feel nothing for him in this game, no happiness at all), to the missions being WAY to short, to them skipping certain important scenes or dumbing down scenes to much. They should´ve used the movie audio like they did in LEGO Lord of the Rings, added DLC with the full Clone Wars and have the voice actors do those voices, longer missions and fixing certain cutscenes. I´m just here for the nostalgia like the rest of the older audience so I feel like this game wasted it´s potential. I´m sure the new kids will like it since it is actually, originally made for them. It saddens me a great deal that it fell short like it did. Edit: I just finished the game and the sequel trilogy was so painful to play through! I didin´t even bother getting "True Jedi" on any of the missions. Peace out!

author: briandragonflame
review: this game is far closer to a Lego city game than a star wars game. I have completed this games story mode and the ever increasing amounts of bug being discovered are sad. basic stuff like capital ships being where they are not supposed to be, characters loading without faces, lightsabers, or even their base model. thankfully i did not experience the maz glitch which can shutdown gameplay i did experience a multiple glitches that affect character selection. one glitch where changing the character roster is never permanent and the other where trying to change a character changes the one 2 over from it instead. i have been launched up to the worlds height limit several times and even glitched into the ground by leaving ships and buildings. this game has a ridiculous amount of glitches and after all this time none have been fixed. other issues include vehicle levels not actually having freeplay, bricks being reduced to stud multiplier and cosmetics. hell sith powers are also reduced to only base force powers and a few select doors that can also be done by a time wasting puzzle that gets repetitive around the third time. the characters feel like nothing more than re-textures of each other except for the jet pack characters that trade a double jump for horizontal movement that breaks so many puzzles. the levels that feature auto movement and splitting paths tend to also break by preventing enemies from appearing. this game feels more like i'm beta testing and not playing a completed product. this is a very disappointing addition to the lego starwars series.

author: MxStella
review: I've had a lot of fun playing this game, and I think the content is solid. But the game is riddled with game breaking bugs, and the infamous transphobic "it's a TRAP" meme makes an unwelcome appearance. It's a big part of Star Wars history, but it's become so closely associated with the transphobic meaning that it's time we bury it.

author: The Quizmaster
review: While you can tell the devs put a lot of effort into it, it's simply just not as good as the originals. There are more characters but they're just skins as they all function the same - r2d2 can no longer hover, palpatine doesnt shoot lightning, etc. Also the levelling system just makes the game grindy and almost tacky - the achievement should be to become a true jedi and collect all the minikits - not increase sprint duration by 10% etc.Most importantly however is the new aiming feature. I hate it - the auto aim in the originals is far better. Auto-aim not only helps determine what structures are destructible, but also means you don't have to 'work hard' to play the game. It's not reasonable to be able to destroy everything you want when using a controller - maybe if using a lightsaber but its still more difficult and time consuming than it should be. This is not the type of game you want to use a mouse and keyboard on, but unfortunately you have little choice.Plus, the open world idea has just made the game more boring. Too much running just to get to the next cut scene.It's not a *bad* game - in fact, it's probably ok. However, the originals are simply superior - thats why we loved them so much all those years ago. You'll have more fun on those than you will on this.

author: APeacefulWarrior
review: If what you're looking for is a game for your kids, or a game to play while drunk or high to get yourself into a childlike mindset, LSS:TSS can be a lot of fun... as long as all you're doing is exploring the absolutely ginormous and gorgeous hub worlds, allowing yourself to get distracted and go chasing off after whatever random thing catches your fancy like some intergalactic butterfly.  On that level, it works, and I certainly can't fault the absurd amount of work that had to go into building all those worlds (pretty much every major planet seen in a SW movie) and stuffing them full of things to find.The problem is basically everything else.The main plot missions are short, repetitive, and almost absurdly easy.  And, I mean, older LEGO games were *easy.*  This is streamlined to the point that all you need are basic motor skills, and I'm not even sure that's a requirement.  There's also a surprising lack of creativity in things like vehicle levels and boss fights.  Pretty much every lightsaber-wielding boss as well as almost any boss with a melee weapon fights in the exact same way, with the exact same patterns, and it gets really obvious the devs ran out of ideas before the halfway point.  The mob battles in Ep 8 and 9 are particularly painful, as you just have to plow through a bunch of nearly identical mini-bosses all fighting exactly the same way.Likewise, the "puzzles" utilized to open doors or operate control panels are exactly the same every time, and get old really fast.  It's little wonder there are upgrades available that let you skip them.The vehicle missions - a highlight of previous games - are downright dull here.  This has the single most boring adaptation of the Death Star battle I think I've ever played.  And that's when they bother adapting them at all.  Numerous major vehicle battles are simply not playable at all.  I hope you weren't looking forward to fighting in the Battle of Coruscant, or doing the core run into the Death Star II, or trying out some lightspeed skipping.  They're just cinematics here.Even the trademark LEGO humor seems downgraded.  For the most part, cutscenes and story beats are simply knockoff actors reciting a chopped-down version of the movie scripts, with very few changes.  Then typically with something wacky happening in the background, even as the characters in the foreground play the story totally straight.  I really miss the whole "Vader pulling out baby pictures" vibe of the older nonverbal games.  There are definitely some good jokes here and there, but way too much time is spent simply recapping stuff fans have already seen.And on top of all that, as of writing 4 months after release, there are still a *ton* of bugs and problems with the mission scripting.  They seem to have fixed all the major game-breaking bugs, but there are still a lot of things that can go wrong, or force you to restart a mission due to a glitch.Basically, having finished the main story, I'm already kind of bored.  I can't even imagine spending the 100 hours needed to get 100%.  Otherwise, the next time I have an urge for LEGO Star Wars, I think I'll just stick to the old Complete Saga, even if it doesn't have 7-9.

author: -okii-
review: TDLR: Game for infants.Why is this game so overrated with 93% review positive? This game is extremely dissapointing considering its predecessors. Game lacks any depth or interest for me to break anything and explore the levels. The levels are extremely short (about 5-10 min, especially vehicle levels are really short), you barely build anything in levels or interact with anything, some levels like The Phantom Menace first level don't make any sense to be an actual level (a vehicle level underwater with a big fish is a joke) or the levels have things that werent in the movies (a level with Jango Fett returning to shoot at Millenium Falcon in The Empire Strikes Back for no reason). The hub worlds feel extremely empty and uninvinting and we spend 10-20 min just walking around to next level or escorting/following a character each time we finish a level without interacting with anything (These people made Lego City Undercover). The cover system is completely pointless and disguises make you pretty much invincible. I wouldn't be too dissapointed about it if it didn't cost 50 euros. No, i am not too old to understand this, I played most lego games in last year and enjoyed them like Complete Saga, City Undercover, Indiana Jones, Lord of The Rings, Batman and Clone Wars. Buy these lego games instead of this lifeless, empty game. Don't buy it for any price.

author: vött
review: TLDR: People are talking about this like its a GOTY contender. It's not, it's a high quality kids' game. Buy it for your kids or for a nostalgia trip. This review is written by someone who has played and owned most lego games of this style, and evaluates the game as a standalone product for someone with considerable experience with video games, mostly to illustrate that it isn't. Pros:+ This game is light-hearted and knows it. I never laughed out loud but many people call it charming and it is. The humor and tone is absolutely the main appeal of this game. It's like a playable version of the family guy star wars parody but less cringy. + This game is gorgeous. The textures are some of the best if not the best I have seen in a video game. + The new class system is a necessary streamlining of the wonky character system from the old games. + There is a lot of content. Aside from 5 missions per film there are many smaller regions which function together as an open world of side quests.Neutrals:- The shooting is a massive improvement over older lego games, but note that this says very little compared to contemporary action games. It's no longer a chore, but it is barebones. Shooting rewards headshots which hints at a slight challenge if you want it, but dying is still meaningless so the skill floor is very low. The cover system sucks about as much as it does in every video game. If you've played enough shooters to have a standard for that it's easy enough that you never need to take cover. - Melee combat is also improved. There's a combo meter that rewards spam rather than punishes it, which is weird but cool i guess. Enemies will start blocking if you spam punch them though, which forces you to switch up your game. The bosses forcing you to stay moving is good. Again, this is barebones but a massive improvement over literally being able to defeat darth sidious with your eyes closed. - There's a lot of content, but none of it is very engaging due to the core gameplay loop being extremely easy. It works fine as a checklist to cross off while turning your brain off and as more opportunities for the game to transmit its signature charm. Cons:- The PC port is a little janky. It's allergic to alt tabbing which is a pet peeve of mine but i suppose is somewhat expected for a series that just added mouse support. Said mouse support doesn't allow for more than 3 buttons.- UI layout is garbage. The UI looks good but is a bother to navigate. - There is no character customization. This was kind of a dealbreaker to me personally, it's a staple of the series that would have seen huge benefits from the new class system.  Summary: I sound negative here but the purpose of that is to dispel the idea that this is a masterpiece for adults. It is very good at what it's trying to do: Entertain children, give older fans nostalgia, and being a love letter to Star Wars. At this the game succeeds with flying colors. What this game isn't trying to do is be revolutionary, or even good, as a contemporary action game. The fact that this games size comes at the cost of the health and working conditions of its creators is also a massive deterrent for me.
